## Page 5

ABSTRACT Archaeological investigations were conducted at 15 prehistoric sites located within the Richland/Chambers Reservoir. This work was performed by the Archaeology Research Program, Southern Methodist University over the course of four field seasons between June 1982 and December 1984. The reservoir is located in Navarro and Freestone Counties, Texas, about 100 km southeast of Dallas. It is being constructed by the Tarrant County Water Control and Improvement District Number One, and will inundate 44,750 acres along Richland and Chambers Creeks. Part One of this volume presents the archaeological investigations at 13 of the prehistoric sites. Major excavations at two additional sites (Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch) are the subject of Volume II in the Richland Creek Technical Series. The investigations reported here record the remains of prehistoric occupations dating from the Late Paleo-Indian period (ca. 8000 B.C. - 6000 B.C.) through the Late Prehistoric period (A.D. 700 - 1650), although evidence dating earlier than the Middle Archaic period (3000 B.C. - 1000 B.C.) is very limited. Artifact assemblages, habitation features, intrasite patterning, and subsistence remains document the activities of hunter-gatherer groups that occupied the reservoir area at various times during the past 5,000 years. In Part Two, the results of the prehistoric site investigations are utilized to present a series of topical and synthetic statements concerning the prehistory of the Richland/ Chambers Reservoir area. Artifact assemblage data derived from stratified contexts and intersite comparisons, dated by a series of 48 radiocarbon determinations, allow the construction of a more detailed cultural chronology for the Middle Trinity River Basin. An analysis of lithic raw material utilization provides evidence of changes through time in hunter-gatherer group mobility and the size of exploitive territories. A technological analysis of lithic assemblages, integrated with the results of a lithic tool replication experiment, represents a continuing effort to define assemblage-specific lithic reduction strategies for the purpose of investigating intersite functional variability. Finally, the results of archaeological and paleoenvironmental investigations are used to develop a diachronic model of hunter- gatherer adaptations to the changing physical and cultural environments of the Richland/ Chambers Reservoir area.

ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The successful completion of any complex project is dependent upon the dedication and assistance of many persons. In this respect, the Richland Creek Archaeological Project (RCAP) is no different. In fact, the highly interdisciplinary and multi-seasonal nature of the Project has involved a myriad of field personnel, analyists, writers, consultants, and support staff. We owe a large debt of gratitude to all these individuals, and in this section we recognize their contributions. First, and foremost, we thank Mr. Woody Frossard of the Tarrant County Water Control and Improvement District Number One (hereafter referred to as the Water District), Mr. Frossard was the representative from the Water District who was assigned ‘the responsibility of selecting an archaeological contractor and insuring that the work was completed in a manner consistent with the Water District's needs for completion of the Richland/ Chambers Dam and Reservoir. Mr. Frossard performed these duties admirably, providing direction, encouragement, and constructive criticism in all phases of the archaeological work. Without Mr. Frossard's support, the Richland Creek Archaeolog- ical Project would not have achieved the success it has. Second, special thanks go to the members of the Memorandum of Agreement Committee, a project review council established by an agreement between the Water District, the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers (USCE), the Texas Historical Commission (THC), and the National Park Service (NPS). The members of this committee, aside from Mr. Frossard, consisted of one person from each of the agencies involved: Ms. Daphne Derven (USCE), Dr. LaVerne Herrington (THC), and Dr. Stephanie Rodeffer (NPS), who was later followed by Dr. Ann Johnson. The MOA Committee members provided valuable comments and support while attending field meetings during some of the coldest and hottest temperature extremes experienced in this part of the State. The ultimate success of this Project is due in large measure to their collective effort. We also wish to thank Mr. Robert Burton, archaeologist with the USCE, for his assistance in developing the Memorandum of Agreement that made the mitigation phase of the RCAP a reality. Mr. Burton was particularly instrumental in negotiating the mag- nitude of mitigation activities within the reservoir. vit A great deal of appreciation goes to the field and laboratory crews who worked during the four seasons of the RCAP. Despite the physical discomfort imposed by summer's heat and winter's chill, the field crews worked steadily and often put in long hours to make sure the job was completed properly. Likewise, laboratory workers put in long, tedious hours washing, identifying, and cataloging artifacts from both prehistoric and historic sites. Crew chiefs of prehistoric crews included: Jeffery Bohlin, Marilee Irvine, Thomas Guderjan, Daniel McGregor, Allan McIntyre, Donald Manchester, and William Martin. INTRODUCTION TO VOLUME III by James E. Bruseth PROJECT BACKGROUND The Richland Creek Archaeological Project began in 1980 as an interdisciplinary program by Southern Methodist University to investigate cultural resources in the Richland/Chambers Dam and Reservoir (see Figure I-1). The reservoir is located about 100 km south of Dallas in Freestone and Navarro Counties, Texas. Construction of the dam and reservoir was started in 1982 and was completed in 1986. The archaeological work carried out in the reservoir consisted of three major phases. The first phase, begun in September 1980, involved the survey of the 44,750 acres to be impacted by the reservoir and the identification of 911 archaeological properties (Raab et al. 1980; Archaeology Research Program 1981). The second phase consisted of site testing and evaluation of 272 properties in order to determine their eligibility for the National Register of Historic Places (Raab et al. 1981). Testing procedures involved an interdisciplinary program of archaeological excavations, geological and geomorphological fieldwork, architectural studies, informant interviews, and archival research. The results identified 106 archaeological sites and historic Structures containing important information, which were considered eligible for the National Register (Archaeology Research Program 1981, 1982). The first and second phases were complete by August 1981. Data from the testing program were used to formulate a plan for the third phase: mitigation of the loss of significant archaeological properties in the reservoir. Any of the 106 significant archaeological properties identified during testing which were located below an elevation of 325 ft msl, under the dam, or inside of highway relocation corridors were recommended for intensive study. A program of archaeological mitigation was begun in June 1982, and carried out in four field seasons, each about three months in duration, with the last field season finished in December 1984. The intensive data collection was undertaken for 80 properties, while it was possible to avoid 26 properties with changes in the design of the dam or in the location of roads. The type of work conducted for each significant property during phase 3 varied from intensive excavation at all prehistoric and many historic sites to architectural documentation, dendrochronology, geomorph- ology, informant interviews, and archival research. THE RICHLAND CREEK TECHNICAL SERIES The present volume is the third in the Richland Creek Technical Series, a five volume set devoted to reporting the prehistoric and historic archaeological mitigation program conducted in the Richland/Chambers Reservoir by Southern Methodist University. The series presents all major data, interpretations, and conclusions for the research conducted at historic and prehistoric sites. More detail on the contents of each volume is presented below. ; Volume I provides background information on the Project. The first half of this volume summarizes management issues, including agency review and monitoring, in-house quality control and task management, and construction and maintenance of a computerized data base management system, The second half of Volume I presents environmental information for the Richland Creek area and reviews the results of pollen, soil, and geological studies. The data are used to model environmental change during the Holocene for the Richland Creek area. The next two volumes in the Technical Series are devoted to reporting the results of investigations at 15 prehistoric sites. Specifically, Volume II reports on excavations conducted at the Bird Point Island (41FT201) and the Adams Ranch (41NV177) sites, Both sites contained large, man-made depressions known as Wylie focus pits; because of these unique features, the sites are combined into a single volume. In particular, village deposits with important information pertaining to local and regional patterns of human adaptation to the environment of North Central Texas were recovered from the Bird Point Island site. Consequently, a substantial part of Volume II is devoted to reporting data on these occupations as well. Volume III, the present volume, is composed of two parts. The first presents basic data on the excavations conducted at 13 prehistoric sites. The presentations for each site are relatively straightforward and serve primarily as a means of communicating the information to other researchers. Brief interpretations on the temporal placement and functional uses of each site are made. However, most synthetic statements are reserved for the second part of Volume III. In this part, syntheses of the overall prehistoric research are presented. This includes chapters on cultural chronology, lithic technology, and raw materials utilization, The final chapter of Volume III presents an overview of the prehistoric archaeology of the Richland Creek area and relates this information into a behavioral perspective of human adaptation to the Prairie Margin of Texas. The last two volumes provide information on the results of archaeological and architectural studies of historic sites in the Richland Creek Archaeological Project area. Volume IV provides information on the research design, field methods, and major data collected from 64 historical properties. Thirty-seven historical properties received archaeological investigations as a primary emphasis, while 27 properties received architectural studies as a primary focus. Site descriptions for each property are given in Volume IV. Volume V, the final Volume in the Richland Creek Technical Series, reviews the results of specialized historic artifact analyses and synthetic studies of historic sites. The Richland Creek historic artifact classification is presented, and specific chapters are devoted to reviewing major artifact classes for sociocultural information. The remainder of the volume reviews categories of data at various synthetic levels and provides insight into the rich traditional lifeways once practiced on the farmsteads in this region. Three sets of microfiche complete the Richland Creek Technica! Series. The first set, located in the back of Volume I, includes the original reports on pollen analysis and geomorphological studies provided by our consultants. The second set, located in the backs of Volumes II and III, contains the information retrieved from all prehistoric sites. The third set, located in the back of Volume V, contains all historic information. In addition to the data provided in the microfiche and the five Technical Volumes, other information, such as original field notes, artifacts, computer data, and site maps are curated at the Institute for the Study of Earth and Man at Southern Methodist University, Dallas, Texas. wisi RESEARCH DESIGN AND INVESTIGATIVE STRATEGIES by Daniel E. McGregor and James E. Bruseth This part of Volume III contains the reports of mitigation phase excavations at 13 prehistoric sites. The field work at these sites was conducted over the course of four field seasons between June 1982, and December 1984 (Table 1-1). The site reports are presented as individual chapters (Chapters 2 through 14). The purpose of the present chapter is to provide a brief review of the Project research design and the criteria used in selecting sites for mitigation work. This is followed by a discussion of the format and contents of the site reports, RESEARCH DESIGN AND SITE SELECTION The basic framework for archaeological research at Richland/Chambers Reservoir has been the study of long-term human adaptation to the prairie margin environment. After completion of the testing phase of the Richland Creek Archaeological Project, a research design was developed to guide the mitigation phase investigations (Raab and Moir 1982). With respect to the prehistoric research, two major concerns influenced the selection of sites for further work. The first of these was the need for sites which dated to a number of different temporal periods, since possible diachronic changes in adaptive strategies were of primary interest. Many of the selected sites were multicomponent, but test excavations had suggested that cultural stratification was present. Secondly, it was thought that sites in a variety of physiographic locations should be excavated in order to sample as wide a range of settlement diversity as possible. Therefore, smaller sites indicative of creekside occupations (41FT193 and 41NV139) and sites associated with minor tributary drainages (41NV173 and 41NV203) were selected in addition to the larger, more intensively occupied sites located on the Pleistocene terraces of Richland and Chambers Creeks. The research design recommended 10 specific hypotheses for testing during future work at prehistoric sites (Raab and Moir 1982:203-207; see also Chapter 3, Volume I). Six of these hypotheses were directly relevant to the sites reported in this volume. These six hypotheses and their test implications are presented below. H1. The amount of the highly distinctive Pisgah Ridge chert in sites in the Project area appears to be inversely related to distance from the Ridge, especially as measured by distance to sites along creeks. Significant paleoenvironmental changes have affected the Project area, and these changes have influenced the form and distribution of prehistoric settlement. Sometime after A.D. 420, and probably after A.D. 800, the Project area experienced a severe drought of undetermined length. Prior to this drought, the pollen evidence suggests a period of relatively greater effective moisture. During periods of relatively greater effective moisture, settlement expanded to occupy many physiographic settings away from sources of water in streams. During periods of drought, settlement was discontinued or restricted largely to stream channel settings. The faunal assemblages of sites will reflect the plant and animal communities that were exploited, with a more diverse fauna appearing during periods of greater effective moisture, and a larger proportion of small game and aquatic species appearing during periods of scarce moisture. CHANGING PERSPECTIVES ON SITE INVESTIGATION STRATEGIES Because the mitigation phase of the Richland Creek Archaeological Project was conducted over four field seasons, time was available between field work phases to review and propose improvements in excavation strategies. This segmentation of the field work was employed to allow field results from previous seasons to be used to refine investigations during subsequent seasons and to improve the overall quality of the recovered data. This self-correcting capability is all too often difficult to operationalize in large CRM projects where field work is undertaken in a single, massive effort or where different phases of field work are conducted by different contractors. The resulting improvements in field work for the Richland Creek Archaeological Project affected two areas. First, the basic criteria used to select a site for intensive data recovery have changed. All sites in the Project mitigation plan cannot be investigated at the same level of intensity, and the relative emphasis of investigation must be geared to the types and quality of data potentially recoverable from each site. Second, the field methods employed for each site evolved substantially, permitting more realistic data collection. This evolution resulted largely from an awareness of the inherent weaknesses in the archaeological record of the Project area and an abandonment of the naive assumption that all parts of an extinct cultural system are knowable (Binford 1964). Some parts of the cultural system are irretrievably lost, and other parts may be retrievable only at too great a cost. Careful management of the data recovery process is essential, and this is most feasible in a multiphased data recovery program. As noted in the previous section, sites were selected for further investigation based on their ability to address specific research hypotheses. (Archaeology Research Program 1981). These hypotheses concentrated on several culture-historical and processual themes. Consequently, sites were selected from a variety of time periods and geographic locations. In addition, sites that s¢emed to have deep deposits with cultural stratigraphy were selected, siace these contexts would presumably provide vertical provenience control on cultural developments. Although testing had shown that visible stratigraphy did not occur at most sites, there appeared to be temporally relevant vertical separation of artifacts at many sites. This was revealed in test units by the occurrence of "older" artifacts, such as dart points at a greater depth, in comparison to “younger” artifacts, such as ceramics and arrow points. ; _ During the first season of mitigation, excavations were undertaken at four sites. Two of these were selected for their possible association with Wylie focus pits (Bird Point Island {41FT201] and Adams Ranch [41NV177], both reported in Volume II); and two others were chosen since they occurred within the dam construction area and would soon be impacted by heavy equipment (41FT158 and 41FT161B). These latter two sites also had deep deposits with apparent cultural stratigraphy. As part of larger, ongoing geological research within the reservoir, the Project geomorphologist investigated one of these sites (41FT158) to understand the geological processes behind the cultural stratigraphy. This work, outlined in Pheasant (1982b), indicated that the profile of the site showed a normal soil development, with Lie FRORCLABDED ERCOBESES CREGRAREE

One other alized } from itats) f sites upted taken lume, Research Design a fine loamy sandy A horizon over a well-developed, clayey B horizon. The site landform also was identified as a T2 terrace; the soils of which were deposited during the Pleistocene. The implications of these findings in terms of site interpretation were substantial. The evidence pointed to the site surface having been stable during much of the prehistoric period, excepting small-scale erosion. Importantly, artifacts would have been deposited on a surface very close to that present today and presumably would have been worked into the soil by some type of pedoturbation. Thus, the cultural stratigraphy was not real; older artifacts were deeper simply because more time had been available for them to move vertically into the soil. A detailed study of this problem was subsequently undertaken, and the impacts to the recovery of archaeological data were assessed (McIntyre and Janak 1982). These findings caused a re-evaluation of all other sites scheduled for mitigation in terms of the potential for non- aggrading surfaces and the pedoturbation of deposits. The results of this evaluation indicated that the only likely areas of appreciable soil aggradation were in the floodplain (e.g., the Perry site [41FT193]), and that the Tl and T2 terraces and the uplands were considerably older than the period represented by human occupation in the reservoir. Therefore, sites on the terraces or uplands could be expected to have stable surfaces, unless of course localized conditions such as erosion or colluviation had taken place. Consequently, culturally relevant vertical separation of artifacts would have to be demonstrated for each site and not simply assumed. As a result of this Season I work, the relative emphasis of field work shifted to sites with shallow A horizons and lower densities of artifacts (e.g., Litthe Cedar Creek [41NV173] and Irvine {41NV182]). Although sites with deep deposits and/or large quantities of artifacts were still investigated, the quality of the retrievable information was reviewed against data from other, geologically better contexts. More specifically, characteristics of a shallow A horizon and a lower density of artifacts were chosen in order to minimize the disturbance factors at the sites. The pedoturbation that vertically mixes artifacts in the A horizon also destroys the visible traces of features, important contexts for archaeological interpretation. On the other hand, the higher clay content of the B horizon discourages much of the pedoturbation activity due to a greater compactness (Edward Janak, personal communication 1983). Consequently, features which are still preserved often occur at the point at which they contacted the B horizon. Furthermore, the shallower the depth to the B horizon, the more of the feature will be intact. Additionally, sites with lower artifact densities were chosen over high-density sites, The reason behind this was the assumption that the fewer the artifacts, the fewer the occupations represented at the site, and the less the chance of several components being mixed by pedoturbation. A few exceptions to this selection criterion were made. Sites with large quantities of artifacts that covered several acres continued to be investigated, since there was a good possibility that reoccupation of the site did not occur in the same locations. Analysis of horizontally distinct clusters at such sites might identify debris associated with individual components. In addition to shifting emphasis away from sites with deep and potentially mixed deposits to shallower, lower density sites, the investigative methods for the sites changed as well. Since vertical provenience of artifacts at many of the sites was not due to cultural activity, techniques to recover data from broad horizontal areas, where the effects of bioturbation would be lessened, were stressed. Large site areas were sampled so that adequate data on overall artifact and feature patterning could be collected and used to examine intrasite activity distributions. Certain techniques, such as the excavation of smail sized test units (50 x 50 cm) on a systematic basis and the input of this information into a computerized contouring program (SYMAP), were found to be highly useful in identifying activity areas and in the horizontal separation of components (see, for example, 41FT200, 41NV173, 41NV182, 41NV206). Initially, this technique was pioneered on the historic phase of the Project with equal success (see Chapter 6, Volume IV). In addition, noninvasive remote sensing devices were used (41NV173), again covering large areas. Information was retrieved that otherwise was not apparent from the excavations. Finally, large parts of several sites (41FT200, 41NV173, and 41NV182) were scraped to the underlying B horizon to expose features and to delineate their patterning relative to the A horizon artifact distributions. All of these techniques have allowed data to be collected to test the Project research hypotheses, and importantly, - have permitted new levels of interpretation to be made concerning the regional prehistory of North Central Texas. SITE REPORT FORMAT AND CONTENT The subsequent site report chapters follow a standard format that includes the following major topical headings: @ Environmental Setting @ Summary of Previous Investigations ® Excavation Strategy © Results of Investigations ® Interpretations The first two sections provide background information on physiographic location and what was known about each site prior to the mitigation phase investigations. The excavation strategy section discusses site specific methods of data collection. The amount of work conducted and the techniques employed varied among the 13 reported sites, and specific details are presented for each of these. Froth flotation was conducted for soil samples from six of these sites. A detailed description of this procedure is presented in Appendix D, but is not repeated in the individual site reports. The results of investigations section includes the presentation of basic data. The content of this section differs somewhat depending upon the kinds of data that were recovered from each site. The descriptions of lithic tools and ceramics are included in this section, but the tool categories and the attributes of the ceramic artifacts are defined in greater detail in Appendices A and B, respectively. Attributes of the lithic debris are not described im the individual site reports. Instead, an analysis of the lithic debris from selected sites is presented in Chapter 17 of this volume. The objective of this analysis is to define assemblage-specific reduction strategies and to compare these between sites of different time periods. This is accomplished with a detailed attribute analysis of both the unmodified lithic debris and the secondarily modified chipped stone artifacts. One requirement for this analysis was that the assemblages had to be assignable to a particular period of occupation. For this reason, only assemblages from predominately single component sites or from essentially unmixed contexts within multicomponent sites were used. The results of investigation section also includes discussions of site stratigraphy and both the vertical and horizontal distributions of the recovered artifacts. Descriptions of cultural features and discussions of the faunal and macrobotanical remains are provided for the sites where these were present. Interpretations are included at the end of each site report. However, these essentially are site-specific interpretations. More synthetic interpretations based on comparisons between all sites are presented in the various chapters that make up Part Two of this volume. Evaluations of the specific research hypotheses are also found in the appropriate chapters of Part Two.

EXCAVATIONS AT 41FT158 by William A. Martin and Daniel E. McGregor, with a contribution by James E. Bruseth ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING Site 41FT158 is situated along the top and slopes of an eroded T2 terrace of Pleistocene origin (David Pheasant, personal communication 1983), This terrace is a long, narrow formation rising approximately 30 ft (9.1 m) above the floodplains of Richland Creek to the west and the Trinity River to the east. Alligator Creek, a tributary of Richland Creek, flows paratlel to the terrace along the base of its northeast slope. Vegetational cover is variable across the site, with pasture covering the northwest part of the terrace and wild grasses, herbs, and some trees covering the terrace east and south of the fence lines (Figure 2-1). Most of the original forest cover has been removed and replaced by secondary growth. Disturbances to the site, aside from the removal of vegetation, include erosion, especially along the slopes, and excavation of modern trash pits with a backhoe. Within the pasture at the northwest end of the site, a trailer and shed used by deer hunters are present. South of the fence line, near Units 25 and 26, the remains of an historic house site are present. These historic period occupations have caused some disturbance to the site, but their effects have been minimal. SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS Test excavations conducted at site 41FT158 in 1980 included 17 shovel tests and one backhoe trench. Shovel tests measured 40 x 40 cm, and the backhoe trench measured about 10 m by 0.5 m. The backhoe trench and all but three of the shovel tests were dug along the northeast slope of the terrace. The other three shovel tests were | placed along the top of the terrace, west of the fence line | (McGregor et al. 1982:28). The results of the testing program revealed that the northeast slope was greatly disturbed by erosion and recently excavated trash pits. Across the site, two natural strata were recognized: a loamy sand A horizon and a sandy clay B horizon. The depth of the loamy sand varied from 1.7 m at the top of the terrace to about 30- 40 cm further down the slope. Artifacts diagnostic of Early and Middle Archaic occupations were discovered throughout the A horizon, These artifacts included Waco Sinkers and a Bulverde dart point. Artifacts at 41FT158 suggested that important archaeological data from the Archaic period might be recovered at the site. Therefore, the site was included in the mitigation phase of the Richland Creek Archaeological Project. Limited excavations designed to examine the top of the terrace were recommended because this area appeared to be the most productive in terms of archaeological data recovery and the least disturbed. EXCAVATION STRATEGY The excavation strategy was a continuation of the earlier testing procedures, with units placed across the top of the terrace to search for cultural features, burials, and other evidence of occupation. Since the archaeological content of the top of the terrace was known only through limited testing, this strategy of systematic excavation units was believed to be the most efficient method for assessing the nature of the site. The 1982 mitigation work consisted of 16 hand excavated units and two backhoe trenches. Excavation units were staked out using metric tapes and a compass to orient them to magnetic north. This method allowed the units to be laid out quickly, with only a small loss in accuracy of alignment. All units were mapped with a transit at the conclusion of the field work to produce a plot of the entire site. ; The top of the terrace was examined most intensively because testing phase results suggested that this area would be the most productive portion of the site. A series of 1 x 1 m excavation units, numbered 18 through 23, was dug along north-south and east-west axes on the top of the terrace (see Figure 2-1). Next, the southern slope of the terrace was examined by digging a series of 40 x 40

RESULTS OF INVESTIGATIONS SITE STRATIGRAPHY The east profile of Units 19 and 29 is a typical stratigraphic profile from 41FT158 (Figure 2-2). Little cultural stratigraphy was found in this site. No midden or features were present, and the observed strata are the result of natural soil formation processes. Four soil zones were observed. Zones | and 2 are the upper and lower portions of the plow zone, respectively. Zone 1 is slightly darker than Zone 2 due to the accumulation of organic matter in recent years. Both Zones | and 2 are comprised of loamy sand. Zone 3 is a dark yellow-brown loamy sand with inclusions of hematite and petrified wood; this zone together with the plow zone makes up the A horizon. Artifacts were found throughout Zones 1-3, but their frequency of occurrence dropped sharply once Zone 4 was reached. Zone 4 has a much higher clay content than the other zones, marking the formation of an argillic, or B, horizon. Bruseth) Four sherds were recovered from site 41FT158. Table 2-1 lists the proveniences and selected attributes for these ceramics. More detail on the attributes can be found in Appendix B. All are undecorated sherds from separate vessels; three are body sherds while one is a rim sherd. Three of the sherds are tempered with a combination of grog and grit, while paste textures are fine to medium. A single sherd is tempered with what we are terming “possible” shell, since the temper inclusions have leached out. The laminated and vesicular structure of the paste and the pitted surface of the sherd suggest that shell may have been the additive. Similar pottery has been found at other sites in the reservoir with the shell inclusions still intact (see Part Two, Volume II). Thickness of the grog and grit tempered sherds ranges from 4.0 to 7.5 mm, with an average of 5.0 mm. The single shell tempered sherd has a thickness of 4.7 mm. Colors for the grog and grit tempered sherds are as follows: the exterior is light brownish gray (10YR6/2); the interior is very dark grayish brown (10YR3/2); and the core is very dark grayish brown. The shell tempered sherd is light brown (7.5YR6/4) on the exterior, interior, and the core. It is difficult to make interpretations on the basis of such a small sample of sherds. However, we are able to state that some degree of occupation of the site occurred by people using two ceramic traditions: a shell temper tradition, and a grog and grit temper tradition. As outlined in Chapter 15, a time frame prior to A.D. 700 is proposed for the shell temper tradition; while a span of A.D. 700 to 1650 is suggested for the grog and grit temper tradition. On this basis, limited but repeated occupation of site 41FT158 during the Late Prehistoric period is suggested.

14 Table 2-1 CERAMIC ATTRIBUTES FROM SITE 41FT158 i Attribute 20.6 28.1 29.5 aU Cn Sherd Location Body 1 1 1 Rim 1 Rim Orientation : Everted 1 Lip Form Rounded 1 Temper Possible shell 1 Grog/sand/grit 1 2 Decoration Method Plain 1 1 2 Total 1 1 - 2 ARTIFACT DISTRIBUTIONS Artifact density was highest in the excavation units located along the top of the ridge (Units 19, 20, 22, 23 and 29), and this area was apparently the focus of prehistoric activities. Projectile points diagnostic of both the Early and Late Archaic periods were recovered from these units. The recovery of three sherds from these same units, and a fourth from Unit 28, suggests some use of the site during the Late Prehistoric period as well. The only other temporally diagnostic artifacts, three Late Archaic period dart points (2 Gary and 1 Yarbrough), were from Unit 31, located downslope to the southeast. Even though the sample of diagnostic artifacts is relatively small, its vertical distribution demonstrates the mixed nature of the site deposit. Level 5 of Unit 29 contained both an Early Archaic San Patrice point and a Late Prehistoric ceramic sherd. In Unit 20, two sherds were recovered from 20 cm below a Late Archaic Untyped, expanding stem point. Lacking good vertical separation of temporal components, it is not possible to assign any artifacts except the projectile points and ceramics to a specific period of occupation. INTERPRETATIONS Interpretations of site 41FT158 are limited by the mixed nature of the deposit, as well as a total lack of features and subsistence remains. However, the question of site chronology can be addressed. The temporally diagnostic projectile points suggest at least intermittent occupation from Early through Late Archaic times. Certain of these projectile point styles are among the earliest recovered in the Project area. The four sherds indicate use of the site during the Late Prehistoric period as well. Volume UI, Part One The lanceolate point is difficult to assign to a recognized type because of the extensive rechipping of its distal end. However, its lanceolate outline, ground base, and lateral edges are characteristic of a variety of unfluted, late Paleo-Indian/Early Archaic point styles. The San Patrice point is generally considered to be diagnostic of the Early Archaic period in East Texas. However, the temporal span of this type is not well documented. At the Wood Pit site (on the Elm Fork of the Trinity River near Dallas), San Patrice points were found in a mixed deposit that also contained Plainview points and artifacts diagnostic of the Early Archaic Carrollton focus (Webb et al. 1971:45). A radiocarbon date of 3980 + 200 B.C. (Campbell 1959) was obtained from mussel shell found near the base of this deposit. Some researchers (¢.g., Shafer 1973:20; Webb et al. 1971:46) have suggested that San Patrice may be a western variant of the more widespread Dalton type, which has been dated to between 8000 and 6000 B.C. in the midwestern and southeastern United States. The single side-notched point recovered from 41FT158 is identical to specimens from two sites which also yielded San Patrice assemblages: Wolfshead in East Texas (Duffield 19636) and John Pearce in northwest Louisiana (Webb et al. 1971). Duffield (1963b:139) assigned these side-notched points to an Early Archaic occupation, but asserted that this occurred later in time than the occupation which produced the San Patrice points. However, Webb et al. (1971:47) suggested that better stratigraphic context at the John Pearce site demonstrated contemporaneity of the side-notched and San Patrice point types. The contention that these types were contemporary was based, at least in part, on the apparent association of side-notched and Dalton point forms at various caves and rockshelters in the midwestern and southeastern United States (Webb et al. 1971:46). More recently, Goodyear's (1982) detailed review of these associations led him to conclude that they are the result of postdepositional mixing of deposits, and that sites with better context show Dalton points as dating slightly earlier than the side- notched forms. A single Bulverde point was recovered during the 1980-81 test excavations at the site (see Figure 2-3a). Bulverde is the diagnostic point style of the Middle Archaic, Marshall Ford phase in Prewitt’s Central Texas chronology, with an estimated age of 2050 B.C. to 1450 B.C. (Prewitt 1981:79). The remaining typable projectile points recovered from 41FT158, Gary (6), and Yarbrough (1), are all assignable to the Late Archaic period. In summary, it appears that most of the site assemblage can be assigned to the Archaic period, but that it represents the remains of a number of short-term occupations that occurred over several thousand years. The relatively low density of artifacts and the absence of definable midden deposits and features, suggest that 41FT158 was occupied by mobile groups of hunter-gatherers. Although little else can be inferred about the nature of individual occupations, the site assemblage itself has been useful for other studies. In Chapters 16 and 17, the lithic assemblage from 41FT158 is one of three primarily Archaic period samples that are used to identify chronological changes in lithic tool assemblages and raw material utilization.

Martin and Daniel E. McGregor, with contributions by James E. Bruseth, Gary Rutenberg, Phillip Murry, and Gayle J. Fritz ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING The same terrace ridge upon which 41FT158 is situated also contains sites 41FT161 and 41FT161B along its eroded southern slope. Sites 41FT161 and 41FT161B are portions of a single site that has been bisected by the road cut for Highway 287. Site 41FT161 was found within 20 m of the road cut along the eroded slope to the north. Site 41FT161B extended along the lower slope of the terrace south of Highway 287, with prehistoric artifacts scattered from the road cut down to the floodplain. Greenbriar, bull nettle, poison oak, and other shrub species common to cleared fields blanketed most of the terrace. A cluster of trees bordered the road cut at the northern end of the site; but for the most part, the site was cleared of trees. A strip of woodland paralleling Alligator Creek was adjacent to the site on the eastern and southeastern edges, at the junction of the terrace and the floodplain. Disturbances to the site, aside from the road cut made during the construction of Highway 287, included plowing, rodent activity, and unscientific excavation by amateur collectors. Plowing had disturbed the upper stratum of the site to a depth of about 20 cm. Burrowing animals in the Project area appear to be more attracted to terraces than to clayey soils of the floodplain. As a result, rodent and root disturbances at site 41FT161B were extensive. Finally, several "potholes" were present in the eastern portion of the site, the result of activity by artifact collectors (Figure 3-1). , SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS During the 1980-81 testing program, seven shovel tests were excavated. These shovel tests measured 40 x 40 cm and were approximately 1 m or more in depth. Most of these shovel tests were placed in the central and eastern portions of the terrace (Figure 3-1), 15 The results of these limited test excavations showed that the stratigraphy at 41FT161B was similar to that at 41FT158 higher on the terrace, consisting of an A horizon of loamy sand overlying a sandy clay B horizon. Although no features were found, artifacts were recovered throughout the A horizon, which extended as deep as 1 m near the upper part of the site. Projectile points identified with the Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods were recovered, suggesting the presence of a long term occupation at the site. In addition to this, local informants reported that burials had been recovered during the construction of Highway 287 (McGregor et al. 1982:30). The presence of artifacts up to 1 m in depth, coupled with the reports of human burials, suggested that this site might contain important information about the Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods. As a result, the site was scheduled for excavation during the mitigation phase of the Richland Creek Archaeological Project. EXCAVATION STRATEGY A four-step data recovery strategy was implemented at 41FT161B to examine the archaeological context of the site. First, the terrace was explored by excavating a series of 1 x 1 m units (Units 8-14, 18-21, 24, 25, 29, 31, and 32) (see Figure 3-1). Depth of units varied according to the nature of the deposit, with excavation ceasing when artifact recovery dropped to an insignificant level (1 or 2 flakes per m3). Second, larger areas were opened to expose fully intact deposits found in the 1 x 1m units (Units 15-17, 22, 23, 26-28, 30, and 33). Third, two hand excavated trenches and a series of contiguous 2 x 2 m units were excavated rapidly to search for undisturbed features and burials (Units 34-51). Fourth and finally, mechanized excavation was undertaken to strip selected portions of the site area to look for features that might only be visible at the contact between the A and B horizons. Units 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, and 14 were excavated first to sample the terrace in both the east-west and north-south directions. These

The widely dispersed nature of the burials prompted the shift in excavation strategy to the third step; i.e., rapid excavation of large areas in search of features and burials. Large excavation blocks were opened near the areas where the burials were found in order to determine whether a cemetery existed or whether a few individuals were buried randomly across the site. To facilitate the rapid examination of the site area, the standard excavation procedures described earlier in this chapter were abandoned during the excavation of Units 34 and 35. Units 36, 37, and 38 were excavated in 10 cm levels and screened, but so little diagnostic material (less than one artifact per m3) was recovered that all subsequent units were dug like Units 34 and 35. Thus, intensive excavation techniques, such as screening and removal of soil in arbitrary 10 cm levels, were not used to excavate Units 34, 35, and 39 through 51. These units were dug rapidly to a depth of 50 cm, the approximate depth of Burials 1 and 2, and then were excavated more carefully to greater depths. Few data important for the interpretation of site 41FT161B were lost because of this shift in methodology. Examination of the artifact tabulations from Units 8 through 33 clearly demonstrates that: (1) the stratigraphy was mixed, probably by bioturbational processes; (2) few diagnostic artifacts were present; and (3) most of the artifact collection consisted of lithic flakes, chips, and shatter with no apparent spatial patterning (except that previously noted in Units 19, 22, 23, 26, and 28). Under these circumstances, additional controlled collection of artifacts would not have added significantly to the site interpretation. BURIAL DESCRIPTIONS Burial 1 Burial 1 was a greatly disturbed burial found in three contiguous 1 x 1 m units (Units 21, 27, and 33) between 50 and 60 em below the surface. The remains of this individual were completely disarticulated and were scattered randomly throughout the units. Some teeth (incisors), the left half of the mandible, and a radius were found in Unit 21. Most of the remains, including part of the right mandible, most of an ulna, part of the ilium, ribs, and unidenifiable bone fragments, were spread across the south half of the unit. The only portion of the individual present in Unit 33 was the distal end of a femur. No grave goods were found in association with this burial. A Gary point was found at a depth of 54 cm below the surface in Unit 27, but it may not have been associated with the burial. Due to the disturbed nature of the burial, it was impossible to determine whether or not the projectile point was part of the interment. Factors responsible for the disturbed context of Burial 1 include rodent activity, and perhaps erosion. Several large rodent burrows were observed within the matrix containing the burial. Rodents probably moved most of the bones, but colluvial movement through erosion also may have affected the burial. Another possible source of disturbance is uncontrolled excavation by amateur collectors. Several potholes were found across the site, and one local collector who visited the site admitted that he had dug on the site for years. It is possible that Burial 1 was disturbed by this collector or others who frequent the site. Burial 2 Burial 2 was discovered in Unit 24, at a depth of 45 cm, when the top of the skull was exposed. No grave pit was visible, so excavators dug an arbitrary pit as they attempted to expose all of the remains. The base of this arbitrary pit was 60 cm below the surface. Burial 2 consisted of the incomplete skeleton of a partially flexed, aduit female which was lying on its right side. The skeleton was oriented in a north-south direction with the skull at the north end, facing west. Most of the bone between the skull and the legs was missing. Only the skull, a fragment of the right radius, the humeri, femurs, tibias, fibulas, and a fragment of the left scapula were present. The tibias exhibited pronounced thickening as the result of infectious pathology. Although only a partial skeleton was present, the orientation of the skull, arms, and legs clearly indicates that Burial 2 represents a primary interment rather than a secondary burial, The presence of rodent burrows throughout Unit 24 suggests that rodent disturbance may have been responsible for the removal of the bones between the skull and the legs. Extensive damage to profiles was caused by cotton rats while the 1982 excavations were being conducted. If the modern pattern of disturbance has been prevalent since the burials were interred (ca. 1000 years ago), then it is quite conceivable that the missing bones from Burial 2 could have been removed by rodents. 19 Burial 3 Burial 3 was a small concentration of cranial fragments found at a depth of only 30 cm below the surface in Unit 25. Fragments of a frontal bone were found in an area measuring 14 cm north- south by 10 cm east-west. It seems certain that these bones were disturbed by plowing and were redeposited downslope by erasion. Burial 4 Burial 4 was found in Unit 34, a hand dug trench, at a depth of 60 cm below the surface. A very dark grayish brown (10YR3/2) oval stain was observed at this level with the right half of the skull visible in the western one-quarter of the stain. The grave pit measured 65 cm north-south by 140 cm east-west and was 14 cm deep. All of the fill was saved for flotation except for soil samples collected for pollen analysis. Burial 4 was comprised of the incomplete skeleton of a partially flexed, adult female(?). The skeleton was oriented in an east-west direction with the skull at the west end, facing north. Like Burial 2, many of the bones between the skull and the legs were missing. The bones present in the grave included the cranium, mandible, left and right humerus fragments, right scapula fragment, a few rib fragments, part of the pelvis, femurs, tibias, and fibulas. No grave goods were associated with Burial 4, but a Steiner arrow point was found within the area where the spinal column would have been. The tip of the arrow point was oriented toward the northeast, suggesting that it may have entered the thoracic cavity or vertebrae from the rear. This interpretation is speculative since the arrow point was not imbedded within any bones. It is possible that the point represents the remains of a arrow placed in the grave as an offering. This consisted of cortical changes (osteitis) in the right tibia, right fibula, femora, and possibly the right humerus. Neoplastic activity on the right tibia occurred largely on its lateral aspect where bone activity was characterized by areas of inferiorly enfolded bone with generalized endostitis occurring throughout the medullary canal. A small circular node (1.2 cm diameter) which may have been active at the time of death occurred several centimeters below the large concentration and enfolded bone. The fibula presented a similar swollen appearance with a possible cloacal opening 0.7 cm wide by 1.3 cm long on the lateral surface of the bone. Volume III, Part One Radiographs showed that the lesion had not penetrated the medullary cavity, but rather that this fossa and the immediate area surrounding it was composed of a slightly less dense bone than the adjacent cortex. Areas of biparietal thinning were found on Burial 2. This was evidenced by a scalloped area towards the posterior portion of both parietals (Brothwell 1965; Ubelaker 1978). The occurrence of this phenomenon is rarely found on individuals younger than age 50; and therefore, when it is present, it is useful as an aid for determining age at death. Bruseth) A total of 29 sherds was recovered from excavations at site 41FT161B. Table 3-2 lists proveniences and selected attributes for these sherds (descriptions of the ceramic attributes can be found in Appendix B). The sherds form three categories based on temper. The first category consists of 23 specimens which have a combination of grog, grit, or bone temper and are similar to the utility wares frequently found at most sites within the reservoir. Grog is the most common additive, with grit and bone being less frequent. The paste is generally well mixed, medium to coarse in texture, and slightly porous. Sherd thickness ranges from 4 to 8 mm, with an average of 7.6 mm. Sherd colors for both the interiors and exteriors are shades of brown (10YR5/3, 10YR4/2, 10YR3/2) and gray (1OYR5/1, 10YR4/1). Core colors are generally darker (lOYR3/1, 10YR2/1). Four of the sherds are decorated with fingernail punctations. A petrographic analysis of thin-sectioned samples from three sherds of this group was undertaken to determine if they were manufactured locally or were imported. The results, presented in Appendix C, indicate that all the sherds sampled were made from local clay sources. The second category consists of sandy paste sherds. Four specimens make up this group, all of which are undecorated. These sherds are a very dark gray (10YR3/1), exterior and interior, with a darker core color (10YR2/1). The thickness of the sherds ranges between 5.9 and 7.4 mm, with an average of 6.6 mm. A petrographic analysis of a thin section from one specimen of this category indicates that these sherds are substantially different from the previously discussed temper category. The differences are in the relative amounts of quartz and quartzite clasts, the larger average grain size, and lower percentage of clay matrix as Provenience 3.1 3.2 8.3 9.2 11.5 15.5 19.1 19.2 19.4 22.1 22.2 22.3 22.4 23.1 23.3 24.1244 25.3 28.2 25.1 Fea6 compared with the thin-sectioned specimens from the grog, grit, and bone temper group. A nonlocal origin may account for this difference, as suggested in Appendix C. The third and final category consists of only a single sherd, identified as having “possible” shell temper. If our assessment on this temper type is correct, the shell has leached out and caused the surface to be eroded and pitted. The sherd is 5 mm in thickness and has an interior, exterior, and core color of 1OYR7/2. In conclusion, examples of three separate ceramic traditions are represented at the site. The most abundantly represented tradition is one consisting of grog, grit, and bone tempered sherds. In Chapter 15 we estimate a time frame of A.D. 700 to 1650 for this type. The sand tempered tradition, represented by a fewer number of sherds, is thought to encompass a time span of A.D. 700 to 900. And finally, the possible shell tempered sherd is associated with a time span prior to A.D. 700. Thus, the ceramics suggest several periods of reoccupation of the site during the Late Prehistoric period. Chapter 15 discusses the significance of these traditions with respect to the local archaeology. FAUNAL REMAINS (by Phillip Murry) A substantial amount of faunal material was recovered from site 41FT161B, The highest density of bone was recovered from the southeastern portion of the site, with very little recovered from the northern or western excavation units (Table 3-3). The fauna was dominated by whitetail deer and, to a lesser extent, cottontail rabbit. Other animals occurring less frequently included turtle, fish, snake, bird, and either dog or coyote. Species represented by a single element were raccoon, beaver, opossum, and skunk. Numerous cotton rat and vole elements were recovered, but this does not necessarily indicate that they were part of the prehistoric diet. Rodent disturbance was extensive at the site, and a complete lack of burned elements suggests that their presence may be the result of natural deaths. In summary, site 41FT161B contained a relatively diverse faunal assemblage, with terrestrial, aquatic and avian species represented. Whitetail deer appears to have been the most important species economically, with cottontail rabbit also well represented. All portions of the deer skeleton were present, suggesting transport of entire animals to the site for butchering. Faunal remains were far more frequent in the southeastern portion

MACROBOTANICAL REMAINS (by Gayle J. Fritz) Carbonized plant remains from site 41FT161B were analyzed at the Ethnobotanical Laboratory of the Research Laboratories of Anthropology, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. The assemblage consisted of eight flotation samples (five light fractions and three heavy fractions) from three features (Features 6 and 7, and Burial 4). The methods of analysis are described below. This is followed by a description of the sample contents. METHODS OF ANALYSIS The contents of each sample were passed through a series of 10 graduated, standard geological sieves, with mesh sizes ranging from 6.4 to 0.2 mm, in order to facilitate sorting. The size groups were examined under a low power (7x to 30x) binocular microscope, and fragments larger than 2.0 mm were sorted and weighed according to category. The weights are recorded in Table 3-4. The smaller size groups were examined for seeds and types of materials not present in the larger fractions. They were not completely sorted, since many fragments smaller than 2.0 mm cannot be identified with enough certainty to justify the time expenditure necessary for such separation. A standard laboratory procedure developed by Yarnell (1974:113-114) involves using the weights of the sorted categories Unit 14 15 16 17 18 19 20 21 i 1 1 3 59.3 121.2 99.4 67.6 (38 47.7 91 12 62 21.3 112 23 4.2 1.8 larger than 2.0 mm in order to calculate the weight of each type of carbonized material larger than 0.7 mm. This method was not applied to the 41FT161B samples due to the large number of rootlet fragments. The weight of the combined carbonized remains smaller than 2.0 mm but larger than 0.7 mm was not determined, since they could not be efficiently sorted from the uncarbonized matter in the time available. The ratio of carbonized to uncarbonized remains appeared to vary considerably from feature to feature and from size group to size group, making highly questionable the assumption that types of materials were represented in the 0.7 to 2.0 mm fractions in the same proportions as they occurred in the larger sized part of the sample. Five of the samples were analyzed entirely. The other three samples were partially subsampled due to time limitations. These latter were the light fraction samples from Feature 7 and Burial 4. All fragments larger than 1.41 mm were examined, but all materials dropping through the screen with that mesh size were passed through a geological sample splitter in order to obtain two equal subsamples of the smaller size groups. Therefore, only 50% of the smaller sized fragments from these three samples were examined. CONTENTS OF FLOTATION SAMPLES Wood Wood charcoal contributed most of the weight of the carbonized portion of the larger than 2.0 mm fractions, totaling 5.46 g. The Psoralea species with tuberous roots most likely to be present in the Project area based on modem distribution is P. latestipulata Shinners, formally described in 1958 (Shinners 1958:22-23). This endemic species is similar to P. esculenta Pursh, and probably would have been identified as the latter before Shinner's 1951 publication. Since the two species are’ distinguished on the basis of stem, leaf, peduncle, and stipule characters, a species level designation for the archaeological specimens cannot be proposed. The picture of prehistoric plant exploitation at site 41FT161B seems to be one of concentration on nuts (hickory, pecan, and acorn) and roots (Psoralea). No evidence for plant domestication was found. These remains reflect utilization of stream valley taxa (hickory and pecan), as well as upland savannah and prairie plants (acorns and tubers). The samples give no indication of the harvest of starchy seeds from annuals such as goosefoot and knotweed, which are known to have become economically important during the Woodland and Mississippian periods in areas of the Eastern Woodlands. SPATIAL DISTRIBUTIONS The higher densities of faunal remains in the southeastern portion of site 41FT161B have been noted previously. This same general area also contained significantly greater amounts of lithic debris, especially from Units 19, 22, 23, and 28. The temporally diagnostic artifacts (projectile points and ceramics) recovered from units in this area contrast with those from the rest of the site (Table 3-5). Although the sample is small, arrow points actually outnumber dart points in the southeastern units. Within the rest of the site, there were three times as many dart points as arrow points. Even though only eight 1 x 1 m units were excavated in the far southeastern area, more ceramics were recovered from these units than from the remainder of the site excavations, The four sandy Table 3-5 D1AGNostic ARTIFACT COUNTS FOR TWO AREAS OF SITE 41FT161B en Artifact Southeastern Units! Vertical mixing of the site deposit is suggested by the distribution of arrow points, dart points, and ceramics in almost all excavation units. Below 60 cm, dart points were the only diagnostics recovered. Unfortunately, this was the only instance in which even a partial vertical separation of these artifacts could be defined. INTERPRETATIONS The diagnostic artifacts recovered from the 1981 test excavations had suggested occupations during both the Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods. It was hoped that the approximately 1 m deep deposit might exhibit vertical separation between these temporal components. Instead, vertical mixing of the site deposit was indicated by the distribution of arrow points, dart points, and ceramics in almost all of the excavation units. STIC 41 FTI1I6IB The identification of a Late Archaic component was based on the assumption that Gary dart points date to that period. However, the results of investigations at sites 41NV182 (Chapter 12) and 41FT201 (Volume II) have provided good evidence for the continued use of Gary dart points well into the Late Prehistoric period. Considering this, it may be that the vast majority of material recovered from site 41FT161B actually dates to the Late Prehistoric period, although the Yarbrough and possibly the Dawson specimens still suggest some Late Archaic activity. In fact, the overall assemblage from site 41FT161B resembles most closely that from 41NV182. Radiocarbon dates from the latter site indicate that the major occupation there occurred between A.D. 600 and A.D. 900. Assemblage similarities include the apparent association of dart points (primarily Gary) and arrow points, and relatively low densities of ceramics. One similar aspect of the ceramic assemblages from both sites is the occurrence of coarse-grained, sandy paste pottery. Sandy paste ceramics are thought to predate Caddoan style ceramics over much of the central and southern portions of East Texas (Shafer 1975; Story 1981), and presumably in the Project area as well. Sandy paste sherds accounted for a higher percentage of the ceramic assemblages from sites 41FT161B (13%) and 41NV182 (11%) than from any of the other excavated sites in the Project area. The spatial distribution of diagnostic artifacts suggests that the higher densities of faunal remains and lithic debris in the / southeastern portion of the site may relate to a somewhat later occupation than that which produced the features and materials in the north central area, What may be represented at the site is a number of individual occupations during the period from A.D. 27 600-900, and perhaps even later. Shifts in the locational focus of occupation through time could explain the relatively greater representation of ceramics and arrow points, and proportionately fewer dart points, in the southeastern area. The fact that Perdiz arrow points and engraved ceramics, which were present in contexts postdating A.D. 1200 at sites 41FT201 and 41NV173 were not recovered from 41FT161B suggests a lack of occupation after A.D. 1200. The subsistence economy at site 41FT161B was based on the exploitation of a variety of wild plant and animal species. Plant exploitation seems to have concentrated on nuts (hickory, pecan, and acorn) and roots (Psoralea), No evidence for plant domestication was found. A variety of animals was also exploited, with terrestrial, aquatic, and avian species being represented in the faunal assemblage. Whitetail deer appears to have been the most important, with cottontail rabbit also well represented. The presence of pit features and burials suggests that 41FT161B functioned as a habitation site. However, the lack of evidence for permanent structures suggests that the inhabitants were not sedentary. In comparison to site 41NV182, which is thought to have been occupied contemporaneously, site 41FT161B contained both relatively fewer and relatively smaller features. Although both sites contained burials, 41FT161B lacked the large pits filled with fire cracked rock which were found at 41NV182. Of the two sites, it would seem that 41FT161B was occupied less intensively. However, because road construction had destroyed an unknown portion of site 41FT161B prior to investigation, the true extent and nature of occupation at that site may not be represented fully.

EXCAVATIONS AT 41FT193, THE PERRY SITE by Daniel E. McGregor and Jeffery Bohlin, with contributions by James E. Bruseth, Gayle J. Fritz, Richard Fullington, Holly Hathaway, Phillip Murry, and David R. Pheasant ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING Site 41FT193 is located within the alluvial floodplain deposits that form the south bank of the present channel of Richland Creek. The floodplain surrounding the site was heavily forested prior to recent clearing associated with reservoir construction. The steep bank of the present channel exposes approximately six vertical meters of floodplain stratigraphy. A general series of depositional zones has been identified for the floodplains of both Richland and Chambers Creeks (Pheasant 1982a), the most outstanding feature of which is a layer of dense black vertic clay sandwiched between a brown clay layer below and a sandy clay layer above. Although this basic stratigraphy is present at 41FT193, it is somewhat more complex with three additional dark clay strata present below the dense black clay layer. SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS Site 41FT193 was discovered during the 1980 survey. Test excavations were conducted at the site during the 1980-81 field season (McGregor et al. 1982:32). Three small hearths associated with the lower, dark clay stratum were exposed and excavated. At the same vertical level as these hearths, and in the same stratum, a discontinuous lens of mussel shell was exposed in the creek bank over a distance of approximately 40 m. A contracting stem dart point (Gary type) was recovered from this shell lens. Carbonized nutshell samples from two of the excavated hearths yielded radiocarbon dates of A.D. 170 + 70 and A.D. 320 + 150 (McGregor et al. 1982:32). A backhoe trench excavated into the creek bank exposed limited amounts of mussel shell and animal bone within the dense black clay zone as well. Although no diagnostic artifacts were observed in the trench profiles, these faunal materials were thought to indicate human occupation at the site during the time period when the dense black clay zone was deposited. 29 Based upon the testing results, site 41FT193 appeared to be a creekside locale which had been occupied occasionally Over a considerable period of time. The relatively frequent flooding of this locale and the aggrading nature of the site deposit suggested that vertically stratified remains of short term occupations would be preserved. The intact features and associated artifacts encountered during testing indicated that further excavation would be useful for constructing a well-dated artifact chronology for the Project area. In addition, the recovery of datable materials from the dense black clay zone was considered to be essential for studies of floodplain geology and paleoenvironmental reconstruction (Raab et al. 1982:206-207), For these reasons, additional work at site 41FT193 was recommended. EXCAVATION STRATEGY When site 41FT193 was revisited in October 1983, it was apparent that further erosion of the creek bank had occurred since the test excavations. Four additional hearths were observed in the bank. Two of these were within the lower dark clay stratum, and two were below it. Of greater importance, however, was the fact that additional material was now visible in the dense black clay zone. This included mussel shell, animal bone, and a few pieces of lithic debris. - To aid in planning the excavations, 10 stratigraphic profiles were exposed by shovel scraping the vertical face of the creek bank from the top of the bank to the creek level. These profiles were about 50 cm wide and were placed at 5 m intervals. The four hearths and several small lenses of mussel shell located between these profiles also were exposed. A permanent datum was established on the surface, some 15 m south of the bank. A transit was used to determine the relative elevations of the exposed geological strata, hearths, and lenses of occupational debris. Evidences of occupation were all located between 2.3 m and 4.4 m below datum. It was decided that the upper 2 m of overburden could be removed mechanically. This 2 m deposit included all soils above

STRATIGRAPHY Five disconformities were recognized in the parent material which separate six stratigraphic units. From oldest to youngest the units consist of silty clay (VI), clay (V), clay (IV), very fine sandy clay loam (11), silty clay (I), and sandy clay loam (I). The uppermost unit retains its original alluvial structure and is known to have formed during historic times. Units IV and V both consist of clay, although Unit V is blacker and denser with well-developed slickensides. Unit V is 109 cm thick in Section Two and is bounded top and base by clear boundaries (i.e., less than 5 cm wide). The underlying silty clay Unit VI is easily distinguished; the basal part of Unit VI contains a prehistoric hearth. Volume III, Part One SOILS The present floodplain soil is 77 cm deep and lies within the historic alluvial material of Unit I. There are A and C horizons. An upper buried soil, the Chambers paleosol, extends from the top of Unit II to the base of Unit IV encompassing three stratigraphic units. It is possible that Unit IV is a separate paleosol. Calcareous shell fragments occur throughout the upper portion of this paleosol, and smal! calcareous nodules occur in the [IC1b horizon and below. The nodules and iron mottles indicate groundwater modifications of the paleosol. A lower buried soil, the Navarro paleosol, starts with the top of Unit V, 2 m below the floodplain surface. The upper meter of this paleosol is the dense black clay; it is vertic, with slickensides, but there is no obvious descent of overlying material into the cracks. Because it was so clayey (estimated 60-70% clay), it was impossible to make a field judgment as to whether significant clay alluviation had taken place. Thus, it is difficult to estimate the length of time that this soil took to form. The lower part of this paleosol coincides with Unit VI; this horizon is highly calcareous and very mottled, suggesting that it has been modified by groundwater action. A prehistoric hearth was found in horizon VIC2b, suggesting that the alluvial material that forms these lower horizons aggraded slowly. PROFILE EXTENSION Section Three Section Three represents a continuation of the site's stratigraphic/soil profile. It was taken from the north wall of the dragline cut, and was located approximately 4 m west of Section Two. At this location Horizon VIC2b measured 27 cm in thickness, and the remainder of the section below this horizon was designated Stratigraphic Unit VU. Unit VI was divided into five soil horizons on the basis of changes in texture and color (Figure 4-4). Three of these (Horizons VIIC3b, VIICSb, and VIIC7b) were very similar to Horizon VIC1b, being composed of dark grayish brown (10YR4/2) silty clay. Interdigitated between these were two noticeably darker zones (Horizons VIIC4b and VIIC6b) composed of dark gray (LOYR4/1) clay. Horizons VIIC4b and VIIC6b were 29 cm and 30 cm thick, respectively, and were quite similar to Horizon VIC2b. STRATIGRAPHIC CORRELATIONS The profiles of the three backhoe trenches (Figures 4-5, 4-6, and 4-7) were recorded following the removal of the upper 2 m of deposit. The description of Section Two was taken from the east wall of Trench 3 (see Figure 4-7). Although the stratigraphy is essentially the same for all three trenches, some variability does exist. In Trench 3, the dense black clay zone (Unit V in the profile description) begins at a slightly lower elevation (225 cm below datum) and is considerably thicker (109 cm) than is the case for the other two trenches. This difference must be considered in relating the radiocarbon date from Feature 401 in Trench 3 to those that were obtained from excavations in the western part of the site. DATING THE DEPOSIT A series of 12 radiocarbon dates from site 41FT193 has provided good temporal control for the upper 5 m of the site deposit (Figure 4-8). The dates range from ca. 170 B.C. to the nineteenth century A.D. Prior to the Season III excavations, it had been thought that the approximately 2 m of deposits overlying the dense black clay zone (stratigraphic Unit V) were quite recent, dating to the historic period. With one exception, the 12 dates are internally consistent and provide the basis for the following conclusions: (1) Archaeological remains associated with the lower dark clay stratum (horizon VIC2b) date to around A.D. 200. (2) Deposition of the dense black clay zone (Unit V) seems to have begun around A.D. 600, and to have continued until after A.D. 1820 + 50. The rate of deposition appears to have slowed significantly after about A.D. 1170 + 150. (3) The 2 m of deposit located above the dense black clay zone were laid down fairly recently, most likely during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries A.D.

## Page 58

38 ARCHAEOMAGNETIC SAMPLING In addition to radiocarbon dating, samples for archaeomagnetic dating also were collected. It was anticipated that this technique might allow the dating of hearths that lacked sufficient charcoal for radiocarbon assay. In addition, the collection of samples would contribute towards establishing an archaeomagnetism curve for the Souther Plains. Presently curves from other areas are used to extrapolate for much of Texas (Holly Hathaway, personal communication 1983). Feature 201, a hearth, was sampled first, since it had sufficient charcoal for a radiocarbon date and this date would serve as a corroboration to the archaecomagnetic determination. Twelve samples were collected with nonmagnetic, one inch cubes in accordance with the methods prescribed by the Archaeomagnetic Laboratory, Colorado State University (Eighmy 1980). The field collection was undertaken by James Bruseth, who had received training in field extraction techniques by Holly Hathaway of the Archaeomagnetic Laboratory. Samples were collected from the oxidized clay in and around the hearth, whenever suitably fired soils could be found. The sampling was undertaken in two episodes. Eight cubes were initially collected, and approximately one month later four additional cubes were collected. Results (by Holly Hathaway) The individual archacomagnetic laboratory report on Sample 1 is provided in Appendix E. The reported paleopole position is based on 6 of 12 specimens recovered in the field. A distinct difference was noted between the remanent directions of the specimens collected during the first session (December 12 and 13, 1983) and those recovered approximately one month later (January 1984); the difference in NRM specimen directions is presented in Table 4-1. Based on these differences, it is possible that movement of the matrix occurred some time in the past (possibly during the hiatus between collection sessions). Intense weather conditions (e.g., heavy rains) could have caused slumpage in the material, or if very soggy when collected, this may have resulted in an instability of the matrix. It is feasible that the difference in remanent directions is real, and the two groups represent different firing occurrences. This possibility, however, should be backed with archaeological evidence and no difference is noted in the field report for the sample. The intensities recorded for each of the 12 specimens were also quite variable for being from a single feature; differences up to two magnitudes were noted between some specimens. This would seem to indicate either different mineralogy among spatially close material (unlikely) or uneven heating of the matrix resulting in “hot spots" about the feature(s). The paleopole plot of Sample 1 does not fall near known portions of the Southwest Master Curve (A.D. 700 to A.D. 1425). Although samples from Arkansas (Wolfman 1979) generally are consistent with the Southwest Curve, the inconsistency of the plot of Sample 1 with the expected archaeological date may represent regional differences in the past, apparent, geomagnetic pole position. Interpretations (by James E. Bruseth) The poor results of the archaeomagnetic dating of Feature 201 necessitated a review of plans for collecting samples from other hearths at the site. The most probable cause of the unusual plot of Sample 1 is the vertisolic nature of the clay soils along Richland Creek. These soils have a very high shrink-swell potential, and soil cracking undoubtedly has occurred in the past. FEATURES Twelve features were investigated during the excavation of site 41FT193. Their numerical designations reflect, in part, their depth below datum. The features located between 200 cm and 299 cm below datum were assigned numbers 201 through 208. Two features (Features 301 and 302) were located between 300 cm and 399 cm below datum. Feature 401 was the only excavated feature between 400 cm and 499 cm below datum, and Feature 501 was the only feature found lower than 500 cm. Three different types of features were recognized. Seven of these were small areas of burned clay and charcoal that appear to be the remains of short term hearths. Four other features consisted of concentrations of carbonized nutshell. The lack of oxidized clay within these concentrations indicates that they were not bumed in situ. Feature 401 was the only example of a third feature type. This was a large hearth containing ash, charcoal, carbonized nutshell, and both burned and unburned faunal remains. The features are described individually below. FEATURE DESCRIPTIONS Feature 201 This feature was first observed in the scraped 230 cm surface. Stripping of the final 30 cm of overburden had removed an undetermined amount of the upper portion of the feature. The profile of Feature 201 is shown in Figure 4-9. The feature appeared as an area of slightly lighter soil with orange, oxidized (burned) clay inclusions against the surrounding black clay matrix. The feature was roughly circular in plan, measuring 20 cm long by 17 cm wide. The profile had an irregular basin shape and a maximum depth of 12 cm below the 230 cm surface. The charcoal sample from this feature was dated to A.D. 1820 + 50. Twelve samples of the oxidized clay were collected for archaeomagnetic dating, and the results are discussed in the preceding section of this chapter. aan ® wm a
