(Beta 14080). FEATURE CONTENTS Flotation samples were processed and analyzed for 10 of the 12 excavated features, excluding Features 207 and 501. The faunal and macrobotanical remains from these features are discussed in greater detail in later sections of this site report. The samples contained very few artifacts aside from lithic debris and plant and animal remains (Table 4-2). The only tools consisted of four, marginally modified unifaces: two from Feature 206 and one each from Features 202 and 204. The amount of soil floated varied considerably between features. To facilitate comparisons, the data in Table 4-2 were converted to frequencies and weights per 100 | of feature fill (Table 4-3). The most obvious differences relate to the criteria used in defining the feature types. The weights of nutshell fragments are consistently high for the carbonized nutshell concentrations. Similarly, burned clay was most common in the fill of the small hearths, since these were defined by the presence of burned clay and charcoal. Feature 401, the large hearth, contained the widest variety of material, with significant amounts of mussel shell, carbonized nutshell, and animal bone. Much of the mussel shell and all of the bone in this flotation sample was bumed. Three species of bivalves were identified, along with elements of fish and turtle. The carbonized nutshell concentrations contained no animal bone, and of these four features, only Feature 302 contained a significant amount of shell, although none of it was identifiable. Faunal remains were relatively more common in the small hearths, but their density varied considerably. In general, feature contents were quite limited. No diagnostic artifacts were recovered from any of the features. The most informative materials were the macrobotanical remains, which are discussed in detail in a later section of this report. Bruseth) A total of 22 sherds was recovered from site 41FT193. Table 4-4 lists the proveniences and selected attributes for these sherds. Despite the fact that the sherds were recovered from several vertical and horizontal proveniences, they all belong to the grog, grit, and bone temper ceramic tradition defined for the reservoir area in Chapter 15, Paste textures are medium to coarse, and all but three sherds are undecorated. The three decorated sherds are punctated with a pointed tool (Figure 4.11n). Interior and exterior colors are shades of brown and gray (10YR5/2, 10YR6/4) with core colors slightly darker (1OYR4/1). Sherd thickness ranges from 4.6 to 10.0 mm, with an average of 7.2 mm. The interpretations of the ceramics from the site are limited because of the small sample size. Nonetheless, the good stratigraphic control shows that the grog, grit, and bone temper ceramic tradition existed concurrently with several arrow point styles, and based on associated radiocarbon dates, this tradition lasted for a considerable time span. As outlined in Chapter 15, a time frame of A.D. 700 to 1650 is proposed for this ceramic tradition within the reservoir area, which is consistent with the radiocarbon chronology for 41FT193. VERTEBRATE FAUNAL REMAINS (by Phillip Murry) Vertebrate faunal remains were recovered from most of the 50 x 50 cm excavation units and from the flotation samples from four features (Table 4-5). Relatively few identifiable elements were recovered, and most of these were referrable to whitetail deer, Odocoileus virginianus. Deer elements were identified for 19 different excavation proveniences (Table 4-6), and Feature 202 contained long bone fragments that are probably from that species. INVERTEBRATE FAUNAL REMAINS (by Richard Fullington) The invertebrate faunal remains from site 41FT193 consisted of the shells of both freshwater bivalves and gastropods. Bivaive remains were recovered from most of the 50 x 50 cm excavation units and from several features. The gastropods were extracted from special soil samples that were collected from five different soil horizons within the stratigraphic/soil sections. BIVALVES Although numerous fragments of bivalve shell were recovered from all excavation levels, much of it was not identifiable as to species (Table 4-8). Very few complete valves were represented. Specimens were counted as individuals of a particular species only when the umbo was present or when the valve was complete enough for an accurate identification. During the field work at site 41FT193, the author made a collection of living molluscan fauna from Richland Creek at a location immediately downstream from the Richland Creek Dam. The living bivalve species were found to be virtually the same as those identified from site 41FT193 (see Table 4-8). The only species found archaeologically but not represented in the modern assemblage were Obiquaria reflexa (three individuals) and Arcidens confragosus (one individual). Considering their infrequent occurrence archaeologically, they may still be present in Richland Creek but simply were not collected. Given the Volume ITI, Part One similarity between the current bivalve species community and that represented archaeologically, it appears that the flow regime of Richland Creek has changed very little between ca. A.D. 200 and the present. It was, as it is today, a typical Texas stream with alternating areas of relatively deep, slow moving water and riffle areas with shallow, faster running water. Given the present size of Richland Creek, and the evidence that it was similar during the past 1,800 years, it is assumed that the creek never supported large populations of bivalve species during this period. One interesting aspect of the 41FT193 bivalve assemblage was that most of the examined specimens were subadults. Freshwater bivalves generally do not reach reproductive age until 3-4 years. At this age the shells should be between 4 and 6 inches in length, which is significantly larger than most of the archaeological specimens. It would appear that by the practice of collecting so many subadults, the prehistoric inhabitants would have maintained a constant pressure on the local bivalve population. GASTROPODS Soil samples for the recovery of gastropods were collected from five soil horizons at various depths in the stratigraphic/soil sections that were described in an earlier section of this site report. These soil samples were washed through a series of sieves, the smallest of which had 1/32 inch (0.79 mm) mesh. The recovered gastropods were identified as to species and counted for each of the five samples (Table 4-9). The gastropods from all five samples were typical woodland species that are common tq the type of woodlands found in the site area today. All of the species are quite small in size and live primarily under logs and leaf litter. None of the species that are commonly found in sandy terrace soils (e.g., Polygyra and Rabdotus) were recovered from these floodplain deposits. It was somewhat unusual that only one specimen of aquatic snail (Physa virgata) was identified. Given the site's creekside location, more aquatic species were expected. In summary, the gastropod species found in each of the five samples are typical of modern assemblages found in environmental settings similar to that of site 41FT193. The only anomalous aspect of sample assemblages was the almost total lack of aquatic gastropod species. MACROBOTANICAL REMAINS (by Gayle J. INTERPRETATIONS Site 41FT193 is a creekside campsite that was occupied sporadically from at least as early as 170 B.C. until perhaps as late as the nineteenth century A.D. The well-stratified nature of the site deposit is a direct result of its creekside location. As the floodplain agegraded through the buildup of flood-deposited alluvium, former occupation surfaces became buried beneath later sediments. Postdepositional disturbances appear to have been minimal. ## Page 73

EXCAVATIONS AT 41FT199 by Marilee Irvine and Daniel E. McGregor, with a contribution by Phillip Murry ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING Site 41FT199 is located on the lower southwestern slope of a terrace, approximately 0.6 km north of the present channel of Richland Creek. A small, intermittent drainage is located less than 40 m west of the site. This drainage has been dammed to construct a large stock tank immediately northwest of the site. During construction of the tank, a small spillway was cut through the approximate center of the site (Figure 5-1). The spoil dirt appears to have been deposited on the southern bank of the spillway on the western edge of the site. Subsequent erosion has deepened and widened this spillway channel, especially along the portion closest to the stock tank, where it has been downcut to a depth of over 2m below surface. The remaining site area has been cleared and is presently in pasture. Ground cover consists of grasses and a few low shrubs. The associated soil type is Crockett sandy loam. SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS The site was originally recorded by SMU in 1974 on the basis of information provided by Mr. Bill Young of Corsicana, Texas. Mr. Young's surface collection included projectile points diagnostic of both Archaic and Late Prehistoric period occupations. In addition, Mr. Young had collected fragmentary remains of a human cranium from a small erosional gulley just north of the spillway channel. Test excavations were conducted at site 41FT199 during the 1980-81 season (McGregor et al. 1982). Eighteen shovel test units (40 x 40 cm) were excavated. A sandy loam A horizon greater than 90 cm in depth was found to be present over much of the site area. A short distance up the terrace slope the A horizon thinned to less than 30 cm and was underlain by a clay B horizon. The test excavations recovered moderate amounts of lithic debris in addition to both dart and arrow points. An Early Archaic San Patrice point was recorded at 40 cm below the surface during 53 the excavation of a geological soil profile. This profile was cut into the south bank of the spillway gully. The point was not collected at that time, and could not be relocated during subsequent visits to the site. Attempts to locate the previously mentioned human burial were also unsuccessful. The significant depth of the site deposit suggested that vertical stratification of artifact assemblages might be present. This fact, as well as the possible presence of a human burial, provided the basis for recommending further excavations at the site. EXCAVATION STRATEGY During the spring 1983 field season, site 41FT199 was investigated by a combination of hand excavations and backhoe trenches (see Figure 5-1), Hand excavations consisted of 72 units dug with a post hole digger (Units 25-32 and 34-97), five 1 x 1m units (Units 20-24), and a single 1 2.8 m unit (Unit 33). The post holes (15 cm in diameter) were excavated in 20 cm levels. All other units were excavated in 10 cm levels. All excavated fill was screened through 1/4 in (6.4 mm) hardware cloth. In addition, 13 backhoe trenches (Units 98-111). were excavated. A total of 48 person-days was expended on this site. The post hole units were excavated at 5 m intervals on a grid system measuring 55 m north-south by 25 m east-west. The purpose of these post hole units was to provide data to be used in generating a series of computer spatial maps (SYMAP program). This strategy was adopted after excavations in Units 20-22 - revealed an apparent midden deposit. The SYMAP results were expected to show relative artifact densities, depth to clay, and changes in soil color for various areas of the site. Units 20-22 were placed north of and parallel to the spillway in an area, identified by Mr. Young, from which human bone had been collected. The reason for opening a 1 x 3 m block was to expose an area large enough to uncover any human remains that might still be in situ. Unit 23 was excavated below the spillway in an area determined to have a high artifact density during testing. It was originally laid

RESULTS OF INVESTIGATIONS SITE STRATIGRAPHY The site is situated near the base of a Pleistocene terrace. The general terrace profile consists of a sandy loam A horizon overlying a clay B horizon. Depths of the A horizon are variable across the site. Volume III, Part One Backhoe trenches excavated in the western and northern parts of the site encountered clay at comparatively shallow depths. The western trenches (Units 98-102) found clay at depths of 40 cm or less. The northernmost trench (Unit 105) exposed clay at only 20 cm below the surface. The series of north-south backhoe trenches (Units 105-110) demonstrated a progressive deepening of the sandy A horizon moving do . Although excavation of Unit 20 by 10 cm levels was terminated at 120 cm because of soil saturation, a post hole digger was used to locate the clay at a depth of 150 cm in this area. The clay is at least this deep in the area south of the spillway gully as well. Excavations there were limited in depth due to the high water table. However, clay was observed at 150 cm below surface in Unit 104 before the trench filled with water. Over most of the site a light brown sandy loam makes up the top 20-25 cm of the deposit. This is very likely the result of recent redeposition of soils eroded from the higher elevations of the terrace. Below this top layer the sandy loam is very dark grayish brown in color and contains a higher density of artifacts. This dark, midden-like soil is only present in areas where the A horizon is fairly deep. The backhoe trench profiles showed that it lenses out both upslope and to the west of Units 20-22 and 33. Within those areas where the A horizon is deepest, there is a gradual downward color change to a brown sandy loam before the clay enriched B horizon is encountered. Evidence of a filled gully was found in the western half of Unit 22. A mottled, disturbed soil extended from the surface to a maximum depth of 50 cm in the west wall profile. CERAMICS No ceramic artifacts were recovered from site 41FT199. ARTIFACT DISTRIBUTIONS The artifact assemblage from site 41FT199 is characterized by a limited number of tools and low overall artifact frequencies (see Table F-5 in Appendix F). It had been hoped that spatial maps of the artifact counts from the 72 post hole units would be useful for identifying horizontal and/or vertical concentrations within the site. Unfortunately, the numbers of artifacts recovered from the post hole units (15 cm in diameter) were not sufficient to provide meaningful SYMAPs. Given the relatively low artifact density at this site, this size unit was too small to provide adequate counts. Of the larger, hand excavated units, artifact density is highest in contiguous Units 20-22. The volume of Unit 33 was approximately 2.8 times as great as each of these 1 x 1 m units. When this volume differential is adjusted for, it is apparent that artifact density is somewhat lower for Unit 33. This correlates with a northward thinning of the very dark sandy loam deposit in this area of the site. South of these units the site deposit was inadequately sampled because of the high water table. A similar sandy loam deposit and fairly high artifact density were found in Unit 23, but this unit could only be taken to a depth of 70 cm. Unit 24, on the other hand, appears to be west of the main site deposit since very few artifacts were recovered from this unit. The number of projectile points recovered from vertically controlled excavation units is limited (9 specimens), but their vertical distribution is what would be expected in a stratified deposit. A single arrow point was recovered from level 3 of Unit 21. Six contracting stem dart points (Gary types, including regular, serrated, and small varieties) came from levels 3 through 9 of various units, while the two expanding stem dart points (Yarbrough type) were from levels 10 and 11. By itself, this evidence suggests that the site deposit was aggrading through time. However, the only geological evidence of stratification was confined to the upper 20-25 cm of the site deposit. Below this there was more than 1 m of fairly homogeneous sandy loam extending to an underlying, clay enriched B horizon. Past research in the Project area has suggested that vertical distributions of artifacts in sandy loam terrace deposits may present a "false stratigraphy" that results from the downward movement of these artifacts from a common occupation surface. Under this interpretation, differences in depth are related not only to variation in the ages of the artifacts, but also to differences in their size or mass (McIntyre and Janak 1983). As a result, the recovery of materials from the same excavation level does not necessarily demonstrate their contemporaneity. Evidence of this phenomenon would consist of a “tendency for artifacts to show a decreasing frequency with depth while displaying a higher mean weight with corresponding depth increases” (McIntyre and Janak 1982:346). This seems to be the case for site 41FT199. Smaller artifacts such as lithic debris display higher frequencies in the upper levels of the site deposit. The lowest excavated levels contain far fewer of these small artifacts, while there is a corresponding increase in fire cracked rock (Misc. Stone in Table F-4). FAUNAL REMAINS (by Phillip Murry) Of the 15 excavated units containing bone at site 41FT199, most contained only small amounts, none of which was identifiable. Units 23, 35, 41, 46, 67, and 71 contained traces of unidentifiable, Velume ITI, Part One mainly unburned, bone. The distal portion of a whitetail deer kumeras was recovered from level 7 of Unit 20. Level 7 of Unit 21 contained a number of whitetail elements. These included a bumed antler tine, metapodial fragments, and several skull and longbone fragments. The only identifiable element from Unit 22 was the proximal portion of a very large whitetail deer antler. This specimen was from level 5, and it shows evidence of having been worked. It is about 7 cm long with the distal end cut and ground square. The proximal end was cut below the burr and beveled. The coronet was largely removed. Whitetail deer molars and additional tooth fragments were recovered from levels 2 and 3 of Unit 33. Level 7 of this unit contained whitetail longbone and vertebrae fragments and a single premolar of this species. Several whitetail longbone fragments were also recovered from level 10, along with a very large gar vertebra. To illustrate the size of this gar, vertebrae of a 36 cm long gar in the faunal collection at Tarleton State University measured 0.5 cm. ni se 3 of al al aS ne aS re rit its ar ty m, ed ed nd . 4INVI60 INTERPRETATIONS } Although several person-days of effort were expended at site | 41FT199, the characteristic soil conditions have tended to impede interpretations. The deep, A horizon deposits which cover much of the area made it impossible to delineate many features, Elsewhere rig the Project area, such archaeologically important contexts were ; often visible only within the clay B horizon. Moreover, in all Ekelihood, the deep A horizon soil has been churned by natural } processes (e.g., bioturbation), and artifact vertical provenience is suspect. _ Despite these limiting factors, however, the site is important E since it provides a sample from a more or less pure Late Archaic period occupation. Although a later occupation is suggested by the two arrow points which were found, the overall rarity of these points, combined with the lack of ceramics, suggests only limited use of the site by Late Prehistoric peoples. In addition to this, a San , Patrice point was found during the initial geological testing, f suggesting a brief Early Archaic encampment at the site. Overall, 57 however, the predominant use of the site seems to have occurred during the Late Archaic period. Perhaps the unusual location of the site on the slope of a terrace contributed to this lack of reoccupation. Most archaeological sites in the reservoir are situated on the crests of rises. Reoccupation of these landforms was a common occurrence and resulted in heavily mixed deposits. Why the Late Archaic peoples would choose to occupy the lower slope of the terrace at 41FT199 is unknown. Perhaps the small slough along the southern part of the site was once a spring, and the presence of water was a major determinant in the location of this Site. On the basis of the artifact content, site 41FT199 seems to represent a short term habitation site. This is seen in the limited range and frequency of tools recovered. The assemblage is dominated by tool forms generally associated with activities such as hunting, butchering, and the processing of animal and plant materials. Terrace resources, such as deer and nuts, could have been easily exploited from the site. Finally, the occurrence of hammerstones, cores, and lithic debris indicates that tool manufacture was undertaken as well.

## Page 79

EXCAVATIONS AT 41FT200, THE HARDY SITE by Daniel E. McGregor, with contributions by Gayle J. Fritz and Phillip Murry ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING Site 41FT200 is located on a low terrace remnant knoll within the floodplain of Richland Creek. The present creek channel is approximately 0.2 km south of the site, and a slough is located along the site's southern and southwestern margins. Ground cover at the site consists of grasses and woody shrubs. A few pecan trees were present on the higher elevations of the knoll during the 1980- 81 survey and testing field season, but since then these have been cleared in association with reservoir construction. The previous landowner had bulldozed a small area of the knoll at the southern edge of the site in an attempt to fill part of the slough channel. Subsequent erosion of this fill has exposed large numbers of artifacts within the disturbed context of the slough. SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS Site 41FT200 originally was recorded by SMU in 1974 on the basis of information provided by Mr. Bill Young of Corsicana, Texas. Mr. Young's surface collection from the site contained artifacts diagnostic of both the Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods. . Test excavations were conducted during the 1980-81 field season (McGregor et al. 1982:34-36). These excavations included eight backhoe trenches, 15 40 x 40 cm shovel test units, one 1 x 1 m unit, and one 1.5 x 1.5 m unit (Figure 6-1). The stratigraphy of the knoll consisted of a sandy loam A horizon overlying a clay enriched B horizon. On the lower, southern slope of the knoll (in the area of Units 14, 15, and 16) this standard terrace soil sequence was capped by a layer of alluvial clay. Testing showed that this upper clay zone contained relatively few artifacts. While artifacts diagnostic of both the Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods were recovered from the test units located on top of the knoll, the buried portion of the site deposit produced only Archaic period diagnostics, including both expanding and contracting stem dart points. 59 The available evidence suggested that the southern portion of the site adjacent to the slough contained a buried Archaic period component. It was hypothesized that the aggrading floodplain of Richland Creek had begun covering this lower portion of the knoll prior to the beginning of the Late Prehistoric occupation of the site. Additional excavations were recommended for this part of the site. EXCAVATION STRATEGY Mitigation phase excavations were conducted during Season IV using a total of 117 person days. The excavations were confined to an area in the southern part of the site where the Pleistocene terrace remnant was overlain by Holocene alluvial clay. The initial phase of investigation involved the excavation of two backhoe trenches (Trenches 1 and 2), each approximately 20 m long (Figure 6-2). These trenches provided stratigraphic profiles of the site deposit extending from the edge of the slough to where the upper clay zone thinned out upslope. Both the upper clay and the buried A horizon were found to be considerably thicker in Trench 2. An additional backhoe trench (Trench 3), 16 m in length and oriented perpendicular to Trench 2, was excavated to examine the Stratigraphy to the east of this deeper deposit. Excavation of two 1 x 1 m units in 20 cm levels (Units 101 and 102) was begun to test the artifact content of the upper clay zone. All excavated fill was dry-screened through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) hardware cloth. Only limited amounts of lithic debris were recovered from the clay. In Unit 102, the buried A horizon was encountered near the bottom of the 20-40 cm level and contained most of the artifacts recovered from that level. All subsequent excavation in Unit 102 was done in 10 cm levels, The upper clay zone was found to be considerably thicker in Unit 101. Excavation of this unit was halted at a depth of 60 cm without ever reaching the buried A horizon. Relatively little cultural material was found to be present in the upper clay zone. RESULTS OF INVESTIGATIONS SITE STRATIGRAPHY Three basic stratigraphic zones were recognized throughout the excavated portion of the site. The uppermost of these was a dark gray (1OYR4/1) clay that is identical to the clay covering the modern floodplain of Richland Creek. Buried below this clay is what appears to be a standard terrace soil sequence of a very dark gray (10YR3/1) sandy loam A horizon overlying a yellowish brown (10YR5/4) clay enriched B horizon. There is a clear and smooth boundary between the upper clay zone and the buried A horizon. The boundary between the A and B horizons is gradual, and might be described more accurately as a thin transitional zone. The thickness of the B horizon was not determined by the excavations. Soil corings taken from the bottoms of Trenches 1 and 2 showed that it was underlain by a sandy C horizon that contained numerous, small calcium carbonate concretions. The thickness of both the upper clay and the buried A horizon varied across the area of excavations. Both tended to increase in thickness in the southern and eastern portions of this area. The upper clay thinned out upslope and extended only a few meters beyond the area of excavation.

Proveniences: Surface, 117.2, 135.6. CERAMICS (by James E. Bruseth) A total of nine sherds was recovered from 41FT200. Proveniences and selected attributes for these sherds are listed in Table 6-2 (details on these attributes can be found in Appendix B). The ceramics from this site fall into two groups. The first group, consisting of a single specimen, is a grog temper category and is similar to the common, grog tempered utility ware found at many other sites within the reservoir. The specimen in the present collection is small (less than 2 cm in diameter) and is undecorated. It has a reddish brown (10YR4/3) color on the interior, exterior, and core. The thickness of the sherd is 5.2 mm. The second group of ceramics, consisting of eight specimens, is part of a distinctive ceramic tradition within the reservoir, occurring in small numbers at only four sites. Sherds in this group are identified as having possible shell temper. In all cases from 41FT200, the shell has leached out, and the identification of temper is based on the laminated nature of the paste. The surfaces of these sherds are highly eroded, as well as being pitted due to the leaching of the shell. Exterior colors are pale brown (10YR6/3); interior and core colors are very dark grayish brown (10YR3/2). The thickness of the sherds is consistent and averages 5.2 mm. All of the sherds are undecorated. As noted in Chapter 15, the shell tempered ceramic tradition appears within contexts indicating a pre-A.D. 700 time frame. The single grog tempered sherd from 41FT200 is thought to date to the Late Prehistoric period. ARTIFACT DISTRIBUTIONS Patterning was observed with respect to both the horizontal distribution of artifacts (Figures 6-7 through 6-9) and their vertical distribution (Table 6-3). The thickness of the buried A horizon varied from about 40 cm in the northwestern excavation units to almost 1 m in the far southern (Unit 130) and southeastern units (Units 118, 128, and 132). In general, artifact counts were highest in the first few excavation levels, and tended to drop off with depth (see Table F-5 in Appendix F). Experience at other Pleistocene terrace sites in the Project area has led to the conclusion that these deposits have not aggraded significantly during the period of human occupation. The projectile points and ceramics from site 41FT200 were tabulated by level in order to examine their vertical distributions (Table 6-3). The established artifact chronologies for this part of Texas (Johnson 1962; Story 1965) have suggested a shift through time in dart point stem forms. Expanding stem forms are thought to date earlier in time, and to have been replaced by contracting stem forms. Although the majority of contracting stem dart points from site 41FT200 were distributed above the majority of expanding stem forms, there is obviously a significant amount of overlap in their distributions. Two dart points were recovered. from much deeper levels. One of these was a San Patrice, which is considered diagnostic of the Early Archaic period. Although this point was recovered from level 12 of Unit 102, this was actually 90-100 cm below the top of the buried A horizon. This might be interpreted as evidence for vertical stratification. However, the tecovery of a Yarbrough point from an even deeper provenience would then be anomalous. Yarbrough points are generally considered to be diagnostic of the Middle Archaic period. The strongest evidence for vertical displacement is the single grog tempered sherd that was recovered from level 6 of Unit 131. This was deeper than all but two of the dart points. This sherd is thought to date later in time than all of the diagnostic artifacts from the excavations. INTERPRETATIONS Site 41FT200 was somewhat unique in having a layer of f alluvial clay covering a site deposit which, on the basis of the test F excavations, appeared to date exclusively to the Archaic period. | Because unmixed Archaic components are very rare in the Project area, further excavations were recommended, 71 The portion of site 41FT200 that was excavated during Season IV appears to have been occupied on a number of occasions during the Archaic period, and perhaps until as late as A.D. 700. Substantial Middle and Late Archaic period occupations are indicated by the recovered projectile points. The San Patrice and Wells points may represent a minor Early Archaic component. Vertical stratification does not seem to be represented by the distributions of expanding stem and contracting stem projectile points. Site 41FT200 is one of only two RCAP sites where Middle Archaic diagnostics (expanding stem dart points) dominated the projectile point assemblage. The other was Site 41NV96. The recovery of ceramics was unexpected, but the eight shell tempered sherds are not inconsistent with the Gary dart points. These sherds seem to represent a relatively late occupation, but one prior to A.D. 700. The single grog tempered sherd is more difficult to explain. It may be that the upper clay zone was deposited over this portion of the site at a considerably later time than had been thought. The absence of other Late Prehistoric period diagnostics, however, suggests that the recovered artifacts represent an essentially pure Archaic period assemblage. This assemblage has been used to investigate chronological changes in lithic technology and raw material utilization (see Chapters 16 and 17). The rather ephemeral nature of the site's features, when compared with sites dating later in time, is interpreted as evidence of short term occupations by relatively mobile groups. The occupants were almost certainly hunter-gatherers, but the poor preservation of animal and plant remains has prevented an adequate reconstruction of the subsistence economy. The burned rock concentrations were probably hearths used in processing and cooking. Similar features have not been common at Project area sites dating later in time. The substantial amounts of lithic debris and the cores, including the cache from Feature 1, are evidence that lithic tool production was also an important activity at site 41FT200.

## Page 93

EXCAVATIONS AT 41NV96 by Marilee Irvine and Daniel E. McGregor, with contributions by James E. Bruseth and Phillip Murry ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING Site 41NV96 is located on a large terrace projection overlook - ing the floodplain of Richland Creek. The terrace surface consists of a series of four sand covered knolls surrounded by slightly depressed areas of clay. Most of the site area is in pasture, but the many large tree roots encountered during excavation indicate that this situation has not existed for long. A narrow strip along the northern terrace edge remains forested. The adjacent floodplain is heavily wooded and is dissected by a number of sloughs. The pre - sent channel of Richland Creek is located about 6 km north of the site. , SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS The site was first recorded by SMU in 1974 on the basis of information provided by Mr. Bill Young of Corsicana, Texas. The diagnostic artifacts in Mr, Young's surface collection indicated occupations during the Late Paleo-Indian, Archaic, and Late Prehistoric periods. The site was tested during the 1980-81 season (McGregor et al. 1982: 39-40). Eighteen 40 x 40 cm shovel test units and two 1 x 1 m units were excavated across the site, which indicated that cultural materials were contained primarily within the sandy loam deposits atop the knolls. The stratigraphy of these knolls was the usual terrace sequence of a sandy loam A horizon (averaging about 30 cm in depth) underlain by a sandy clay B horizon. The artifacts were distributed throughout the sandy loam deposit, with a few occurring in the upper few cm of the B horizon. Artifacts diagnostic of both the Late Archaic and the Late Prehistoric periods were recovered. No evidence of natural stratification was detectable within the sandy loam A horizon. In general, the expanding and contracting stem dart points of the Late Archaic period were recovered from 3 levels lower than the arrow points of the Late Prehistoric period, but the vertical distributions of these groups did overlap. It is suggested that the materials from both components were originally deposited on the same ground surface, and that their present vertical distributions are the result of the differential downward movement of artifacts due to pedoturbation within the relatively loose sandy loam A horizon. The greater density of the sandy clay B horizon is thought to have impeded this downward displacement. Mr. Young's surface collection contained a large, unfluted, lanceolate projectile point diagnostic of the Late Paleo-Indian period and several artifacts presumed to be Early Archaic in age. Similar materials were not recovered from the test excavations, Later discussions with Mr. Young indicated that most of these early materials were collected from a single small knoll (Knoll D in Figure 7-1). Only one shovel test unit had been excavated there during testing. Limited additional excavations were recommended at site 4INV96 for the purpose of locating additional early materials and to investigate further the vertical distributions of temporal components. EXCAVATION STRATEGY Twenty-three 1 x 1 m units (Unit 21-43) were excavated to investigate the site deposits associated with the four knolls (Figure 7-1). Vertical control was achieved by excavating in arbitrary 10 cm levels, All units were excavated at least one level into the underlying clay deposit. All excavated fill was passed through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) mesh screens. In addition to the hand excavated units, a series of 16 backhoe trenches (Units 44-59) was excavated to examine site stratigraphy and to search for possible features. These trenches were placed both on top of and down the slopes of the knolls, providing a more complete picture of the site's Stratigraphy. Fifty-eight person-days were expended during the investigation of site 4INV96.

RESULTS OF INVESTIGATIONS SITE STRATIGRAPHY The stratigraphy of the knolls consisted of a sandy loam A horizon overlying a sandy clay B horizon. In general, the A horizon was deepest atop the knolls and thinned out downslope. Erosion appears to have removed the A horizon from the low- lying areas between the knolls where clay is exposed at the surface. The depth of the A horizon averaged about 30 cm, but was considerably deeper in certain areas. On top of Knoll A the sandy loam was 60 cm deep in Units 28 and 32. It was relatively shallow across most of Knoll B, except for a small area investigated by Units 34 and 48 where it was 70 cm deep. The A horizon was quite shallow over most of Knoll C. However, in Unit 41 on the western slope of this knoll the sand clay was encountered at 80 cm below the surface. The A horizon was very shallow in all units excavated on Knoll D, reaching a maximum depth of 30 cm in Unit 24. This large amount of variability in the thickness of the sandy loam A horizon is not the result of cultural activities. Instead, the profiles of the numerous backhoe trenches depicted a gently undulating surface of the sandy clay B horizon that appears to be a natural feature of the terrace deposit. ARTIFACT DESCRIPTIONS A complete tabulation of all artifacts by provenience is presented in Appendix F (Table F-6). The lithic tools and ceramics are described in detail below. Proveniences: surface (3), 28.7, 37.2, 38.2, 41.4, 41.6, 48 (backhoe trench). CERAMICS (by James E. Bruseth) A sample of 26 sherds was recovered from site 41NV96. Proveniences and selected attributes for these sherds are presented in Table 7-1 (see Appendix B of this volume for a discussion of these attributes). The majority of the sherds are undecorated, with medium to coarse texture pastes and with grog, bone, and grit temper combinations. Dominant exterior and interior sherd colors include shades of brown (LOYR6/4, 10YR5/2) and gray (1OYRS5/1, 10YR3/1), while core colors are darker (1OYR3/2, 10YR3/1). Sherd thickness ranges from 5.5 to 8.8 mm, with an average of 6.7 mm. Only two decorated sherds were found, both incised: one with lines vertically oriented (at right angles) to the rim, and one with lines of unknown orientation. The small size of the decorated sherds makes it impossible to associate them with established ceramic types (cf., Suhm and Jelks 1962). Overall, the ceramic assemblage at 41NV96 is similar to those from most other sites within the reservoir. The ceramic assemblage belongs to a tradition of grog, bone, and grit tempered utility wares defined for the reservoir and discussed in Chapter 15 of this volume. These ceramics were occasionally decorated on the rims with simple incisions and punctations, and where specimens are large enough to discern affinity to established types, they conform to Canton Incised and Maydelle Incised (Suhm and Jelks 1962). A temporal range of A. D. 900 to 1600 is proposed for this ceramic tradition. ARTIFACT DISTRIBUTIONS When work at 41NV96 began, it was hoped that vertical separation between the Archaic and Late Prehistoric components could be demonstrated, especially for those areas of the site where the sandy loam deposit was relatively deep. This did not prove to be the case. Late Prehistoric period diagnostic artifacts (arrow points and ceramics) were relatively rare at the site. Despite this rarity, there were several instances where ceramics were recovered from levels below Archaic period expanding stem dart points. Specifically, this occurred in Units 32, 20, and 41 on Knolls A, B, and C, respectively. Reversals in the stratigraphic location of contracting and expanding stem dart points were even more common. As a result, it appears that the terrace deposit was not aggrading during the period when site 41NV96 was occupied. Instead, the vertical distribution of artifacts seems to be the result of their differential downward displacement from a common depositional surface as a result of natural soil mixing processes. Artifact density was highest for the central knoll (Knoll B). This knoll and the western knoll (Knoll C) contained the greatest variety of diagnostic materials, with both expanding and contracting stem dart points, arrow points, and ceramics se ht el elle wv. =.) gm

## Page 98

78 INTERPRETATIONS The recovered artifacts suggest a relatively substantial Archaic period utilization of site 41NV96. Comparatively minor occupation during the Late Prehistoric period is indicated by three arrow points and 26 sherds. Site 41NV96 was one of only two sites excavated at Richland Creek in which expanding stem dart points dominated the projectile point assemblage. The other was site 41FT200 (see Chapter 6). The time range of these expanding stem forms has not been established for the Project area, but a Late, or possibly even Middle Archaic time frame is suggested. Other than a single Clear Fork gouge and a Wells dart point, no definite Early Archaic materials were recovered from the excavations. Early Volume II, Part One materials do occur in Mr. Young's surface collection from these knolls, including two Waco Sinkers and a large, unfluted, lanceolate projectile point. The vertically mixed nature of the site deposit makes it impossible to assign the nondiagnostic artifacts to individual components. The interpretive value of the site is further diminished by a lack of features and a scarcity of subsistence information. However, because of the dominance of Archaic period diagnostics, the site assemblage itself has been useful for other studies. In Chapters 15 and 16, the lithic assemblage from 41NV96 is one of three Archaic period samples that are used to identify chronological changes in lithic tool assemblages and raw material utilization.

ne sd, it yal 1er ce aic for | to aw EXCAVATIONS AT 41NV139, THE FROSSARD SITE by Daniel E. McGregor and David R. Pheasant ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING Site 41NV139 is located withia the alluvial floodplain deposits that form the east bank of the present channel of Chambers Creek. Within the channel at this location, an erosional bench of brown clay is present between the creek and the steep cut bank (Figure 8- 1). Along the eastern edge of this bench, a shallow erosional gully has formed at the base of the cut bank. Archaeological materials were first.observed within this gully. The bench surface is highest immediately .o the west of the gully, where a slightly elevated area is capped by a thin mantle of recent alluvial sediments. The channel itself is generally free of vegetation. The floodplain surrounding the site was densely forested prior to recent clearing associated with reservoir construction. SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS The site was originally discovered by Mr. Woody Frossard, and was recorded by SMU during the 1980 survey. At that time lithic debris, fire cracked rock, and a Gary dart point were found within the shallow erosional gully at the base of the cut bank. Site 41NV139 had been visited on three other occasions prior to the Season IV field work. It was one of two stream bank sites at which preliminary geological and palynological investigations were conducted at the beginning of the 1980 survey. A backhoe trench (Unit 5) was excavated at that time to expose a stratigraphic/soil section from which columns of soil samples were extracted. Two sets of samples were taken; one for geological analyses (grain size and soil chemistry), and the other for pollen analysis. The results of geological studies at site 41NV139 figured prominently in the development of the initial model of the Holocene depositional history of the Project area floodplains 79 (Pheasant 1982a). The initial results of the pollen work were considered to be promising, and have been reported in Raab et al. (1982). Archaeological testing of 41NV139 was conducted in 1981 (McGregor et al. 1982:41), The primary purpose of this work was to determine whether the site contained in situ archaeological deposits that could be used to date the geological and palynological sequences. Test excavations consisted of two 40 x 40 cm units, one 1X 1 m unit, and one 0.5 x 1 m unit (see Figure 8-1). The results of these limited test excavations suggested that the bench area was the intact lower portion of floodplain alluvial deposits from which the upper deposit had been eroded away. Within this bench deposit, cultural remains were encountered at three different vertical levels. The lowest of these consisted of a rock filled hearth (Feature 1) exposed by test Unit 2. Charcoal from this feature yielded a radiocarbon date of 1690 + 120 B.C. (McGregor et al. 1982:41). Unit 1 sampled a lens of mussel shell and charcoal that was 30 cm above the level of the dated hearth. This shell deposit extended back into the bank for an undetermined distance. An apparently in situ concentration of artifacts, consisting of lithic debris, fire cracked rock, and mussel shell was found in Unit 4, just below the bench surface and at a higher elevation than either the hearth or the shell lens, In addition, two Gary dart points were collected from the surface of the erosional gully near Unit 4. Additional geological and palynological investigations were conducted in 1982, during Season I of mitigation. A backhoe trench (Unit 6) was cut into the creek bank, exposing almost 5 m of floodplain alluvial deposits in profile. This stratigraphic/soil section is described in a later section of this site report. Pollen samples were taken from all identified stratigraphic zones. These were analyzed in an attempt to replicate, and perhaps refine, the results of the initial pollen study. The results of the pollen analysis, discussed in Chapter 5 of Volume I, suggested distinct limitations on the usefulness of pollen data derived from stream bank sediments for reconstructing environmental change.

EXCAVATION STRATEGY The objective of Season {V field work at site 41NV139 was to investigate further the Archaic period deposits in the northern part of the site. This was the area in which a hearth (Feature 1), anda lens of mussel shell and charcoal had been discovered eroding from the clay bench. The research design called for mechanically stripping a portion of the bench area down to the level of the shell lens. From there, excavation of the shell lens and deeper deposits was to be done by hand. A backhoe was used to remove 1-1.5 m of overburden from an area measuring 4 x 8 m (see Figure 8-1). The shell lens originally encountered in test Unit 1 was found to be present throughout the northern half of this area. A rock and charcoal filled hearth (Feature 2) also was discovered at about the same depth as the shell deposit. Elevations were taken using a transit and stadia rod. Unfortunately, the planned hand excavations were never accomplished. A period of heavy rain resulted in the inundation of the site before this work would be initiated, and the field season ended before the floodwaters receded. STRATIGRAPHY The soil section is divided into five major alluvial units. Units I, I] and ITE are separated by distinct geologic discontinuities which are also buried paleosurfaces. Units II], 1V, and V have more gradual transitions. Lesser alluvial changes have been noted within each alluvial unit. . Alluvial Unit I is the youngest and uppermost. It contains at least two, and perhaps three depositional changes. The upper 4 cm 8&3 represent a recent overbank deposit and retain some sedimentary bedding. The whole of Unit I is almost certainly historic. Alluvial Unit I is separated from Unit II by an abrupt and smooth boundary. The boundary is a geologic discontinuity and a paleosurface of possible historic age. The paleosurface has been termed the Chambers Paleosurface (see Figure 8-2). Alluvial Unit II extends from 39 cm to 172 cm below the surface, It is composed of clay, although as much as 20% variation in the texture has been found (Tables 8-1 and 8-2). Between 63 and 108 cm below the surface, the alluvium may be different from that immediately above and below it. It is also possible that these two levels correspond with two additional paleosurfaces. Alluvial Unit I is separated from Unit III by a clearly defined paleosurface; it is a major geologic discontinuity in the floodplain stratigraphy, termed the Navarro Paleosurface. Unit III is composed of the heaviest and blackest clay in the section; it is almost 1 m thick. The boundary between Units III and IV is poorly defined; it is a gradual transition and there is no recognizable paleosurface. Alluvial Unit IV is a less heavy clay than Unit III, and it is not black; obviously it represents an earlier period of creek deposition, although how much earlier is not known. There is a considerable variation of texture within this unit. The transition between Units IV and V is also gradual. The matrix appears to have been disturbed in the transitional zone. A hearth some 10 cm below the assumed surface of Unit V suggests that at one time a paleosurface may have existed close to this level. Alluvial Unit V is coarser than Units II, IN, and IV and more homogeneous than IV. It has a sandy clay loam texture. SOILS The section contains a surface soil and two buried paleosols. The surface soil consists of an aggrading A horizon and is coextensive with geologic Unit I. The soil is 39 cm thick and has relatively uniform amounts of organic matter throughout (see Table 8-1). The soil is divided into Al, Al2 and A13 horizons. The 4 cm thick Al horizon is a recent alluvium and retains some of its sedimentary bedding structure. Calcium carbonate, phosphorus and pH values are similar throughout this historic soil. Below the Chambers Paleosurface is the uppermost of the two buried paleosols. The soil is calcareous and has pH values between 7.5 and 7.6. The organic phosphorus content is 25 to 30% higher in the upper part of the paleosol than in the lower part; possibly because it is close to a paleosurface. The Chambers Paleosol is an immaturely developed soil; the length of its development probably can be measured in hundreds of years. The second and lower of the two paleosols lies beneath the Navarro Paleosurface. this buried paleosol is termed the Navarro Paleosol. The upper part of the Navarro Paleosol is a black clay with a high organic content. The organic matter decreases with depth. The pH is close to neutral, but the soil is calcareous with increasing amounts of calcium carbonate with depth. Below the IIICib horizon there are no major pedogenic features. Groundwater effects become more important, with mottling and the development of calcareous nodules. In the VC4b and VC5b horizons calcium carbonate powder coats the sandy clay loam matrix. This fine powder is groundwater deposited, possibly from lateral percolation of creek waters. COMPARISON OF STRATIGRAPHIC/SOIL SECTIONS AT SITES 41FT193 AND 41NV139 The stratigraphic/soil section at site 41NV139 is very similar to that of site 41FT193 (Chapter 4). Five stratigraphic units were distinguished at 41NV139 compared to six at 41FT193. However, three of these units at 41FT193 (Units Il, III, and IV) were subsumed within Unit II at 41NV139, and two disconformities arguably were present within the latter, but were not designated as such. Unit | is of recent historic age at both sites, and some of the original alluvial structure is still visible. These units are coarser than the lower units in both sections. Unit I is thicker at 41FT193 (77 cm) than at 4INV139 (39 cm). The dense black clay of Unit III at 41NV139 is equivalent to Unit V at 41FT193. Both units are similar in texture, color, thickness, and other soil/geological characteristics. The upper disconformity was termed the Navarro Paleosurface, but neither the paleosol nor the paleosurface is believed to have taken long to form. Beneath this dense black clay zone are Unit IV at 41NV139 and Unit VI at 41FT193. Both units are subdivided into upper and lower horizons. These units are very similar except that the lower horizon at 41FT193 (VIC2b) was darker in color. An equivalent darker horizon was not recognized at 41NV139. Unit VI was the lowest unit exposed in the stratigraphic/soil section at 41FT193. There are great similarities between the two sections, even though they are located more than 10 km apart with a difference in floodplain elevation of about 7 m. Because of these similarities, it is reasonable to suggest that the floodplains of both Richland Creek and Chambers Creek had a similar depositional history during the latter part of the Holocene. The paleoecological implications of the floodplain deposits are discussed in Chapter 5 of Volume 1. FEATURES Three features were identified at site 41NV139. All were small concentrations of burned rock and charcoal that appear to have been hearths. Feature 1 was discovered eroding from the edge of the bench during test excavations. The western half of this feature had been destroyed by erosion, but the remaining portion was roughly semicircular in plan and measured about 60 cm in diameter. The top of Feature 1 was measured at 474 cm below the surface. Charcoal from this feature was radiocarbon dated to 1690 +120 B.C. Feature 2 was discovered during the Season IV backhoe block excavation at the northern end of the site. This concentration of burned rock and charcoal was exposed only partially and was awaiting further excavation when the work had to be abandoned. The shape and dimensions could not be determined, but the elevation was 445 cm below the floodplain surface. This hearth was in direct association with the lens of mussel shell and charcoal which varied in elevation between 436 cm and 445 cm below the surface. ; Feature 3 was exposed in profile in the backhoe trench, Unit 6. It was a basin-shaped concentration of charcoal and fire cracked rock measuring 35 cm in diameter and 25 cm in maximum depth. The top of the feature was 395 cm below the surface. INTERPRETATIONS The stratigraphic/soil section described for site 4INV139 is representative of the upper 4.91-m of alluvium in this portion of 8&5 the Chambers Creek floodplain. It is very similar to the section at site 41FT193 on Richland Creek (see Chapter 4), In fact, this same alluvial sequence recurs with minor variation along the channels of both Richland and Chambers Creeks throughout the Project area (Pheasant 1982a). The most outstanding and consistent feature of this sequence is the layer of dense black clay which has been designated Unit ITI at site 4INV139. A series of backhoe trenches cut into the Richland Creek floodplain at varying distances south of site 41FT193 indicated that this dense black clay zone extends throughout the floodplain area. It was similar in depth, in thickness, and in other depositional characteristics everywhere it was examined. A series of radiocarbon dates from site 41FT193 (see Chapter 4) suggests that the dense black clay zone was deposited between approximately A.D. 600 and A.D. 1800. A similar time range is assumed for the deposition of Unit III at site 41NV139. The environmental implications of this black clay layer, in combination with the results of paleoenvironmental research that has been undertaken at bogs located outside of the reservoir, are discussed in Chapter 6 of Volume I. The clay bench area at 41NV139 is the in situ lower portion of the alluvial sequence from which the upper 3-4 m has been eroded away. The alluvium containing the shell lens and two hearths (Features 1 and 2) correlates with Unit V in the stratigraphic/soil section. These archaeological remains were stratigraphically lower than the earliest sampled portion of the 41FT193 site deposit (ca. 170 B.C.). The 1690 + 120 B.C. date from Feature 1 reinforces the view that these remains date to an earlier period. Site 41INV139 offered an opportunity to extend the study of creekside occupations back into the Late Archaic, and possibly even the Middle Archaic period. Unfortunately, the heavy rains and flooding of the site in December, 1984, forced the abandonment of excavations before a more extensive portion of the shell lens, and an associated hearth, could be investigated. Because of this, very little can be said about the nature of occupation, other than the fact that site 41NV139 was a creekside campsite that was visited on several occasions during the Archaic period. Small, rock filled hearths were constructed, and mussels were collected and processed. There was no evidence whatsoever that the site was occupied during the subsequent Late Prehistoric period.

EXCAVATIONS AT 41NV160 by Daniel E. McGregor, with a contribution by James E. Bruseth ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING Site 41NV160 is located on a series of low sandy knolls within the Richland Creek floodplain, approximately 1.2 km south of the present creek channel. Known locally as "Little Island Field," these small knolis provide a dry, elevated position during periods of flooding. Ground cover at the site consists of grasses, greenbriar, and woody shrubs, with an overstory of pecan trees. SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS The site was tested during the 1980-81 field season by a series of 22 40 x 40 cm shovel test units and a single 1 x 1 m unit (McGregor et al. 1982:42-43). Artifacts diagnostic of both the Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods were recovered from a deposit consisting of approximately 90 cm of sandy loam overlying clay in the units located atop the knolls. Shovel test units placed in the low-lying areas between the sandy knolls encountered floodplain clay and were essentially devoid of artifacts. The vertical distribution of temporally diagnostic artifacts recovered from the 1 x 1 m unit (Unit 1) suggested that a separation of the Archaic and Late Prehistoric assemblages was present. Ceramics and arrow points were confined to the upper 40 cm of the unit, whereas dart points were the only temporal diagnostics recovered from below this level. Additional excavation was recommended at site 41NV160 to investigate further this possible component separation. EXCAVATION STRATEGY Four 1 x 1 m units were excavated during the 1983-84 field season. In addition, two backhoe trenches were excavated to provide a more adequate profile of the site deposit. 87 All 1 x 1 m units were excavated in 10 cm-vertical levels, and the matrix was dry-screened through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) hardware cloth. From each level, a soil sample of 10 1 was collected and subsequently water-screened through 1/16 inch (1.6 mm) mesh. Units 30 and 31 were placed a short distance to the north and south respectively, of the earlier 1 x 1 m test unit (Figure 9-1). The sandy knoll in this portion of the site appeared to be the most promising based upon the testing results. Unit 33 was located atop a second knoll approximately 30 m to the north. All three of these units were excavated down into the clay substratum. Unit 32 was placed adjacent to Unit 30 to expose further a concentration of animal bone encountered in the upper levels of the latter unit. These bones later were determined to be the remains of a modern cow. Excavation of Unit 32 was terminated at 30 cm below the surface. RESULTS OF INVESTIGATIONS SITE STRATIGRAPHY A backhoe trench (Unit 34) excavated into the main knoll revealed a profile of approximately 85 cm of sandy loam. overlying a clay substratum (Figure 9-2). Unit 35 was a backhoe trench located in the low area between two knolls. Its profile consisted entirely of the black vertisol clay (Trinity clay) that covers most of the Richland Creek floodplain. The elevated knolls at site 41NV160 appear to be eroded Pleistocene terrace remnants surrounded by more recent floodplain clay deposits. FEATURE DESCRIPTIONS The only feature recognized at site 41NV160 was a concentration of large animal bones located between 20 and 40 cm below the surface in the two adjacent Units 30 and 32. These faunal remains were later determined to be unrelated to the prehistoric occupation of the site.

Bruseth) A total of 17 sherds was recovered from 41NV160. Proveniences and selected attributes for the sherds are listed in Table 9-1 (see Appendix B for a discussion of these attributes). Three paste textures, with associated differences in temper, are observed in the ceramic assemblage. Two sherds have a coarse texture and are tempered with grog and grit; the grit consists of fragments of hematite. These two sherds, undoubtedly part of the same vessel, have a distinctive, dark reddish brown (2.5YR3/2) color on the interior and exterior. The core color is lighter (2.5YR4/8). Both sherds are undecorated. Eight sherds have a medium textured, sandy paste. The interior, exterior, and core colors of these ceramics are a very dark grayish brown (1OYR3/2). All are undecorated. The final paste grouping consists of six sherds with a grog and grit temper combination and medium to coarse texture. Three of these sherds are decorated, with methods of decoration including punctations (pointed instrument) and brushing (see Table 9-1). Exterior colors range from light yellowish brown (10YR6/4) to dark grayish brown (10YR4/2); interior colors range from very dark grayish brown (10 YR3/2) to biack (1OYR2/1); core colors are dark (1OYR3/1, 10YR2/1). Sherd thickness ranges from 4.8 to 13 mm, with an average of 7.6 mm. The sandy paste sherds tend to be thinner than other paste types. With the exception of the hematite tempered sherds, the ceramics from the site are similar to other sites within the reservoir. Since the hematite tempered wares are unique and not common at other sites, we are not able to make chronological inferences about these sherds. The grog and sand tempered ceramics, on the other hand, do enable some chronological inferences to be made. The sandy paste wares, as outlined in Chapter 15, are proposed to date before A.D. 1000. The grog tempered sherds are part of a larger ceramic tradition that existed within the reservoir from A.D. 1000 to A.D. 1600. ARTIFACT DISTRIBUTIONS Artifact counts by unit and level are presented in Appendix F (Table F-8). The lithic tools and ceramics have been described in the preceding section of this site report. Artifact density was considerably higher for Units 30, 31, and 32 than it was for Unit 33. Unfortunately, the site deposit appears to have been far more mixed than the testing results had indicated. This can be demonstrated best by the vertical distribution of temporally diagnostic artifacts within Unit 31. An expanding stem Yarbrough dart point was recovered from Level 4. Level 5 contained an untyped dart point, a contracting stem Gary point, a fragmentary arrow point, and six sherds. An additional sherd was recovered from Level 7 of this unit. Once this vertical mixing of the site deposit had been recognized, excavation of the site was terminated. SUBSISTENCE INFORMATION Preservation of both botanical and faunal materials at site 41NV160 was generally poor. Eight grams of wood charcoal from Level 2 of Unit 33 represent the only recovered macrobotanical material. Faunal materials consisted almost entirely of the remains of a modem cow from Units 30 and 32. Eighteen grams of fragmentary bone were recovered from the 40-50 cm level of Unit 31; none of the bone was identifiable as to species. The expanding stem dart point styles (Ellis, Marshall, Williams, and Yarbrough) are thought to date to the Late Archaic period, and to predate the contracting stem, Gary style dart points. Occupation during the subsequent Late Prehistoric period is represented by the recovered arrow points and ceramics. The results of test excavations had suggested that the assemblages resulting from the Archaic and Late Prehistoric occupations might be vertically separated within the site deposit. It was hoped that further excavations would recover assemblages of tools, debris, and subsistence data which could be assigned to particular temporal components. This was not possible due to the mixed nature of the site deposit. The recovered artifacts can be considered only as a mixed multicomponent assemblage and, as such, have somewhat limited interpretive value. The substantial amounts of lithic debris, the aborted bifaces, and the cores are evidence that lithic tool production took place at the site. The complete and broken bifacial and unifacial tools probably were used at the site, although the activities performed with these tools cannot be reconstructed satisfactorily. The almost complete lack of faunal and floral remains precludes any interpretations concerning subsistence practices. Site 41NV160 is located on a series of elevated knolls in the floodplain of Richland Creek. Although somewhat limited in size, these knolls provided an excellent location from which floodplain resources could be exploited easily. The diagnostic artifacts suggest that this location was visited repeatedly over a period of perhaps 3,000 years. Unfortunately, the lack of features, subsistence data, and component separation makes more detailed interpretations impossible.

McGregor, with contributions by James E. Bruseth and Phillip Murry ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING Site 4INV171 is located on the edge of a T1 terrace ridge that extends into the Chambers Creek floodplain (Figure 10-1). The old stream bed of Chambers Creek, which predates recent channelization, is located at the base of the terrace. The creek has created a steep erosional bank along the site's northwestern edge. At the time of the 1981 testing, the far northern part of the site remained wooded, while the rest of the site was largely cleared and used for pasture. The wooded area was cleared prior to the initiation of mitigation phase excavations, facilitating a more comprehensive investigation of the site area. The stratigraphy for the upper part of the site consists largely of a shallow, sandy loam A horizon overlying a clay B horizon. In the southern area of the site, artifacts are confined to the upper 20 to 30 cm which represents the sandy loam stratum. The northern portion of the site along the terrace edge has a somewhat different stratigraphy. Here the sandy loam is underlain by a sandy clay containing small gravel and caliche inclusions. The artifact- bearing deposit is deeper in this area (up to 70 cm). The associated soil type at this site is Crockett fine sandy loam. A high degree of rodent burrowing was evident throughout the site in the excavations. SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS The site was originally recorded during the 1980 survey of the Richland/Chambers Reservoir area. Subsequent test excavations consisted of 19 40 x 40 cm shovel tests, two 1 x 1 m units, and two backhoe trenches (McGregor et al. 1982:45). Unit 13, a40 x 40 cm unit in the central portion of the site, was substantially deeper than the surrounding test units, so a 1 x 1 m unit, Unit 20, was excavated in the general vicinity to investigate a possible cultural depression. The two backhoe trenches, Units 21 and 22, also were excavated to investigate this depression. Although artifacts were noted as deep 91 as 70 cm, no convincing pit profile or other evidence of a feature was observed. Two 40 x 40 units, Units 17 and 18, and a1 x 1 m unit, Unit 19, were excavated along the northwestern edge of the site in the wooded area. The sandy loam deposit was deeper (70-80 cm) with artifacts recovered from the upper 70 cm. Disturbance due to rodent burrowing was evident in the different units, but cultural Stratification was suggested by the vertical distribution of artifacts. Faunal preservation from this area was also good, and recovered specimens included species associated with woodland, grassland, and aquatic habitats (Murry 1982:235). Artifacts diagnostic of both the Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods were recovered from the test excavations, with vertical stratification of the northern deposit suggested by the provenience of dart points versus arrow points and ceramics (McGregor et al. 1982:44). It was recommended that further excavations should concentrate on the deeper, and apparently less disturbed, deposits located along the northern edge of the site. EXCAVATION STRATEGY During Season II, 10 1 x 1 m units and six backhoe trenches were excavated to investigate further the archaeological potential of site 41NV171 (see Figure 10-1). Five of the 1 x 1 m units (24-27 and 29) and all six backhoe trenches were located in the more promising northern portion of the sité. Three 1 x 1 m units (28, 31, and 32) were placed along the terrace edge above the former channel of Chambers Creek. This area had been inaccessible during testing because of the dense tree and ground cover which had since been cleared from the site. Two additional 1 x 1 m units (30 and 33) were located to investigate the site deposits on the higher elevations of the terrace ridge. All of the 1 x 1 m units were excavated in 10 cm levels, and the matrix was passed through 1/4 in (6.4 mm) screens. The backhoe trenches, Units 34-39, were excavated in order to provide stratigraphic profiles of the terrace deposit in the northern part of the site. A total of 21 person-days was expended at site 41NV171.

RESULTS OF INVESTIGATIONS SITE STRATIGRAPHY The Pleistocene terrace deposits of site 41NV171 form a ridge that projects northeastward into the Chambers Creek floodplain. The southern part of the site exhibits a stratigraphy that is common for terrace deposits in the Project area. This consists of a sandy loam A horizon (20-30 cm deep) overlying a clay enriched B horizon. Downslope in the northern end of the site, the B horizon is considerably sandier and contains small and medium-sized gravel inclusions. Minor amounts of small-sized gravel are also present within the sandy loam A horizon in this area. As excavation proceeded it became clear that rodent burrowing was a serious problem in all areas of the site. This was especially true for the artifact-bearing A horizon, and was also evident to a lesser degree in the sandier B horizon of the northern part of the site. FEATURES A concentration of ash and flecks of charcoal were encountered between 20 and 40 cm below the surface in the northern half of Unit 24. This portion of the A horizon had been disturbed so badly by rodent activity that neither the outline nor the profile of this possible feature could be defined clearly. Large amounts of animal bone, some of it bummed, and mussel shell were recovered from the same vertical levels of this unit. It was not possible to demonstrate that this ash concentration represented in situ burning, as the surrounding soil matrix appeared unaltered. Bruseth) A total of 13 sherds was recovered from site 41NVI171. Proveniences and characteristics of the sherds are listed in Table 10-1 (see Appendix B for a discussion of these attributes). The majority of the sherds are undecorated, possess pastes of medium to coarse texture, and are tempered with combinations of grog, grit, and bone. Interior and exterior sherd colors range in the browns (7.5YR5/6, 10YR5/3) and the grays (10YR3/1, 7.5YR4/0); while core colors are darker, ranging between 10YR3/2 and 10YR2/1. Two decorated sherds were found: one punctated (blunt instrument), and one brushed. A single, sandy paste, undecorated sherd was also found. Sherd thickness ranges from 5.0 to 7.0 mm with an average of 6.1 mm. Although the interpretation of the ceramic assemblage from 41NV171 is hindered by the small sample size and the small size of individual sherds, the majority of the sherds seem to belong to a ceramic tradition of grog, grit, and bone tempered utility wares manufactured in the reservoir area between A.D. 1000 and 1600. The single, sandy paste sherd is similar to ceramics from pre-A.D. 1000 contexts (Chapter 15 of this volume discusses the ceramics from this and other sites, in more detail). Based on the ceramic data, there appears to have been several occupations of the site during the Late Prehistoric period. ARTIFACT DISTRIBUTIONS A tabulation of the artifacts recovered from all excavation units at site 41NV171 is presented in Appendix F (F-9). The lithic tools and the ceramics have been described in the preceding section of this site report. As was found to be the case during testing, artifact density was highest in the northern part of the site. Units 24, 26, 29, and Test Unit 19 all contained relatively large numbers of artifacts and almost all of the faunal remains recovered from the site. Unit 27, although located between Units 19 and 24, contained relatively few artifacts and no faunal remains. Of the units placed along the western edge of the terrace (25, 28, 31, and 32), only Unit 31 contained a significant amount of material. But here, and in the units located upslope (30 and 33), the sandy loam A horizon was quite shallow (less than 30 cm) and faunal remains were not preserved. Because so few temporally diagnostic artifacts were recovered, it is difficult to define any patterning in their spatial distributions. Archaic period dart points, and Late Prehistoric period arrow points and ceramics were recovered from both the northern and southern portions of the site. Some excavation units contained only

Whitetail deer dominates the passemblage, but the diversity of species is striking considering the velatively small sample size. The rodents may be intrusive since evidence of extensive burrowing was noted during the excavations. 95 INTERPRETATIONS Site 41NV171 appears to have been occupied during both the Late Archaic and the Late Prehistoric periods. Although the limited excavations conducted at this site recovered relatively few temporally diagnostic artifacts, those assignable to the Late Prehistoric period dominate the assemblage. Because of the mixed nature of the site deposit, it was not possible to assign the nondiagnostic materials to particular periods of occupation. A lack of definable features also limits the interpretive potential of the site. The low density of artifacts and the lack of definable midden deposits argue against relatively long term or intensive occu- pations of the site area. The site's location adjacent to the former channel of Chambers Creek is reflected by the faunal assemblage. Aquatic species included freshwater mussel, fish (gar and catfish), turtle, and watersnake, However, terrestrial species, most notably whitetail deer, dominate this assemblage. Identifiable elements of cottontail rabbit, spring lizard, pocket gopher, and cotton rat were recovered as well. The most reasonable interpretation for site 41NV171 is that it functioned as a temporary campsite where lithic tool production occurred (as evidenced by hammerstones, core fragments, aborted bifaces, and lithic debris) and a wide variety of animal (and probably plant) species were processed.

## Page 117

EXCAVATIONS AT 41NV173, THE LITTLE CEDAR CREEK SITE by Marilee Irvine and Daniel E. McGregor, with contributions by James E. Bruseth, Gayle J. Fritz, Richard Fullington, and Phillip Murry ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING Site 41NV173 is located on the southem end of a terrace ridge - at the western edge of the Chambers Creek floodplain. The closest water source is Little Cedar Creek, an intermittent tributary of Chambers Creek that flows along the southern edge of this terrace. The present channel of Chambers Creek is located approximately 1.2 km east of the site. Much of the site area is in pasture, but a group of several large bois d'arc and hackberry trees is present along the crest of the terrace ridge in the north central part of the site. The site deposit consists of a sandy loam A horizon overlying a clay enriched B horizon. In the area around the trees the soil exhibits a dark, organic staining indicative of a midden soil. SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS The site was originally recorded by SMU during the 1980 survey. Test excavations performed during the 1980-81 field season consisted of 18 shovel test units (40 x 40 cm), two 1 x 1m units, and three backhoe trenches. The general site stratigraphy consisted of a shallow, sandy loam A horizon (about 30 cm deep) overlying a clay B horizon. The sandy loam A horizon was found to be considerably deeper in one area of the site. Backhoe trenching of this spot revealed the profile of a large pit with a maximum depth of 60 cm below the surface. The test excavations recovered substantial numbers of artifacts, including arrow and dart points, ceramics, lithic debris, and faunal materials. The density of ceramic artifacts at 41NV173 was the highest of any of the sites tested in the Richland/Chambers Reservoir area. The ceramic assemblage showed strong similarities to Caddoan materials reported from sites to the east and northeast of the Project area. Most of the recovered artifacts, as well as the possible midden deposit at this site, were thought to be associated with a Caddoan related, Late Prehistoric period component (McGregor et al. 1982:44-45), 97 EXCAVATION STRATEGY The excavation strategy devised for site 4INV173 evolved through several different stages, each determined from the results of the previous step. The initial stage was to establish a grid system for the site (Figure 11-1), A permanent datum was set, and a 20 m grid system was established using a transit and metric tape measure. Six 20 x 20 m blocks were established on the site to be used for reference. The next stage of investigations involved magnetic and electromagnetic conductivity (EM) surveys of the site area. Previous work at Bird Point Island (41FT201) had indicated that localized anomalies in both the magnetic and electromagnetic properties of soils often correlate with the locations of archacological features. Similar results were expected at 41NV173. The surveys at Little Cedar Creek were conducted over four 20 x 20 m blocks covering 1600 m2, Measurement of the magnetic field over the site was accomplished using two proton magnetometers. One magne- tometer remained stationary on the site to monitor the time fluctuations in the earth's magnetic field (diurnal drift). The second magnetometer measured the field over the survey area at 1 m intervals. The collected readings were first computer-corrected for diurnal drift, and then used to generate a color density contour map of the site’s magnetic field which keys the magnetic intensity of a given area to a specific color. Several anomalies of potential archaeological interest were identified, and a priority list was established for further investigation. Electromagnetic conductivity (EM) surveying measures the conductivity of the soil, which is primarily a function of soil moisture content. Because of the different water retention and transmission characteristics of sandy loam versus clay soil horizons, changes in their depth or continuity are often detectable (see Chapter 10, Volume II for further details). The EM-38, a portable sensor developed by Geonics Limited, was used for this survey. It covered the same 1600 m2 area as the magnetic survey, and readings were again taken at 1 m intervals. These data were used to generate density contour maps of the site's conductivity which indicated large scale changes in the depths of the soil
