The next stage of investigation was the collection of data for producing spatial maps (SYMAP program) of the site's subsurface characteristics. A series of 117 50 x 50 cm units was excavated at 5 m intervals across the site, within the previously established 60 x 40 m grid system. These units were excavated in 10 cm levels down to the clay B horizon. All fill was screened through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) mesh. Munsell soil colors were taken for each level, and the depth to clay was recorded, These data were used to generate site maps plotting artifact densities, depth to clay, and soil color changes by level. This, in conjunction with the magnetometer and EM results, provided a picture of the site below the surface. The anomalies that were identified from the techniques described above were compared and an excavation strategy was developed. A series of trenches composed of contiguous 1 x 1 m units was excavated through the centers of the anomalies. The trenches started from outside the anomalies and were excavated toward their centers in stratigraphic levels. Eleven anomalies were identified from the surveys, and each of these was investigated using this method. The numerical designations of the contiguous, square meter units used to investigate each of the 11 anomalies are presented in Table 11-1. Their locations are shown in Figure 11-2. All excavated fill was passed through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) mesh screen. After a trench was completed, the floor was scraped to provide a clean surface for feature observation. Any features or other items of interest were flagged for future consideration. After these trenches were completed, six backhoe trenches were excavated to further investigate those anomalies determined to be of possible cultural significance. The backhoe trench walls Volume LI, Part One were cleaned and profiled. In two cases a single, square meter unit was excavated within an anomaly in 10 cm levels in order to collect soil, flotation, and fine screen samples for more detailed analyses. The next stage of work consisted of block excavations. These blocks were 2 x 2 m, but were excavated in 1 m2 quadrants. Again, all excavated fill was passed through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) screen. These blocks were located in areas where no anomalies had been identified during any of the above mentioned surveys. Their primary purpose was to open up large areas down to the clay surface where any existing features could be detected. Two areas of block excavation were dug, exposing 16 m? of clay surface. A third area of block excavation was begun, but this was abandoned after only three 1 x 1 m units (Units 234, 235 and 236) had been excavated. Although the above technique was adequate for exposing the clay surface, the time remaining to complete excavations at the site required the use of a different technique for exposing larger areas. The method employed was the use of a small bulldozer to make 3-4 m wide cuts across the east-west axis of the site. Six of these cuts were made through both excavated and unexcavated areas of the site during Season II (see Figure 11-2). These bulldozer trenches were cut down into the top few centimeters of the clay, removing the sandy loam A horizon. They then were hand scraped using sharpened hoes, and any features or other anomalies were flagged. Once the trenches had been completely scraped and all features marked, each feature was investigated separately. The features were photographed, mapped, cross-sectioned, and sampled for artifact, faunal, and floral contents. Flotation samples were collected from features that were determined to be of cultural origin. The site was revisited during Season IV with the objective of mechanically stripping a more extensive area in the northern portion of the site. Most of the A horizon deposit that remained between Bulldozer Trenches 1 and 4 was removed at that time (see Figure 11-1). As before, the stripped surface was scraped with sharpened hoes, and the newly discovered features were mapped and investigated. A total of 260 person-days was required to complete all stages of investigation at site 41NV173. RESULTS OF INVESTIGATIONS The results of the magnetic and electromagnetic (EM) surveys in conjunction with the spatial maps derived from the 50 x 50 cm unit data served to guide subsequent excavations at site 41NV173. The results of each of these different stages of investigation will be discussed in the order in which they were performed. BLOCK EXCAVATIONS The 2 x 2 m blocks were located in areas where no anomalies had been identified. Six of these blocks had been planned, but only four were completed before this technique was abandoned. Units excavated during this phase of investigation were 216-227, 229, and 231-236. Their locations are shown in Figure 11-2. The sandy loam A horizon was quite shallow in all of these units, and very few faunal remains were recovered. The only temporally diagnostic artifacts recovered are all associated with the Late Prehistoric occupation of the site (arrow points and ceramics). A single feature (Feature 2) was discovered during these excavations. This was a small circular pit and it is described in a subsequent section of this site report. More extensive block excavations had been planned for site 41NV173, but this strategy provided only limited results in terms of locating features. The documentation of features was considered essential for interpreting the site. Therefore, block excavation was discontinued in favor of the mechanized removal of the A horizon from much larger areas of the site. MECHANIZED EXCAVATIONS During Season II, six trenches, oriented east-west, were cut across the site by a bulldozer, exposing the top of the clay B horizon. Fifteen dark stains of various sizes and shapes were identified. AIl of these were located in relatively restricted sections of only two of the six bulldozer trenches (Trenches 2 and 3 in Figure 11-2). Additional mechanized stripping at the site during Season IV resulted in the identification of seven features and 14 post holes, The results of their investigation are discussed in the following section of this site report. 103 All temporally diagnostic artifacts (projectile points and ceramics) observed on the surface of the stripped areas were collected. These included 18 sherds, one Perdiz arrow point, one Gary dart point, and four expanding stem dart points (one each of Bulverde, Ellis, Marshall types, and an untyped specimen). FEATURES Twenty-eight feature numbers were assigned during the excavations at site 41NV173. Subsequent investigation indicated that seven of these features were noncultural in origin. These seven had been designated Features 6, 8, 10, 11, 17, 19, and 22. The 14 post holes identified during Season IV were not given individual feature numbers. The 21 numbered features that were determined to be of cultural origin and these 14 additional post holes are described below. This is followed by an analysis and discussion of feature contents. FEATURE DESCRIPTIONS The cultural features are described in numerical order, followed by a brief description of the 14 post holes identified during Season [V. A plan map of their locations is shown in Figure 11-9. Feature 1 (Figure 11-10a) This small, oval-shaped pit (42 cm long by 32 cm wide) was first observed at 18 cm below the surface in Unit 166 during the investigation of Anomaly A-3. The profile was basin-shaped and extended to a depth of 12 cm below the surface of the clay B horizon. A sample of scattered charcoal was collected, but was too small for radiocarbon dating. No artifacts were observed during the excavation of the feature fill, and its subsequent flotation produced little more than 18 pieces of lithic debris and carbonized plant remains. Feature 2 (Figure 11-10b) This feature was a circular pit (56 cm in diameter) located in adjacent Units 224 and 227. It was initially recognized as a dark stain in the surface of the clay B horizon at a depth of 28 cm below the surface. Cross-sectioning revealed an irregular, basin-shaped profile with a maximum depth of 10 cm below the surface of the B horizon. No artifacts were recovered during the excavation of the feature fill. A small charcoal sample was collected, but was insufficient for radiocarbon dating. A flotation sample was not collected from this feature. Feature 3 (Figure 11-10c) This was a circular pit measuring 67 cm in diameter. It was basin-shaped in profile, extending only 10 cm below the scraped surface of Trench 3. Originally, this feature was thought to be a hearth because charcoal was found scattered throughout the fill. A sample was submitted for radiocarbon analysis, but yielded a “modern” date (Beta-9062). Feature 21 (Figure 11-12b) This feature had a shallow, basin-shaped profile with a maximum depth of 10 cm below the scraped surface. The excavated fill was almost devoid of cultural materials. In general, such features contained little more than lithic debris and, occasionally, fire cracked rock and faunal remains (Table 11-2 and 11-3). The four largest features (Features 18, 24, 27, and 28) yielded much more substantial collections of artifacts. Because the volumes of excavated fill varied greatly between features, the figures in Table 11-3 were corrected for volume, and the counts and weights per 100 | of fill are presented in Table 11-4. Most of the variation in the densities of faunal remains appears to correlate with the horizontal locations of the features. Spatial maps showing the distributions of animal bone and mussel shell within the site's A horizon were discussed in an earlier section of this chapter. Two high-density concentrations of bone were identified (see Figure 11-5). The smaller of these was in the northwest comer of the grid system, and corresponds to the location of Feature 28. The second concentration was in the north central portion of the grid. Features 9, 16, 20, 24, 25, and 26 were located within the limits of this second concentration; and they contained relatively high densities of bone within their fill. The spatial map for mussel shell showed a single, very high density cluster in the north central portion of the site grid (see Figure 11- 6). Although fire cracked rock was present in the fill of these features, the relatively small amounts suggest that they are not equivalent to the large roasting pits present at sites 41FT201 (Volume II, Chapter 4) and 41NV182 (Chapter 12, this Volume). Nine of the features at site 41NV173 contained temporally diagnostic artifacts (projectile points and/or ceramics), and these suggest that two different periods of occupation may be represented. Based on radiocarbon dates from site 41NV182, the coarse-grained, sandy paste ceramics recovered from Features 12 and 24 are thought to date sometime between A.D. 700 and A.D. 900. Feature 24 also contained one Gary dart point and ‘three Scallorn arrow points. Feature 28 contained the highest density of ceramic artifacts, with 40 sherds and 2 pipe fragments. The A.D. 1410 + 60 date from this feature provides a date for the distinctive ceramic assemblage from the site and also for the use of maize. Three other features contained maize cupule fragments (Features 7, 13, and 27), as did two flotation samples from Unit 230 (98N 80E). Feature 13, a post hole, contained no diagnostic artifacts; but Feature 7 contained a single arrow point. Feature 27 contained two arrow points and 17 primarily grog tempered sherds. The temporal placement of Feature 18 is uncertain. Although the 1 x 1 m unit sampling this large pit contained one Gary dart point, one untyped, straight stem dart point, and no arrow points, it also recovered 12 grog tempered sherds. The former are diagnostic of the earlier component, while the latter suggest a late temporal placement. Three other features each contained only one diagnostic artifact. One grog tempered sherd was recovered from both Feature 4 and Feature 15, Feature 16 contained a Steiner arrow point. The ‘temporally diagnostic artifacts indicate that most of the features probably date to the ca. A.D. 1400 component. An earlier component appears to be represented by Features 12 and 24, and possibly others in the north central portion of the site. 114 CERAMICS (by James E. Bruseth) Vessel Sherds A sample of 1131 sherds was recovered from site 41NV173. Table 11-6 lists selected ceramic attributes according to spatial areas of the site and by feature number. The spatial divisions, formally defined in the following section of this chapter, are used to examine differences in the horizontal location of temporal components, Additional information on the design element configurations observed on the ceramics is presented in Tables 11- 7 and 11-8 (see Appendix B for details). Only sherds which are large enough for element configurations to be identified are listed. Finally, the proveniences of sandy paste ceramics are listed in Table 11-9. These sherds have been found to be sensitive chronological indicators at other sites and, consequently, are listed separately. Since the site is located on a terrace knoll away from a major water source, it was thought initially that the area may not have been reoccupied as frequently as were other sites within the reservoir. The analysis of the ceramic artifacts has verified this interpretation, at least for the Late Prehistoric period. Two ceramic traditions are represented: one consisting of sandy paste wares, and the other of grog, grit, and bone temper wares. The occurrence of sandy paste sherds demonstrates that occupation took place during the A.D. 700 to 900 time period. These sherds occur over much of the site but are concentrated in Area 2 and in certain features within this area (see Table 11-9). The remainder of the sherds from the site are associated with a single, major occupation during which grog, grit, and bone tempered ceramics were used. The overall contemporaneity of these sherds is supported by the general uniformity in ceramic attributes among the different spatial areas. Of course, sample sizes are small in some cases (particularly for Areas 3 and 4); but comparisons between Feature 28, which has been radiocarbon dated to A.D. 1410 + 60 and reflects a discrete temporal episode, and the remainder of the site show that similar ceramic characteristics occur. For these reasons, the ceramics are discussed as two groups: sandy paste sherds, and grog, grit, and bone tempered wares. A total of 11 sandy paste sherds which possess characteristics similar to sandy paste sherds from other sites in the reservoir was recovered from 41NV173. They have a very high sand component, but it is unclear whether this represents the intentional use of sand as a tempering agent or the selection of a sandy clay for pottery manufacture. The sherds have a medium paste texture and a rather uniform thickness, ranging from 5.0 to 6.5 mm and averaging 6.2 mm. Exterior colors are shades of brown (10YR4/3, 10YR2/2), with interior and core colors darker (Q0YR2/2, 10YR2/1). All specimens are undecorated. The remaining 1120 sherds are considerably different from the sandy paste sherds. Although a variety of tempers is evident, the most common is grog in combination with grit or bone. Paste textures are medium. Although most sherds are undecorated, the rim panels on vessels are frequently decorated. Common decoration methods are incised and engraved lines, with occasional punctations and brushing. Most punctations were made by pointed instruments, except when fingernails were used to make pinched ridges. Since the sample of decorated specimens is large, several design element configurations can be observed (see Table 11-7, and Figures 11-18 and 11-19). The category of crosshatched incised lines is most frequent, with parallel engraved lines being next most frequent. Overall, the composition of design config- urations is almost equally split between the incised and engraved categories, underscoring the high incidence of engraving at the site as compared to most other sites in the reservoir. The ceramic design configurations are similar to several Caddoan types: Canton Incised and/or Maydelle Incised, Poynor Engraved, Karnack Brushed-Incised, Killough Pinched, and Avery Engraved. All of these are Late Caddoan types with the exception of Canton Incised, Volume III, Part One . However, the distinction between Canton Incised and Maydelle Incised is made purely on the basis of vessel form, and since most sherds are too small for accurate form assessment, little emphasis should be placed on the possible identification of Canton Incised. Although vessel form identification is hampered by the small size of the sherds (most are less than 4 cm in diameter), a few sherds are large enough to suggest the more common fonns. These are bottles, bowls, and jars. Several carinated rim elements are present and suggest this bowl variation was popular. The color of the vast majority of the sherds (including both interior and exteriors) is brown and, less commonly, red. The most frequent shades are red (2.5YR3/6, SYR5/6) and brown (10YR3/1, 10YR3/2, 10YR4/1, and 10YR6/2). Sherd wall thickness ranges from 4.0 to 8.0 mm, with an average of 5.9 mm. The few basal sherds that are recognizable as such are thicker and average 9.4 mm. In conclusion, the ceramics from the site offer important chronological information not only for interpreting the sequence of occupations at the site, but also for interpreting the ceramic chronology for the entire reservoir. As. noted above, the 11 sandy paste sherds suggest a limited occupation of the site sometime between A.D. 700 and 900. The remainder of the sherds appear to represent a single occupation around A.D. 1410 that occurred over much of the site. The ceramics are similar to the grog, grit, and bone temper tradition noted for the early Late Prehistoric occupations at other sites. However, these sherds occur within a later temporal context at 41NV173, and correspondingly, have some important attribute differences. These include the higher incidence of engraved wares, the occurrence of several design element configurations similar to Late Caddoan ceramic types, and the possible increased use of carinated bowls and bottles. Pipe Sherds A total of nine clay pipe sherds was recovered during excavations at 41NV173. All but three are less than 2 cm in diameter limiting their interpretive potential. Proveniences and selected attributes of all the pipe sherds are listed in Table 11-10, and the larger specimens are illustrated in Figure 11-20a-c. Only three specimens are large enough for form identification, and all three indicate a tubular shape. The clay used for the pipes is unique in comparison with most of the vessel sherds. Paste textures are finer, and sand temper, in combination with bone or grog, is more Table 11-9 DISTRIBUTION OF SANDY PASTE CERAMICS AT SITE 41NV173 ee Number of Sherds a General Surface Area 2 Area 3 Feature 12 Feature 24 Provenience om Dae Pe Total ll Volume III, Part One Table 11-10 ATTRIBUTES OF CLAY Pire SHERDS i Area 2 Area 5 Feature 28 i Tubular 3 4 2 Temper Sand/Grog 2 Sand/Grog/Bone 3 2 2 Stem Inside Diameter (mm) 5.0 6.0 common. In fact, two of the pipe sherds (both from Feature 28) are similar in paste characteristics to the sandy paste sherds from the site. We do not interpret this to indicate an early temporal association for these sherds, but rather a functional selection of paste characteristics. The spatial locations of the sherds suggest, at first glance, a nonrandom distribution. However, upon closer examination, it is clear that low sample sizes are partially responsible for this apparent patterning. Feature 28, located in Area 1, had two pipe fragments, and this feature also had a large sample of vessel sherds. Area 2, representing the north central part of the site, had three pipe fragments, while Area 5, representing the southern part of the site, had four. Thus, pipe fragments actually occur over much of the site. Ceramic Ball A ceramic ball (Figure 11-20d) made with a medium texture, sandy clay was recovered from Feature 28. The ball is spherical in shape and measures 2.4 cm in diameter. A single dimple has been made on the surface, apparently with the end of a finger. The original use of this artifact is unknown. ARTIFACT DISTRIBUTIONS Spatial patterning in the horizontal distributions of various artifact categories was discussed in an earlier section of this chapter. These patterns were based solely on data obtained from the systematically placed 50 x 50 cm units, and subsequent excavations yielded results that were in complete accord with these earlier findings. The crest of the ridge in the north central part of the site's 40 x 60 m reference grid appears to have been the primary focus of activity. The highest densities of lithic debris and faunal remains were located there, within an area of organically stained midden soil. A separate, high-density cluster of both ceramics and bone was detected near the northwest corner of the grid, where Feature 28 was discovered during subsequent investigations. The recovery of relatively small numbers of dart points and sandy paste ceramics suggested that a minor early (ca. A.D. 700- 900) component was represented at the site. The distribution of the early diagnostics recovered from all A horizon excavations (50 x 50 cm and 1 x 1 m units) in the intensively investigated northern half of the site grid is shown in Figure 11-21. It can be seen that the early diagnostics cluster in three locations. These are the north central portion of the grid (Area 2 in Figure 11-21), and in close spatial association with Feature 18 (Area 4) and Feature 27 (Area 3). The northwest quarter of the grid, excluding Area 3 and a portion of Area 2, contained no early component diagnostics and has been designated as Area 1. No projectile points were recovered from the northeast quarter of the grid except for those within Areas 2 and 4. This area did, however, contain ceramics, and has been combined with the south half of the grid (Area 5) for this analysis. These same spatial divisions have been used for the ceramic analysis presented in the previous section of this chapter.

When all projectile points and ceramics from the A horizon excavations are considered (Table 11-11) it is obvious that the lack of early component diagnostics from Area 1 is not merely a factor of sample size. The units excavated in Area 1 contained 36 arrow points and 370 sherds. The six dart points from Area 5 were from various units in the south half of the grid, but did not tend to cluster spatially. . It appears that early component activity was confined primarily to Area 2. Two of the features within Area 2 (Features 12 and 24) have been assigned to this component. The only ceramics recovered from these features were of the sandy paste variety (see Table 11-6). Feature 24 also contained a Gary dart point and three Scallorn arrow points. The recovery of early component diagnostics in close spatial association with Feature 18 (Area 4) and Feature 27 (Area 3) suggested that they also might relate to the early component. However, the artifacts recovered from these large pits did not support this interpretation. The two arrow points and 17 sherds from Feature 27 suggest that it dates to the late component (ca. A.D. 1400). The artifacts from Feature 18 are less definitive. Although the two Gary points suggest an early component date, the 12 grog tempered sherds (all undecorated) could relate to either component. The major occupation of the site appears to have occurred around approximately A.D. 1400. In fact, late period diagnostics dominate all five spatial subdivisions, especially in terms of the ceramic assemblage. This is indicated by the similarity between the ceramics from Feature 28, dated to A.D. 1410 + 60, and the ceramic assemblages from each spatial subdivision of the site. The ceramics from site 41NV173 are significantly different from earlier Project area ceramic assemblages. These differences include a higher incidence of engraved wares, the occurrence of several design element configurations similar to Late Caddoan ceramic types, and the possible increased use of carinated bowls and bottles.

Fritz) Twenty-nine flotation samples from site 41NV173 were analyzed at the Ethnobotanical Laboratory, Research Laboratories of Anthropology, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Twenty-four of these samples were from 19 different features. Multiple samples were taken from the two large pits at the site (four from Feature 18 and three from Feature 27). The other five samples were collected from individual 10 cm levels of an excavation unit located within the site's midden deposit. Macrobotanical remains larger than 1/32 inch (0.79 mm) had been separated from other types of material prior to shipment to North Carolina. The unsorted contents of the 1/43 inch (0.59 mm) screen were examined macroscopically for seeds, but carbonized remains other than seeds were not sorted from the rootlet fragments and soil particles that constituted the bulk of their contents. Fragments larger than 2.0 mm were sorted completely according to category (Table 11-16). The weights of pecan shell, acom shell, Psoralea tuber, and maize cupules include fragments as small as 1.41 mm. All carbonized seeds were separated. The weights of carbonized plant remains from all 29 samples included 25.26 g of wood charcoal, 16.24 g of hickory nutshell, 0.08 g of pecan shell, 0.17 g of acorn shell, 0.59 g of Psoralea tuber, and 1.11 g of unknown carbonized material. The samples also contained 11 carbonized seeds and six unidentifiable seed fragments distributed among 14 samples. Five of these seeds are the spheroidal vetch type (Vicia sp.), one is an unidentified member of the legume family (Fabaceae), one is maygrass (Phalaris caroliniana), one is an unidentified grass, one is an unidentified member of the Caryophyllaceae, and one could not be placed at any taxonomic level. Except for the vetch seeds, which are widely distributed among features at Project area sites, it seems unlikely that any of these taxa were playing much of a role in the prehistoric subsistence system here, if any. Corn cupules (Zea mays spp. mays) and/or cupule fragments were recognized in six flotation samples. One fragment came from Feature 7; three fragments (possibly all from the same original cupule) were found in Feature 13; one cupule fragment came from Feature 27; and Feature 28 contained three cupules plus six cupule fragments. Unit 230 (98N 60E) contained two good fragments from different cupules and four more questionable pieces in the level 3 sample, and two fragments from seemingly different cupules in the level 5 sample. 41NV173 Seeds are present in relatively low numbers. The occurrence of maize in six of the 29 flotation samples does, however, indicate a possible food-producing element at this site. INTERPRETATIONS The artifact assemblage from site 4INV173 suggests that the principle occupation of the site occurred during the Late Prehistoric period. An ephemeral Late Archaic component may be indicated by seven straight and expanding stem dart points, five of which were recovered from surface contexts. Arrow points outnumbered dart points by a ratio of 3.1:1, the highest of any site excavated in the Project area. Twenty-four of the 37 dart points were of the contracting stem Gary, regular variety, Gary, serrated blade, and Gary, small variety types. The assemblage also contained the highest density of ceramics of any Project area site. Over 1100 sherds were recovered, the majority of which are thought to be assignable to a very late (ca. A.D. 1400) period of occupation. These sherds show a number of differences when compared to those in other Project area ceramic assemblages, including a higher incidence of engraved wares, the presence of several design element configurations similar to Late Caddoan ceramic types, and the possible increased use of carinated bowls and bottles. The majority of Gary dart points and sandy paste sherds, thought to date to a relatively minor early Late Prehistoric component (A.D. 700-900), were located in the extreme north central part of the site and in the vicinity of Feature 18. However, most of the features and artifacts recovered from the site are thought to relate to the major period of site occupation, dating around A.D. 1400. : Unfortunately, two of the three radiocarbon determinations are considered unacceptable for dating this principal occupation. A modem date was obtained on charcoal from Feature 3, and a very small sample of carbonized nutshell from Feature 16 yielded a date of 880 + 110 B.C. using the accelerator (AMS) technique. The only diagnostic artifact from Feature 16 was a Steiner arrow point indicative of the Late Prehistoric period. It is possible that 123 the nutshell derived from an earlier Late Archaic occupation and was included incidentally in the feature fill. The A.D. 1410 + 60 date from Feature 28 provides the best temporal placement for the major occupation of site 41NV173. In terms of technology and decoration, the ceramics from this feature are virtually identical to the total ceramic assemblage. Because three maize cupules and six cupule fragments were recovered from Feature 28, this date also gives a temporal placement for the use of maize at the site. The site's midden deposit and numerous pit features are indicative of a relatively sedentary occupation. Although no definite evidence of permanent house structures was found, two clusters of post holes may indicate the location of more ephemeral structures. Seasonal indicators in the macrobotanical and faunal assemblages provide limited evidence for occupation during all seasons of the year, but a nonsedentary, multiseasonal use of the site could also be inferred from these remains. The subsistence economy, as indicated by the faunal and floral remains, shows some minor differences when contrasted with the evidence from other Project area sites. The faunal assemblage was dominated by whitetail deer, while very few elements of other species were identified. While it is possible that dependence upon deer was even more pronounced at 41NV173 than at other Project area sites, the differences are more likely due to variable preservation. The faunal remains from several of the features were more similar to those from other sites, and include turtle, rabbit, fish, snake, rodent, frog, and raccoon. Elements of domestic dog and bison were identified also. As at other Project area sites where flotation has been conducted, the macrobotanical remains were dominated by nuts (hickory, acorns, and pecan) and tubers (Psoralea). The relatively low numbers of seeds indicate that they were a very minor dietary element. Of particular interest is the presence of maize. Maize cupules and/or cupule fragments were recovered from four features and from an excavation unit located in the midden deposit. Maize was extremely rare in Project area samples and appears to occur only in post-A.D. 1300 contexts at site 41FT201. While subsistence at site 4INV173 was oriented primarily toward wild plant and animal resources, the occurrence of maize in six of the 29 flotation samples seems to indicate a partial reliance on food production during the late occupation at this site.

EXCAVATIONS AT 41NV182, THE IRVINE SITE by Daniel E. McGregor and Jeffery Bohlin, with contributions by James E. Bruseth, Gayle J. Fritz, Phillip Murry, and Gary Rutenberg ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING Site 41NV182 is located-on a large knoll at the southern end of a long terrace ridge that projects into the floodplain of Richland Creek. The creek, encircling the southern portion of the knoll, is actively eroding both the southwestern and southeastern edges of this landform, exposing Eocene bedrock .in both locations. These Eocene strata are capped by Pleistocene terrace deposits that form the surface of the knoll. Most of the site had been cleared and was in pasture during the 1980-81 survey and test excavations. A forested strip remained along the southern perimeter of the knoll adjacent to the creek. This area has since been cleared. The former landowner reported that the site area had been under cultivation as recently as 10 years ago and was subject to seasonal plowing. SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS The site was originally recorded by SMU in 1974 on the basis of information provided by Mr. Bill Young of Corsicana, Texas. Test excavations performed during the 1980-81 field season consisted of 26 shovel test units (40 x 40 cm), two 1 x 1 m units and three backhoe trenches (McGregor et al. 1982:49-50). The site stratigraphy consisted of a sandy loam A horizon (20- 40 cm thick) overlying a clay B horizon. The artifacts recovered from testing, as well as those in Mr. Young's surface collection, indicated that the site had been occupied during both the Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods. Artifact density was relatively low in all areas except the lower portion of the knoll’s southeastern slope. In this area artifact density was quite high, and the relative darkness of the soil suggested a possible midden deposit. Both burned and unburned bone identified as whitetail deer were recovered also. A 11m unit (Unit 20) placed near the edge of the midden stain exposed a single post hole at the surface of the clay B horizon. The testing results suggested that a midden and associated structure might be present at the site. The relative shallowness of the A horizon indicated that post hole patterns and other features would be preserved in places where they had penetrated into the underlying clay. Additional excavations were recommended to further investigate the more productive southeastern portion of the site. EXCAVATION STRATEGY Prior to the start of excavations, a grid system measuring 80 x 40 m was laid out over the southeast slope of site 41NV182. The grid was oriented 17° east of magnetic north, conforming to the orientation of the slope (Figure 12-1). Within the gridded area an initial series of 50 x 50 cm units was excavated at 5 m intervals. All units were excavated to a depth of 30 cm, which represented the average depth to the clay B horizon in this portion of the site. The soil matrix was water-screened through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) mesh hardware cloth. A total of 149 units was excavated during this initial phase of site investigation. The counts of recovered artifacts were used to generate spatial maps (using the SYMAP program) of the site's subsurface content, The resulting maps indicated two major areas of high artifact concentration. Both of these were located in the eastern portion of the grid system. To further define this patterning, an additional series of 133 50 x 50 cm units was excavated. This resulted in units located at 2.5 m intervals over an area measuring 25 x 40 m (Figure 12-2). Again, these units were excavated to a depth of 30 cm, and the soil was passed through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) screen. The next phase of investigation involved the excavation of trenches composed of contiguous 1 x 1 m units in the two areas where the SYMAPs showed high artifact densities. Excavation in the northern area initially consisted of cross trenches composed of 30 contiguous units (see Figure 12-2). An additional 1 x 1 m unit and a 0.5 x 1 m unit were added to further investigate two features encountered during these excavations (Features 1 and 2). 125

Following excavation, a 5 m long profile of the north wall of these units was drawn. The final phase of Season III investigation consisted of the search for and excavation of features. In two areas of the site (Areas 1 and 2 in Figure 12-2), the A horizon was mechanically removed to expose any features preserved in the clay enriched B horizon. A bulidozer was used to strip these areas to the top of the B horizon. The resulting surface was planed off using a tractor equipped with a box scraper, and finally, by hand scraping the surface with sharpened hoes. A plan map showing feature locations and configurations was made for both stripped areas. Most of these features were cross- sectioned and sampled for artifactual, faunal, and floral contents. Three human burials (Features 12, 15, and 16) and a single burned rock concentration (Feature 4) were excavated completely. Feature 17 was sampled with four 0.5 x 1 m units (Units 4007- 4010) excavated in arbitrary 10 cm levels. All excavated fill was water-screened through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) hardware cloth. Mechanical stripping of the A horizon from Area 3 followed the same procedures described above. Several additional features were identified, mapped and investigated. Once again, features were cross-sectioned and sampled for artifactual, faunal, and floral contents. : A total of 218 person-days was expended to accomplish all phases of investigation at site 41NV182. RESULTS OF INVESTIGATIONS SITE STRATIGRAPHY The large knoll on which site 41NV182 is located is underlain by Eocene age bedrock of the Wilcox Formation. This bedrock is only visible within the channel of Richland Creek. The knoll itself is made up of Pleistocene age terrace sediments. The archaeological deposits of site 41NV182 are contained within the upper part of these terrace sediments. The general site stratigraphy consists of an artifact-bearing, sandy loam A horizon underlain by a sandy clay, argillic B

It also varied in color depending upon the amount of organic staining, but was always noticeably darker than the yellowish brown B horizon. Biological disturbances such as plant root growth and rodent burrowing, and recent cultural disturbances such as plowing have primarily impacted the sandy loam A horizon. The clay B horizon is a much more stable zone in comparison to the A horizon. Experience during site excavation showed that the upper parts of features, such as pits and post holes, were not definable within the A horizon. These features were visible only in places where they had penetrated into the underlying B horizon. They were identifiable as dark stained areas on the surface of the lighter colored clay. The stratigraphic characteristics of the site deposit figured prominently in our choice of excavation techniques. After the A horizon had been sampled extensively, selected areas of the site were stripped to the top of the clay B horizon to facilitate the identification of features. This technique was successful and the features are discussed below. FEATURES Thirty-one features were identified at site 4INV182. Of this total, seven were post holes that appear to be related to the prehistoric occupation. Two features (Features 2 and 24) were of recent historic age. Additional post holes associated with the historic Feature 2 were not given individual designations, but were considered to be part of that feature. Features 12, 15, and 16 contained human burials. Feature 14 was originally designated as Burial 1, because a human mandible was observed at the scraped surface of this feature. However, subsequent excavation of this supposed grave pit failed to locate any additional, intact, human remains. All 31 features are described below. These descriptions are followed by an analysis and discussion of feature contents. A more detailed discussion of the burials is presented in a later section of this site report. Roper (1976) argued that lateral displacement of artifacts (and thus, skeletal material) on a disturbed site may be minimal. PALEOPATHOLOGY The individuals recovered from site 41NV182 are relatively free from disease impacting the skeletons. Burials 2 and 3 demonstrated probable (slight) periostitis on tibial fragments. An amorphous neoplastic area (approximately 2.25 cm by 0.8 cm) was ‘ found midshaft on the medial aspect of the right femur of Burial 2. No associated cloacal openings or periostitis was noted. For Burial 9, a possible anomaly was noted on the proximal articular surface of the (right?) fifth proximal phalange. The defect is a groove into the articular surface of the bone, giving the surface a ‘horseshoe’ appearance. Dental pathology is minor and limited largely to carious lesions and calculus deposits. Enamel hypoplasia and root hyper- cementosis are found in lesser amounts. Dental calculus is prevalent on the posterior teeth of most adult individuals and is moderate in degree. Table 12-6 presents a brief summary of the dental pathologies. ARTIFACT DESCRIPTIONS A complete tabulation of all artifact classes by their proveniences is presented in Appendix F (Table F-11). Artifacts recovered from features are tabulated separately in Table 12-2. The lithic tools and ceramics are described below. Provenience designations follow each description and present the unit number first, followed by the level number (e.g., 313.1). LITHIC TOOLS Arrow Points Alba (7 specimens, Figure 12-8a,b). Although some later material does occur (perhaps the engraved specimens; Figure 12-11g) and a radiocarbon date of A.D. 1140 + 50 was obtained from Feature 21, most of the material from the site seems to relate to an earlier occupation. Radiocarbon dates place this occupation between A.D. 670 and 870. At this time, both grog and sand tempered ceramics were used, with some of the sherds heavily tempered with sand. Although many of the vessels were plain, punctations and incised lines on the rim panels were used Volume ITI, Part One occasionally. These designs are similar to stylistic elements present on the type Canton Incised (Suhm and Jelks 1962:22-23). ARTIFACT DISTRIBUTIONS During the mitigation program at 41NV182, spatial maps (SYMAP program) of the distribution of all artifact classes were generated from the 50 x 50 cm unit data. These spatial maps showed that the vast majority of artifacts were located in the eastern portion of the grid system (east of 270E). All subsequent excavations were located in this area of the site. The spatial maps also indicated that two separate areas of high artifact density were present within this eastern portion of the grid system. This is best illustrated by the distribution of lithic debris, the category with the largest numbers of specimens (Figure 12-12). The distribution of faunal remains was somewhat different. The major concentration of animal bone covers an area approx- imately 20 m north-south by 10 m east-west (Figure 12-13). Most of this concentration was located in the central portions of Areas 1 and 3. Later excavations in this section of the site served to confirm the animal bone distribution represented by the spatial maps. The distribution of mussel shell (Figure 12-14) was similar to that of bone, except that it formed a somewhat tighter cluster. The highest densities of both bone and shell were located within the area where subsequent investigations discovered a number of prehistoric pit features of various sizes. This seems to have been the principle area of activity at the site, where vertebrate and invertebrate animals were processed, and where their remains were discarded. Two major areas of fire cracked rock concentration can be observed in Figure 12-15. Subsequent investigations indicated that these are associated with the three large depressions that have been identified at site 41NV182. The somewhat smaller cluster to the north corresponds to the location of Feature 18. The larger, southern cluster seems to represent overlapping concentrations associated with Features 3 and 17. The association of these features with large amounts of fire cracked rock suggests that they may be analogous to the large roasting pits identified at site 41FT201 (see Chapter 4, Volume II). Definable clusters in the distribution of ceramics are not so apparent (Figure 12-16) but this may be due to the relatively small numbers of specimens recovered from each of the 50 x 50 cm units. As was the trend for the other artifact categories, the vast majority of ceramics were recovered from the eastern portion of the grid system. In fact, 224 of the 250 total sherds recovered from all 50 x 50 cm units were from those units located east of the 270E line. One interesting pattern concerns the distribution of the coarse-grained, sandy paste sherds. Sandy paste ceramics are thought to predate Caddoan style ceramics over much of the central and southern portions of East Texas (Shafer 1975; Story 1981), and presumably in the Project area as well. From the South Area excavations, including Feature 21, 27 arrow points and 36 dart points were recovered, for an almost identical arrow:dart point ratio of 0.75:1. It is apparent that both areas of the site contained a scattering of materials related to relatively minor Archaic period occupations. These are indicated by the expanding and straight stemmed dart points, and perhaps some portion of the contracting stem Gary points. Although the arrow/dart point ratios are similar, certain point styles seem to be disproportionately overrepresented in the | North Area (Table 12-10). These include the Gary, regular variety and Gary, small variety among the dart points, and the Steiner and perhaps, Scallorn among the arrow points. These four point types may be most characteristic of the A.D. 700-900 occupation. Aside from the difference in the percentages of sandy paste sherds, the ceramic assemblages from these two subareas were very similar. The dominant temper type was grog, which is true for all Late Prehistoric period. sites in the Project area. The relatively few decorated sherds exhibited primarily punctations and incised lines. It appears that both grog tempered and sandy paste ceramics were used concurrently during the earlier, major period of occupation (ca. A.D. 700-900), and that only the grog tempered wares were diagnostic of a less intensive, slightly later use of the site (ca. A.D. 1000-1200). VERTEBRATE FAUNAL REMAINS (by Phillip Murry) The vertebrate faunal remains from all 1 x 1 m units, 0.5 x 1m units, and the excavated features at site 4INV182 were included in this analysis, The animal bone from the 50 x 50 cm units was weighed, and the spatial distribution of this material has been discussed in the preceding section of this site report. It was not, however, included in this analysis. Total weights of both burned and unburned bone were recorded for each excavation unit and feature (Table 12-11). When possible, the remains were identified as to skeletal element and species. The spatial maps of animal bone densities based on the contents of the 50 x 50 cm units indicated a major concentration, measuring about 20 m long and 10 m wide. This concentration stretched from the northern edge of Area 1 in the north, to the northern edge of Area 2 in the south. Subsequent excavations, although more limited in areal extent, also recovered the greatest amounts of animal bone from this same area. Volume HI, Part One 240 260 280 300 EAST FRAGMENTS OF FIRE CRACKED ROCK Figure 12-15. This included numerous elements of whitetail deer and testudinid turtle, along with minor amounts of fish, bird, rodent, and rabbit. A short distance to the south was an east-west trench composed of contiguous 1 x 1 m units. The units with the largest amounts of faunal remains were between 276E and 284E (Units 2156-2163). Remains of whitetail deer and testudinid turtle were the most numerous, but the relative lack of smaller species is probably due to the fact that no flotation samples were taken from these units. Several elements of domestic dog were recovered from two of these units as well. The most abundant and diverse collections of faunal remains were recovered from a series of pit features located at the southern edge of Area 1 and within Area 3 (primarily Features 7, 8, 9, 11, and 21). Deer and turtle (both softshell and testudinid) were most abundant; but rabbit, fish, snake, bird, raccoon, and rodent were also well represented. A vertebra and mandible fragment of domestic dog were recovered from Feature 9. Substantial quantities of bone were recovered from the 0.5 x 1 m units excavated within Feature 17. Possible bison remains were recovered from two 1 x 1 m units. Both of these specimens were very thick fragments of long bone that were tentatively assigned to that species. All intact, mandibular teeth of whitetail deer were examined to determine the ages of the individuals and, if possible, the season of death. Based on eruption and degree of wear, age could be determined for seven individuals (Table 12-12). According to Schmidly (1983:297), deer are in their prime between 2.5 and 7.5 years of age. The seven individuals from site 41NV182 may all fall within this range, although four of them are at the early end of it. The estimation of the season of death requires the determination of age in months. This is difficult to determine precisely for individuals that were older than 1.5 years and, therefore, could not be provided for the sample from site 41NV182. In summary, site 41NV182 produced an abundant and diverse faunal assemblage. Fritz) Nineteen flotation samples from 16 different features were examined for macrobotanical remains at the Ethnobotanical 145 Laboratory, Research Laboratories of Anthropology, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. The smallest screen size examined for these samples was the 1/32 in (0.79 mm) portion. Macrobotanical remains larger than 2.0 mm had been separated from other types of materials larger than 2.0 mm had been separated from other types of materials larger than 2.0 mm, present in the light and heavy fractions, prior to shipment. Contents of the 1/16 in (1.59 mm) and 1/32 in (0.79 mm) screens were sent to North Carolina with no previous sorting. Fragments larger than 2.0 mm were sorted completely according to category (Table 12-13). The weights of pecan shell, acom shell, and Psoralea tuber include fragments smaller than 2.0 mm. but larger than 1.4 mm. All carbonized seeds were separated. Items recovered from these samples included wood charcoal (8.76 g), hickory nutshell (9.69 g), pecan shell (0.16 g), acorn shell (0.16 g), the tuber thought to be Psoralea (0.40 g), a bulb resembling the wild onion, Allium sp. (0.11 g), and unknown carbonized fragments (0.64 g). The 19 samples contained only six, reasonably intact, carbonized seeds. Wood charcoal was present in all 16 features. Thick shelled, hickory nut (Carya sp.) fragments were present in all features except Post Hole 7. Pecan shell (Carya illinoensis) occurred in nine features. Acorn shell (Quercus spp.) was recovered from 13 features. As at other Project area sites, the most abundant plant food represented, other than nuts, was prairie turnip tuber (Psoralea sp., possibly Psoralea latestipulata). These remains occurred in 10 features at the site. Feature 1 also contained fragments, weighing 0.08 g, of what appears to be a type of tuber other than Psoralea. No taxonomic determination of that material has been made. Another type of underground plant part was present in Feature 5. The heavy fraction of that sample included a bulb that closely resembles wild onion (Allium sp.). The 19 samples contained only six reasonably intact, carbonized seeds and 10 unidentifiable, seed fragments. Two spheroidal vetch or wild pea seeds were recovered. The specimens in Feature 1 has an exceptionally well-preserved hilum and surface patterning that looks like Lathyrus pusillus. The specimen from Feature 7 is not as well preserved and might be either Lathyrus or Vicia. One chenopod seed (Chenopodium sp.) and one spurge seed (Euphorbia cf. maculata) were present in Feature 9. Use of the former genus for food is possible, but both specimens might have been charred incidentally rather than during activities connected with food processing or consumption. Two seeds, one from Feature 6 and a second from Feature 14, remain unidentified. The former resembles the true seed (interior “kernel") of wild sumpweed fruit (/va sp.), but also looks very much like the true seed inside the hard fruit wall of biconvex Polygonum nutlets. No diagnostic embryo or ribbing could be discerned, and the shape seems somewhat altered by carbonization. The low numbers of seeds in these samples reflect the same pattern exhibited by macrobotanical assemblages from other Project area sites. Hickory nuts, acorns, pecans, and tubers are the dominant plant foods represented. Other underground plant parts were exploited, and a few seed types evidently were gathered as a minor dietary element. No evidence of plant domestication was found at site 41NV182. The Psoralea and vetch seeds suggest spring/early summer occupation, while the Chenopodium seed and the high nutshell percentages indicate a fall utilization of the site as well. INTERPRETATIONS Most of the features and artifacts from site 41NV182 are thought to have resulted from an occupation dating between A.D. 700 and A.D. 900. It appears that both contracting stem, Gary dart points and arrow points were in use during this period. Expanding and straight stem dart points accounted for a relatively minor portion of the projectile point assemblage, and they probably indicate a minor, yet significant occupation of the site during the Late Archaic period.

The coarse-grained, sandy paste sherds are thought to be diagnostic of the A.D. 700-900 period. These accounted for over 11% of the total 442 sherds from site 41NV182, but were relatively more common in what has been defined as the North Area of the site. This difference in the spatial distribution of sandy paste sherds is thought to indicate a less intensive, slightly later occupation that was concentrated in the South Area of the site. The A.D. 1140 + 50 radiocarbon date from 147 Feature 21 suggests that this later occupation was contemporary with Late Prehistoric period occupations elsewhere in the Project area (See Volume II). Subsurface features at the site included three, very large depressions that are thought to have been roasting pits, based on their association with large amounts of fire cracked rock. The irregular profiles of these large pits, and the presence of smaller, intrusive pits within them, suggest that they were reused repeatedly during the period of site occupation. The only radiocarbon date from within one of these features (A.D. 870 + 140) was on charcoal from a concentration of fire cracked rock located within Feature 18. The two large roasting pits in the South Area of the site are thought to have been contemporary with Feature 18, but these have not been dated. A series of smaller pit features was located in the area between the large roasting pits. Almost all of these are thought to date to the A.D, 700-900 occupation, but other than Feature 21, only Feature 9 has been dated (A.D. 670 + 130). The exact functions of these features are uncertain, but most may represent storage or trash pits. Because Features 8 and 9 contained such high densities of fire cracked rock, it is possible that they represent smaller roasting pits or earth ovens. The large numbers of features and the presence of burials suggest a relatively sedentary occupation at site 4INV182. Although seven post holes were identified, no firm evidence of permanent structures was found. Macrobotanical remains suggesting both spring/early summer and fall occupations were recovered from many of the features. An occupation of the site by groups of at least semisedentary hunter-gatherers is hypothesized. With respect to subsistence, substantial amounts of faunal and floral remains were recovered from the site. Whitetail-deer remains dominate the faunal assemblage but a wide variety of other terrestrial and aquatic species also were identified. These included turtle (both testudinid and softshell), freshwater bivalves, fish, bird, rabbit, raccoon, rodents, domestic dog, beaver, and possibly bison, Nuts (hickory, acorn, and pecan) and tubers (Psoralea) dominate the plant remains. A few seed types evidently were gathered as a minor dietary element. A rather generalized subsistence economy based on a broad range of wild plant and animal resources is indicated, but there is no evidence for agriculture during this period. ## Page 169

EXCAVATIONS AT 41NV203, POLECAT HILL by William A. Martin and Daniel E. McGregor, with contributions by James E. Bruseth and Phillip Murry ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING Site 41NV203 is located on a high knoll overlooking the floodplain of Mesquite Creek, an intermittent tributary of Richland Creek. The knoll is the only elevated landform in the lower Mesquite Creek floodplain and is actually an upland erosional remnant. The soil on the knoll is Lamar clay loam and the surrounding floodplain soil is Kaufman clay (Meade, Chervenka, and Greenwade 1974). Mesquite Creek is actively eroding the western portion of the knoll and has undoubtedly destroyed the western end of the site, as indicated by the presence of high artifact densities at the edge of the steep erosional bank. A few oak, hickory, and mesquite trees are present on top of the knoll and along the creek bank, but most of the site and surrounding area has been cleared and used for pasture. Slope erosion along the southern and eastern edges of the knoll is pronounced, with broad areas of lighter colored subsoil exposed. As a result, the precise limits of the occupation cannot be determined, although it is clear that the total site area was rather small. The present extent of the cultural deposit covers an area of only about 10 x 20 m. Despite its small size, the knoll's height above the floodplain and location adjacent to the creek would probably have made it an attractive location for aboriginal occupation. SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS Polecat Hill was reported to the SMU research team in 1980 by Mr. Oscar Bounds, the landowner. Test excavations were conducted at that time, consisting of seven 40 x 40 cm shovel tests and two 1 x 1 m units (Figure 13-1). Results of the test excavations demonstrated that artifact density was highest on the crest of the knoll and decreased sharply downslope (McGregor et al. 1982:51- 52). Very few artifacts were observed on the slopes of the knoll, even though ground exposure was excellent, indicating that most of the deposit had been washed away with the topsoil. The cultural deposit was relatively shallow on top of the site as well, with most artifacts confined to the upper 30 cm of the profile. A few artifacts were recovered as deep as 80 cm below the surface in Test Unit 1, but deep vertical cracks were also observed in the soil suggesting that vertical displacement of artifacts had occurred as a result of the active soil. The cultural deposit contained Gary type dart points, as well as arrow points and ceramics which are characteristic of Late Prehistoric period occupations. The dart points may date to the Archaic period, suggesting the possibility of a mixed deposit of Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric period occupations. The faunal assemblage is notable because of its excellent state of preservation and the diversity of species present. As with most sites, deer was the dominant species, but several aquatic species, such as fish, turtle, and water snake, were recovered as well. Site 41NV203 was recommended for additional excavation because the faunal sample appeared to offer a strong potential for clarifying Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric subsistence patterns in the western end of the Project area, an area in which few sites had been found. More specifically, the uplands in the western portions of the reservoir are located in the Tall Grass Prairie biotic zone, as noted in the Introduction to this volume. Most of the other excavated sites are situated in the central and eastem parts of the reservoir where the Post Oak Savannah biotic zone occupies the uplands. Since the faunal and floral resources of these two zones differ significantly, subsistence practices were expected to differ also. The excellent faunal preservation, coupled with the probability of locating features containing macrobotanical remains, caused this site to be scheduled for additional data recovery. In addition, the location of the site along a tributary of Richland Creek, rather than along the main channel where many of the other sites are situated, offered an opportunity to compare assemblage characteristics not only between the western and eastern portions of the reservoir but also between tributary and main channel sites. This opportunity was an additional motivation for excavation at Polecat Hill. 149

EXCAVATION STRATEGY Season IV excavations were confined to the crest of the knoll since test excavations indicated that this was the most productive area of the site. A total of 123 person-days was expended to investigate this area. An excavation block measuring 5 x 15 m was laid out, with the long axis oriented parallel to the eroded creek bank, 29° west of magnetic north (see Figure 13-1). Since the orientation was away from magnetic north, grid coordinates were assigned, using designations of A for the long axis and B for the short axis. The block contained 75 1 x 1 m units of which 39 were excavated (Figure 13-2). Although most of the block was excavated in a checkerboard pattern, with every other unit being dug, a few contiguous units were excavated. This procedure resulted in the excavation of 50% of the site. Vertical control was maintained by excavating in 10 cm arbitrary levels. A 10 1 soil sample was collected from each level for fine screen processing through 1/16 inch (1.6 mm) mesh. All remaining soil was dry- screened through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) hardware cloth. A single cultural feature was uncovered during the excavation. This was a pit which was partially exposed in the western halves of Units 107 and 108. It was cross-sectioned along the west wall of these units, and all fill from the eastern half of this feature was saved; 30 I were screened through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) mesh, and 10 | were processed by means of flotation. RESULTS OF INVESTIGATIONS SITE STRATIGRAPHY The soil profile of the knoll consists of a dark grayish brown, clay loam A horizon, 25-30 cm thick, which forms a gradual, smooth boundary with a light olive brown B horizon. The clay loam B horizon extends down to about 60 cm where it forms a clear, smooth boundary with a yellowish brown, clay loam C horizon. All of the clay in these horizons is calcareous and moderately alkaline, which accounts for the excellent bone preservation observed at the site. The clay is very sticky and plastic when wet, and very hard and friable when dry. As previously noted, deep vertical cracks form when the soil is dry due to its high shrink-swell potential. This undoubtedly has affected the vertical provenience of several artifacts. The Lamar clay loam comprising the knoll contains substantial amounts of shale and siltstone. In fact, the resistance to erosion exhibited by these rocks has resulted in the presence of the knoll as an erosional upland remnant on the floodplain (Edward Janak, personal communication 1984). The shrink-swell activity of the clay soil has fractured the rock, creating thousands of tiny fragments. These fragments impeded screening progress and also created artificially high counts of fire cracked rock, since these rocks were classified as fire cracked prior to the site's examination

FEATURE 1 Feature 1 was the only cultural feature uncovered during the excavation of 41NV203. The eastern half of this pit was exposed in Units 107 and 108, while the western half extended outside of the excavation block toward the creek bank. Feature 1 is slightly irregular in outline, but it appears to be roughly oval with a diameter of 132 cm. In profile, the feature is a shallow, basin- shaped pit (Figure 13-3). It was first observed at a depth of 30 cm and extended down to 55 cm below the surface. The pit fill was very dark gray (7.5YR3/0) in color, with areas of yellowish brown (10YR5/4) along the edges. The pit fill was clearly visible against the light olive brown (2.5Y5/4) subsoil. Artifact content was not very different from the artifact content of the general deposit. The quantities of baked clay and charcoal recovered in the 10 | flotation sample were minimal. Only 13 g of baked clay and 0.12 g of charcoal were recovered. In fact, the pronounced lack of macrobotanical remains is the most notable characteristic of this feature. Whereas nearly all features at other sites contained substantial amounts of charcoal and hickory nut shell, Feature 1 contained only 0.12 g of wood charcoal, 0.01 g of Psoralea, and two carbonized vetch seeds, thought to be Vicia. Psoralea (sp) and Vicia mature in the spring, so at a minimum a spring or early summer occupation is indicated by their presence in the feature fill. It is difficult to interpret the function of Feature 1 based on content. The contents of the 10 1 flotation sample include 1 arrow point, 2 core fragments, 71 flakes greater than 6 mm, 150 flakes less than 6 mm, 45 fragments of fire cracked rock (23 g), 1.3 g of baked clay, 25.2 g of unbumed bone, 6.1 g of burned bone, 12.8 g g), 48.9 g of unbumed bone, 9.6 g of burned bone, and 35.5 g of mussel shell. Interpretation of feature function is hindered by the fact that most of the feature fill includes artifacts that were present in the soil when the pit was dug and were dumped back into the pit during the fill episode. Thus, it is impossible to determine which artifacts were intentionally included in the feature. The low quantities of baked clay and charcoal indicate that the pit was not used as a hearth, but its actual function cannot be assessed. Materials: quartzite (7), sandstone (4), siltstone (2). Proveniences: level 1 (9), level 2 (3), level 3 (1). CERAMICS (by James E. Bruseth) A total of 379 sherds was recovered from 41NV203. The number of sherds exhibiting selected attributes pertaining to sherd location, rim orientation, lip form, tempering material, and decorative motif are presented in Table 13-2. The ceramic frequencies for each attribute are presented by vertical provenience only (i.e., total ceramics from each 10 cm level at the site). Patterns in the horizontal distribution of ceramics are discussed in a subsequent section. The only exception to this form of presentation is the inclusion of Feature 1 on the table as a separate provenience. Explanations of ceramic attributes are presented in Appendix B. Most of the sherds from 41NV203 are tempered with combinations of grog, grit, and bone and exhibit medium to coarse paste textures. Incising and punctation are the most common decorative techniques, but other decoration methods are present, including brushing and engraving. The configurations of design elements include random fingernail punctations (Figure 13-5a), parallel incised lines (Figure 13-5c), and crosshatched incised lines (Figure 13-5d). ARTIFACT DISTRIBUTIONS Site 41NV203 yielded the densest concentration of artifacts found anywhere in the reservoir area. The quantity of artifacts recovered from the 39 1 x 1 m units that were excavated is staggering. A total of 34,439 pieces of lithic debris was uncovered from the 6.4 mm mesh. Including the 71 flakes recovered from 6.4 mm mesh in Feature 1, the total is 34,510. This translates to an average of 2,900 flakes per cubic meter. Tremendous quantities of other artifacts were recovered also, yielding densities of 43 bifaces, 188 unifaces, 46 projectile points, 32 sherds, 675 g of bone, and 354 g of mussel shell per cubic meter. The extremely high artifact density of 4INV203 is probably a reflection of intensive occupation on a recurrent basis over many years. Unlike most other sites, the small size of the knoll limited the area of occupation, which in tum limited the area in which debris was discarded, resulting in a massive accumulation of artifacts on the top of the knoll. Comparison of artifact frequencies on a unit by unit basis suggests that some degree of spatial separation of activity areas is evident. In general, the northern half of the block excavation contains the highest artifact densities, but the horizontal distribution of specific artifacts varies from class to class. Most of the units with high concentrations of lithic debris are located in the northern half of the block (Figure 13-6a), but the unit with the highest frequencies, Unit 155, is present in the south half, suggesting that stone tool manufacture was conducted all across the knoll. In contrast, all of the high density units for ceramics are limited to the northwest quarter of the block (Figure 13-6b). Bone is also concentrated in this area (Figure 13-6c), so it seems reasonable to conclude that cooking and/or refuse disposal was conducted in this area on a regular basis. Unfortunately, there is considerable overlap of artifact concentrations, owing to the occurrence of multiple occupations within the small area encompassed by the knoll. This overlap of | activity areas limits any further interpretation of the horizontal distribution of artifacts. The vertical distribution of artifacts varies only slightly from unit to unit. In all units, the highest density of artifacts occurs within the upper 20 cm of the deposit. The only variability present is in regard to some units having the highest frequencies in level 1 (the upper 10 cm) as opposed to other units which having the highest frequencies in level 2 (the second 10 cm level). Despite this, the vertical distribution of temporally diagnostic artifacts indicates that no discernible cultural stratigraphy is present at 41NV203. The variability within this upper 20 cm is largely due to chance and is probably related to the degree of bioturbation that has occurred within any particular unit. The site is an upland remnant that apparently has been relatively stable on top throughout the Holocene. Under these conditions, artifacts deposited on the ground surface were moved downward by the natural action of roots, rodents, and other forms of bioturbation as well as the shrink-swell action of the Lamar clay loam. FAUNAL REMAINS (by Phillip Murry) As previously noted, the alkaline nature of the Lamar clay loam is conducive to excellent bone preservation. As a result, 41NV203 provided the best preserved faunal assemblage in the reservoir area and included a broad diversity of species. The spectrum of species recovered at the site is more diverse than at most other sites, but this may reflect the relative lack of preservation at many of the other sites, rather than a major difference in patterns of faunal exploitation. The high density of bone is undoubtedly due to the fact that all occupations at Polecat Hill were confined to the same small area on top of the knoll. Patterns of seasonality in site occupation are clearly discernible from the faunal assemblage. A deer mandible from Unit 101 represents an individual that was aged 1 year and 6 months at the 157 time of death (based on dental eruption and wear). Since deer give birth in this part of Texas between May and June (Schmidly 1983), this individual was taken in November or December. Although the other deer mandibles recovered at the site are too old to provide reliable estimates of seasonality (ranging from 2.5 to 9.5 years old), it seems likely that fall was the primary time of deer exploitation, since their behavior changes during the rutting season, making it easier for hunters to approach them (Smith 1975:37). The presence of wild turkey in two units (Units 115 and 131) also indicates a fall occupation, as does the duck bone in Unit 133. Spring and summer occupations are indicated by the presence of fish and turtle. Turtles hibernate during the winter months and are most easily exploitable during the spring, summer, and fall. Site Polecat Hill contains the highest density of turtle bone of any site found in the reservoir area. Whereas deer bone dominates the assemblage at all sites in the eastern end of the Project area, turtle bone outnumbers deer bone here (as well as at 41NV206). Turtle bone was recovered in 108 levels, totaling 630 elements, whereas deer was present in only 80 levels totaling 255 elements. Deer provide much more food energy per individual than do turtles, so deer were still the major dietary item. However, the high incidence of turtle suggests that regular occupation of the site occurred during the spring and summer months. The presence of gar, catfish, and other fish bones also supports the idea that spring and summer occupations occurred. The location of Polecat Hill in the western end of the reservoir places it within a narrow strip of Bottomland Forest extending into the Tall Grass Prairie. Therefore, one might expect that there was a heavier reliance on prairie species here than at sites in the eastern end of the reservoir, where the Post Oak Savannah offered a higher density and greater variety of exploitable resources. The intermittent nature of Mesquite Creek may have been unsuitable for fishing during the primary seasons of site occupation, resulting in the relatively limited use of fish. Volume UI, Part One INTERPRETATIONS Polecat Hill (41NV203) is one of the smallest archaeological sites within the Richland/Chambers Reservoir area, yet it has the highest artifact density of any site. Originally, four factors prompted the selection of the site for mitigation: (1) a high artifact density, which appeared to represent a limited time span on the basis of testing data; (2) the excellent bone preservation qualities of the soil and the diversity of fauna present; (3) the location of the site next to an intermittent stream and its potential for clarifying the nature of occupations away from the main channel of Richland Creek; and (4) the site's location in the western end of the reservoir, which offered potential for comparison with the other sites selected for mitigation which were centered in the eastern end of the reservoir. Only one other site in the western end of the reservoir, 41NV206, appeared to have potential for addressing the research goals. Therefore, both 41NV203 and 41NV206 were deemed important for understanding the settlement/subsistence system on a Project-wide scale. The results of the intensive excavation of Polecat Hill lead to several conclusions. First, the extremely high artifact density demonstrates that intensive occupation occurred at the site. Second, the relative lack of features indicates that the site was occupied recurrently on a short term basis. If continuous, long term occupation had been responsible for the accumulation of cultural debris, then numerous pits and hearths similar to those found at habitation sites, such as 41NV173 and 41FT201, should have been present. Third, the flora and fauna represent species available during spring, summer, and fall, suggesting that short term occupations occurred at the site several times a year. The extremely high density of turtle bone suggests that spring and summer occupations were especially prevalent. Fourth, artifacts associated with several time periods recognized in the Project area (i.e., the Late Archaic period to the later portion of the Late Prehistoric period), are present at the site, indicating that the site was regularly used over a span of at least 700 years. However, the ceramics from the site indicate that most frequent habitation occurred during the period from A.D. 900 to 1300. The mixture of material from several different periods of occupation complicates the interpretation of the site. Originally it was believed that the high artifact density was the result of intensive occupation during a more limited time span. Results of mitigation, however, have revealed that the assemblage is mixed to a greater degree than was thought on the basis of testing data. Under these circumstances, it is impossible to say whether spring, summer, and fall occupations occurred during all periods equally, or whether certain seasons of occupation were common only during certain periods. The small habitable area present on top of the knoll limited all occupations to the same area. Thus, there is considerable mixture of components over the entire site area and very little spatial separation of activity areas can be observed. There does seem to be a concentration of ceramics within the northwest comer of the block excavation, possibly reflecting cooking, refuse disposal, or later occupations occurring here. The only other conclusion that can be reached by examining the horizontal distribution of artifacts is that more debris was deposited on the northern half of the block than in the southern half. This suggests that habitation was concentrated on the south half, while the north half was used for refuse disposal during many of the occupations.
