wea Vee f of EXCAVATIONS AT 41NV206, GUY'S GARDEN by William A. Martin with contributions by James E. Bruseth and Phillip Murry ENVIRONMENTAL SETTING Guy's Garden (41NV206) is located on a low knoll in the floodplain of Richland Creek, approximately 350 m south of the creek, at an elevation of about 315 ft (95.5 m) msl. The site is named after the landowner, Mr. Guy Langsford, who plows it annually to plant a garden. The knoil is a Tl terrace remnant comprised of Crockett fine sandy loam which is surrounded by the heavy Trinity clay of the floodplain (USDA, SCS 1974). The lower portion of the terrace is frequently inundated. Only the top of the knoll appears to be free from seasonal flooding as evidenced by the well-developed soil horizons (Edward Janak, personal communication 1984). SUMMARY OF PREVIOUS INVESTIGATIONS The site location was reported to SMU researchers during the survey and testing program in 1980-81 by Mr. Langsford. Mr. Langsford had an extensive artifact collection from the site's surface which included artifacts diagnostic of both the Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods. Therefore, the site appeared to have potential for clarifying our understanding of long term prehistoric occupation in the westernmost portion of the Project area. Test excavations were conducted during the 1980-81 season (McGregor et al. 1982:34). Ten 40 x 40 cm shovel tests and two 1 x 1 m units were excavated (Figure 14-1). Most artifacts were confined to the upper 20 cm plow zone, although some artifacts were found as deep as 45 cm below the surface. Based on evidence from the two 1 x 1 m units, a roughly stratified deposit was suggested in which arrow points and ceramics were confined to the upper 10 cm, whereas dart points were recovered as deep as 30-40 cm. The presence of a possible stratified deposit, coupled with the shallow A horizon which indicated good potential for locating subsurface features, prompted the recommendation for additional work during the mitigation program. EXCAVATION STRATEGY Mr. Langsford still owned the site at the time of mitigation, during Season IV in the fall of 1984, so excavations were limited in accordance with his wishes. Mr. Langsford was kind enough to permit extensive excavation by hand, but did not want his garden damaged by the use of heavy equipment. Therefore, excavation was limited to digging 213 50 x 50 cm units within an area of 3,600 m2 (Figure 14-1). A total of 45 person-days was expended on this work. The first units excavated were dug in arbitrary 10 cm levels in hope of detecting the cultural stratigraphy suggested by the test excavations. Unfortunately, no clear separation of components was discernible. Since experience at other TI terrace sites (e.g., 41FT201, 41NV96, 41NV177) had shown that the A horizon is usually too disturbed by bioturbation to warrant excavation in 10 cm levels, this procedure was abandoned. Instead, most units were excavated down to the B horizon as a single level, or to a depth of 40 cm below the surface in cases where the B horizon was absent. All soil was dry-screened through 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) mesh. RESULTS OF INVESTIGATIONS SITE STRATIGRAPHY The terrace deposits on top of the knoll are characterized by a dark brown, sandy loam A horizon, 20-30 cm thick, a dark yellowish brown, clay B horizon, 50-70 cm thick, with a mottled light gray C horizon. Ceramics from 41NV206: (a) fingernail punctations, (b) random punctations, (c) incised lines, (d) engraved lines. show similar basic colors with darker values (10YR3/1, 5YR4/2, 7.5YR4/0). Core colors are even darker, tending towards dark gray (10YR4/1) and very dark gray (10YR3/1). Sherd thickness ranges from 3.9 to 7.5 mm, with an average of 5.7 mm. Eleven decorated sherds were recovered (see Table 14-3). The most common decoration consists of random punctations produced with fingernails (Figure 14-3a) and pointed instruments (Figure 14-3b). Other decorations include incising (Figure 14-3c) and engraving (Figure 14-3d). All of the decorated sherds are too small to allow typological affiliation with any established ceramic types (cf., Suhm and Jelks 1962). The temporal placement of the sherds is based on the type of temper observed in the paste, as well as on the decorative techniques employed and the rim and lip forms of the vessels. The sherds appear to have come from utility ware vessels with incised and punctated decorations along the rim panels. The sherds from 41NV206 are similar to samples from other sites which have been identified as belonging to a grog, grit, and bone temper utility ware tradition. The types Canton Incised and Maydelle Incised (Suhm and Jelks 1962) were recognized at other sites and could very well be represented at 41NV206; however, the sherds from the site are too small for accurate determination. Within the reservoir, this ceramic tradition has an estimated temporal span of A.D. 900 to 1300. Although some of the plain sherds could belong to the latter portion of the Late Prehistoric period (ca. A.D. 1300-1600), only one sherd with an attribute (i.e., a rolled outward lip) characteristic of the latter period was found. On this basis, occupation after A.D. 1300 is thought to be minimal. FAUNAL REMAINS (by Phillip Murry) The faunal assemblage at Guy's Garden is less diverse than that recovered at Polecat Hill (41NV203), even though both sites are located in the western end of the Project area in close proximity to each other. Whereas 20 species were identified at 4INV203, only six species were identified at 41NV206 (Table 14-4). Part of this discrepancy may be due to the relatively low bone preservation potential of the soil at Guy's Garden and the smail size of the excavation units used. Volume III, Part One Although no deer mandibles were found which could indicate age at death and, therefore, season of exploitation, the overall abundance of deer bone suggests that a fall occupation occurred at the site. Like, 4INV203, Guy's Garden contained a tremendous quantity of turtle bone, with turtle elements outnumbering the deer elements recovered (see Table 14-4). Turtle bone was present in 30 units (52 elements total), whereas deer bone was present in only 27 units (28 elements total). The high density of turtle bone suggests that summer occupations were frequent at 41NV206, and that turtle was the principal animal species available for exploitation. Unlike 41NV203 where a few fish elements were found, no fish remains were recovered in the 6.4 mm mesh at 41NV206. Since fine screen samples were not taken from the 50 x 50 cm units, it is not possible to quantify the nature of fish utilization. However, the close proximity of the site to Richland Creek and the evidence for summer occupation suggests that fish would have probably been exploited. SPATIAL DISTRIBUTIONS Systematically spaced, 50 x 50 cm units were dug to obtain data for the SYMAP program in order to produce maps of artifact distributions. The distribution maps for the three most distinct artifact classes are presented in Figures 14-4, 14-5, and 14-6, Clusters of lithic debris, fire cracked rock, and ceramics were selected for illustration because these categories provided the most interpretable information at other sites, such as Bird Point Island (41FT201). Although only these three artifact classes are illustrated, the distribution of all classes are discussed here. The highest density cluster of lithic debris represents 117-160 flakes per 50 x 50 cm unit and occurs at 160N 124. This is surrounded by a large, high-density cluster between 156-172N and 120-128E, on the highest part of the knoll. Eight, smaller, high- density clusters occur along the lower elevation of the knoll, roughly paralleling the 99.5 m contour, just above the contact with the Trinity clay of the floodplain. Based on this pattern, it appears that most stone tool manufacture occurred on top of the knoll, although it was not limited to this area alone. Lithic debris clusters overlapped Houses 1 and 2 at Bird Point Island (41FT201), and additional lithic analysis at that site demonstrated that much of the manufacture of stone tools occurred inside the houses. Although the highest density cluster of lithic debris at 41NV206 occurs on the portion of the site best suited for habitation, no other evidence of houses, such as a cluster of ceramics, is present. It seems likely that habitation was concentrated on the highest elevation of the knoll, but it is improbable that substantial structures were present, judging from the distribution of other artifact classes generally associated with houses. The densest clusters of unifaces range from 4 to 7 and from 7 to 11 artifacts per unit. These clusters occur within the area of the large lithic debris cluster on top of the knoll, and within or parallel to the smaller clusters along the 99.5 contour. Since the category of “uniface,” which includes hundreds of marginally modified flakes, is actually a subset of lithic debris, the parallel distribution of these clusters is not surprising. Distribution of other specific tool types, such as end scrapers and side scrapers, does not reveal any concentration which could be interpreted as a work area. Assuming that dart points are earlier than arrow points, the distribution of dart points and arrow points should delineate temporally distinct occupations or activity areas. When plotted on the site map, dart points tend to fall into two clusters, both of which are outside of the lithic debris cluster found on the top of the knoll. One of these clusters lies between 176-184N and 108-116E and overlaps the distribution of arrow points. The other cluster is in the southern portion of the site, between 116-140N and 124- 136E. This second area is devoid of arrow points, and would be interpreted as an Archaic period activity area were it not for the fact that the highest density of ceramics also falls within this area. SYMAP of ceramic distribution at site 4INV206. 167 with arrow points at Bird Point Island (41FT201), and it is possible that this area represents a Late Prehistoric activity area that involved the use of dart points as knives or scrapers. However, it is also possible that a Late Prehistoric activity area, involving the use of ceramics, was deposited on top of an Archaic period occupation associated with the dart points. Bifaces are concentrated on top of the knoll within the area encompassed by the cluster of lithic debris. Although a few, smaller clusters exist in isolated units across the site, it is difficult to assess their significance. They may represent random discard rather than specialized work areas. The largest concentration of fire cracked rock does not occur on top of the knoll, but is located downslope, to the northwest of the concentration of lithic debris, unifaces, and bifaces on top of the knoll. The densest cluster of fire cracked rock has between 44 and 63 fragments per unit, while the next contour contains 25-44 fragments per unit. These contours are concentrated between 172- 184N and 108-116E. Two smaller clusters of fire cracked rock occur in individual units located at 168N 112E and 160N 112E. The location of the fire cracked rock concentration away from the majority of the lithic debris and stone tool distribution suggests that there is some degree of spatial isolation of heat related activity, such as roasting or heat treating lithic raw material. Some degree of coassociation exists between fire cracked rock and dart points. The northern cluster of dart points, located from 176-184N and 108-116E, occurs within the area encompassed by the densest fire cracked rock concentration (see Figure 14-5). These dart points are Gary points and untyped contracting stemmed points, which are the same types that were associated with roasting pits at Bird Point Island (41FT201). This coassociation between dart points and fire cracked rock at 41NV206 may represent roasting activity, either associated with a pit, as at 41FT201, or confined to the A horizon, as at 41NV177. Instead of a temporally mixed deposit, the coassociation of arrow points and dart points in this portion of the site may represent a contemporaneous deposit during the early to middle portion of the Late Prehistoric period. The highest ceramic contour represents 3-5 sherds per unit and is located at the southern end of the knoll at 128N 132E, It is surrounded by a larger area containing 2-3 sherds per unit, ranging from 120-140N and 124-136E. A few, small, high-density clusters occur in isolated areas; three of these clusters fall within the fire cracked rock concentration on the northwest portion of the site. This correlation of ceramics and fire cracked rock has been observed in other sites in the Project area and is thought to reflect cooking activities. The distribution of ceramics to the south of the major lithic debris and stone tool concentrations provides additional evidence that there is observable spatial separation of work areas. The distribution of baked clay closely parallels the distribution of ceramics. This pattern was observed at Bird Point Island (41FT201) and probably reflects activities in which ceramic vessels were used to cook, and baked clay resulted from the heat of the fire. Charcoal, on the other hand, is concentrated away from clusters of ceramics, fire cracked rock, or other artifact classes. The largest cluster is along the base of the knoll and appears to be unrelated to prehistoric cultural activity. On the other hand, smaller clusters in individual units scattered across the top of the knoll may be related to prehistoric hearths. Bone, ranging from 2.8 to 7.0 g, occurs in only two units, located at 156N 112E and 136N 132E. Otherwise, a low density scatter occurs across the top of the knoll. These smaller bone concentrations may represent discard of trash. | INTERPRETATIONS The artifact distributions at 41NV206 strongly suggest that functionally discrete areas exist at the site. Lithic debris and stone tools are concentrated along the northwest portion of the site, and

This suggests that some degree of spatial separation existed between stone tool manufacture, roasting, and cooking activities. However, the distribution of temporally diagnostic artifacts does not permit the spatial separation of occupations. For instance, dart points, which could represent either Archaic period or Late Prehistoric period occupation, occur within the ceramic cluster from a Late Prehistoric period occupation. Varying quantities of dart points, arrow points, and ceramics are scattered all across the site, with no clear separation of components. Site 41NV206 probably represents a small temporary campsite which was occupied on a recurrent basis over the course of several centuries. The artifact distributions noted on the SYMAPs suggest Volume LI, Part One that no substantial houses were located at the site. Houses at Bird Point Island (41FT201) were marked by the co-occurrence of lithic debris, bifaces, projectile points, ceramics, and baked clay resulting from a wide variety of activities concentrated within the house areas over long periods of time. No such degree of overlap among artifact distributions was noted at Guy's Garden, so it is likely that only temporary shelters were present. The nature of the projectile point types and ceramics is such that occupation was primarily limited to the early part of the Late Prehistoric period (A.D. 900-1300), with limited occupation during both the Late Archaic period (A.D. 1-700) and the latter part of the Late Prehistoric period (A.D. 1300-1600).

## Page 191

ARTIFACT CHRONOLOGY by Daniel E. McGregor and James E. Bruseth When work began on the RCAP, only a rather general local artifact chronology had been established. This was due partly to the relatively limited amount of previous research in the middle Trinity River basin, but also to the nature of the local archaeological record. There was a general lack of well stratified sites and dated single component sites. Because of this, attempts to develop local artifact chronologies have depended almost entirely on the established, or presumed, dating of typologically similar artifacts in adjacent regions (i.e., North Central, East, and Central Texas). The dating of diagnostic artifact styles has been developed most accurately in Central Texas (e.g., Jelks 1962; Johnson et al. 1962; Shafer 1963; Sorrow et al. 1967; Weir 1976; Prewitt 1981). For reasons of geology, both East and North Central Texas generally lack the well stratified stream terrace deposits and rockshelters that have provided the essential contexts for Central Texas chronological refinement. Unfortunately, diagnostic artifacts from the middle Trinity are more closely related typologically to East and North Central Texas materials than they are to the better dated Central Texas materials. In the first section of this chapter, previous efforts to chronologically organize the archaeological materials from closely related areas surrounding the Richland/Chambers Reservoir are reviewed. The results of these studies provide a background for the presentation of new data from the RCAP. The existing information is then combined to propose a refined artifact chronology for the Project area. PREVIOUS CHRONOLOGIES UPPER TRINITY RIVER A chronological sequence of diagnostic artifacts was established for the upper Trinity River drainage through definitions of the Trinity aspect (Crook and Harris 1952, 1954a) and the subsequent Wylie focus (Stephenson 1952). The Archaic 171 period Trinity aspect was divided into early (Carrollton focus) and late (Elam focus) periods, and artifact traits were described for each of these. Diagnostics of the Carrollton focus included: the Carrollton and Trinity dart point types, a variety of steep-bitted gouges, scrapers, and spokeshaves, the Waco sinker, and the chipped stone Carrollton ax. Also associated with the Carrollton focus was a constant minor percentage (about 5%) of late Paleo- Indian projectile point types (e.g., Plainview, Scottsbluff). The Ellis dart point was the most common projectile point type of the Elam focus, followed by Yarbrough and Elam. The Darl and Ensor points reported by Crook and Harris were thought by Suhm et al. (1954:79) to belong to the Yarbrough type. A few contracting stem Gary dart points were said to be associated with the Elam focus, but these were thought to appear in late Elam times (Crook and Harris 1954a:12). Scraping tools were still present, but were generally smaller and less numerous than their Carrollton focus counterparts. Diagnostic artifacts of the subsequent Wylie focus (Stephenson ‘ 1952) included both dart and arrow points. The Gary type was the most common dart point form, and Ellis was present in minor amounts. Arrow point types included Alba, Fresno, Harrell, and Perdiz. Smal! snub-nosed scrapers and small drills or awls were among the diagnostic lithic tools. Pottery was present in Wylie focus sites, with both shell temper and clay/grit temper represented in similar proportions. The shell tempered sherds were of the Nocona Plain type, which was-associated with the Henrietta focus (Krieger 1946; Suhm et al. 1954). The clay/grit tempered sherds exhibited incised, punctated, engraved and brushed decorations similar to ceramic types a68ociated with both early (Sanders focus) and late (Frankston focus) Caddoan groups. As defined, the Wylie focus included materials spanning a very long period of time. As a result, its usefulness in terms of artifact chronology is somewhat limited. It appears that artifacts ranging in age from the Late Archaic through most of the Late Prehistoric period were included among the traits of the Wylie focus (see Chapter 21, Volume IJ). Similar problems have been noted for sites of the Trinity aspect (Hofman 1978:312; Richner and Bagot 1978:52; Richner and Lee 1977:35). Temporal control for the

172 changes in artifact types is limited, and the stratigraphic and contextual integrity of the sites has been questioned. The only published date for the Carrollton focus is 3995 + 200 B. C., on mussel shell from the Wood Pit site (Crook and Harris 1959). The validity of this date is questionable because of problems with dating shell, and because the sample was from an intermediate level within a deep sandy deposit. It was not associated with a feature or definable occupation surface. Both the Carrollton and Elam materials probably represent substantially mixed assemblages spanning several thousand years of occupation. UPPER SABINE RIVER Johnson(1962) defined the LaHarpe aspect to organize the Archaic period materials of East Texas. Characteristic artifacts included expanding stem dart points during the earlier phases, contracting stem dart points during the later phases, with plain pottery appearing during the terminal phase. The Archaic period ended with the introduction of arrow points and abundant decorated pottery. Much of Johnson's study was based on materials from the Yarbrough site, located on the upper Sabine River approximately 90 km northeast of Richland/Chambers Reservoir. Five temporal periods were recognized at the Yarbrough site. The artifact sequence was based on the relative vertical distributions of diagnostic artifacts. Considerable overlap of these distributions was noted, such that "in the upper levels, most of the early styles of artifacts continued (although their late occurrence may conceivably result from partial mixing of deposits)" (Johnson 1962:212). It appears that the stratigraphic situation at the Yarbrough site was similar to that at sites along the upper Trinity River. A series of brief occupations by Paleo-Indians during Period 1 was represented by a number of early projectile point types. These included Clovis, Plainview, Meserve, and San Patrice. The earliest of three Archaic periods (Period 2) was characterized by Yarbrough, Ellis, Edgewood, and Morrill dart point types. The diagnostics for Period 3 were Gary and Yantis dart point types. Several bifacial knife styles, Mineola end scrapers, side scrapers, Clear Fork gouges, and full-grooved axes were all thought to date to the Archaic, but were distributed throughout the deposit. The terminal Archaic Period 4 was characterized by Gary and Kent dart points and the first appearance of pottery. These are plain, grog tempered wares identified as Williams Plain, and perhaps Sanders Plain. Decorated ceramics were assigned to Period 5, as were the few recovered arrow points. Recognized pottery types included Sanders Engraved, Poynor Engraved, Bullard Brushed, and Maydelle Incised. The Period 5 materials were said to represent the Sanders focus of the Gibson aspect, as well as one or more foci of the later Fulton aspect (Johnson 1962:234). More recent work conducted in the upper Sabine River basin (Skiles, Bruseth, and Perttula 1980; Bruseth and Perttula 1981) has provided more details on Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric time periods. An Early Ceramic period has been recognized and is presumed to date between A.D. 1 and 850. This period is characterized by contracting stem dart points and thick, plain ceramic wares. Following this, two phases of the Caddoan cultural tradition are distinguished. The earliest is the Pecan Grove phase and dates from A.D. 850 to A.D. 1350. Ceramics are the most diagnostic artifacts of this phase, and show close similarities to styles of the Sanders focus. Specifically, types Sanders Engraved, Canton Incised, and Monkstown Fingernail Impressed are found. Next, the Forest Hill phase is recorded and dates from A.D. 1350 to 1650. This Caddoan phase shows ceramic similarities to the Titus focus, with types Ripley Engraved, McKinney Plain, and LaRue/Nash Neck Banding common. MIDDLE TRINITY RIVER Cedar Creek Reservoir is located less than 25 km north of Richland/Chambers Reservoir. Excavations were conducted at Volume III, Part Two three Cedar Creek sites, for which Story (1965) defined a five period sequence of occupations. Period 1 was an ephemeral Paleo- Indian occupation represented by a Folsom point medial section and the basal section of a second point exhibiting Paleo traits. Period 2 was the earlier of two Archaic periods. The diagnostic artifacts of this occupation were thought to include rectangular and expanding stem dart points, notched pebbles, and a high percentage of large scraping and cutting tools, including Gossett and Clear Fork gouges, Albany spokeshaves, and Mineola end scrapers. Period 3 represented the Late Archaic occupation, and was marked by the presence of contracting stem Gary dart points. While Gary points were thought to be associated with early pottery in East Texas (Johnson 1962; Tunnell 1961), the Cedar Creek data suggested to Story (1965:250) that Period 3 was largely preceramic. Period 4 was the early Neo-American (Late Prehistoric) occupation which was marked by the appearance of arrow points. The Scallorn and Granbury types were thought to be most diagnostic, but Alba, Friley and Steiner were also thought to be associated. Both plain and decorated ceramics were being made during Period 4. Period 5 was the final prehistoric occupation recognized at Cedar Creek Reservoir. Diagnostic arrow point types were Cliffton, Perdiz, and Catahoula-like. Small flakes and drills also were thought to be associated with this period. Pottery continued to be manufactured, with shell tempering and engraved decoration appearing during Period 5. Subsequent work at the proposed Tennessee Colony Lake provided several radiocarbon dates in association with diagnostic projectile points. A date of 1864 + 57 B.C. was obtained on charcoal associated with a rectangular stem Carrollton point (Richner and Bagot 1978:232). Two contracting stem Gary points were associated with four dates from the same context. Two were on charcoal (685 + 49 B.C. and 719 + 58 B.C.) and two were on mussel shell (903 + 57 B.C. and 1151 + 59 B.C.) (Richner 1982:221). The charcoal dates are considered more reliable. UPPER NAVASOTA RIVER Following an archaeological survey of Lake Limestone (formerly Upper Navasota Reservoir), Prewitt (1974) presented a preliminary artifact chronology for the area (Table 15-1). Like Richland/Chambers Reservoir, the location of Lake Limestone is intermediate between the East Texas and Central Texas archaeological areas. Diagnostic artifacts of both East and Central Texas origins were recognized by Prewitt (1974:12). Subsequent excavations (Mallouf 1979) did little to alter this framework. Most of the sites exhibited substantially mixed deposits, but site 41LT12 contained generally stratified components of the Middle Archaic, Late Archaic and post-Archaic periods (Mallouf 1979:44). Unfortunately, no radiocarbon dates could be obtained to date this sequence. Most of the artifact types recognized by Prewitt were present in the excavation assemblages. The relative vertical distributions of projectile points were said to demonstrate the sequence of expanding stem dart points dating earlier than contracting and bulbar stem forms. There was, however, considerable overlap in these distributions (Mallouf 1979:41). ARTIFACT CHRONOLOGICAL EVIDENCE FROM THE RICHLAND CREEK ARCHAEOLOGICAL PROJECT The same contextual problems that have hampered chronological refinement in North Central and East Texas also characterized most of the RCAP sites. The sites located on Pleistocene terraces have had essentially nonaggrading surfaces during the period of human occupation (See Chapter 7, Volume J). As a result, there is a lack of clear vertical separation between components. Certain sites did, however, provide much better

THE PERRY SITE (41FT193) The importance of the Perry site is the direct result of its long history of alluvial deposition (see Chapter 4). The excavated deposits were radiocarbon dated to between 170 + 120 B.C. and A.D. 1820 + 50 (Figure 15-1). When the standard deviations are considered, only one of the radiocarbon dates (A.D. 590 + 90) appears to be out of sequence. The vertical distribution of the dates indicates that alluviation was relatively rapid until between A.D. 800 and 1170, when it slowed markedly. As a result, there is good vertical separation between the remains of sequential occupations prior to A.D. 1170. Some mixing of temporally distinctive artifacts may have occurred during the period of relative surface stability that appears to have lasted from ca. A.D. 1170 until the nineteenth century. Although the Perry site is the best context for establishing artifact chronology, the sample is smali. Diagnostic artifacts recovered from the various levels of excavation are shown in Table 15-2. In addition to these, a single Gary, regular variety dart point was recovered during test excavations from a lens of mussel shell associated with Soil Horizon VIC2b (see Chapter 4). This extensive mussel shell deposit correlated stratigraphically with the 340-350 cm excavation level. Radiocarbon dates from three different features associated with this horizon provide an average date of approximately A.D. 200 for the artifacts at this depth. The next group of dart points (two untyped, straight stem, two Gary, serrated blade, and one Gary, small variety) was recovered 173 between deposits with radiocarbon dates of A.D. 300 + 60 and A.D. 670 + 60. Although one untyped, straight stem specimen was at least 20 cm below the others, the three point types represented were not vertically separable. The two untyped specimens have relatively short, almost parallel sided stems. They are most similar to some examples of the Kent type, but the workmanship is better than that indicated by the type descriptions (Suhm and Jelks 1962:199; Suhm et al. 1954:432). The Gary, serrated blade specimens exhibit characteristics of the Neches River, oletha variety defined by Prewitt (1974:67), including right-hand beveling and serration of the blades, and almost parallel-sided but slightly contracting stems. However, the dating of these specimens is considerably later than the Middle Archaic period estimate for the Neches River, oletha. The dart point typed as Gary, small variety is most similar to the smaller examples of Johnson's (1962:163) Gary, hobson variety. Its stratigraphic position above the Gary, regular variety specimen is limited evidence for a gradual diminution in size through time for the Gary type. Arrow points were confined to the excavation levels between 230 cm and 270 cm. The time period represented seems to extend from about A.D. 700 to possibly as late as the nineteenth century. The problematical A.D. 590 + 90 date is out of sequence both in terms of the radiocarbon dates and the artifact distributions, and is not considered reliable (see Chapter 4). The often demonstrated Scallorn-Perdiz sequence is indicated here by the single Scallorn point in the level below the Perdiz, Cliffton, and Steiner specimens. On the other hand, stratigraphic evidence from the Adams Ranch site will be used to suggest that Steiner is an earlier type than Perdiz. This relationship cannot be demonstrated at the Perry site, but the slow rate of deposition in this portion of the profile may be responsible for the lack of vertical stratification. Ceramics were confined to the excavation levels between 230 cm and 260 cm, dating later than A.D. 800. THE "WYLIE FOCUS PITS" The fill excavated from the large depressions ("Wylie focus pits") at both Bird Point Island and the Adams Ranch site was divided into stratigraphic zones which were dated by a series of radiocarbon determinations. The stratigraphic integrity of the artifact assemblages from these features is not as ideal as that of the Perry site for several reasons. Because these features were located within intensively occupied multicomponent sites, there is a possibility that artifacts from earlier occupations could have been incorporated into later fill episodes. In addition, bioturbation and/or later cultural activities within these features could have resulted in the introduction of artifacts that actually postdated the original deposition of a stratigraphic zone. In spite of these possible problems, the assemblages from these features provide additional data sets covering approximately the same time span as the assemblage from the Perry site, and provide useful corroborative information. The radiocarbon dates indicate that the original excavation of the pit at Bird Point Island occurred Volume III, Part Two somewhat earlier than the one at Adams Ranch. In both cases the ‘assemblages from the earliest stratigraphic zones are rather limited in the numbers of artifacts recovered. However, there are differences between these earliest assemblages which have temporal significance, and these are discussed below. BIRD POINT ISLAND (41FT201) Three stratigraphic zones were recognized within Feature 1. Radiocarbon dates from each of these were used to produce the following temporal estimates: A.D. 1000 - A.D. 1650 for Zone 1; A.D. 580 - A.D.860 for Zone 2; and 170 B.C. - A.D. 130 for Zone 3 (see Chapter 6, Volume II). Zone 3, the earliest of these, contained six dart points but no arrow points (Table 15-3). The ratio of arrow points to dart points increases from 1:4 in Zone 2 to approximately 5:1 in Zone 1. The only arrow point types present in Zone 2 were Alba and Scallorn. Both are generally recognized as early arrow point types, but both were also found in greater numbers in the Zone 1 assemblage. Perdiz is most common type in Zone 1. Other types found only in Zone 1 included Steiner, Hayes, and Catahoula-like. Because such a long period of time seems to be represented by the Zone 1 deposit, the co-occurrence of these types does not necessarily imply strict contemporaneity. These may represent earlier materials that were introduced incidentally into the pit fill from the surrounding site deposit. The recovery of dart points from Zone 1, even in relatively minor proportions, was somewhat surprising. This zone was dated to later than A.D. 1000, a time when it is generally thought that dart points had been replaced entirely by arrow points. Although some mixing of materials between zones may have occurred through both natural and cultural processes, other lines of evidence presented in Chapter 7 of Volume II were used to argue for the concurrent use of arrow points and Gary dart points during most of the Late Prehistoric period. The strongest line of evidence was the consistently higher proportion of dart points from the fill of features dated to the Late Prehistoric period than from the A horizon deposits surrounding these features. The most likely explanation for this phenomenon is that dart points were being used in the activities associated with these features. If the dart points were simply the remains of earlier occupations, it is unlikely that they would be relatively more common in Late Prehistoric feature fill. Temporal changes in ceramic artifacts are difficult to discern because of the relatively small sample from Feature 1 (109 sherds). However, certain trends can be noted. The majority of sherds was recovered from Zone 1. Only four were found in Zone 3, and these were from the upper part of that zone. It is suggested that the 170 B.C, - A.D. 130 time period was preceramic, and that the four sherds had been displaced from an upper zone. These four sherds are more similar to those from Zones 1 and 2 than they are to the ceramics from demonstrably early contexts within the Adams Ranch pit. At the Adams Ranch site, shell temper characterized the earliest ceramics. The four Zone 3 sherds at Bird Point Island belong to a grog, grit, and bone temper tradition, as do the ceramics in Zones | and 2. The distribution of decoration types shows some differences between Zones 1 and 2 (Table 15-4). A higher percentage of plain sherds was present in Zone 2. Zone 1 had the only engraved sherds as well as a far higher percentage of incised sherds. No differences between zones in tempering materials could be demonstrated for this particular assemblage. ADAMS RANCH (41NV177) The fill within Feature 1 at the Adams Ranch site was also divided into three major stratigraphic zones. The estimated time spans are: A.D, 200 - A.D. 700 for Zone 3; A.D. 800 - A.D. 1000 for Zone 2; and post-A.D. 1000 for Zone 1. As at Bird Point Island, few diagnostic artifacts were present in the earliest zone (Table 15-5). Two contracting stem dart points (one Gary, regular variety and one untyped), a single untyped, bifurcated stem arrow point, and seven shell tempered potsherds were the only diagnostic artifacts recovered from Zone 3. Five dart point fragments and one arrow point fragment were also recovered. 175 The seven sherds are most important in terms of artifact chronology. They are the earliest dated ceramics from the RCAP area, and belong to a distinctive ceramic tradition that is represented at three other Project area sites (41FT158, 41FT200, and 41FT201). Two additional shell tempered sherds were found in the lower part of Zone 2, but those occurred in an area of apparent redigging by later inhabitants of the site. Moreover, the lack of any grog, grit, or bone tempered sherds in Zone 3 is seen as further evidence of the early dating of this shell temper tradition. The other 10 sherds from Zone 2 and all 36 sherds from Zone 1 belong to the grog, grit, and bone temper tradition found at most sites in the reservoir and dated elsewhere between A.D. 900 and A.D. 1650. The only decorated sherds were from Zone 1. Incised and punctated decorations were the most common, followed by punctated/incised and brushed. Engraved decoration was not represented in the Feature 1 assemblage. Most of the arrow point types were present in both Zone | and Zone 2. Three types occurred only in a single zone, and may be significant in terms of artifact chronology. The Steiner type was confined to Zone 2 (A.D. 800 - 1000), while the Perdiz and Catahoula-like types occurred only in Zone 1 (post-A.D. 1000). As at Bird Point Island, dart points were present in all three stratigraphic zones. The majority of these could not be assigned to an established type. ARTIFACT CHRONOLOGY FOR THE RICHLAND/CHAMBERS RESERVOIR The stratigraphic data presented above are most important for building an improved artifact chronology for the Project area. Unfortunately, stratified and dated contexts extended back to only about A.D. 1. The artifact sequence for the earlier part of the prehistoric period must be reconstructed by a less direct approach. The assemblages from sites with predominantly Archaic period deposits will be compared to assemblages that are known to date later in time. By contrasting the intersite distributions of certain artifact types, changes through time in material culture can be inferred. Interassemblage comparisons are also used to investigate changes through time in ceramic artifacts during the Late Prehistoric period. Although only relatively small ceramic samples were recovered from most dated contexts, intersite comparison of the ceramic assemblages is nonetheless helpful in refining the local cultural chronology. Using the archaeological resuits from Richland/Chambers Reservoir along with the work by previous investigators, a refined artifact chronology can be offered for the Project area (Figure 15-2). This chronology includes both the temporal periods outlined in Chapter 3 of Volume I, and a series of local phases that can now be defined as a result of the RCAP investigations. These phases represent subdivisions within the Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric periods, and were initially introduced in Chapter 12 of Volume II. The term phase, in contrast to a period which only indicates a length of time, is used here to refer to a cultural episode that occurred within a specific time period and that possessed a variety of traits sufficiently distinctive to be separated from other cultural episodes. In Chapter 18 details on the internal site composition, economic strategy, and overall settlement organization used during each phase are presented. The current chapter only provides chronological details on these cultural episodes. In addition, Figure 15-2 presents the distribution of all nonmodern radiocarbon dates from the RCAP sites. Specific details concerning these dates can be found in Table 15-6. PALEO-INDIAN PERIOD (11,000 TO 6000 B.C.) The traits listed for the Paleo-Indian period are based , neccessarily on data from outside the Project area. The few diagnostics of these periods that were recovered from RCAP sites were either mixed with artifacts from later occupations or were from surface contexts. At Horn Shelter No. 2, the earliest points are of an untyped, lanceolate form and are followed by a sequence of Folsom, Brazos Fishtail, and Plainview types. The Brazos Fishtail is somewhat similar to, and is thought to be a variant of the San Patrice type (Prikryl and Jackson 1985:22; Turner and Hester 1985:147). Two radiocarbon dates on charcoal (7550 + 200 B.C. and 8030 + 370 B.C.) and two on snail shell (8080 + 130 B.C. and 8360 + 150 B.C.) were associated with the Brazos Fishtail points. A date of 6450 + 110 B.C. on snail shell was associated with the Plainview stratum. An additional snail shell radiocarbon date of 7325 + 360 B.C. was associated with the Plainview stratum at Horn No. 1 (Watt 1978:127). The nearest dated occurrence of the Angostura type is the Loeve site on the San Gabriel River, where radiocarbon dates of 7700 £ 910 B.C. and 6550 + 130 B.C. were associated stratigraphically (Prewitt 1982:237). Although Prewitt (1981:77) considers the Angostura type to be diagnostic of the Archaic stage Circleville phase, it is here considered late Paleo-Indian based on both age and style. ARCHAIC PERIOD (6000 B.C. TO A.D. 700) Subdividing the materials from the Archaic period occupation of the Richland/Chambers Reservoir into temporally discrete subsets is a difficult task. Because of a general lack of stratified components or dated single component sites, artifacts of the Archaic period form an almost undifferentiated assemblage. Three RCAP sites (the Hardy site 41FT200, 41FT158, and 41NV96) contained substantial numbers of Archaic period diagnostics that were rare or absent at other excavated sites. Because none of these sites produced radiocarbon dates, chronological placement of these artifacts must rely on comparisons with the artifact chronologies that have been established for areas close to the Project. As a result, the Archaic chronology is more generalized and tentative than that for the later periods. These three sites contained not only projectile point types thought to be diagnostic of the Early and Middle Archaic, but Late Archaic and Transitional Archaic diagnostics (Gary dart points and shell tempered ceramics) as well. A few Late Prehistoric period artifacts, deposited during later periods, were also recovered from 41FT158 (grog tempered ceramics) and 41NV96 (arrow points and grog tempered ceramics). Unlike other RCAP sites, expanding stem dart points outnumber the contracting stem types at Hardy and 41NV96 (Table 15-7). Although the contracting stem Gary was the most numerous type at 41FT158, the combined total of expanding stem and other typologically early types (Bulverde, San Patrice, and the untyped, lanceolate specimen) outnumbers these. EARLY ARCHAIC (6000 TO 3000 B.C.) Although Lynott (1981:103) has suggested that the San Patrice projectile point type is diagnostic of this time period in North Texas, this type is considered here to be related to the late Paleo- Indian period. A lack of dated Early Archaic assemblages in East Texas prevents cross dating of artifact types to that region. Of the Central Texas projectile point types considered to date to this time span, only the Wells type was found in the Project area. The Wells type is considered diagnostic of the Early Archaic, San Geronimo phase in Prewitt's (1981) Central Texas chronology, with an estimated age of 5050 B.C. to ca. 4050 B.C. (Prewitt 1981:78). Although conclusive evidence is lacking for the Project area, other artifacts such as the Clear Fork gouge and Waco sinker may also date to the Early Archaic period. MIDDLE ARCHAIC (3000 TO 1000 B.C.) The temporal range of expanding stem dart points is not well established for the Project area, but a Middle Archaic (3000 - 1000 B.C.) range is suggested for some of these. Expanding stem types which are thought to date to the Middle Archaic include Yarbrough (Figure 15-3a-g), Edgewood, Palmillas (Figure 15- 3h,i) and possibly many of the untyped, expanding stem specimens. Expanding stem dart points typed as Ellis and Marshall may date later in time. Although relatively few in number, they were more often found in the later sites (Table 15-7). At the proposed Tennessee Colony Lake, a straight stem dart point typed as Carrollton was dated to 1864 + 57 B.C. (Richner and Bagot 1978:232). This date is within the 2050 B.C. to 1450 B.C. range suggested by Prewitt (1981:79) for the morphologically similar Bulverde type (Figure 15-4a,b). Most of the straight stem dart points could not be classed as Bulverde or Carrollton. A few of the untyped, straight stem specimens may be Middle Archaic in age, especially those with long and relatively wide rectangular stems (Figure 15-4c). However, most were generally smaller in size, with shorter and narrower stems (Figure 15-4d-g). The two specimens from the Perry site (Figure 15-4f,g) were dated to between A.D. 300 and A.D. 670, demonstrating that some straight stem dart points are considerably younger. tes.

Ellis and Marshall may date to the earlier half of this time span. For the latter part of the Late Archaic period, a Transitional Archaic phase (200 B.C. - A.D. 700) has been identified for the Project area. The beginning of this phase corresponds with the initial excavation of the large depression ("Wylie focus pit") at Bird Point Island, and the ending with the introduction of arrow points into the Project area. Components of the Transitional Archaic phase were recognized at five RCAP sites on the basis of either the presence of large depressions (Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch) or the occurrence of distinctive shell tempered ceramics (41FT158 and Hardy). The earliest dated ceramics from the RCAP sites belong to a distinctive shell temper tradition. These shell tempered sherds were recovered from four of the sites and were always limited in number. They are uniformly thin and undecorated, with a plately texture and a shell tempered paste. In some cases the shell has been leached out, leaving platey vesicules in the paste. These ceramics appear to be very similar to sherds recovered from Lake Limestone (Prewitt 1974, 1975; Mallouf 1979), which are described as consisting of buff to pinkish buff colors, being made from fine-grained clays (kaolin), and having a compact platey structure. Although shell temper was not observed in the Lake Limestone specimens, the other strong similarities suggest to us that the Richland Creek sherds may also be made from non-local, kaolinitic clays, perhaps from the Limestone County area. No local sources of this clay type are known, and the texture of these sherds varies significantly from the coarse-texture clays used during later periods which petrographic analysis has suggested were manufactured locally (see Appendix C). The best evidence for the early dating of this tradition is from the Adams Ranch site, where seven shell tempered sherds constituted the only ceramics from the earliest stratigraphic zone of Feature 1, This zone was radiocarbon dated between A.D. 200 and A.D. 700. LATE PREHISTORIC PERIOD (A.D. 700 TO 1650) In terms of diagnostic artifacts, the Late Prehistoric period is distinguished primarily by the initial appearance of arrow points and two additional ceramic traditions. Within the Late Prehistoric period in the Project area, three distinct phases have been recognized (Figure 15-2): the Richland Creek phase (A.D. 700 - 900); the Round Prairie phase (A.D. 900 - 1300); and the St. Elmo phase (A.D. 1300 - 1650). For purposes of this chapter, however, artifact chronology cannot easily be discussed by individual phases since few traits are uniquely associated with a single phase. In a few instances the dominance of a given artifact type can be attributed to a phase, and in such cases this is noted. Otherwise the discussion covers the Late Prehistoric time period overall. In the central and southern portions of East Texas, sandy paste ceramics are thought to predate the Caddoan ceramic tradition (Shafer 1975; Story 1981). Coarse-grained, sandy paste sherds were present at several Project area sites, but occurred in significant proportions only at the Irvine site (11% of all ceramics) and at 41FT161-B (13%). The major component at both of these sites has been assigned to the A.D. 700 to 900 period Richland Creek phase. The use of sandy paste ceramics may have been restricted to only a portion of that time period, most likely the earlier portion. The lack of sandy paste ceramics in the early stratigraphic zones of the "Wylie focus pits” at Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch indicates that this tradition cannot be documented locally prior to about A.D. 700. This is considerably later than the presumed dating of sandy paste ceramics in East Texas, where introduction possibly as early as 200 B.C, has been suggested (Story 1981:146). The most common ceramics at RCAP sites are those belonging to the grog, grit, and bone temper tradition. The earliest occurrence of this tradition appeared to be contemporary with the sandy paste traditon. It was present in the Richland Creek phase features at the Irvine site, two of which have yielded radiocarbon dates of A.D. 670 + 130 and A.D 870 + 140. It remained the dominant ceramic tradition throughout the remainder of the prehistoric period. Within the long time span of this grog, grit, and bone temper tradition, there are proportional changes in methods of decoration that have chronological significance. When the ceramic assemblages from several sites are compared (Table 15-8), these changes can be characterized. Although all of these sites were to some extent multicomponent, the principle components represented differ between them. The earliest assemblage (Irvine) contained mainly punctations and incised lines and engraving is more frequent than in the later

Overall, ceramic designs are similar to those of several late Caddoan types, including Maydelle Incised, Poynor Engraved, Karnack Brushed-Incised, Killough Pinched, and Avery Engraved. As suggested previously, the Gary type continued to be used after the introduction of arrow points, and well into the Late Prehistoric period. This is based on their consistent appearance in later features at Irvine, Little Cedar Creek, and Bird Point Island. The sequence of arrow point types is based on a composite of the stratigraphic information from the Perry site and the two Wylie focus pits. At Perry, the Scallorn type may date as early as A.D. 700, and the stratigraphic distributions at Adams Ranch and Bird Point Island suggest that its use continued until after A.D. 1000. Both the Steiner and Alba types appear relatively early (A.D. 800 - 1000) at Adams Ranch, and both are found at Bird Point Island in the stratigraphic zone dating later than A.D. 1000. The Perdiz type seems to date consistently later than these other types at all three sites. Although there is a degree of overlap in the temporal distributions of particular arrow point types, Scallorn and Steiner are most diagnostic of the Richland Creek phase, Alba of the Round Prairie phase, and Perdiz and Cliffton of the St. Elmo phase. Among the other lithic tools, the distinctive drill/awls are restricted to the Late Prehistoric period, but do not appear to be associated with any particular phase. These artifacts are identical to the "awls" that Shafer (1973:220) described from the Davis site, and considered to be diagnostic of the Late Prehistoric period in East Texas. They also occur in Late Prehistoric contexts in both North Central and Central Texas. The only other bifacial tool that may be temporally diagnostic is the small, subtriangular knife form. This artifact type was well represented only at the Little Cedar Creek site (41NV173), and is apparently associated with the St. Elmo phase. No distinctive unifacial tool forms can be assigned exclusively to the Late Prehistoric period. Steeply chipped unifaces are significantly less common than they were in Middle and Late Archaic assemblages. Notably absent are the small, snub-nosed end scrapers that are associated with the Late Prehistoric period in Central Texas (Prewitt 1981:83; Suhm et al. 1954:112) and in the

EVALUATION OF THE RESEARCH HYPOTHESIS As noted in Chapter 1 of this volume, several prehistoric research hypotheses were developed prior to beginning the mitigation phase of the Project. These hypotheses are addressed at various points within Volumes II and III, depending on the particular data's applicability to the hypothesis. The artifact chronology information of this chapter is pertinent to addressing one of the culture-historical hypothesis: H1. Archaic stage sites in the Project area can be subsumed taxonomically within the Carrollton and Elam foci of the Trinity aspect, and the Neo- American stage sites within the Wylie focus of North Central Texas Two test implications were presented for this hypothesis: (1) demonstration of stylistic similarities in artifact assemblages between sites in the Project area and sites in the upper Trinity River basin, and (2) contemporaneity of the sites with similar assemblages. The part of this hypothesis which deals with the Archaic period will be evaluated here. The part dealing with the Wylie focus is addressed in Chapter 21 of Volume I. Comparisons between the Project area and the upper Trinity River drainage are difficult because Archaic period culture history continues to be insufficiently documented in both areas. Volume III, Part Two Crook and Harris’ (1952, 1954a) original definitions of the Carrollton and Elam foci and their artifact traits remain the most complete treatment of this subject. As mentioned in an earlier section of this chapter, the stratigraphic integrity of these Trinity aspect sites has since been questioned. The Carrollton focus in particular may contain a mixture of artifacts that actually spans several thousands of years. Even so, there are few specific similarities between Carrollton diagnostics and the Archaic period assemblages from the Project area. Several of the artifact types common to both areas (Clear Fork gouges, Waco sinkers, steeply chipped scrapers) are also known to be more widespread in their distribution, and their presence in the Project area does not necessarily indicate cultural connections with the Carrollton focus. Dart points of the Carrollton and Trinity types are not common in Project area assemblages. The smaller straight stem dart points called "Dallas Pentagonal" by Crook and Harris (1954a:3) are more similar to specimens from the Project area. However, based on evidence from the Perry site, the Project area specimens may date considerably later in time. Artifact traits of the Elam focus (primarily Ellis, Yarbrough, and Gary dart points) are more numerous in the Project area. However, these same traits are also shared with the LaHarpe aspect sites, particularly those in its central area (Johnson 1962:269). This was noted previously by Johnson (1962:270), who suggested that the Elam focus might be included within the LaHarpe aspect when better data became available. In summary, there seem to be few specific similarities in artifact traits between sites of the Carrollton and Elam foci and the Archaic sites in the Project area. Shared traits are also common to Archaic period sites in other regions. If cultural ties are to be defined on the basis of artifact similarities, then the Project area Archaic shows closest affinities to the LaHarpe aspect of central East Texas.

LITHIC RAW MATERIAL UTILIZATION by Daniel E. McGregor Temporal differences in the use of lithic material types have been recognized previously for the prehistoric period in North Central Texas. In defining the Archaic period Trinity aspect, Crook and Harris (1952) noted the more frequent use of nonlocal “flint” for artifacts diagnostic of the earlier Carrollton focus relative to those of the later Elam focus. Most of Elam focus artifacts were made from locally available quartzites, and this trend was said to be even more pronounced in the subsequent Wylie focus (Crook and Harris 1952:27). The authors attributed these differences to "an increasing adaptation to the Dallas County region environment" (Crook and Harris 1952:24). Grady (1978) noted similar changes in lithic material utilization for the Archaic period in the middle Trinity River drainage. The more frequent use of nonlocal materials during the Early and Middle Archaic was thought to reflect a higher degree of mobility over larger territories, and an exchange network that involved interaction with groups exploiting adjacent territories where high quality cherts were available. The less frequent occurrence of nonlocal materials in Late Archaic assemblages was seen as resulting from reduction in the size of group territories and the development of more regionally oriented exchange systems through time. Temporal differences in lithic material use were also recognized for the Richland/Chambers Reservoir area (McGregor, Raab, and Irvine 1982:66-67). Based on the artifact samples from test excavations, it was suggested that a higher proportion of chert was characteristic of Archaic period assemblages relative to those of the Late Prehistoric period. This conclusion resulted from a comparison of both the chipped stone tools and the lithic debris from only three single component assemblages (one Archaic and two Late Prehistoric). The recovery of larger samples from the subsequent RCAP excavations allows a more complete investigation of the patterns of lithic material use. In this chapter, we identify the local and regional lithic resources that were available to the prehistoric inhabitants of the Richland/Chambers Reservoir area. During analysis, all lithic artifacts from the RCAP sites were sorted into a series of raw material types. The relative amounts of various material types represented in the assemblages from these sites are compared, and intersite differences are identified. Based on the dating of these particular site assemblages, the differences in material use are interpreted as having resulted from reductions in the size of exploitive territories through time. Additional support for this interpretation is provided by an analysis of the regional distribution of temporally diagnostic projectile points made from one distinctive lithic material type with a spatially restricted local source (Pisgah Ridge chert). SOURCES OF LITHIC MATERIAL For the purpose of discussing lithic resources, an area considerably larger than the middle Trinity River basin will be considered (Figure 16-1). Within this region silicious materials suitable for the manufacture of chipped stone tools occur in two general forms: (1) in primary bedrock deposits; and (2) as redeposited gravels. The chert-bearing bedrock deposits of interest to the present discussion are the Lower Cretaceous limestones (Fredericksburg Group) to the west and southwest of the middle Trinity drainage, and the Tehuacana limestone (Paleocene) which outcrops a short distance to the west of Richland/Chambers Reservoir. The high quality chert of the Edwards formation (Figure 16-1) is the most abundant bedrock source. Its area of outcrop is predominantly that portion of the Edwards formation located south and southwest of the Brazos and Bosque Rivers (Henry et al. 1980; Perttula 1984). A minor bedrock chert source is located a short distance west of the Richland/Chambers Reservoir. Pisgah Ridge chert occurs as nodules and small seams in the Tehuacana limestone member of the Kincaid formation (Midway Group) on Pisgah Ridge, about 6 km west of Richland, Texas. The Tehuacana limestone itself outcrops discontinuously over a distance of approximately 200 km (Figure 16-1), but the Pisgah Ridge outcrop is the only known source of this visually distinctive chert. , 185

Geological map of the study area. The major sources of silicious gravels throughout the region are known collectively as the Uvalde gravels (Byrd 1971; Menzer and Slaughter 1971). The Uvalde gravels occur on upland stream ‘divides and, to a lesser extent, in reworked terrace deposits throughout central and northeast Texas. They include pebbles and cobbles of quartzite, chert, and silicified wood. Chert is only a minor constituent of the upland gravels at Richland/Chambers Reservoir, where fine grained quartzites predominate. However, the lithological content of these upland gravels is not uniform throughout the larger region that is being considered. Byrd (1971:18) noted that in certain locations just east of the Balcones Escarpment in Central Texas, chert and limestone were the dominant constituents, while quartzites predominated farther to the east. He suggested that the chert and limestone were derived from the Edwards formation, a source sufficiently close so that the limestone was not abraded away or dissolved during transport

In discussing the upland gravels in the vicinity of Aquilla Lake, Ritchie and Slaughter (1972:150) suggested that the abundant chert cobbles in these gravels may have been derived from the Lower Cretaceous limestone formations which outcrop not far to the west of Aquilla Creek. In order to assess this regional variability in lithological content, upland gravel outcrops at four locations along an east- west transect were inspected by the author (Figure 16-1). While the observed differences have not been quantified, chert cobbles were present in both greater relative frequency and larger size at Location 1. Location 1 is in the uplands adjacent to Aquilla Lake, east of the former confluence of Aquilla and Hackberry Creeks. Much of the chert in these gravels is indistinguishable from bedrock samples of Edwards chert, suggesting that some portion of them originated in the Edwards limestone. Location 2 overiooks the upper reaches of Ash Creek, a tributary of Richland Creek. It is only a short distance east of the divide between the Brazos River and the Trinity River drainage basins. Location 2 exhibited both lower relative frequency and smaller size for chert cobbles than did Location 1, but significantly more than was observed for Locations 3 and 4. The gravels at Locations 3 and 4 did not differ noticeably from one another. At both locations chert was a very minor constituent, occurring in nodules that were significantly smaller than those at Locations 1 and 2. LITHIC MATERIAL TYPES All chipped stone artifacts recovered from the RCAP sites were assigned to one of the following lithic material categories: Variety 1. Chert Variety 2. Quartzite Variety 3. Pisgah Ridge Chert Variety 4. Silicified Wood Variety 5. Other Originally, a subset of the artifacts now included in Variety 1 was identified as Edwards chert on the basis of its dark to light gray color and lustrous surface finish. It has been determined subsequently that cobbles and pebbles of identical materials are present in upland gravels located far to the east of the Edwards formation outcrops. These materials do occur in higher proportions and larger clast size west of the Richland Creek drainage, but, because minor amounts are known to be present in the Project area gravels as well, they cannot be considered strictly nonlocal materials. The vast majority of materials in Variety 2 are fine-grained quartzites that have also been termed Ogallala chert (Hughes and Willey 1978:47; Mallouf 1976:48; Pertulla 1984:135). This is the most common material in the upland gravels of the Project area. Variety 2 also includes small amounts of medium and coarse- grained quartzites that are also present in the local gravels. Pisgah Ridge chert (Variety 3) contains numerous small fossil fragments which give it a speckled appearance. Its color is predominantly black or dark gray, although it weathers to a white patina. This material occurs as nodules and small seams in the Tehuacana Limestone member of the Kincaid Formation on Pisgah Ridge, about 6 km west of Richland, Texas. Silicified wood (Variety 4) is also available locally. It is present as cobbles in the Uvalde gravels, and also occurs in larger nodule size within the Wilcox formation. The other category (Variety 5) consists primarily of sandstone, siltstone, and ironstone. These materials are available locally, but are present only in very minor amounts in the artifact assemblages. 187 LITHIC MATERIAL USE AT RICHLAND/CHAMBERS RESERVOIR TEMPORAL VARIABILITY IN CHERT UTILIZATION The analysis of projectile points recovered from test excavations at Richland/Chambers Reservoir suggested variation over time in the choice of lithic materials used in projectile point manufacture (McGregor, Raab, and Irvine 1982:66). A large majority of the expanding stem dart points, which were thought to date to the earlier part of the Archaic period, were made of high quality cherts. This was not the case for the contracting stem dart points, nor for the arrow points. A much higher percentage of these later projectile point forms were made from quartzite or silicified wood. This same general pattern can be demonstrated for the projectile points recovered from the RCAP mitigation excavations (Table 16-1). Of the few dart points that are believed to date to the late Paleo-Indian or Early Archaic periods (Angostura, San Patrice, Wells, and Untyped, lanceolate specimens), only the two San Patrice specimens are made from materials other than chert, The types thought to be diagnostic of the Middle Archaic period (i.e., Bulverde, Edgewood, Yarbrough, and perhaps the Untyped, expanding stem forms) are among the highest in percentages of chert. Of all dart point types, chert was used least frequently for manufacturing the three varieties of the Gary type, and for the Dawson type. Gary points are thought to have been used during the Late Archaic, Transitional Archaic, and Late Prehistoric periods. The chert percentages for all dart points classified by stem form are presented in Table 16-2. Overall, the use of chert for the manufacture of Late Prehistoric period arrow points was greater than for contracting stem dart points. Of the best represented arrow point types, the use of chert was highest for the Perdiz, Alba, and Hayes types. Chert was used least frequently for the Steiner and Scallomm specimens, types which are thought to be the earliest arrow points in the Project area. Based only on the projectile points, it would appear that the use of chert was highest during the Middle Archaic period and earlier. Chert use was much lower for the Late Archaic through the earliest part of the Late Prehistoric period, but increased somewhat after this. There is a problem with attempting to relate directly these changes in chert use to changes in the size of group territories. Although many of the chert nodules available in Project area gravels may not have been sufficiently large for manufacturing dart points, arrow point production would have required considerably smaller blanks. While greater accessibility to larger pieces of chert may be indicated by the Middle Archaic dart points, this is not necessarily required for the production of arrow points. The lithic debris assemblages may provide a more reliable indicator of overall lithic material utilization. Because most of the RCAP sites contained more than one component, the precise temporal placement of the lithic debris assemblages is less certain than it is for many of the projectile point types. Dominant components can, however, be identified for many of these sites, so that general comparisons can be made. For example, Middle Archaic diagnostics were dominant at only two sites: 41FT200 and 41INV96. The lithic debris assemblages from these same two sites contained the highest percentages of chert (Table 16-3). Consistent differences between the Late Archaic and the various Late Prehistoric components are not so well defined (Table 16-4). This could be as much a result of the multicomponent nature of the site assemblages as it is a reflection of actual patterns of chert utilization during this time span. Alternatively, it may be that chert use changed relatively little during the Late Archaic and all subsequent periods. The increased use of chert for temporally later arrow point types (Alba, Hayes, and Perdiz) has been demonstrated, but the lithic debris assemblages do not indicate any marked increase in chert use for the Round Prairie and St. Elmo phase components. The idea that the presence of exotic lithic materials can provide an indication of the scale of prehistoric group mobility has been discussed in the recent literature (Binford 1979; Goodyear 1979; Meltzer 1984; see also Binford and Stone 1985; Gould and Saggers 1985). Based on ethnographic evidence, Binford (1979:259) suggested that mobile hunter-gatherers tend to obtain lithic materials incidentally to the execution of basic subsistence tasks. He observed that the proportions of lithic material types in a given site asssemblage are primarily a function of the raw materials available in the habitat exploited from that location, plus those of any artifacts discarded at the site which had been procured from the areas of previously occupied sites (Binford 1979:260). In such cases, the material types within a given assemblage can be seen as a measure of the scale of settlement mobility. While none of the identified material types can be considered strictly exotic to the Project area, it is argued that accessibility to chert was greater for those prehistoric groups whose exploitive territories included areas located a significant distance to the west of the reservoir. In those areas the upland gravel deposits contain a far greater abundance of chert relative to the gravels of the Project area, The chert may have been transported from its source directly as the result of changes in site location over considerable distances, or through exchange with adjacent groups that had direct access to it. In either case, a reduction in the size of the territory that was exploited would effectively limit a group's access to this material. In addition, a reduction in the frequency of changes in site locations (settlement mobility) would reduce the rate at which this material was introduced into Project area sites. The longer a group remained within the Project area, the more locally obtained lithic materials would be utilized and added to the site assemblages. If this argument is accepted, then the temporal variations in chert use described above can be interpreted as follows. Middle Archaic settlement systems were characterized by relatively high mobility over territories that were large enough to include both the Project area and areas where substantially greater amounts of

Pisgah Ridge is a prominent limestone capped escarpment located about 6 km west of the town of Richland, in Navarro County, Texas. Within the area of Pisgah Ridge, the limestone is exposed discontinuously over a distance of 9 km. To the south it is present below the surface, but does not outcrop again for a distance of 15 km. North of Richland Creek the limestone is not seen again until a point approximately 75 km to the northeast. An archaeological survey of the entire Pisgah Ridge escarpment demonstrated that outcrops of this chert are restricted to an area atop the ridge that is 2 km long and .3 km wide. As noted previously, the Tehuacana limestone member outcrops over a total distance of about 200 km, and could possibly contain chert at other locations. Brief reconnaissance surveys were made of Tehuacana limestone outcrops on both the north and south sides of Lake Tawakoni on the Sabine River, and in the vicinity of Lake Mexia on the- Navasota River. No chert outcrops were discovered in either area, and it seems likely that the chert outcrop on Pisgah Ridge is the only source of this material. The temporal differences in chert utilization described in the preceding section of this chapter were interpreted as indicating changes through time in the size of group territories. Projectile points made of Pisgah Ridge chert, diagnostic of all time periods from late Paleo-Indian/Early Archaic to Late Prehistoric, were recovered from sites in the Richland/Chambers Reservoir area. Although Pisgah Ridge chert was a relatively minor lithic resource, it was thought that a study of the spatial distribution of temporally diagnostic artifacts made of this material would be useful for examining the questions of mobility and territorial size. In addition to the artifact collections from the Richland/ Chambers Reservoir sites, several other collections were also examined for Pisgah Ridge chert artifacts (Table 16-5). In most cases only the chipped stone tools were studied. Lithic debris assemblages were examined for the collections from Joe Pool Lake, Tennessee Colony Lake, Lake Palestine, and three sites at Lake Whitney. Three private artifact collections from sites within the study areas were also examined: the Young, Reading, and Harper collections. The Young collection remains in the possession of Mr. Bill Young of Corsicana, Texas, and is the best documented of the three. Mr. Young's extensive collection was made from numerous sites located primarily along the middle Trinity River, Richland and Chambers Creeks, and Aquilla Creek. The Harper collection is Volume III, Part Two curated at Southern Methodist University, and includes primarily sites in the upper Trinity River drainage in Dallas and Denton Counties. The only Pisgah Ridge chert artifacts in the Harper collection were from two sites, one in Ellis County and one in Navarro County. The Reading collection is on display at Navarro College in Corsicana, Texas. It includes artifacts from sites within both the middle Trinity and upper Navasota River drainages. Unfortunately, the locations for most of these sites are based on verbal descriptions only. The original map showing site locations was not available for study. Most sites yielding Pisgah Ridge chert artifacts were located within the middle Trinity River basin, including both Richland and Chambers Creeks (Figure 16-2). However, this material was found to be present at sites in each of the adjacent river drainages (i.e., the Sabine, Neches, Brazos, and Navasota). In general, many of the chipped stone tools and the lithic debris from these sites are poor chronological indicators. In all, 37 different sites contained one or more projectile points made of Pisgah Ridge chert (Table 16-6 and Figures 16-3 through 16-5), and the spatial distribution of these artifacts is the subject of the following analysis. Only three projectile points thought to be diagnostic of the late Paleo-Indian or Early Archaic periods were documented during this study. Two of these are typed as San Patrice and the third is a Dalton point with the blade reworked into a drill (Figure 16-3a). Interestingly, two of these specimens are from sites at Lake Fork Reservoir on a tributary of the Sabine River (Figure 16-6), and are farther from the known source of Pisgah Ridge chert than any other artifact documented by this study. Because the Tehuacana limestone outcrops only about 40 km west of these sites, it might be reasonable to suggest that an additional source of this chert may exist there. CONCLUSIONS The relative proportions of lithic material types represented in the projectile point and lithic debris assemblages from RCAP sites have been used to demonstrate temporal variations in chert utilization. Chert use was highest during the Middle Archaic period and earlier. Chert use was much lower during the Late Archaic and the earlier part of the Late Prehistoric period. There is some evidence for an increase in the use of chert during the St. Elmo phase (A.D. 1300-1650), but this is based almost exclusively on the projectile point data and is reflected less clearly in the lithic debris. These differences in chert use are interpreted as resulting from reductions in group territorial size and settlement mobility over time. Although chert is present as a minor constituent in the upland gravels of the Project area, it occurs in both greater relative frequency and larger nodule size in gravel deposits to the west of the Richland Creek drainage. Access to chert would have been greater for those prehistoric groups whose exploitive territories included areas located a significant distance to the west of Richland/Chambers Reservoir, specifically those areas along tributaries of the central Brazos River. Reduction in the size of group territories would limit access to this material, and reduction in settlement mobility would tend to reduce the rate at which it was introduced into Project area sites. The lack of definable site components attributable to the Paleo- Indian and Early Archaic periods limits our knowledge of lithic raw material use prior to the Middle Archaic period. Of the few recovered projectile points that are thought to date to these earliest periods, only the two San Patrice specimens are made from materials other than chert. The predominate use of high quality, nonlocal lithic materials is considered diagnostic of the Paleo- Indian period for North Central Texas (Lynott 1981:101; Richner and Bagot 1978:51), and for North America in general (e.g., Goodyear 1979; Meltzer 1984). This pattern of raw material use is invariably interpreted as evidence that Paleo-Indian adaptations were characterized by high settlement mobility over very large territories. Middle Archaic period settlement systems appear to have been characterized by relatively high mobility over territories that were large enough to include both the Project area and areas where substantially greater amounts of chert were locally available. In comparison, Late Archaic and Late Prehistoric peoples confined their settlement systems within significantly smaller territories, and/or made less frequent changes in site locations. The result of these adjustments was a loss of, or less frequent, access to the more abundant chert resources located west of the Project area. Lith Figu Dae Leer iibl cdi bulk chil ABM ET
