Lithic Raw Material Utilization Additional evidence for these hypothesized reductions in territorial size was provided by an examination of the regional distribution of Pisgah Ridge chert projectile points. Again, materials assignable to the Paleo-Indian and Early Archaic periods were too limited to allow definite conclusions. However, it is probably significant that the San Patrice and Dalton points from sites at Lake Fork Reservoir were the farthest from the known source of Pisgah Ridge chert of all the artifacts documented by this study. Aside from these two specimens, expanding stem (Middle Archaic) dart points are distributed farthest from the known source, having been recovered from sites along the middle Trinity River, Waxahachie Creek, the Navasota River, and tributaries of the central Brazos River. It is again stressed that the sites associated with these central Brazos River tributaries are within areas where upland gravel deposits contain a far greater 195 abundance of chert than was available in the Richland/Chambers Reservoir area. Progressively smaller clusters are formed by the distributions of contracting stem (Late Archaic) dart points and Late Prehistoric period arrow points, respectively. Although it was not clearly indicated by the chert percentage data, this reduction in the spatial distribution of Pisgah Ridge chert arrow points may indicate smaller territories for Late Prehistoric period peoples relative to the Late Archaic period. Unfortunately, the arrow point sample is rather small and many specimens cannot be assigned to a temporally diagnostic type. For these reasons, their distribution offers little insight into possible variations in territorial size for the three temporal phases that have been defined within the Late Prehistoric period.

## Page 217

LITHIC REDUCTION SYSTEMS AND INTERASSEMBLAGE VARIABILITY: PROBLEMS OF RECOGNITION by Duane E. Peter and Daniel E. McGregor Archaeologists today attempt to extract a maximum amount of cultural information from the stone tools and debitage which comprise the major component of most prehistoric sites. Lithic studies, both of the artifacts themselves and the information they impart concerning technology, have long been recognized as a source of understanding of site function within a settlement- subsistence system. However, the development of analytical frameworks that can provide effective indicators of site function or chronological changes in lithic reduction systems has been less than satisfactory. The formation processes contributing to the archaeological context make the recognition of site function very difficult (Raab 1982:8-12). Nevertheless, the explanatory advantage of being able to relate interassemblage variability to functional differences between sites is a very compelling reason for developing an effective analytical framework. This chapter, therefore, attempts to address the analytical problems associated with the recognition of lithic reduction systems and their relationship to site function. It is proposed that an examination of the entire reduction system as attempted by Collins (1975), Ferring (1979), Ferring and Peter (1982), Johnson (1981), Jefferies (1982), and Morrow (1984) is essential if the study of lithic technology is to serve as a means of processual inference. The characterization of two reduction systems, bifacial core reduction and debitage production, is attempted by means of attribute analysis. Controlled replication studies of these reduction systems are used to evaluate the contribution of the attributes to the recognition of substrategies within the reduction process and the presence of multiple strategies within a single assemblage. The replication data are also used as a comparative data base for the recognition of assemblage-specific reduction strategies within the Richland Creek lithic assemblages. The technological analysis presented here recognizes activity sets such as decortication, internal core reduction, preforming, core blank selection, and tool blank selection which are meaningful in a behavioral context. The examination of these behavioral processes in relation to overall assemblage variability, resource availability, and distance to raw materials generates the basis for assemblage comparisons. The viability of such an approach for recognizing intersite functional differences is examined. PREVIOUS APPROACHES Until the 1970s, one analytical framework dominated the examination of intersite functional differences as reflected in lithic assemblages. Most analytical efforts focused upon the formal tools within an assemblage (Holmes 1894; Muto 1971; Crabtree 1966, 1970) and their relative proportions. Systemic ratios, as proposed by House and Ballenger (1976), have also been used to relate biface use and discard to the lithic reduction activities conducted at a site. House and Ballenger (1976) proposed the Index of Biface Discard (BD) as a means of differentiating sites on the basis of the relative proportion of biface use and discard in relation to early stage reduction. A second ratio, the Index of Early Stage Reduction (ER), proposed by House and Wogaman (1978) reflects the relative proportions of early stage reduction and bifacial thinning. Unfortunately, this latter index is not useful due to the limited definition of a biface thinning flake which was used in the ratio. Bifacial thinning will produce the classic biface thinning flake as defined by House and Ballenger (1976:54); however, numerous other flakes lacking a lipped and/or multifaceted platform will be produced also. Another systemic ratio under consideration concerns use- related artifacts. It has been hypothesized that use-related artifacts may have significant differences in frequency of occurrence between sites. The most viable implication of this hypothesis is related to the occurrence of marginally modified pieces. Functional differences among sites should be reflected in the proportion of marginally modified pieces in relation to the total quantity of chipped stone. It has been postulated that marginally modified tools, assumed to be tools of expediency, should occur in larger proportions at sites within a foraging system which is highly mobile or at extraction sites within a less mobile, logistically oriented system. The potential for cultural interpretation of lithic debitage was initially explored through the efforts of researchers such as Jelinek (1975, 1977), Munday (1976, 1977) and Collins (1975). These initial studies stimulated a variety of approaches to characterizing reduction activities represented by archaeological assemblages. Frequencies of debitage types have often been examined in relation 197

## Page 218

198 to hypothesized models of stone too! manufacture (Fish 1981:374- 386) as a means of inferring the reduction activities represented within an assemblage. Attributes such as weight, platform type, amount of dorsal cortex, and numerous size dimensions have also been examined (Katz 1976; Pokotylo 1978; Bouey 1983:39-42) in an effort to interpret the tool production or maintenance activities conducted at a site. Many studies (Raab, Cande, and Stahle 1979; Stahle and Dunn 1982; Magne and Pokotylo 1981) have also sought to characterize the reduction sequence or trajectory of a given assemblage on the basis of a single variable or a small set of attributes of the debitage alone. These approaches have immediate appeal, for they reduce the variability to a single or very small set of variables which reduce the analysis necessary for valid results. Unfortunately, the statistics involved in such an approach allow significant latitude in the interpretation of the results. Their own test cases are not always classified as accurately as one would like (Stahle and Dunn 1982:92; Magne and Pokotylo 1981:46). Unfortunately, most of these studies have failed to address the problems associated with the recognition of site function through lithic studies. The models of lithic reduction systems and their expected by-products frequently reflect a lack of knowledge concerning lithic mechanics (Raab, Cande, and Stahle 1979:176) or a lack of understanding concerning the expected by-products of a particular technology (Morrow 1984:24). These models are also largely hypothetical; consequently, there is some question concerning how well they reflect the actual prehistoric technology. The "product groups" defined by Collins (1975:25) and the “stages” recognized by Bradley (1975:7-10) are necessarily inferred and require sophisticated judgments on the part of the analyst. Models of bifacial core reduction and debitage production systems and the expected characteristics of their products are similarly inferred. Replication studies (Burton 1980:131-148; Patterson and Sollberger 1978:103-112; Raab, Cande and Stahle 1979:167-182; Stahle and Dunn 1982:84-97; Patterson 1982:50-58; Magne and Pokotylo 1981:34-47) designed to provide realistic models of the reduction process have been infrequent. Such studies are essential, for they provide an excellent model for expectations concerning particular reduction strategies within the prehistoric assemblage. It is realized, however, that such replication models do not represent the only strategies available to the prehistoric knapper; rather, they merely serve as a source of comparative data for the development of realistic models. The interpretation of site function is further confounded by the formation processes affecting the archaeological context. This is especially true for those assemblages which are the result of activities from numerous occupations. The success of any analytical framework in yielding effective indicators of differing site functions is therefore dependent upon good temporal control. Unless radical differences in raw material use or the reduction systems is known to correlate with given temporal spans, detailed analysis of the debitage from a mixed assemblage will be unproductive. GOALS OF THE RCAP ANALYSIS It remains to be determined, however, if lithic assemblages will yield effective indicators of differing site functions. It has been a working hypothesis of the RCAP that such is the case (see Chapter 1). Following the lead of Raab, Cande, and Stahle (1979), bivariate graphs of flake dimensions were proposed for the placement of the components within the manufacturing trajectory. The flaws within this approach were quickly realized (Ferring and Peter 1982:36- 44; Bruseth et al. 1983:451-455) and alternative approaches were examined. As others have noted (Collins 1975; Ferring and Peter | 1982; Johnson 1981; Jefferies 1982; Morrow 1984), the analysis of lithic reduction systems depends on an understanding of the entire reduction process. Lithic reduction is a cultural process patterned by the desired function of the finished tools, the type and Volume III, Part Two size of available raw materials, the cultural tradition of the flintknapper, and the principles of fracture mechanics. An understanding of this cultural process may be achieved through the recognition of the kinds of reduction systems present and the nature of those systems relative to intra-assemblage variability in cores, debitage, debris, and tools. Recognition of reduction systems is best achieved though the delineation of assemblage- specific reduction strategies (Bradley 1975). A reduction strategy, or a planned order of detachments designed to produce an intentional product, is actually composed of several substrategies. These substrategies (i... decortication, preforming, internal reduction, error recovery, and tool blank selection) are processual activity sets which are directed by decisions of the flintknapper, and are important behavioral domains for assemblage analysis and comparison. The traditional approach to characterizing reduction systems has been to focus on @ priori artifact types as the units of analysis. Such an approach, however, fails to recognize the relative positions of artifacts within the reduction system. It is only through the study of attribute relationships both within and between artifact types that we will begin to understand reduction strategies and their relationships to the larger behavioral system. Unfortunately, archaeologists have not been successful in isolating relevant attributes in lithic assemblages. A lack of understanding of lithic reduction mechanics and little interest in conducting replication studies with such goals in mind have contributed to this problem. Therefore, a replication study of two reduction systems, a bifacial core reduction and a debitage production system, was conducted on raw materials similar to those available to the prehistoric occupants of the RCAP area. It was reasoned that the attribute analysis of the replicated, staged reduction of raw materials would reveal those attributes most suited for the recognition of the reduction strategies employed at a site or the assignment of artifacts to particular substrategies (i.e., decortication, preforming, etc.) within a reduction strategy. The study of attribute relationships permits the investigation of dependent variables such as flake shape in relation to technological attributes such as amount of cortex or platform preparation. This process reveals important reduction relationships which are not dependent on the frequency of the reduction process. If certain attribute relationships within the replicated debris can be used to correctly identify the stage of reduction and/or the reduction strategy, then the Richland Creek lithic assemblages can be compared to the replication data to aid the recognition of assemblage-specific reduction strategies. Of course, such an approach requires the assumption that similar strategies were employed prehistorically. The viability of this approach for recognizing intersite functional differences will be evaluated. Our ability to recognize multiple reduction strategies within an assemblage may also be evaluated through the replication study. The proposed analytical framework involves more than the attribute analysis of the debitage and debris alone. The recognition of the reduction strategy depends upon the analysis of the early and late aborted bifaces and all finished tools as well. Although the recognition of the tool blank form is not always possible, the size dimensions and the technological attributes remaining often reveal the position of the tool within the reduction strategy. Systemic indices concerning relative proportions of cores and bifaces in relation to the lithic debris are also examined to determine their utility in differentiating site function versus that of the attribute analysis. This analytical framework is applied to a selected group of assemblages from the RCAP. This selection reflects the need to limit detailed analysis to a reasonable amount of lithic debris and the realization that no analytical scheme will be effective in differentiating site function if the assemblage is from a context in which several occupations or activities are intermixed. It is essential, therefore, to select assemblages which represent occupational activities from a limited time span. After all, the detailed analysis of numerous assemblages which cannot be placed within a temporal framework will not produce interpretable results. ## Page 219

ee Tee Lithie Reduction Strategies assemblages represent a spectrum of occupation from the Middle Archaic period to the St. Elmo phase (A.D. 1300 - 1650). The Hardy site (41FT200) represents primarily a Middle Archaic occupation. Unfortunately, a distinctive Late Archaic assemblage was not available for study. The remaining assemblages are of the Late Prehistoric period. The Irvine site (41NV182) represents the Richiand Creek phase (A.D. 700 - 900). The Round Prairie phase (A.D. 900-1300) is represented by the block excavation of House 1 at Bird Point Island (41FT201). The later St. Elmo phase (A.D. 1300 - 1650) is best represented by the assemblage recovered from the western half of the Little Cedar Creek site (41NV173) (Figure 17-1). The upper three levels of the Perry site (41FT193) were also included in this analysis as representative of the Late Prehistoric period overall. The selection of these assemblages provides adequate samples from known temporal contexts. Variation in site complexity ranging from a possible sedentary hamlet (Bird Point Island) to a short term foraging camp (Perry) also provides an important functional framework for an evaluation of the proposed analytical schemes. ANALYTICAL FRAMEWORK The analytical framework for the RCAP assemblages recognizes lithic reduction as a behavioral system in which a special set of raw materials, skills, and functions are involved. The purpose of this analytical framework is to reveal the kinds of reduction systems present and the activity sets represented by assemblage variability in cores, debitage, debris, and tools. As Collins (1975) has noted, the recognition of “product groups” or activity sets is essential to the interpretation of the adaptive role of lithic technology within a cultural system. The proposed analytical framework focuses on processual activity sets which are common to almost all reduction systems. A reduction system necessarily involves choices or decisions on the part of the knapper. The planned order of detachments to systematically produce intentional products comprises a reduction strategy. The strategy, in turn, is made up of a number of activity sets, such as decortication and preforming, internal core reduction, and tool blank selection which are important behavioral domains for assemblage comparisons. The activity sets or substrategies recognized within this analysis are as follows: CORE BLANK SELECTION The choice of core blanks is largely dependent on the availability and form of raw materials, the shape of the desired product, and the technique of the flintknapper. Two forms of core blanks are recognized. Primary core blanks are those made on naturally occurring nodules or cobbles. These may be either bifacial or debitage cores (Figure 17-2). Secondary core blanks are made on flakes detached from either primary bifacial or debitage cores. The use of secondary core blanks was likely quite common, since a flake approaches the lenticular shape of a biface; consequently, the effort needed to produce a biface and the potential for errors are both reduced. The recognition of the two forms of core blanks is dependent upon the stage of reduction at the time of discard. Many cores have been reduced to the point that the blank form is “indeterminate.” Those blanks which exhibit cortex on several surfaces and the shape of the original cobble are designated as "primary" core blanks. The recognition of secondary blanks depends on the presence of a platform and an associated bulb of percussion. DECORTICATION/PREFORMING Decortication and preforming are achieved simultaneously during the initial stages of reduction. Decortication is actually incidental to the primary goal of bifacial edging or preforming. 199 Preforming is essential to the establishment of morphological homogeneity of the blank so that the removal of flakes of predictable size and shape may be accomplished. Since the morphological variability of the decortication/preforming flakes is dependent upon the morphology of the raw material, it is assumed that the morphological variability of these flakes will be great. Because of the simultaneous accomplishment of these two processes, it is also assumed that the presence of cortex on a flake is good a priori evidence of its removal during decortication (Ferring 1979). It should be emphasized, however, that the recognition of interassemblage variability of this substrategy focuses on the patterns of decortication and preforming rather than the frequencies of artifact classes. Frequencies of artifact classes may reflect differing portions of the reduction process, but the recognition of significant technological differences can be recognized best through patterns of attribute relationships. The technological attributes chosen for this study (Appendix G) permit an examination of the relationships of flake dimensions to platform preparation, error recovery, and amount of cortex. INTERNAL CORE REDUCTION The previous substrategy of decortication/preforming has removed most of the cortex and reduced the morphological variability of the core blank; therefore, it is assumed that the by- products of internal core reduction will exhibit very little cortex and will exhibit less variability in morphology than the decortication/preforming debris. Of course, flakes without cortex are not limited to internal core reduction. Flakes, especially small ones, may be removed any time after decortication begins. As with the decortication/ preforming flakes, attribute relationships are examined to infer patterns of the reduction process. ERRORS AND ERROR RECOVERY Hinged or overpassed terminations are assumed to be the result of insufficient or excessive loadings, respectively. Flakes exhibiting such terminations may have an effect on the size and shape variability of the assemblage. The patterns of error recovery may also be studied by examining flakes which have hinge or step scars on their dorsal surface. TOOL BLANK SELECTION Although most bifacial tools have been reduced to the point where recognition of the blank form is impossible, many aborted bifaces and unifacial tools exhibit evidence of the original blank form. The size and shape of the finished tools also reveal the minimum blank size necessary for the production of those tools. The size relationships between the tools and the debris at the site often reveal whether or not debitage production was necessary or whether the debris incidental to bifacial reduction was sufficiently large to be used as tool blanks. The examination of attribute relationships within the above substrategies should reveal the kinds of reduction systems represented within the prehistoric assemblages. Archaeologists (Skinner and Gallagher 1974; Lynott and Peter 1977; Lynott 1978; Henry et al. 1980) have long recognized the possibility of two reduction systems being primarily responsible for the production of bifacial tools within North Central Texas. It has been assumed that the large dart points of the Archaic period were the result of bifiacial core reduction and the smaller arrow points of the Late Prehistoric were produced from secondary core or flake blanks removed from debitage cores. The presence of numerous bifacial blank/preforms within prehistoric assemblages indicates that bifacial reduction of either primary or secondary cores was prevalent.

Figure 17-2. Schematic model of reduction-systems and their respective strategies (after Ferring and Peter 1982: 9.4). The two reduction systems of concern here do not reflect significant technological differences; after all, both involve bifacial thinning of a primary or secondary blank. The bifacial core reduction system (Figure 17-2) involves the reduction of the core itself as the intended product. The spalls removed from the core are necessary by-products of intentional tool production; therefore, they are waste flakes or "debris." Many of these waste flakes, however, may be suitable secondary blanks for the production of unifacial tools Debitage production systems, on the other hand, involve the production of flakes as the intended product. The resulting core and the unsuitable flakes generated while producing the desired flake blanks are the by-products. Success in distinguishing the by-products of both reduction systems, however, has unfortunately been judged on the basis of the presence or absence of temporal separation of the two systems. Furthermore, hypothetical models have also been used to predict the expected products of these two systems. Consequently, which attributes or attribute relationships are most critical to our understanding of the prehistoric technology of different reduction systems remain to be determined. A detailed study of replicated bifacial core reduction and debitage production systems was proposed as an approach to this continuing problem of system differentiation. REPLICATION STUDY REPLICATION METHODOLOGY The objective of the replication study was to reproduce bifacial artifacts by alternative reduction strategies within a controlled experimental! situation. Such a controlled experiment permits an objective comparison of the by-products of bifacial core reduction and debitage production. As noted earlier, an understanding of such by-products is frequently assumed in the literature, when in truth, the sources of variability in debitage assemblages are very poorly understood. To gain an understanding of such variability in relation to the stages of reduction, certain sources of variability must be controlled. Raw material type and size, the knapper's abilities, and the sequence of flake removal are the most critical 201 variables. Of course, the reproduction of bifacial artifacts represented within the archaeological assemblages is also very important. Failure to control these variables will result in a data base which is not relevant to the archaeological assemblages under study. Eleven cobbles (6 quartzite, 5 chert) were initially selected for reduction. Extreme difficulties in systematically removing flakes from four quartzite cobbles resulted in their abandonment. Only cobbles thought to be similar in size to those used by the prehistoric inhabitants of the Richland/Chambers Creek area were utilized, Archaic dart points from the RCAP assemblages served as models for the replication experiment. Ideally, arrow points should have served as models also; however, time constraints did not allow additional replication. The lack of replicated arrow point production is not as critical as it may seem, for the debris from the dart point production provides a very good comparative data base by which to judge the technological parameters of the Late Prehistoric assemblages. A single flint knapper, J. B. Sollberger, bifacially reduced the flake blanks or cobble cores. A quartzite hammer stone, an antler billet, and an antler flaker were used to reduce the cores. Control over the sequence of debitage removal was attained by placing each flake or group of flakes produced by a given process (e.g., platform preparation) in a numbered plastic bag. All debris, even the dust and shatter, was systematically collected from the swept concrete floor. COBBLE REDUCTION Four of the seven specimens (Table 17-1) were bifacially reduced into a single tool. Only one specimen, a chert cobble, was reduced to a finished dart point (Figure 17-3a). Another chert cobble was reduced to a preform (Figure 17-3b) before snapping and hinging of pressure flakes made further thinning of the specimen impossible. The fracture characteristics of the remaining chert cobble prevented systematic thinning; consequently, an aborted biface (Late Stage) with a small amount of cortex was the final product (Figure 17-3e). The removal of thinning flakes from the quartzite cobble was equally difficult. The repeated snapping of flakes resulted in a large, thick biface with no cortex remaining (Figure 17-3f). The failure to produce a finished tool from each cobble raises questions concerning the comparability of the resulting debitage. The full range of debitage from the quartzite cobble is obviously unavailable for examination; nevertheless, the data concerning early reduction and initial thinning elements may be compared to the archaeological assemblages. The chert debitage, on the other hand, is representative of the entire bifacial core reduction sequence. Although dart points were the desired product, the various stages within the reduction sequence are well represented. Such a sample should permit an evaluation of the reduction processes contributing to assemblage variability. FLAKE BLANK REDUCTION One quartzite cobble from the Richland/Chambers Creek area and two chert cobbles from the “Uvalde gravels” found east of Aquilla Lake were used for the production of the flake blanks. All flakes removed from the cobbles in order to produce a satisfactory flake blank were collected. Reduction of the cobbles ceased upon the production of a flake blank satisfactory for further reduction. The size of the quartzite cobble and one chert cobble was similar to that likely used by the prehistoric inhabitants of the Richland/ Chambers Creek area. The remaining chert cobble was much larger; however, the selected flake blank was similar to that from the smaller cobble (Table 17-1). All of the flake blanks were reduced to finished dart points (Figure 17-3c,d,g). Reduction of an additional quartzite flake blank was attempted, but satisfactory flakes could not be detached. In retrospect, it would have been desirable to have reduced the

Comparability of a debitage production system with a core reduction system, however, should not focus on the production of the flake blanks alone. Recognition of a debitage production system would be quite easy if flake blanks were the end product, It is the variability of the debitage produced during the blank reduction which is most critical to the recognition of the two reduction systems. ANALYSIS OF REPLICATION DEBRIS As discussed above, several analytical schemes have been designed to infer lithic reduction stages from debitage attributes. These analytical frameworks have ranged in focus from a very limited number of attributes (Raab, Cande and Stahle 1979; Stahle and Dunn 1982; Morrow 1984:20-28) to a multivariate examination of an exhaustive attribute list (Katz 1976; Pokotylo 1978). This spectrum of analytical frameworks has had one objective, however: the discovery of a limited number of attributes that will allow the systematic analysis and classification of archaeological collections. Like the previous analyses, this analysis is exploratory in nature concerning the relative worth of the selected attributes for recognizing reduction strategies. Unlike the previous attempts, it is readily recognized that the variability within a reduction system is not likely to be characterized by a single attribute, but rather by a set of attributes which define classificatory units which are meaningful in a behavioral context. Consequently, the interreiationships of flake dimensions (length, size, etc.) and technological attributes (platform type, dorsal scar pattern) are examined for patterning within the reduction sequence. CORE REDUCTION DEBRIS Production of the bifacial core tools produced a total of 870 pieces of chert debris and 383 pieces of quartzite debris. Table 17- 2 reveals that the percentages of debris types are remarkably similar for the two raw material types. The lower relative frequency of whole quartzite flakes and corresponding higher frequency of quartzite shatter is not unexpected given the difficulties in knapping quartzite. The high percentages of shatter from the reduction of both raw materials suggest that most analysts’ reliance on whole flakes for characterizing a reduction strategy may be biased. Recent efforts (Magne and Pokotylo 1981; Stahle and Dunn 1982) to recognize reduction stages within prehistoric assemblages have incorporated all debris; however, the contribution of shatter and proximal flakes to the resulting size distribution remains to be evaluated. Decortication and Preforming - During the replication study, the knapper made us aware that decortication is not a primary goal of the first stage of bifacial reduction, but is largely incidental to the processes of bifacial edging and preforming. Nevertheless, the presence of cortex on flake debris is often assumed to indicate removal during the early stages of preforming (Ferring 1979). An examination of the cortical flakes removed during the reduction of cobble 2 reveals that the last cortical flake was removed when almost two-thirds of the reduction sequence was completed. This position of a cortical flake suggests that decortication may occur throughout much of the reduction sequence and that its usefulness as an indicator of early stage reduction is suspect. It should be noted, however, that such late occurrences of cortical flakes are not statistically important. Seventy-one percent (n = 27) of the cortical flakes from cobble 2 had been removed when 30% of the reduction sequence had been completed. Therefore, the occurrence of cortical flakes later in the reduction sequence is quite sporadic (n = 11). Although these late occurring cortical flakes increase the range of variability of the cortical flakes, it is equally apparent that the cortical classes provide an important framework for characterizing initial preforming. Cortex appears on 22.6% of the chert cobble debris and on 36% of the quartzite cobble debris. The difference may be attributed to the failure to reduce the quartzite cobble to a finished biface. Since only one of the chert cobbles was completely reduced, the frequency value for chert cortical flakes also is inflated. It is apparent that the relative frequencies related to cortex: removal depend upon a number of factors (degree of reduction, amount of cortex on cobble, etc.). The usual reliance upon frequencies of artifact classes alone for the recognition of interassemblage variability may be productive (Jefferies 1982); however, the archaeological context is often a palimpsest of behavioral activities which are not so easily separated and understood. Technological differences among such sites are best recognized by examining the patterns of decortication and preforming.

Lithic Reduction Strategies These Cell 3 flakes cannot be logically related to any bifacial production and/or maintenance activities, and may represent some other facet of the techno- logical system. It is suggested that these flakes may have been produced as the result of flaking activities not directed towards the production of bifacial tools. They may be chipping debris from the production of other types of tools, or may themselves have been the focus of production. Morrow is clearly interpreting flakes with cortex present on their platforms only as “specialized flakes.” Our replication sample, however, reveals that such flakes are a very common product of bifacial core reduction. Such flakes (Table 17-3) comprise 10.9% of the total debris produced by bifacial reduction. The replication material clearly demonstrates that our logical assumptions concerning the by-products of bifacial reduction must be verified rather than assumed to be fact. As expected, a multifaceted platform is the predominant platform type for the interior chert flakes. Nevertheless, single faceted and cortex platforms remain well represented. Such is the case for the interior quartzite flake assemblage in which cortex and single faceted platforms are predominant. Three factors likely contributed to this underrepresentation: (1) the incomplete reduction of the cobble limited the proportion of interior flakes produced; (2), the analyst's ability to clearly distinguish multiple flake scars on quartzite material is hampered by the coarse texture of the quartzite which renders the delineation of individual flake scars more difficult; and (3), the greater tensile strength of quartzite may reduce the need for extensive platform preparation to avoid platform crushing. Unfortunately, the relative contribution of these thrée factors cannot be presently evaluated. Error Recovery Error recovery is very poorly represented in the replication assemblage. This is especially interesting since error‘recovery has been noted in prehistoric assemblages (Ferring and Peter 1982). Given the relatively high percentage of snap terminations on the quartzite debris (Table 17-3), one would expect some need for error recovery; however, evidence of such a process does not survive on the dorsal surfaces of the debris. The more knappable chert exhibits a minimal amount of error recovery with hinges being the most common termination form other than the usual feathered termination (Table 17-3). SUMMARY The above analysis of the core debris reveals that the amount of dorsal cortex, platform type, and flake size are the best indicators of the reduction sequence. No one attribute, however, reflects the degree of reduction performed. It is the interaction of these attributes which best characterizes bifacial core reduction. Dorsal scar patterns, on an intuitive basis, should also reflect the reduction sequence. Perhaps the difficulty of recognizing the states of this attribute as defined for this study obscures the expected patterning. A simple count of the dorsal flake scars may be more useful as indicated by Magne and Pokotylo's study (1981:34-42). However, examination of their Figure 2, reveals that dorsal scar count alone provided for the separation of only the initial decortication flakes from the subsequent flakes. The relationship of dorsal scar patterns to the stages of reduction is therefore not as direct as often assumed. FLAKE BLANK REDUCTION DEBRIS Production of the flake blank tools yielded a total of 1692 pieces of chert and 351 pieces of quartzite. As with the cobble 207 reduction debris, the debris types produced by the reduction of the quartzite and chert flake blanks are almost identical in relative frequency (Table 17-2). The higher absolute frequency of the chert debris is due to the greater size of the chert blanks—over twice as large as the quartzite blank. Nonetheless, the mass of the individual quartzite flakes is much greater than that of the chert, for almost five times as many chert flakes were needed to reduce twice as much mass as that of the quartzite flakes. Once again, the predominance of shatter as the primary by-product of lithic reduction is apparent. Decortication and Preforming The relative frequencies of cortical flakes for both raw material types (Table 17-5) are significantly lower than that produced by bifacial core reduction. It should be noted, however, that the replication study did not include the reduction of the entire cobble into several flake blanks. The production of additional flake blanks would produce greater quantitites of cortical flakes. Magne and Pokotylo's (1981:45) study indicates that debitage production may produce an assemblage which is 33% cortical flakes. This figure is comparable to that produced by bifacial core reduction. Variability within the preforming stage of flake blank reduction is summarized in Figure 17-4 and Table 17-5. As with the bifacial core reduction debris, flake shape is most variable within the mid-range categories of cortex. Nonetheless, the analysis of variance results show no significant variability between groups (F = .48, SIG. = .62 - quartzite; F = 1.65, SIG. = .19 - chert). It is apparent that flake shape is quite constant through the reduction sequence of either bifacial core or flake blank reduction. The bivariate graph of flake size indices in relation to amount of cortex demonstrates that the debris from flake blank reduction exhibits a pattern very similar to that of cobble reduction. The size of the flakes is merely smaller throughout the reduction trajectory. Of particular note is the distinctly smaller size of the two initial classes of cortical flakes (100-76, 75-51%). If the production of the flake blanks was conducted at a location other than that of their bifacial thinning one would be able to detect flake blank reduction within a prehistoric assemblage containing no other reduction system. Those flakes exhibiting more than 75% dorsal cortex are actually no larger than most of the flakes exhibiting no dorsal cortex. The effect of the knappability of raw material may be exhibited in the remainder of the bivariate graphs relating flake dimensions to amount of cortex present. It is apparent that tHe quartzite flakes exhibiting the most cortex are always very small compared to the chert flakes exhibiting similar amounts of cortex. The tenacity of the quartzite apparently requires preliminary edging and platform preparation for the removal of the larger secondary flakes. The reduction of the chert flake blanks, however, begins with the removal of long thick flakes. As the amount of cortex decreases, so do the flake dimensions, except for a slight increase in the 1 - 25% cortex class. Perhaps, the most telling attribute concerning the effect of the raw material on the dimensions of the flake assemblage is platform thickness. The mechanics of lithic reduction indicate that platform thickness should be closely related to flake size (Ferring and Peter 1982:38- 39). Even though platform thicknesses of the two material types are very similar, there are significant differences in the lengths and thicknesses of the corresponding cortical classes. Raw material differences are most likely responsible for this variability. The cross matrices of cortical classes and the technological attributes reveal a reduction pattern similar to that of the bifacial core reduction. The platform types exhibit the expected pattern of cortical and single faceted platforms in association with cortical flakes. Cortical and unidirectional dorsal scar patterns are most common on the flakes exhibiting 51 - 100% cortex, while unidirectional and perpendicular patterns appear on the majority of the remaining cortical flakes (Table 17-5).

Cell Values represent COUNT and PERCENT Internal Core Reduction ; As expected, interior flakes comprise the major portion of the debris produced by flake blank reduction. Contrary to expectations, single faceted platforms remain the dominant platform type, while multifaceted platforms follow in relative abundance (Table 17-5). Cortical platforms are even more frequent than multifaceted platforms within the quartzite sample. The greater amount of cortex on the quartzite flake blank may have contributed to this relative abundance of cortical platforms on interior flakes. Dorsal scar patterns on both the chert and quartzite debris are similarly at odds with expectations. Unidirectional and bidirectional patterns remain as the predominant patterns. It is apparent that the increasingly small size of the flake precludes more complex scar patterns. The dimensions of the interior flakes (Figure 17-4) are the smallest within the reduction sequence. The chert debris is particularly interesting, for the interior flake dimensions are remarkably similar to the flakes exhibiting 26 - 50% cortex. Those flakes exhibiting less than 25% cortex are larger than either of these classes. The chert interior flakes, however, exhibit a smaller range of variability than any of the cortical flakes. The quartzite interior flakes, on the other hand, are the most variable of any flake class. The large size of the chert flake blanks likely contributed to this dissimilarity between the raw material types. Error Recovery As with bifacial core reduction, evidence of error recovery is almost non-existent. Terminations, other than normal feathered terminations, occur on only 10% of the replicated debris. The vast majority of these terminations (hinged, blocky, and snap) occur on the products of internal core reduction (Table 17-5). It is interesting that so few of these termination scars are observable on the dorsal surfaces of subsequent flakes. SUMMARY The analysis of the flake blank debris reveals interrelationships between the amount of cortex and technological attributes which are very similar to those within the bifacial core reduction debris. The most apparent difference between the by-products of the two reduction systems is the overall difference in flake size. The dimensions (thickness, length, width, platform thickness) of the flake blank debris (Figure 17-4) are consistently smaller than those of the bifacial core reduction debris. The relationship between the size dimensions and the cortical classes of the flake blank debris, however, is not as linear as that of the cobble debris. Those flakes exhibiting no cortex or greater than 75% cortex are quite small while the flakes exhibiting 51 to 75% cortex are significantly larger. The chert flakes exhibiting 1-25% dorsal cortex are also larger in relationship to the remaining cortical classes. This relationship may reflect the larger size of the original flake blank. Although the overall differences in the size of the by-products of the reduction systems are real, the recognition of such differences within an archaeological context may not be an easy task. A very clear understanding of the size variability of the raw materials used by the inhabitants of a site is necessary. It is also apparent that the reduction systems will be recognizable only if they are recovered in distinct areas or assemblages. The intermixing of the by-products of these processes will make their recognition a very difficult, if not impossible, task if the debris alone is examined. ANALYSIS OF THE RCAP ASSEMBLAGES As noted earlier, five assemblages representing the Middle Archaic period and phases within the Late Prehistoric period were chosen for analysis. These assemblages represent the most adequate artifact samples from these temporal periods. The debitage from all five assemblages is examined. CORE BLANK SELECTION Cores recovered from all five sites are included in this analysis. The cores from these sites represent the entire core assemblage recovered from the site areas selected for detailed analysis. The blank/preforms of all five assemblages are also discussed in this section, for they often retain characteristics diagnostic of the original core blank. The raw materials represented in the core assemblages from these sites vary considerably. The greatest variety of raw material is present within the Archaic component of the Hardy site (41FT200). Quartzite, chert, silicified wood, and Pisgah Ridge chert are the predominant raw materials (Table 17-6). Raw material variability is similarly great at the Irvine site (41NV182); however, quartzite is the predominant material used. The two

The bifacial cores or blank/preforms exhibit a similar trend in raw material usage (Table 17-7). Interestingly, chert is as well represented as quartzite in the early and late aborted biface samples from the Hardy site (41FT200). The later assemblages (Irvine [41NV 182], Bird Point Island (41FT201], Perry [41FT193], and Little Cedar Creek [41NV173]) exhibit predominantly quartzite blank/preforms. Silicified wood and Pisgah Ridge chert are not represented at all in the later occupations. Of the 104 cores and blank/preforms recovered from the Hardy site (41FT200), 43.3% were flaked beyond the point that the core blank form could be recognized. It is apparent, however, that primary cores (nodules, cobbles) are a primary source for debitage cores, for only three flake blanks were recognized within the entire core sample. Secondary cores are also poorly represented within the blank/preform sample. Flake blanks are poorly represented at the remaining sites also. It is only within the aborted late class (Table 17-7) at the Bird Point Island site (41FT201) and the Little Cedar Creek site (41NV173) that secondary blanks are well represented in relation to the other blank forms. Unfortunately, the lack of secondary ’ cores within the blank/preforms may merely reflect the analysts’ inability to recognize their presence once a blank has been bifacially shaped. The recognition of secondary cores within an assemblage (Ferring and Peter 1982:9.12-9.13) may depend upon the availability of raw material. If raw material is plentiful, the knapper is more likely to abandon a secondary core at any point within the reduction process; consequently, there is no reluctance to discard a flake blank. However, if resources are scarce, the knapper would likely reduce a flake blank as much as possible before abandoning it. The diagnostic attributes of a flake blank would likely be removed in the process. The size of the cores (Table 17-6) from the Hardy site (41FT200) are generally larger than those from the remaining sites. Only the cores from the Perry site (41FT193) (Mean Size = 1086.5; n = 2) are larger. The core size variability is very dependent upon the stage of reduction at the time of discard. Those cores with more cortex were obviously discarded early in the reduction process. Since the proportion of cores exhibiting 50% or more cortex is greatest at the Hardy site (41FT200), the Perry site (41FT193), and the Irvine site (41NV182) (Table 17-6), one would expect those sites to exhibit a greater mean core size. Unfortunately, the small sample of cores from the Perry site (41FT193) precludes any observations concerning the lesser’ availability of larger cobbles during the Late Prehistoric period. The relative size of the early and late aborted bifaces is expectedly smaller than that of the discarded cores (Tables 17-6 and 17-7). An expected gradual reduction in size from the early aborted bifaces to the late aborted bifaces is not consistently exhibited by these assemblages, however. The quartzite blank/ preforms from the Bird Point Island site (41FT201) and the Little Cedar Creek site (41NV173), and all of the blank/preforms from the Irvine site (41NV182) are the only samples which exhibit a significant reduction in mean blank size from the early aborted bifaces to the late aborted bifaces (Table 17-7). The reduction of flake blanks versus that of primary cores may contribute to the inconsistencies observed within the other assemblages. The discard of blank/preforms at these sites indicates that tool production was an important activity at most of the sites. An examination of the ratio of whole flake debris to blank/preforms from these assemblages (Table 17-8) indicates that bifacial tool production was most intensive at the Little Cedar Creek site (41NV173) and least intensive at the Perry site (41FT193). However, examination of the primary raw materials, chert and quartzite, separately reveals a different pattern. Biface production at the Perry site (41FT193) remains at a very low level for both raw materials. The production of quartzite bifaces, however, is most intensive (a low value for this index) at the Hardy site (41FT200) with the Little Cedar Creek site (41NV173) following closely. The biface discard index (BD = number of bifaces, including fragments and projectile points divided by number of unfaceted and cortex platform flakes) further reveals that the amount of biface use and discard in relation to the amount of initial reduction flakes is practically the same for all the assemblages. The biface discard index value is significantly higher for the quartzite material, however. The use of quartzite as a blank material and the associated debris is highly variable among these sites. Perhaps, the lack of greater amounts of initial reduction flakes of quartzite reflects the need to test the nodules and produce a knappable flake blank at the source area rather than carry nodules back to camp and then discover that they are not suitable. Unfortunately, the interpretation of these ratios is not a straight forward matter. The small samples of whole flakes from the two latest assemblages (Little Cedar Creek [41NV173] and Perry [41FT193]) raise important questions concerning the production of the numerous blank/preforms. At the Perry site (41FT193) the production of two blank/preforms should have produced more than 161 flakes. A similar problem exists at the Little Cedar Creek site (41NV173). The number of blank/ preforms is exceedingly high in relation to the number of whole flakes. Perhaps, the initial reduction of these blank/preforms took place elsewhere, either within the site or at the raw material source. Whatever the case, the

The lack of larger primary flakes (51 - 100% cortex) may reflect their use as blanks for unifaces. Given the results of the replication study, it is difficult to attribute the larger size of the Archaic debris solely to the use of bifacial core reduction for tool production. The presence of some secondary cores at the Hardy site (41FT200) denotes that multiple reduction strategies were utilized. The larger size of the Archaic period debris is likely related to one or both of the following factors: (1) the postulated broad territorial range of the Middle Archaic period would have brought these people into areas where larger blanks or cobbles could be acquired, and (2) perhaps the Archaic inhabitants of RCAP exploited the large, prime cobbles so intensively, that subsequent occupants of the area were forced to use smaller cobbles. Although it is evident that the Middle Archaic occupants of RCAP were utilizing more distant source areas (see Chapter 16), it is presently unknown if they also exhausted the prime cobbles of the local sources. An examination of the size variability of cobbles available today is needed in order to address this alternative. As with the replication material, the joint distribution of the cortical classes and the technological attributes were examined by means of a cross matrix. Assemblages from the Irvine site (41NV 182) and the Bird Point Island site (41FT201) most closely approximate the patterns exhibited by the replication material. This is especially true for the quartzite flakes from the Irvine site (¢41NV182) and the Bird Point Island site (41FT201). Several factors may have contributed to these differences. Of course, observer error must be considered as a source of such variability; however, all analysis was supervised with the intent to minimize inter-observer bias. Assuming that observer error was minimized, it is apparent that the prehistoric knappers utilized faceted platforms more extensively to control flake removal during bifacial thinning of quartzite than our modem knapper did. This factor, together with the possible greater emphasis on bifacial thinning within these assemblages (relative to the other assemblages), may explain this occurrence of multifaceted platforms. Termination shape is most commonly feathered, with hinged terminations following in frequency. Due to this excellent control of flake removal, error recovery is minimal (Table 17-9). INTERNAL CORE REDUCTION The three earliest assemblages (Table 17-9) exhibit the largest proportions of interior flakes. As with the decortication flakes, unidirectional dorsal scar pattems are most common among the interior flakes. Multidirectional dorsal scar patterns follow in frequency of occurrence for both chert and quartzite flakes with the exception of the earliest (Hardy [41F1T200)) and latest (Little Cedar Creek [41NV173]) assemblages. In those assemblages the bidirectional scar patterns are better represented than the multidirectional. The apparent lack of internal core reduction at 41NV173 is likely responsible for the above pattern at that site; however, the lack of multidirectional scar patterns on the larger flakes of the Hardy site (41FT200) is not so easily explained. A comparison of the mean interior flake size from the Hardy site (41FT200) (Figure 17-5) with that of the replication material (Figure 17-6) reveals that the former are significantly larger. Perhaps, the final finishing of bifaces was not a predominant activity at the site. As with the decortication flakes, the internal core reduction flakes exhibit a high percentage of multifaceted platforms (Table 17-9). This is especially true of the interior chert flakes from the three earliest assemblages and the quartzite flakes from the Bird Point Island site (41FT201) and the Irvine site (41NV182). The interior flakes from the Perry site (41FT193) and the Little Cedar Creek site (41NV173) exhibit percentages which are very similar to those of the replication study. Although sample size may have contributed to this pattern, the emphasis on initial reduction rather than bifacial thinning within these two assemblages is likely - responsible for the lack of multifaceted platforms within the interior flake assemblage. As usual, the assemblage from the Little Cedar Creek site (41NV173) stands in contrast with the other assemblages. Its anomalous characteristics may be due to sample size; nevertheless, it is notable that no flakes exhibit cortex on their platform surfaces only. It was previously noted that the Little Cedar Creek site (41NV173) exhibited a high proportion of relatively small cortical flakes. The initial reduction of raw materials, perhaps flake blanks, is evident. Perhaps the larger flakes removed during cobble reduction were utilized as secondary blanks or the production of flake blanks was the primary goal of the knappers. Either strategy would diminish the number of interior flakes exhibiting cortical platforms. The reduction of these flake blanks apparently took place elsewhere. As with the replication material, flake termination and error recovery vary little between assemblages (Table 17-9). Feathered terminations are most common with hinges a distant second. The prehistoric knappers apparently maintained excellent control over flake removal throughout the reduction process. Due to this control, evidence of error recovery is very limited throughout these assemblages. Only the Hardy site (41FT200) and the Little Cedar Creek site (41NV173) exhibit a significant amount of recovery which originates from the same direction as the flake scar bearing the error. Why the earliest and the latest assemblages should share this trait is unclear at this time. TOOL BLANK SELECTION The preceding discussion has noted the size dimensions and the technological attributes of the reduction strategies used to bifacially reduce primary and possibly secondary cores within the five assemblages. However, a thorough understanding of the reduction process necessarily involves an examination of the blanks selected for tools. Indeed, the recognition of a purposeful debitage production strategy is dependent upon the evaluation of tool blanks. The evaluation of the tool blanks will involve unifaces, finished bifaces, and projectile points. Blank size and shape and the technological attributes when recognizable will be examined. Flake blanks are overwhelmingly the prehistoric knapper's first choice as a secondary core for the production of a unifacial tool (Table 17-10). This is especially true for the marginally modified artifacts. It is readily apparent from Table 17-10 that the flake blanks used for unifacial tools, especially the steeply chipped tools, are much larger in size than the unmodified debris left at the site (Table 17-11). This indicates the use of debitage cores or the large flakes removed during the early stages of bifacial reduction. The large number of interior flake blanks, however, reflects the use of debitage cores for the production of sufficiently large blanks. The size and shape of the blanks also reflect the use of larger debitage cores. A comparison of the technological attributes of the unifaces (Table 17-11 and 17-12) with those of the debris (Table 17-9) reveals that multifaceted platforms are more common on the unifacial tool blanks of the Bird Point Island site (41FT201) and the Irvine site (41NV182) just as they were on the debris. The . presence of multifaceted platforms on the tool blanks of these sites might be related to the predominant use of interior flakes as blanks. Interestingly, this relationship does not hold up at the Hardy site (41FT200) where the unifacial tool blanks are predominantly interior flakes, but platform types are mainly single faceted. Perhaps, the occupants of the Hardy site (41FT200) were utilizing larger debitage cores which required less platform preparation than the removal of a large flake from the smaller pieces of raw material apparently available to the later RCAP occupants. As with the debris assemblages, unidirectional dorsal scar patterns are most common. Feathered terminations also remain as the predominant termination form. The identification of flake blanks within the bifacial tool categories is more difficult, for the bifacial flaking often removes all identifiable characteristics of the original blank. Within all of the assemblages examined, however, flake blanks are represented within the bifacial tool categories. Among the finished bifaces (Table 17-13), the few identifiable flake blanks range in size from a value of 6.2 to that of 205.2. The bifaces of an indeterminate blank form tend to be larger with a maximum size index of 396.0.

The recognizable flake blanks also exhibit a shape index which is within the range of the normal debris variation. The size of two- thirds of these flake blanks, however, is of sufficient magnitude to suggest that the blanks represent either flake removal from a debitage core or initial bifacial reduction by-products. The predominance of single faceted (n = 6) or cortex platforms (n = 1) further supports such a conclusion. Interestingly, many of the flake blanks of finished tools are larger than those recognized as early or late aborted bifaces. Within the projectile point assemblages, flake blanks are also recognizable (Table 17-14). As expected, there is a notable size difference between the dart and arrow points. Like the other finished bifaces, many of the projectile points could not be fashioned from the normal debris (Table 17-11) recovered from the site. The use of debitage cores or large, initial bifacial reduction flakes is necessary for the production of these tools, especially the dart points. Many of the arrow points could be made Chert Flake wee Quartzite Flake relation to amount of cortex (three classes) present on the from the larger debris recovered from the sites. Unlike the other finished bifaces, the projectile points from these assemblages are smaller than the late, aborted bifaces from their respective assemblages. SUMMARY RESULTS OF THE REPLICATION STUDY The attribute analysis of the replication of two reduction systems provided a comparative data base for the evaluation of the lithic technology represented in five assemblages from the RCAP. An experimental basis for our assumptions concerning bifacial and debitage production systems was definitely needed for an evaluation of present efforts to characterize reduction systems and related strategies. : ; The attribute analysis of the replication debris clearly demonstrates that the by-products of bifacial core reduction and debitage production systems are not easily recognized within an archaeological assemblage. The only variable that is consistently different between the two systems is that of flake size. The differences are not great enough, however, that one would be able to recognize both systems within a mixed assemblage. It is only through the additional analysis of the activity sets of core blank selection and tool blank selection that multiple reduction systems may be recognized. The examination of the individual attributes, however, did reveal their relative worth for the recognition of the reduction process. Within the replication assemblage and the RCAP assemblages it is apparent that flake termination and error recovery provide little worthwhile information. The lack of variability in these attributes reveals that their occurrence is quite constant regardless of the reduction process. Dorsal scar patterns exhibit more variability, but the pattern is not as well defined as archaeologists have often assumed. The assumption that dorsal scar patterns become more complex as the reduction process proceeds is not substantiated by the replication data. Admittedly, the lack of a linear relationship between dorsal scar pattern complexity and the amount of dorsal cortex may be related to the analysts’ abilities to detect the full scar pattern. A more reliable method of recording this attribute is needed. Perhaps, dorsal scar count, as used by Magne and Pokotylo (1981) is a more replicable approach. The greatest variability within the replication material is exhibited by the flake dimension attributes (length, width, thickness, platform thickness) and a calculated size index. It is Volume III, Part Two evident that flake size varies significantly throughout the reduction sequence. Size alone, however, does not permit the confident placement of a flake within the reduction sequence. It is only when flake size is related to the cortical classes that the reduction sequence is properly characterized. Unlike other research efforts (Stahle and Dunn 1982; Magne and Pokotylo 1981), this study did not reveal that flake size would permit an evaluation of the degree of reduction represented within a given assemblage. Discriminant analysis of the flake size dimensions was unsuccessful as a means of properly classifying the flakes from the replication study. The relationship between platform type and the amount of dorsal cortex is also very useful for the characterization of a reduction system. The cross matrix of the states of these two attributes revealed that flakes with cortex platforms, but without dorsal cortex, are normal products of bifacial reduction and not “specialized flakes” as sometimes assumed. The replication data also revealed that multifaceted platforms are not as abundant on interior flakes as often assumed. Once again, however, this attribute relationship does not permit a ready portrayal of the reduction sequence represented at a site. The reduction strategies represented within the RCAP assemblages were first suggested through the analysis of the size and platform attributes in relation to the amount of cortex. This Middle Archaic assemblage exhibits a greater variety of raw material, larger sized debris, and a lesser proportion of multifaceted platforms on quartzite debris than the later assemblages. The first two elements may reflect a higher degree of mobility which provided access to raw materials which were both more varied in type and larger in size than the locally available materials (see Chapter 16). Of course, the larger size of the dart points used during the Archaic period required a larger primary or secondary core. It is also possible that the Archaic occupants of the RCAP area utilized the prime cobbles within the local sources to the point of exhaustion. The foraging band who used this site carried raw material onto the site, conducted primary reduction of those materials, and maintained their existing tool kit as indicated by the extremely small interior flakes. The total reduction sequence related to the production of finished tools is not indicated. Such activities seem consistent with the interpretation that the Perry site (41FT193) served as a short term foraging camp. The Little Cedar Creek site (41NV173) also exhibits an abundance of initial reduction debris. These cortical flakes are relatively small in comparison with the other assemblages. 228 indicate that internal core reduction was conducted either elsewhere on the site or at another location. It is possible that the site was occupied primarily for the use of the nearby source area. Although the proposed analytical framework did not provide any radically different interpretations of assemblage function, it did provide indications of functional differences among the selected assemblages. In this respect it was more successful than the usual dependence on bifacial discard indices or proportions of expedient tools. Perhaps, the most disappointing aspect of this analysis is the failure to readily identify the stages of reduction represented within an assemblage, and consequently site function, on the basis of the debris attributes. Further research concerning the diagnostic traits of the stages within reduction strategies is needed, Cluster and discriminant analysis of the attributes of the replication debris may point the way to statistical assessments of the degree of bifacial reduction conducted at an archaeological site by isolating attributes or attribute clusters which are primarily associated with a particular activity set. Magne and Pokotylo Volume III, Part Two (1981) and Stahle and Dunn (1982) have provided the initial impetus for this effort. The proportion of various flake sizes in relation to reduction stages (Patterson and Soilberger 1981) also needs to be investigated. It should be noted, however, that an understanding of the lithic technology of an assemblage in relation to the total behavioral system will always depend on more than a single attribute or attribute cluster denoting the presence or absence of reduction stages. Our zeal for analytical efficiency should not cause us to ignore the complexities involved with site formation processes. Reliance upon a single attribute to provide determinations of site function is an overly narrow perspective. It is only through replication studies, which provide an experimental basis for our inferences, and the analysis of the entire tool production trajectory in the broader cultural context that we will be able to approach our perceived goal of functional differentiation and ultimately an understanding of settlement-subsistence systems. ## Page 249

HUNTER-GATHERERS OF THE PRAIRIE MARGIN: SUMMARY OF THE PREHISTORIC ARCHAEOLOGICAL RECORD by James E. Bruseth, Daniel E. McGregor, and William A. Martin In Part One of this volume and Parts One and Two of Volume Il, the results from four seasons of excavations at prehistoric sites within the Richland Creek Archaeological Project are presented. The discussion has been detailed to present basic information from field work and data analysis on the mitigation of prehistoric sites within the Richland/Chambers Reservoir. Part Two of the present volume and Part Three of Volume II depart from this descriptive presentation and provide syntheses of various aspects of the prehistoric investigations conducted during the Richland Creek Archaeological Project (RCAP). Specifically, the previous chapters of Part Two of this volume have been concerned with the establishment of a refined artifact chronology for the Project area and with the establishment of changes in lithic technology and raw material usage over time. The present chapter builds upon these earlier studies to accomplish two goals. First, an outline is presented of culture- historical patterns in the data. This is done by summarizing the trends during each of the major chronological periods described in Chapter 15. Second, certain topical problems are then addressed that attempt to move beyond culture history and explain aspects of culture behavior. This is accomplished through an ecological approach to examining hunter-gatherer subsistence-settlement strategies from a diachronic perspective. The Richland Creek data record a developmental history markedly different from the neighboring Caddoan groups less than 50 km to the east (cf., Story 1981; Bruseth and Perttula 1981), and comparisons with these nearby inhabitants provide insight into hunter-gatherer adaptive strategies within the RCAP. PROBLEMS OF DATA INTERPRETATION In any synthesis of a major body of data, an important question confronting the researcher is how far the data can, or should, be “pushed.” Is a careful discussion of basic trends most appropriate, or should speculative interpretations also be included? We have chosen a compromise between the two by first presenting major trends in the data and then providing our interpretations of what these trends mean. We wish to point out that these interpretations should be viewed as our best estimates of cultural developments in the RCAP area and are proposed as a testable model for other researchers to use. This section examines the major weaknesses in the data base that may serve to make some of our interpretations speculative. Although extensive excavations were conducted at 15 prehistoric sites over four field seasons of mitigation as well as the test excavations conducted at several other sites during the survey and testing phase of the Project, major gaps still exist in the data. Most importantly, not all periods of occupation are equally tepresented in the reservoir. For example, there is evidence of occupation from the Paleo-Indian to the Late Prehistoric periods, but our sample for the Paleo-Indian through Middle Archaic is severely limited. This is largely due to the geological facto pointed out in Chapter 7 of Volume I. The vaileys of Richland and Chambers Creeks have undergone significant changes during the period of known human occupation. The terraces and floodplains as they appear today represent one stage in a long series of erosional and aggradational cycles. Although the T1 terrace was deposited during the Pleistocene, it was eroded to its present configuration during the Pleistocene/ Holocene transition. The floodplain, in contrast, has experienced a massive build-up of deposits throughout most of the Holocene. As a result, much of the evidence of late Pleistocene and early Holocene occupations may have been either destroyed by stream, valley incision, or buried deeply within Holocene floodplain sediments. If we base our interpretations of the Paleo-Indian through Middle Archaic occupations on the kinds of sites that are normally found by surface surveys, we are almost certainly observing only a biased segment of the original settlement patterns. Unfortunately, this fact of geology became apparent too late in the Project to permit large-scale excavations into floodplain deposits to search for buried sites. Although a limited attempt was made to do this at the Perry site (41FT193), the full potential of this approach has not been realized. In our opinion, these geological conditions exist throughout much of northern and eastern Texas, and large-scale subsurface testing of floodplain 229
