## Page 250

230 alluvium holds the greatest promise for locating intact early sites in these regions. An additional factor that has limited our efforts of archaeological interpretation concerns the soils of the terraces and uplands in the Project area. The Pleistocene terraces of the Project area have been geologically stable through the period of human occupation. Although localized conditions have caused small areas of colluvial or alluvial deposition and other areas of erosion, these deposits are relatively rare. The occurrence of sites on nonaggrading surfaces is part of a larger phenomenon observed over much of the eastern part of Texas (Story 1981; Bruseth and Perttula 1981), and presents a major problem for archaeological interpretation. Further compounding this situation is pedoturbation that has been documented throughout much of the area (Duffield 1970; Story 1976; Brown 1975; Bruseth and Perttula 1981). This has resulted in artifacts being displaced vertically within the soils of these geologically stable surfaces. Although the deposits appear to have “cultural stratigraphy,” with older artifacts usually occurring deeper, this in fact is not the case. The older artifacts have simply had more time to be vertically displaced. Some workers have taken exception to the view that many of the terrace and upland surfaces in East Texas are geologically stable (e.g., Crook and Harris 1952; Slaughter et al. 1962; Fields 1984; Bianchi 1984; Heinrich 1985), and instead have argued for colluvial and alluvial aggradation. Evidence often used in support of this interpretation is the occurrence in sites of rock concentrations located at varying depths below the present surface. These are interpreted to represent hearths on old surfaces. However, based on the occurrence of similar features at some Richland Creek sites and on experiments using magnetometers to model the formation processes of these features, we suggest as an alternative hypothesis that the features represent earth ovens used for processing plant and animal foods. This interpretation has important implications for understanding the variable depths of the features. According to the earth oven hypothesis, these rock concentrations represent the bottom portions of pits excavated into the soil for food processing. Thus the rocks were never on an exposed ground surface, but were buried into pits of variable depth. Of course, the Richland Creek experimental work is most convincing for the RCAP, and further research is needed before final conclusions can be made for other areas of East Texas. Nonetheless, this work points up present interpretative problems concerning the archaeology at many sites in this part of the State. The final factor that has biased our interpretations is preservation of the economic data. Floral and faunal preservation have been generally poor throughout the reservoir, and in fact, the situation is no different than that recorded for the remainder of this part of Texas (Story 1981). However, based on work elsewhere in East Texas (Bruseth and Perttula 1981; Perttula and Bmuseth 1983), and on the results of the 1980-81 RCAP testing program, it was known that some economic data would be recovered. However, in the majority of cases these data would be minimal from any given context. Consequently, a major emphasis of the mitigation program was the analysis of as many different feature contexts as possible. Our assumption was that the bias from small, poorly preserved samples in individual features could, to a certain degree, be overcome by analyzing multiple samples. In fact, the analysis of several contexts should provide a more reliable picture of the overall subsistence strategy, and certainly has merit over relying upon data from a single well preserved feature which may not be truly representative of the entire range of foods in the diet. The outcome of this extensive recovery program has been generally rewarding. While the remains recovered from individual features were often small, the sum of many such features has allowed us to suggest overall trends in economic strategies. Importantly, the data record a hunting and gathering subsistence strategy throughout the prehistoric record, with maize horticulture utilized only to a very small degree late in the prehistoric record. This stands in contrast to developments from surrounding areas (Story 1981; Lynott 1981). Volume III, Part Two NATURAL SETTING OF THE RCAP As recorded in Chapters 5 and 6 of Volume I, the RCAP is located along the Prairie Margin of Texas, a major ecotone separating the Eastern Deciduous Forest from the Midwestern Plains. Moreover, the Prairie Margin is part of a continent-wide ecotone extending from Canada to Texas (Shelford 1963:328). Along this zone the forests of the eastern U. S. give way to the Great Plains. In some areas this transition is relatively sharp, perhaps a few tens of kilometers as in the Project area. In other areas a complex mosaic of prairie, savannah, and woodland communities form the transition between grassland and forest. In this section we examine essential characteristics of the environment to serve as a background for understanding trends in human adaptations to the area. Within the RCAP area, three major vegetational communities are found: Post Oak Savannah, Bottomland Forest, and Tall Grass Prairie. Since the disturbances that have occurred within each zone from historic settlement are not relevant to this discussion, we only reconstruct each community as it would have appeared at approximately 1850. Chapter 6 of Volume I presents greater detail on the environmental construction from the GLO records for the Project area. Included within these GLO records are directions, distances, and sizes of witness trees for all major tracts of land. This type of data, although potentially biased (cf., Wood 1976; Warren 1976), has been nonetheless a useful tool for the reconstruction of pre-Euro-American settlement in many parts of the midwestern United States (King 1984). In addition to the GLO witness tree data, other more general botanical summaries of Texas, such as Kiichler (1964) and Gould (1975), as well as data on soils and topography, have been used to interpolate between the known GLO data points. The results of this effort are shown in map form in Figure 18- 1, based on Figure 6-1 in Volume I. This represents our best approximation of the distribution of pre-Euro-American settlement vegetation and provides a valuable ecological baseline for understanding the potentially exploitable prehistoric biomass surrounding the RCAP. Climax species would have been little bluestem, indiangrass, purple top, silver bluestem, and Texas wintergrass. The occurrence of these species indicates that the density of trees was substantially less than is seen today, and the area would have ‘been more open and a true savannah environment. Important faunal resources indigenous to this area would have included whitetail deer, red wolf, fox squirrel, raccoon, gray fox, easter cottontail rabbit, opossum, and several species of rodents, snakes and birds. Several elements of this community would have made it particularly important to prehistoric populations. The dominance of oak and hickory species, accounting for nearly 95% of all trees, would have offered great potential for acorn and hickory nut collection, both known to have been important foods of native American groups throughout the Eastern Woodlands during the historic contact period (Swanton 1946:364-367). In addition, the high frequency of nut producing trees would have created a favorable environment for deer, and hunting of this mammal would no doubt have been a major exploitation strategy. An important plant food available in this habitat, but not found commonly in the others, would have been the prairie turnip (Psoralea spp.; Correll and Johnston 1970:813-817). The remains of the tuber from this plant are omnipresent at many of the reservoir sites, and its common occurrence underscores its importance in the prehistoric diet. A similar heavy usage of this plant is documented further to the north in the Great Plains by historic Native American groups (Wedel 1978; Reid 1977; Kaye and Moodie 1978). 231 BOTTOMLAND FOREST As with the Post Oak Savannah, the dominant overstory species of this zone would have been post oak (Table 18-2). The second most frequent species in the Savannah, blackjack oak, would have dropped in frequency within the Bottomland Forest to fifth, again based on GLO records. The species that would have replaced it in occurrence are ash, hackberry, and elm. Less common species would have included hickory, red oak, locust, and bur oak. In the swamps and wetter parts of the floodplain, green ash, sugarberry, hackberry, and cedar elm would have been dominant with willow and cottonwood also occurring. Understory vegetation probably would have consisted of shrubs (¢e.g., greenbriar, Virginia creeper, poison ivy, and grape), grasses, and sedges. The difference in the vegetational composition between the Bottomland Forest and the Post Oak Savannah is due in large part to a single factor. The bottomlands tend to collect runoff from rain that falls in the surrounding uplands and thus provide a better watered environment for plant growth. Potentially important mammal species of this area would have been whitetail deer, fox squirrel, raccoon, gray fox, bobcat, swamp rabbit, eastern cottontail, opossum, several species of fish and amphibians in creeks and other water sources, and a variety of birds. This vegetational zone would have offered several species of potentially high economic value to prehistoric people. The oak species would have comprised a third of all trees, and acorns would have been an important autumn food source. The dense shrubby understory would also have permitted the exploitation of several types of wild berries, grapes, and fruits. And finally, the total faunal biomass would have been the greatest of any of the habitats, with a greater variety and frequency of most species. Two obvious exceptions to this would have been deer and bison, both of which would have been greater in frequency in the Post Oak Savannah and the Tall Grass Prairie, respectively. Nonetheless, the high overall exploitable biomass would have made this zone a focus of many procurement activities throughout the prehistoric period. The dominant climax species would have been little bluestem, followed by big bluestem, indiangrass, switch grass, side oats grama, and hairy grama. LATE HOLOCENE CLIMATIC CHANGE The location of the RCAP along the Prairie Margin of Texas offers a unique perspective for the investigation of prehistoric cultural behavior. As noted earlier, the zone is the transition between the Eastern Deciduous Forests and the Midwesterm Plains. Importantly, the location of the Prairie Margin has not been static during the Holocene. As pointed out in Chapter 5 of Volume I, changes in temperature and moisture regimes have caused advances and retreats of the forests and grasslands. Moreover, based on continent-wide historical records, periods of drought are found to have occurred over consecutive years and to have been concentrated in the grasslands of the Midwest (Bochert 1950). More specific studies of drought in the Midwest were conducted by Albertson and Weaver (1945). These have shown that the effects of the 1930s drought upon vegetation resulted in 20 to 50% of upland trees being killed, and a lowering of the water table causing many springs to stop flowing. Dyksterhuis (1948:373), studying the effects of the 1930s drought upon the Cross Timbers region of Texas, noted that trees died on the western margin of this biogeographical zone. The overall pattern of vegetational change noted during dry periods in the Midwest is the replacement of tall grasses by mid and short grasses and the woodlands by tall grasses (Bochert 1950:35). Recovery of vegetation after dry periods can be slow and substantial erosion can occur (Albertson and Weaver 1945:423). Similar conditions can be assumed to have occurred during prehistoric droughts. The dynamics of the Prairie Margin have important implications for archaeological research in the area. Prehistoric economic strategies possible in grasslands versus forests were markedly different, and the movement of this ecotone can be assumed to have influenced prehistoric societies. This ecotone, then, can be viewed as a natural archaeological laboratory for examining the impacts of environmental change on human populations (e.g., Wood and McMillan 1976). In the remainder of this section, we outline the major environmental periods for the late Holocene. The periods were devised after analysis of paleoecological data from along the Prairie Margin in Oklahoma and Texas, and the summary presented here is based on a more detailed presentation in Chapter 5 of Volume I. ENVIRONMENTAL PERIOD I: 3000 B.C. TO A.D. 500 This period appears to have been one of relatively greater effective moisture. How much greater than at present is difficult to estimate, but the rapid sedimentation rates on the floodplain of Richland Creek and high representation of arboreal taxa in the regional pollen record suggest significantly wetter conditions. This is not to imply that dramatically different species composition existed during this period as contrasted with the present. Rather, significant changes in the proportional representation of species would have existed in comparison with today. We suggest that much of the area presently occupied by Tall Grass Prairie was then covered with an open canopy woodland, or a savannah, environment. In all probability, the arboreal species present today in the Post Oak Savannah would have occurred throughout the Project area. This would have provided greater numbers of hickory and oak trees in proximity for exploitation by prehistoric hunter-gatherers along Richland Creek. Furthermore, the increased woodland area would have provided more forage for deer and allowed an increase in the frequency of this species. Volume III, Part Two The bottomlands appear to have been subject to frequent flooding and relatively rapid alluviation. The frequent deposition of sediments would have prevented a mature climax forest from developing, as exists in the area today, and instead the floodplain would have consisted of a highly diverse vegetation mosaic representing communities in various stages of succession. The overall biotic potential would have been greater than today's, due to the increased variety of floral and faunal resources such an environment would have provided. ENVIRONMENTAL PERIOD II: A.D. 500 TO A.D. 1200 During this period, the western margin of the savannah woodlands surrounding the Project would have started to slowly recede eastward as an increasingly drier climate was becoming established. The sedimentation rates for the floodplain indicate approximately comparable deposition to the previous period, but the increase in clays observed in floodplain stratigraphy argues for slower movement of water. It appears that overbank flooding was gradual, perhaps indicating a decreased occurrence of intense storms. The formation of a prairie environment along Richland Creek would have resulted in a net decrease in the potentially exploitable biomass. However, as the recession of the woodlands would have been from the west to the east and the RCAP is located on the eastern edge of the Tall Grass Prairie, the prairie environment may not have reached the reservoir area until late in this, or even into the next, period. The floodplain environment would have been similar to that of the previous period. The rates of sedimentation would most likely have been sufficient to have prevented a climax forest from developing, and a rich variety of exploitable bottomland resources would have been present. ENVIRONMENTAL PERIOD III: A.D. 1200 TO 1820 The evidence from a variety of sources suggests this period represented a major climatic deterioration. The cessation in floodplain alluviation suggests a marked decrease in rainfall that persisted until historic times. In all likelihood, the Tall Grass Prairie observed today was established during this period, and resulted in substantial amounts of grassland surrounding the central and western portions of the reservoir. Bison would have been more common than before, but based on the overall rarity of this species at archaeological sites throughout North Central Texas (Lynott 1979), this animal would have still been infrequent. ‘The prairie would have also resulted in a marked decrease in the abundance of many important food species such as nuts and deer. The floodplain would not have been seasonally inundated, and a climax forest would have developed. Within the floodplain, this factor would have further decreased the abundance of many exploitable resources. In particular, deer would have been less abundant since they prefer edge areas and a floodplain forest does not provide this situation. However, this effect may have been partially offset by the increased edge area formed by the forests of the floodplain meeting the grasses of the prairie in the uplands. HUNTER-GATHERERS OF THE PRAIRIE MARGIN: DESCRIPTIVE TRENDS IN THE DATA The purpose of this section is to use the chronological foundation established in Chapter 15 ta reconstruct the lifeways of the prehistoric inhabitants during each major temporal period. As the following discussion indicates, a hunting and gathering lifestyle was maintained throughout the entire prehistoric record in the

More specifically, the focus of this discussion is on reconstructing, to the extent possible, the lifeways of the extinct societies that inhabited the RCAP through consideration of four topics: settlement patterns, demographics, technology, and economy. It must be pointed out from the beginning that not all topic areas are fully realizable for all periods. As noted in an earlier section, the data from the reservoir are disportionately representative of certain time periods. For instance, our samples of Paleo-Indian through Middle Archaic occupations are very small. In particular, no in situ Paleo-Indian or Early Archaic deposits were located within the reservoir, and our samples from these periods are limited to artifacts mixed with components from other periods. The Middle Archaic period is only slightly better represented. More artifacts diagnostic of this period are present, but these are still mixed with those from later periods of occupation. As a result, the primary focus of this discussion begins with the Middle Archaic and continues through the Late Prehistoric periods, a temporal range of approximately 3000 B.C. to A.D. 1650. The Paleo-Indian and Early Archaic periods are treated only briefly. The most detailed information comes from the last 3000 years, where evidence of more substantial occupations provides better data on the Late Archaic through Late Prehistoric. Not all sites with evidence of occupation from one or more of the major periods of reservoir prehistory are used in the following discussions. None of the mitigated sites are exclusively single component occupations; all have some evidence of multiple occupations. In some instances a particular occupation may be dominant, such as the Richland Creek Phase occupation at the Irvine site, and in these cases the overall site assemblage is treated as representing this period of occupation. Although artifacts from earlier and later periods may be mixed in, the bias in the sample is clearly towards the dominant occupation. In other cases, such as Bird Point Island, different periods of occupation are largely horizontally separated. Consequently, spatial divisions of the site can be used as components representing different periods. And in still other instances, particular features at some sites are sufficiently distinctive to suggest affiliation with a period other than that which the site overall is thought to represent. In these situations, the feature is analyzed separately from the remainder of the site. Depending on the materials that were recovered, the feature may be included in discussions of some artifact classes and excluded from other discussions. PALEO-INDIAN AND EARLY ARCHAIC: 11,000 B.C. TO 3000 B.C. There is relatively little evidence available concerning the Paleo-Indian and Early Archaic occupations of the Project area. Diagnostic projectile points are known from surface collections and from subsurface contexts where they were mixed with artifacts from later components. Because no radiocarbon dates from these periods have been obtained from middle Trinity River sites, dating of these artifacts is based on their typological similarities to dated materials from adjacent regions. The Paleo-Indian occupants of the Project area are assumed to have been highly mobile groups of hunter-gatherers. Low regional population densities and movements over very large territories are thought to be characteristic Paleo-Indian adaptations. This is based on the low density of sites and the fact that diagnostic projectile points were often manufactured from non-local lithic materials. This predominate use of high quality, exotic cherts is considered diagnostic of the Paleo-Indian period for North Central Texas (Lynott 1981:101; Richner and Bagot 1978:51), and for North America in general (e.g., Goodyear 1979; Meltzer 1984). As was noted in Chapter 16, all but two of the Paleo-Indian projectile points from the Project area were made of high quality cherts that may be non-local. The two exceptions are the San Patrice specimens, one made of silicified wood and the other of 233 Pisgah Ridge chert. This tendency for San Patrice points to be made from local lithic materials has been noted previously for North and East Texas, and a relatively lower degree of mobility has been suggested for the groups associated with these types (Lynott 1981:103; Shafer 1973:18-19). The distribution of known Paleo-Indian projectile points from sites along Richland and Chambers Creeks and the adjacent Trinity River drainage is shown in Figure 18-2. As has been noted in Chapter 7 of Volume I, the distribution of Paleo-Indian diagnostics probably tells us less about early settlement patterns than it does about which physiographic locations are most conducive to the exposure and discovery of these artifacts. The sites in Figure 18-2 are invariably situated on either Pleistocene terraces or upland landforms. In most instances, the surfaces of these landforms have been essentially nonaggrading thoroughout the known period of human occupation. The inner valleys of creeks and rivers were no doubt occupied, but Paleo-Indian sites in these locations either were eroded away by post-Pleistocene valley incision or buried deeply by Holocene floodplain sedimentation. It should also be noted that archaeological investigations and collector activities have not been uniform across the area shown in Figure 18-2. Because of the limited and biased nature of the present data base, the Paleo-Indian occupation of the Project area remains poorly understood. Information concerning much of the Archaic period in the Project area is only slightly more complete than that for the Paleo- Indian period. Acceptable radiocarbon dates for all but the Transitional Archaic period derive exclusively from creek bank sites where diagnostic artifacts were rare or absent. Therefore, the time spans assigned to the Archaic period subdivisions are largely hypothetical. This is most obvious in the case of the Early Archaic period (ca. 6000 B.C. - 3000 B.C.). Unlike the preceding Paleo- Indian period, diagnostic artifacts assignable to the Early Archaic occupations of the Project area are virtually unknown. Although Lynott (1981:103) has suggested that the San Patrice projectile point type is diagnostic of this time period in North Texas, this type is considered here to be related to the late Paleo- Indian period. A lack of dated Early Archaic assemblages in East Texas prevents the cross dating of artifact types to that area. Of the artifact types considered by Prewitt (1981) to date the 6000 B.C. - 3000 B.C. time period in Central Texas, only the Wells projectile point and the Clear Fork gouge were recognized within Project area assemblages. Both of these artifact types were very rare, and this may indicate only limited use of the Project area during this time period. However, it seems more likely that this lack of evidence is in part due to our present inability to recognize the local Early Archaic artifact styles. S. prehistory, the Archaic stage has been identified as a period during which mobile bands of hunter- gatherers foraged for plant and animal resources (Willey and Phillips 1958). It is also a time during which cultures "settled in" to their respective environmental niches (Caldwell 1958). These statements are generally applicable for the RCAP, although our assessments for the Middle Archaic are handicapped by a limited amount of data. Significant deposits were present at only four of the mitigated sites: 41FT158, 41FT200 (Hardy), 41NV96, and 41NV160 (Figure 18-3). However, at 41 FT158 and 41NV160 the Middle Archaic materials were mixed with substantial deposits of later occupations, limiting the usefulness of these sites for temporal comparisons. The principal Middle Archaic data from these sites consists of projectile points, stone tools, and associated lithic debris. In addition, minimal economic data are available from three of these sites. Less intense occupations were observed at two other sites, but these materials only consisted of a few diagnostic tools or projectile points in contexts mixed with later artifacts. Consequently, for this discussion we rely upon the data from the sites with major occupations to form our conclusions, The environment during this period appears to have been relatively moister than later periods. Since the paleoenvironmental data for the Project are not available for earlier periods, we are unable to draw specific comparisons to previous environments. In all likelihood during the Early Archaic, Texas was experiencing the Altithermal, a large-scale dry climatic episode observed over much of North America (Antevs 1955; Delcourt and Delcourt 1980), although data to support this are few (Gunn and Mahula 1977). The moist conditions of the Middle Archaic would have created a savannah environment in much of the area around the Project that today is covered with tall grass prairie. Specifically, the pre-Euro-American composition of the Post Oak Savannah, consisting of oak and hickory trees interspersed with prairies, is believed to be an accurate model for the area surrounding much of the reservoir during the Middle Archaic. The Middle Archaic appears to be the earliest period for which coeval floodplain deposits are currently exposed in the channels of Richland and Chambers Creeks. Not surprisingly, this is the first period for which both terrace and creekbank site locations have been documented. Unfortunately, neither of the two creekbank sites (41FT180 and 41NV139) with archaeological remains radiocarbon dated to this period were investigated beyond their initial testing. The only evidence from Middle Archaic creekside occupations consists of small rock lined hearths and substantial deposits of discarded mussel shells. The only additional data pertaining to Middle Archaic settlement patterns is the frequency of cherts from site deposits. Grady (1978) has argued that the frequency of chert, which is assumed to be imported into the eastern part of Texas, is a good indicator of the range of interaction of prehistoric groups. Based on his study of East and Central Texas samples, he proposed that a reduction in chert frequencies over time represented a decrease in group territory size. More local quartzites were used in the Late Archaic compared with the Early and Middle Archaic since the reduced territory sizes brought fewer people into contact with imported

The nearest large outcrop of chert is from along the Brazos River, and most of the imported chert for the RCAP came from this area (see Chapter 16). Figure 18-4 graphs the frequency of chert as a percentage of all raw materiais in the lithic debris assemblage from certain RCAP sites. A high frequency of chert, accounting for more than 60%, is observed for the two Middle Archaic sites, Hardy and 41NV96. A marked decrease in the frequency of chert is observed for later periods, and the RCAP data show a similar trend to that noted by Grady. However, the occurrence of chert does not in itself indicate what is happening in terms of group territory size. Instead of a reduction in group territory, the results could indicate decreased interaction and exchange with neighboring groups. An indication of which case is correct can be made by examining the known spatial distribution of Pisgah Ridge chert projectile points in North Central Texas. As discussed in Chapter 16, this distinctive chert outcrops 10 km south of the reservoir and is unique to that area. Figure 16-6 displays the spatial distribution of Pisgah Ridge chert projectile points. By comparing the distribution of expanding stem dart points, indicating Middle Archaic occupations, with arrow points from Late Prehistoric occupations, a clear decrease in areal extent is seen. At the Middle Archaic period sites, few data on internal site organization and activity are available. The principal features encountered were small rock concentrations randomly distributed over the scraped portion of the site. These features were most frequent at the Hardy site, and were proposed to be either subsurface hearths or roasting pits. It seemed doubtful, however, that these features could be subsurface hearths since most were encountered more than 50 cm below the ground surface. The roasting pit hypothesis seems more reasonable since this activity would be expected to have taken place below the ground surface. Complicating this interpretation, however, is the fact that these features were different in some respects from the roasting pits identified at many other sites in the Project area. Specifically, the features at the Hardy site consisted of large pieces of Wilcox 235 sandstone, the local stone available for the activity, concentrated on a horizontal plane 40 to 60 cm below the ground surface. At first, it was thought that these materials were placed on older, and lower, surfaces than are present today. However, careful inspection of the soil profile showed the normal A and B horizons at Hardy were formed on a stable Pleistocene age terrace deposit. A more likely interpretation, then, is that these features were roasting pits used for a short term, perhaps single, episode of use. Unlike the roasting pits observed at other sites, these were not extensively re-used and the rock remained in the features after use. In the other roasting pits, large pieces of rock were scavenged and reused in later roasting episodes, resulting in only small, exfoliated pieces remaining today. Burned rock concentrations like those at site the Hardy site were not common at other Project area sites. They are, however, known from several sites in the middle Trinity River basin and in adjacent areas. One oval-shaped concentration of fire cracked pebbles and bumed clay was discovered at the Wild Bull site at Cedar Creek Lake (Story 1965), and a total of seven similar features was recorded at the Pecan Springs site at Lake Bardwell (Sorrow 1966). Test excavations at site 41FT48 in the Big Brown Lignite Prospect identified three circular concentrations of thermally altered sandstone and quartzite cobbles (Wooldridge 1979), Bumed rock concentrations appear to be even more common in the upper Navasota River drainage, where they have been reported at Lake Limestone (Mallouf 1979) and from the Jewett Mine Project area (Espey-Huston and Associates 1982; Day 1984; Fields 1984). The largest sample of these features was from site 41LN178 (Day 1984), where most were thought to date from the Archaic. With respect to Middle Archaic demographics, if we assume that the number of sites is a reflection of population size, then a case can be made for a relatively low level of population. This is seen by the comparison of the number of Middle Archaic sites to the number of Late Archaic/Transitional period sites. Compared with the seven Middle Archaic sites, 15 Late Archaic/Transitional period sites are noted. A potentially biasing problem in this type of comparsion is the length of time involved during each period. However, in this instance the Late Archaic is actually shorter by 300 years than the Middle Archaic, indicating that the higher numbers of sites cannot be attributed to this factor. Another potential problem is the frequency with which groups moved from one site to another. Groups that move more frequently will produce greater numbers of sites (Prewitt 1983). However, as we argue for later periods in the RCAP, group movement seems tc have decreased through time, and this factor if anything should inflate the number of Middle Archaic sites relative to Late Archaic sites. Consequently, the data are interpreted to indicate a low Middle Archaic population. Technological advances made over time in the RCAP are shown in Figure 18-5. The major hunting technology indicated for the Middle Archic period is the spear and atlatl, which were inherited from earlier periods. Certainly other technologies must have been employed using perishable materials such as reed baskets or “wooden tools, but these items have not been preserved. Consequently, our assessment of Middle Archaic technology is necessarily simplistic. Dart point styles diagnostic of this time period are Bulverde, Carrollton, Yarbrough, and perhaps Dawson. In addition, Waco sinkers and Clear Fork gouges are also present. A variety of stone tools is observed from sites of this period (Table 18-3). Correcting for the lower sample sizes for sites of this period, the variety of tool forms seems similar to that observed in later periods. Looking at the relative occurrence of major tool categories among Middle Archaic sites(Table 18-4), some differences are noted. At both the Hardy site and 41NV96, where sufficient samples for comparison were recovered, projectile points are similar in frequency. However, the relative occurrence of bifacial versus unifacial tools demonstrates considerable variability between the two sites. Work requiring bificially made tools was undertaken nearly twice as commonly at the Hardy site (41FT200), whereas activities using unifacial tools were more commonly undertaken at 41NV96. TO A.D. 700 The data base available for this period is significantly better than for the Middle Archaic. In addition to a general Late Archaic period, we are also able to discriminate a Transitional Archaic phase at some sites. The identifying characteristics of this phase, as outlined in Chapter 15, consist of the presence of shell tempered ceramics and/or the construction of a large depression, commonly referred to as a “Wylie focus pit.” Aside from these few characteristics, the sites are similar to the Late Archaic sites within the reservoir, and in all probability the people responsible for these traits also formed the archaeological deposits at many of the other sites. Unless ceramics or a large depression are encountered, we are not able to discriminate this fact. The dates for the Transitional Archaic phase indicate that this period of time extended from 200 B.C. to A.D. 700, or the latter half of the Late Archaic period. The environment during the Late Archaic appears to have been much the same as for the Middle Archaic. Figure 18-5 shows this time period as one of increasingly moister conditions. However, this is largely speculative and in need of testing by analysis of additional pollen cores. In terms of the specific. environment around the reservoir, we have suggested that a savannah condition existed. The floral and faunal resources of the Post Oak Savannah would have been found around much of the Project area, and it is possible that these conditions covered much of the area today occupied by the Tall Grass Prairie in Texas. The floodplain of Richland Creek was rapidly alluviating and would have created a highly varied vegetational mosaic in different stages of succession.

Figure 18-6 shows the types of occupation based on excavations conducted at each site. Major occupations were recorded for seven sites, minor occupations for six, and creek bank occupations for two others. Transitional Archaic deposits consisting of shell tempered pottery and/or large depressions were observed at four sites. Concerning Transitional/Late Archaic (hereafter referred to only as Late Archaic) settlement patterns, several lines of evidence suggest changes from the previous Middle Archaic. First, Figure 18-4, showing the frequency of chert usage in the lithic assemblages from sites, and data presented in Chapter 16, demonstrate that during the Late Archaic the percentage of chert in the lithic assemblages decreased markedly. In addition, Chapter 16 demonstrates that the distribution of Pisgah Ridge chert also shows a significant decrease in spatial distribution. Both of these changes are interpreted to be indicative of decreased territorial size in comparison with the preceding Middle Archaic period. A second line of evidence suggesting a settlement pattern change is the occurrence of the large depressions at the Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch sites. As described in Chapter 21 of Volume II, these pits appear to represent large roasting ovens associated with Transitional Archaic band coalescence. This coalescence was used for interband feasting and for cooperative 65 15 110 165 122 90 159 128 31 93 74 79 36 83 193 46 203 239 201 126 242 ] 2 2 1 7 1 7 2 1 il 2 2 10 4 8 7 11 1 194 4 4 5 13 9 15 16 29 13 10 29 2 36 32 40 28 42 26 8 43 73 17 12 36 34 6 29 82 16 15 34 11 2 3 38 11 7 12 71 16 75 193 44 34 82 14 1 5 33 12 4 8 41 7 11 68 19 10 13 4 1 53 2 34 3 14 10 24 3 1 2 2 8 3 1 1 7 5 39 8 18 22 16 12 31 4 4 1 6 11 5 2 34 3 51 - 216 97 20 83 195 29 123 357 177 61 165 51 33 44 59 114 62 105 442 29 1352 379 546 1131 2538 4 2 2 1 3 11 1 3 7 2 3 7 1 1 3 5 1 2 3 6 6 12 5 4 8 21 processing of certain plant and animal foods that were seasonally abundant but restricted in distribution and harvestable only for short periods of time (e.g., Psoralea tubers and nuts). In addition, these pits were used as cemeteries. The locations of these features probably indicate territorial “tension zones” where local bands came into contact more often, due to the restricted distribution of food resources or to cultural factors. Inherent in this interpretation is the assumption that the large pits signified more than feasting, processing, and burial centers but also served as symbols of interband reciprocity and as territorial markers. The occurrence of these structures is hypothesized to be an adaptive response to increased stress upon critical food resources as a result of decreased group territories. Combined with the reduced size of group territories is an apparent increase in population size. This is seen in the greater number of sites illustrated in Figure 18-6. Although as argued previously, site components cannot be translated directly into numbers of people, the greatly increased numbers of sites argue strongly for a higher population. In addition, evidence from some of the sites indicates that large areas were occupied (e.g., 41NV96). Whether this is due to site reoccupation or large resident populations cannot be determined, although we suggest that larger group sizes coupled with long durations of occupation was responsible for the observed pattern. Story (1981:146) has also observed that ceramics appear within East Texas during this time period and has speculated that there are two separate traditions. A sandy paste tradition occurs in the southem part of East Texas and a grog (and sometimes bone) tempered tradition occurs in the northern part of the area (see also Shafer 1973:27-33, 1975). Story (1981:146) further argues that the ceramic traditions reflect distinctive cultural groups, both of which constructed small, conical burial mounds. The Coral Snake Mound (Jensen 1968; McClurkan et al. 1966) on the Louisiana side of the Sabine River, the Jonas Short Mound (Jelks 1965:22-52; McClurkan et al. 1980) on the Angelina River, and possibly the Westerman Mound (Story 1981:146) in the Neches River drainage are associated with the southern group. RICHLAND CREEK PHASE: A.D. 700 TO A.D. 900 The archaeological record provides somewhat better preserved components for the Richland Creek phase compared with previous periods. In particular the extensively investigated component at the Irvine site (41NV182) provides a good sample for this phase. Sites with Richland Creek phase occupations are shown in Figure 18-7, and overall, fewer sites are recorded for this period. However, when a correction is made for the decreased time frame of this phase (i.e., 200 years versus 1700 years for the Transitional/Late Archaic), a greater population level is likely represented. Major occupations were observed at four sites, less intense occupations at three, and creek bank activity at one. This phase occurs within Environmental Period II, a time of slowly drying climate (Figure 18-5). Since this trend appears to have begun first in the southern part of the state and slowly spread. northward, it is not clear exactly when the impact was felt in the Project area. Palynological analysis of bogs nearby the Project (see Chapter 5, Volume I) suggests that drier conditions began in the area around A.D. 500. However, geological studies of floodplain sediments from within the reservoir indicate that lower rates of deposition in the valley of Richland Creek did not occur until later, sometime after A.D. 800 but before A.D. 1170.

The evidence in terms of Richland Creek phase settlement patterns comes principally from studies of chert distribution within and around the RCAP (see Chapter 16, this volume). As Figure 18-4 demonstrates, a reduction in the percentage of cherts (assumed to be imported) is first detected in the Late Archaic, but this trend continues during the Richland Creek phase. This evidence suggests decreased interaction with groups to the west and probably a reduction in group territorial size. The distribution of Pisgah Ridge chert projectile points shown in Figure 16-6, offers additional information on Richland Creek phase settlement patterns. As noted previously, during the Late Archaic this marker chert showed a significant decrease in areal distribution compared with the Middle Archaic. A further decrease is noted for the Late Prehistoric period overall, and suggests that Richland Creek group territory size decreased. Data on intrasite feature and artifact patterns are available for this phase from the extensive investigations undertaken at the Irvine site. Based on the spatial distribution of A horizon artifacts (see Chapter 12, this volume), scraping was selectively undertaken to expose features which are only visible in the subsurface B horizon. On the basis of this information, three types of features were observed at the site: large pits (generally larger than 9 m in greatest dimension), small pits (between .5 and 3 m in diameter), and post holes. The post holes were found to occur either isolated or ina cluster. At first, the cluster of post holes was suspected to be the location of house, and it was thought that we were simply unable to detect the remainder of the house pattern. However, subsequent work at other sites in the reservoir has shown that this same intrasite pattern existed during other time periods, and we 2 1 1 1 1 i 2 1 3 2 1 47 166 5 7 4 4 2 5 10 2 82 9 2 li 3 11 4 3 1 31 19 72 8 3 205 208 2 114 12 now believe that a complete circular or rectangular arrangement of post holes is not present. Instead, the post hole cluster was the entire pattern, and we simply do not have a neat, circular or square arrangement of post holes. This indicates that instead of the substantially built structures observed at Bird Point Island, less substantial and more impermanent shelters were constructed at the Irvine site. Perhaps something existed on the order of the structures described by Sjoberg (1953:287) for the Tonkawa. These were described as "brush shelters,” with a haphazard framework of poles and branches used to form a cone-shaped structure, with grass thatching and hides placed over top (Sjoberg 1953:287). An additional feature that was encountered at this site is an organic darkening of the soil, or a midden. This is the earliest time period for which this characteristic has been found, and suggests that more intense activity took place at the site during the Richland Creek phase. Specific tasks that could result in this type of soil staining include cooking, food processing, and trash disposal (Cook and Heizer 1965). This evidence, in combination with the presence of the post hole cluster which likely represents a structure location, argues for longer use of the site than occurred during the Late Archaic. More specifically, a semi-sedentary habitation is suggested. This shift to a greater degree of sedentism may be the consequence of the decreased group territorial sizes; this issue is addressed in more detail in a later section of this chapter. An important technological innovation that occurred within this phase was the introduction of the bow and arrow (Figure 18- 5). However, dart points are also found and indicate that both the dart and the atlati as well as the bow and arrow were used. ROUND PRAIRIE PHASE: A.D. 900 TO 1300 The Round Prairie phase components provide the best samples of artifacts and features of any time period within the RCAP. In addition, the extensive excavations conducted at the Bird Point Island site have resulted in substantial information on intrasite patterning of a Round Prairie phase community. Consequently, these combined data sets permit more detailed statements to be made on prehistoric lifeways during this phase. Eight sites are observed during this phase: three major occupations, four minor occupations, and a single creek bank location (Figure 18-8). This phase occurs during the Environmental Period II, a time of slowly increasing aridity. As argued earlier, this dry period is part of a large-scale trend that began first in the southern part of Texas and slowly spread northward, The time of arrival of this event in the reservoir is uncertain, and consequently it is difficult to model the area's vegetation. In all likelihood, the savannah environment that is proposed to have dominated the area covered today by the Blackland Prairie would have been declining. Based on records of historical droughts, this shift in vegetation from woodland to grassland would have begun on the western margin of this biotic zone and proceeded eastward. Since the RCAP is located on the eastern margin of this zone, the full impact of the drying trend may not have been felt until after the Round Prairie phase. Several lines of evidence pertaining to Round Prairie phase settlement patterns are discussed here. The first is the relatively high number of components relating to this phase. When the numbers of sites are corrected for the temporal duration of the phase, an overall decrease in components is seen when compared with the preceding Richland Creek phase. More specifically, eight components are observed for the 400 years of the Round Prairie phase, in contrast to the eight components of the 200 year span of the Richland Creek phase. However, it should be pointed out that these temporal ranges are only estimates based primarily on radiocarbon dates. Despite having several dates for each phase, the differences in length of occupation may be due in part to our inability to accurately measure phase lengths. It is perhaps safest to conclude that the number of sites is comparable to the previous Richland Creek phase, and that a similar population level existed. ST. ELMO PHASE: (A.D. 1300 TO A.D. 1650) A reduced number of sites dating to the St. Elmo phase is noted in the reservoir (Figure 18-9). Major occupations are noted at two sites, minor occupations at two, and creek bank activity at one. Despite the reduced number of sites, extensive work has been conducted at two sites (Bird Point Island and Little Cedar Creek), and the data from the St. Elmo components at these sites provides substantial insight into economic strategies and intrasite community patterning during this phase. Consequently, these two sites are used to model most of the following statements about lifeways. The environment during this phase is proposed to have been significantly drier in comparison to previous periods. Overbank flooding along Richland Creek had virtually ceased, and a significant decrease in rainfall is the postulated cause. It must be stressed that these statements are relative, and that the decrease in rainfall was lower in relationship to previous periods. In fact, the data from the RCAP indicate that the climate during this period may not have been significantly different from today's. Several significant vegetational changes within the RCAP can be assumed to have occurred as a result of the climatic change. First, the lack of deposition on the floodplain of Richland Creek and its major tributaries would have permitted a climax forest to become established, in contrast to the highly variable mosaic of vegetational succession that occurred previously. Floodplain vegetation would have been much as depicted in the descriptions presented earlier in this chapter for the Bottomland Forest zone. The upland areas along Richland Creek would have developed into the Tall Grass Prairie that is locally termed the Blackland Prairie.

The same major classes observed at Bird Point Island are represented at both the Little Cedar Creek and Bird Point Island sites, the two components where sample sizes are sufficient for comparison. However, two projectile point styles do occur with greater frequency: Perdiz and Cliffton. Ceramic styles also show some change. Although the same grog, grit, and bone tempered ware is common, vessel decorations show the dominance of incisions and engraving over punctations and incisions. The percentages of identifiable faunal remains by component are shown in Tabie 18-5. A decrease is observed in the number of species exploited when compared with earlier phases. Specifically, during the St. Elmo phase, no turkey, opossum, or beaver were found. These species either prefer more wooded conditions (turkey; Ellis and Lewis 1967) or occur within close proximity to wetland resources (opossum and beaver; Smith 1975). Interestingly, both the Little Cedar Creek and Bird Point Island sites contain bison. This species is present in very low frequency, but its occurrence supports the environmental interpretation that grasslands were in close proximity to the RCAP. In fact, the decrease in turkey, opossum, and beaver may also be reflecting this drier condition. Since turkeys prefer at least 70% tree cover (Ellis and Lewis 1967), a reduction in the woodland habitat is suggested by the absence of this species. The lack of opossum and beaver may imply that the floodplain environment was not as wet as before. In addition to a decrease in the variability of species exploited, a substantially higher number of deer and a reduced number of turtle were utilized at both Bird Point Island and Little Cedar Creek. A hunting strategy concentrating more upon whitetail deer is evident. The fact that both sites show this trend argues that it represents a broad cultural pattern and is not due to an opportunistic factor, as discussed for previous phases. Relatively well preserved floral samples are observed for the sites of this phase (Table 18-6). In comparison with previous phases, an important change is evident. Maize appears for the first time in the reservoir, and the complete absence of this food resource from all earlier time periods convincingly places its adoption in the RCAP area after A.D. 1300. Maize utilization, however, was very limited, and was clearly only a supplement to a diet based on wild plant and animal exploitation. The low incidence of this food could indicate that either it was grown locally or that it was traded from neighboring groups (Fritz 1985); both methods of maize aquisition are documented for historic Indians of Texas (Newcomb 1961). Other wild plant remains were present in much the same frequencies observed for earlier phases. Hickory nutshell was the most common plant by weight, and representation by all major 247 plant groupings was observed. It is perhaps significant that a drop in the occurrence of wild seeds occurred in comparison with the Round Prairie and the Richland Creek phases (Table 18-6). As Table 18-7 shows, a wide variety of seed was still present, but each type was represented by low numbers. Importantly, sumpweed, the most common species during the previous phases, was present, but not abundant. The low frequency of seeds may in fact represent accidental inclusions in prehistoric hearths and not intentional collection and utilization as foods. Another means of examining the relative importance of the floral remains is by looking at the percentage of all features which possess a given species (Table 18-9). This method shows that corn was more common than is suggested by the weight data alone, although corn was present in only a portion of the features from each site of this phase. Hickory nutshell was the most frequent plant remain, followed by Psoralea and acorn. Overall, other than the presence of maize, the floral assemblage is quite similar to previous phases, and no significant changes in economic strategy are apparent. As noted earlier, the introduction of maize seems to have served only as a supplement to the existing wild food diet. HUNTER-GATHERERS OF THE PRAIRIE MARGIN: BEHAVIORAL TRENDS IN THE DATA In this section we attempt to move beyond the culture-historical and lifeways discussions and examine certain behavioral trends in the RCAP data. Our selection of trends for examination has by no means been meant to cover all, or even a wide number of, possible behavioral problems. A great many important, and potentially answerable, questions are applicable to the RCAP data. Instead, we have chosen as our emphasis what for us are the two most intriguing issues in the overall data base: (1) the persistence of a hunting and gathering economic strategy and (2) the emergence of cultural complexity within the RCAP. The first problem concerns the continuation of a hunting and gathering economic strategy throughout all periods of reservoir prehistory, despite interaction with agricultural groups (the Caddo) less than SO km to the east. Although some evidence of maize use was found in the St. Elmo phase components (A.D. 1300 to 1650), this plant food occurred late in the archaeological record and was only a minor supplement at best. In contrast, the Caddoan groups to the east were much more dependent on this plant food (Briseth and Perttula 1981; Perttula and Bruseth 1983; Story 1981), and the hunter-gatherers of the RCAP would have had the opportunity to adopt a similar economic strategy. We examine the reasons behind this difference in economic patterns of two neighboring groups. ~ The second behavioral problem concerns the emergence of cultural complexity along the Prairie Margin. As Price and Brown (1985:3) have recently commented, hunter-gatherers are all too often simplistically characterized as small, ephemeral groups of people who eat, sleep, scrape hides, and only occasionally reproduce. Notions of cultural complexity, as evidenced by permanent habitations, food storage, organized cemeteries, etc., are usually associated with more “advanced” economic strategies (e.g., horticulture). A few notable exceptions to this have been observed (e.g., the Northwest Coast Indians), but these have largely been viewed as unusual cases. An ever increasing body of archaeological data is accumulating which indicates that complex social and cultural forms have arisen many times among hunting and gathering societies (Winters 1969; Hayden 1981; Testart 1982; Price and Brown 1985). It appears that models based on contemporary hunter-gatherers have not provided us with a representative sample of the range of patterns that have existed in prehistory (Price and Brown 1985:6). Along the Prairie Margin, significant changes in hunter- gatherer complexity are apparent over time. These changes are evident in the size and degree of interaction with surrounding groups, in the types and permanence of habitation sites, and in the

THE PERSISTENCE OF A HUNTING AND GATHERING ECONOMY As noted above, a hunting and gathering lifestyle was maintained throughout the prehistoric time frame of the RCAP. Some evidence of the use of maize was found late in the archaeological sequence (post-A.D. 1300), but the relative rarity of this food suggests that it served only as a minor supplement. In this section we examine the reasons behind this persistence of a hunting and gathering lifestyle. It is useful for this discussion to make comparisons with the Late Prehistoric archaeological record from the Caddoan archaeological area, located less than 50 km from the Project area. Although evidence from this area on economic plant and animal uses has only recently been systematically collected, sufficient data from several sites are available for comparison. These data offer a useful contrast between neighboring groups which employed different economic strategies, yet based on common ceramic styles maintained close interaction. At a basic level two factors, either individually or collectively, would seem to be responsible for the difference in economic strategies observed between the two areas. The first is the types of soils of the Prairie Margin. It is a well known fact that the Tall Grass Prairie is situated on dense clay soils, unlike the woodlands to the east which are located on lighter sandier soils. Lynott (1981:106) has argued that the tough prairie sod was too difficult to cultivate to permit prehistoric agriculture to become widespread, and that this was the major limiting factor upon prehistoric agriculture. The second contributing factor is differential rainfall. Maize needs adequate moisture during the early part of the growing season to properly mature and to produce kernels for human consumption and for successive plantings. Perhaps deficient rainfall was responsible for the RCAP inhabitants not becoming agricultural. We examine each of these factors in more detail below. SOIL VARIABILITY Soils are the product of five factors: (1) mineralogical composition of the parent material, (2) climate, (3) plant and animal activity within the soil, (4) topography, and (5) the time during which climate and plant and animal acitivity have had to act upon the parent material (Fisher 1965:11). These factors have interacted to produce three broad groupings of soils over North Central and East Texas. In the forested portions of the area (Post Oak Savannah and Oak-Hickory-Pine Forest), alfisols and ultisols are found (Godfrey et al. 1973). These are lightly colored, fine sandy loams and clays with subsoils (B horizons) consisting of red to orange loamy sands to plastic clays (Fisher 1965:14). Although the natural fertility of the soils varies greatly, most are suitable for some degree of primitive horticulture (Keller 1974). In marked contrast, the soils of the Tall Grass Prairie are vertisols, and are the product of weathering of calcareous clays, marls, and chalks (Fisher 1965:14). The resulting soils are dark grey to black, friable clays, with pH values in the alkaline range. Although these soils are often high in natural fertility, the dense structural property results in poor water movement and horticultural crops such as maize often do poorly because of the poor soil drainage. Moreover, as observed earlier, the native Tall Grass Prairie would have created a dense root mat which would have been difficult to penetrate with primitive cultivating tools (e.g., wooden or bison scapula hoes). The final group of soils of the area is found in the floodplains of the creeks and streams that transect the region; these soils are termed alluvial entisols (Godfrey et al. 1973). A wide variety of Volume III, Part Two soil types is actually found in this group since each floodplain reflects the upland soils surrounding the stream (Fisher 1965:14). Within the forested areas of the region, alluvial soils are mostly light gray and light gray-brown colored clays, loams, and sands. Within the vertisols of the prairie, denser floodplain soils of dark colors are found. Although many of these soils have high natural fertility, they are generally poor for agriculture due to periodic inundation and poor soil drainage. Initially, then, there does seem to be support for the hypothesis that the Tall Grass Prairie soils were generally poor for prehistoric agriculture, whereas the soils to the east were better. The chief reason seems to be the permeability of the soils, with the sandy loams of the eastern part of the state draining better than the clays of the prairie. However, within the Post Oak Savannah the sandy loam soils better suited to horticulture are dominant. Since a significant portion of the RCAP is located within the Post Oak Savannah, and in fact much of the Project data is from sites of this zone, the presence or absence of sandy soils cannot be a determining factor for the presence or absence of maize horticulture. In fact, even within the Tall Grass Prairie zone, a "double dendritic” pattern of sandy soils paralleling major creeks and streams is found (Schmidly 1983: 143). These sandy soils are remnants from Pleistocene environments (Sorenson et al. 1976) and tend to occur on terraces within the stream valleys. Thus, even in the prairie environment, significant areas of potentially tillable soil occur which could have been farmed. Soil type could not have been a limiting factor on prehistoric farming activity. DIFFERENTIAL RAINFALL The argument for this factor is quite simple: without adequate moisture you cannot grow maize. The easiest manner in which to judge if sufficient rainfall occurred within the RCAP to support prehistoric agricuture is to examine modern rainfall patterns over the state. Figure 18-10 shows annual rainfall isopleths for North Central and East Texas. An east-west gradient exists, with the OQak- Hickory-Pine forest of the east receiving the greatest amounts of rainfall. However, the RCAP area lies between the 36 and 40 inch per year isopleths, and although it receives less rainfall than East Texas, substantial moisture still is received, Wedel (1961:32) has argued that primitive maize agriculture would have only been possible in the Midwest east of the 97th meridian. To the west of this zone, generally less than 20 inches of rainfall per year is received. Although the distribution of rainfall throughout the year is most important to maize horticulture, generally unfavorable conditions are found below 20 inches in annual rainfall. The RCAP is located to the east of the 97th meridian, and receives almost twice the minimal amount of annual precipitation. Importantly for maize farming, the majority of this rainfall comes during the spring and early summer, the critical period of maize development (Keller 1974), Rainfall patterns, therefore, are adequate in the RCAP for maize horticulture. Affecting these assessments, however, are the potentially complicating problems of paleoclimate and periodic drought. In Chapter 5 of Volume I, the paleoenvironment for the Project area was assessed based on data collected as part of the RCAP and on information from other projects. Significant changes in the past climate of the Project area were outlined, and have been summarized at the beginning of this chapter. Despite these changes which have resulted in periods of markedly different rainfall, the climate of today is thought to be similar to that experienced during the driest period of the last 3000 years, with the exception of periods of severe but temporary drought. This information means that, if anything, the rainfall patterns for past groups in the RCAP would have been similar if not greater than observed today. Drought is a different matter, since historical records show that it influences maize production in the state (Story 1981:Table 2). Periods of drought, moreover, tend to occur more frequently within the Midwest than other parts of the country and tend to occur over consecutive years (Bochert 1950). Both East and Central Texas are plagued by droughts, and often times a dry

Importantly, despite periodic drought, corn was grown and harvested in quantities to be a staple by the historic Wichita of North Central Texas (Newcomb 1961:253-254) and by the historic Caddo of East Texas (Swanton 1942). In addition, significant quantities of corn have been found from prehistoric contexts in North Central Texas at the eleventh century Cobb-Pool site in Dallas County (Fritz 1986) and several Caddoan sites in East Texas (Perttula and Bruseth 1983). Thus, drought would no doubt have created instability in prehistoric farming, but similar detrimental factors were experienced by groups to the east and west of the RCAP who were able to produce maize crops. Periodic droughts, therefore, could not have been a limiting factor preventing the inhabitants of the Project area from adopting an economic strategy dependent on maize agricuture. THE POST OAK SAVANNAH AS AN "AFFLUENT RESOURCE" ZONE We are left then with no clear reason for the difference in economy between the Late Prehistoric inhabitants of the Project area and the Caddo of East Texas. Neither the factor of variability in soil types nor differing rainfall patterns adequately accounts for the persistence of a hunting and gathering economic strategy. To find an alternative solution to this problem, we must first review our understanding about why groups adopt agriculture in the first place. It has, until recently, been an accepted assumption that cultures, once confronted with the option of growing their food instead of having to rely upon wild harvests, will automatically do so. Implicit in this assumption is the belief that self-production is somehow “better” and that all cultures will share this view of food production. More recent assessments of the shift from total reliance upon food collection to combined food collection and food production, view the addition of domestic food products simply as one more supplement to the diet (Testart 1982:530; Hayden 1981:520). In fact, given the option, most groups would 249 instead opt for increased mobility and “mapping onto” wild resources instead of the reduced mobility that horticulture requires (Binford 1980; Cohen 1985; Woodburn 1980). Thus, the relevant question is not "why did the RCAP inhabitants not adopt agriculture?” but "why did the RCAP inhabitants not have to adopt agriculture?” The answer to this question lies in the nature of the environment of the RCAP. As outlined earlier in this chapter, three major biotic zones occur within the RCAP: Post Oak Savannah, Tall Grass Prairie, and the Bottomland Forest. Immediately to the east, the Oak-Hickory-Pine Forest is found, and is the heartland of the Caddoan archaeological area. The native resources within each zone which may have supplied important parts of the prehistoric diet are listed in Table 18-10. The abundance of each species within a given zone is indicated as either “highly abundant,” “moderately abundant," “infrequent,” or “absent.” These assessments represent subjective appraisals based on modem biological studies and quantification of data provided in the Texas General Land Office records (see Bruseth 1987). Table 18-10 also shows the total number of highly abundant species within each zone. This figure is used to compare the potential importance of each zone for prehistoric utilization. Two zones tie for the greatest number of abundant species: Post Oak Savannah and Bottomland Forest. Each has five abundant species. Although this would suggest that each zone was approximately comparable for prehistoric exploitation, this is not necessarily the case. For example, the Post Oak Savannah has a high abundance of acorns, Psoralea, and deer-the three species most easily exploited in large biomass quantities, and three of the four species that formed the bulk of the prehistoric diet in the Project area. The fourth species that formed a staple in the prehistoric diet was hickory nuts, and this species would have been moderately abundant in the Post Oak Savannah and highly abundant in the Bottomland Forest. The other two zones, Oak-Hickory-Pine Forest and Tall Grass Prairie, each show only a single abundant resource. In the case of the Tall Grass Prairie this indicates a marginal environment in terms of prehistoric ultilization. However, the Oak-Hickory-Pine Forest's total of one abundant resource is misleading since several species are shown that occur in moderate abundance, and the overall biomass potential of this zone would have been substantially greater than the Tall Grass Prairie. Although the Oak-Hickory-Pine Forest would have not been as important to prehistoric groups as the Post Oak Savannah or the Bottomland Forest, it certainly would have ranked third in food potential. It is evident, then, that the Post Oak Savannah was a biotic zone with a high number of key resources. Table 18-1 shows that of the trees that were encountered by early Texas land surveyors in the 1850s, oak and hickory trees made up nearly 95% of all species encountered. This means that almost all of the trees of this zone would have represented key food resources for the inhabitants of the RCAP. Comparable data from the Oak-Hickory-Pine Forest show that oaks and hickories would only have accounted for 72% and from the Bottomland Forest these trees would have amounted to only 43%. Thus, the Post Oak Savannah would have had the highest relative occurrence of nut producing trees. In absolute numbers, however, this zone would have had fewer trees overall, since by definition it was a savannah environment. The trees would have been either isolated occurrences or in clusters and separated from other trees by small “pocket” prairies. Importantly for prehistoric utilization, such conditions actually favor nut production in trees, since the entire crown can receive ample sunlight (Asch and Asch 1978:317). Forests cause severe competition for light and only the tops of many trees receive sufficient light. Modern studies of nut production have shown that isolated hickory trees average about cight times the quantity of nuts by weight than similar trees in forests (Talalay et al., 1984:342). This factor of nut production would have far more than compensated for the dispersed nature of the tree distribution in the Post Oak Savannah, and in fact would have made the area a prime region for nut collection.

Although this plant is relatively rare today, possibly due to increased grazing and land cultivation, the distributions of modern species show that it prefers sandy soils and limestone outcrops (Correll and Johnston 1970:813-817). Psoralea latestipulata, the species most probably exploited by the Richland Creek inhabitants (Fritz 1982), specifically prefers rocky or sandy prairies (Mahler 1984:159). Thus, in the vicinity of the RCAP, the most likely location of this plant food would have been in the Post Oak Savannah since this is the only area of suitable sandy soils, and rocky soils are not found in the Project area. Although this plant could also have grown in the sandy soils further to the east in the Oak-Hickory-Pine Forest, it has not been found in macrofloral remains (cf., Bruseth and Perttula 1981) and may not have been a common element of local flora. Since the plant's omnipresence at RCAP sites indicates it was a staple during much of prehistory, Psoralea was no doubt harvestable in large quantities from nearby sources. Whitetail-deer is another food resource that was important to the prehistoric inhabitants of the RCAP and that would have been abundant in the Post Oak Savannah. Although deer would have been found in all biotic zones, they would have been most frequent in the Post Oak Savannah. Since the primary food of deer is browse (Lay 1969:8), the relative abundance of this animal is tied to the frequency of this resource. Browse, consisting of leaves and twigs of woody plants, is commonly found along edge areas and would have been frequenjin the open woodland of the Post Oak Savannah. In climax forest settings, these plant foods are limited, and as a result deer generally avoid such settings for this reason except during the fall when mast is available (Smith 1975:34). Deer are primarily a species of the edge area environment (Servinghaus and Cheatum 1956:137). Additionally, the higher incidence of nut producton in the Post Oak Savannah would also have contributed to a high deer population. Deer are attracted to fresh green growth of woody plants and forbs (Cook 1984:467), and they would have frequented the disturbed parts of the floodplains where vegetational succession was taking place. We can conclude, then, that deer would have been most frequent in the Post Oak Savannah, less frequent but present in the Bottomland Forest and the Oak-Hickory-Pine Forest, and relatively rare in the Tall Grass Prairie. In the Tall Grass Prairie, deer would have been Volume III, Part Two largely confined to forested areas of stream valleys (Schmidly 1983:296). A final important, but non-food, resource that would have been abundant in the Post Oak Savannah is Wilcox sandstone. As observed at Bird Point Island (see Volume II, Part One), this stone was collected and heated for earth oven roasting. The roasting process was used both to prepare foods for immediate consumption and to preserve them for delayed consumption. Hilliard (1980:16), in describing processing of hickory nuts, notes that roasting stops the process of germination by removing the moisture content, makes the shells easier to remove, and kills larvae that might have infested the nuts. Beneficial effects of roasting can also be assumed for some of the other foods. For instance, roasting would also have been a means of drying Psoralea tubers and animal meat. Importantly, many of the plant foods used by the RCAP inhabitants are seasonally specific and require immediate collection and preservation if they are to be used as stores for other parts of the year. Specifically, Psoralea matures and flowers during the first two weeks of May and must be collected during this time. Prior to this, the tuber is too small and premature collection will result in under-exploitation of the resource. After the optimum harvest date, the top withers and blows away, making the detection of the tuber very difficult (Kaye and Moodie 1978:331-332). Acorns and nuts present a different scheduling problem since they fall from trees and lie on the ground. However, studies have shown that non-human scavengers such as squirrels and deer and coverage by leaf litter can severely limit yields (Asch and Asch 1978:317; Talalay et al. 1984). Exploitation is most profitably undertaken immediately after the major period of nut fall, usually shortly before or after the first fall freeze. Thus, the Wilcox sandstone would have been an important resource that permitted the abundant but seasonally specific plant resources of the Post Oak Savannah to be efficiently processed for storage. Getting back to our original question of why a hunting and gathering economy persisted in the RCAP, and the corollary question of why maize horticulture was not employed, we are now in a position to provide some answers. The Post Oak Savannah offered an abundance of all key food resources in close proximity. In this sense, the Post Oak Savannah can be considered to have been an “affluent resource” zone (cf., Thomas and Kayama 1982), where natural abundant resources made maize horticulture unnecessary. In terms of nutrition, deer would have supplied the principal source of protein, acorns and hickory nuts significant sources of fats and carbohydrates, and Psoralea tubers additional carbohydrates. In addition, fruits, berries, and wild seeds would have been available at various times of the year in the Post Oak Savannah and the Bottomland Forest zones, and would have provided important dietary supplements such as vitamins. Com would have merely added carbohydrates to a diet already rich in carbohydrates obtained from acorn and from Psoralea tubers, so it would not have contributed significantly to nutritional quality of the diet. In essence, the natural food base was able to supply the essential food elements to maintain a healthy diet. The occurrence of Wilcox sandstone provided the capability to process these resources, and allowed the seasonal abundances to be turned into year-round staples. Given these locally abundant resources, there was no motivation to change the hunting and gathering strategy by adopting agriculture. EMERGENCE OF CULTURAL COMPLEXITY As noted at the beginning of this section, hunter-gatherers have only recently begun to be viewed as having intricate cultural forms. Complex societies of hunter-gatherers have developed in the absence of agriculture, and the importance of food production in the developmental process is being downplayed (Brown 1985:201). In this section, we examine the emergence of cultural complexity in the RCAP and attempt to explain why it occurred.
