As a heuristic device to facilitate our explanation, we present a model of the organizational alternatives that interact to make a given group complex or simple (Figure 18-11). We realize that our model is somewhat simplistic, summarizing human behavior by the interaction of only a few factors. However, to make any model comprehensible, it is necessary to simplify the multitude of factors contributing to human behavior to a few key elements which account for most of the variability. Our model is intended to serve as a starting point for understanding the development of hunter-gatherer complexity in North Central Texas which can later be ammended when new data come to light. The basic assumption of this model is that hunter-gatherer behavior is directed towards obtaining sufficient food resources to satisfy the needs of the group. Unlike models of optimal foraging where the emphasis is placed on individual foraging behavior (Smith 1983), the emphasis in our model is on group behavior. We argue that the overall group, whether it be an extended family or the entire band, interacts in such a manner as to provide a synergistic effect resulting in a greater diversity of options than are present to the individual. The model furthermore assumes that hunter-gatherers are resource managers, consciously selecting among a series of alternative strategies to provide an adequate food supply. Given a stable and abundant set of resources, equilibrium will exist between people and the environment (Brown 1985:208) and natural biological mechanisms (Hayden 1981:521) will hold population in check. This condition appears to have existed during the Early and Middle Archaic periods, and the RCAP evidence suggests egalitarian bands existed that were characterized by fluid group organization, relatively easy access to resources, immediate consumption of those resources, and lack of food storage technology. Under such a condition, a resource management strategy of high residential mobility was employed (Figure 18-12) whereby the group moved from resource to resource to overcome seasonal and spatial inequities in natural food distribution. Story (1985), in a recent overview of the Archaic of the western Gulf Coastal Plain, has argued for a change from the Early to the Middle Archaic noted by increased population, the first appearance of organized cemeteries, and the probable beginning of group territories. Variations in site size and type additionally suggest that group composition was variable and depended upon the seasonal and spatial variation in resources (Story 1985:41-43), Since within the RCAP few data are available for the Early and Middle Archaic, we cannot evaluate whether this statement holds for the immediate Project area and we are unable to differentiate complexity between these two periods. As noted earlier in this chapter, the first significant data from the RCAP for limits on population and territory size come from the Middle Archaic. This evidence, principally in the form of chert distributions, indicates a large but defined territorial area. Insufficient data exist from the Early Archaic to determine if this pattern was established prior to the Middle Archaic. Against this baseline of low-level hunter-gatherer complexity, we can begin to examine the emergence of complexity and the causes behind it. According to our model, two factors can cause a change in the basic equilibrium between resource abundance and resource need (Figure 18-11). The first factor is population change. Specifically, an increase in the population requires some change in the energy capture strategy be implemented to increase the food base. As the model shows, a number of alternative strategies is available to change the overall resource management approach. It should be added that not all possibilities available to hunter-gatherers are considered in the model, For example, Bender (1978) has argued that social factors have an important place in the development of hunter-gatherer complexity. Our choice of strategies has emphasized those factors that can be tested ‘with the RCAP data, and we do not possess adequate control to test the importance of complexity that may have arisen as a result of social influences. The other factor that can upset the equilibrium is change in the environment. It is probable that neither factor alone caused a change in the balance between the natural resource base and the human needs. In nonfluctuating environments, natural biological controls act to keep population down, and it is in fluctuating environments that populations rise or fall (Brown 1985:208). Thus, although we stress the importance of environmental and population factors as intiating changes in the cultural system, neither is a direct "prime mover.” Together they interact to alter the cost curves of resource management strategies and consequently foster a change in those strategies (Earle 1980). The first period of detectable change is during the Transitional/Late Archaic (1000 B.C.‘ to A.D. 700) where a variety of paleoecological data from along the Prairie Margin of Texas suggests that relatively moist conditions were present (see Chapter 5, Volume I). Specifically within the Project area, this corresponds to Environmental Period I when much of the area today covered by the Tall Grass Prairie is proposed to have been a savannah environment. The floodplain of Richland Creek was rapidly aggrading and would pave contained vegetation in various states of succession. In terms of our resource management model, these more favorable environmental conditions would have permitted population to increase. Greater densities of nut producing trees would have been available, as well as increased populations of deer and other edge area species, The Late Archaic population increase is reflected in the greater numbers of sites and in the higher numbers of artifacts at sites. The distribution of Pisgah Ridge chert, as noted earlier in this chapter, shows that group territorial size significantly decreased, most likely in response to the increased numbers of people. The roasting activity was for food preparation associated with ritual feasting and for processing food for later consumption. The latter function is an important technological adaptation, in that this is the first evidence of storage activity within the RCAP and represents a major advancement over previous periods (cf., Testart 1982). As noted earlier, during the Middle Archaic only small, apparently single episode, roasting pits were used, suggesting a strategy of food processing for immediate consumption (Woodburn 1980:99). At a broader level, the large depressions are proposed to have functioned as sociological and ideological symbols. A prominent feature of the Prairie Margin of Texas is the abundance of key food resources (e.g., Psoralea, acorns, and hickory nuts), yet these resources are noted by marked seasonality and spatial inequity. As noted earlier, the Post Oak Savannah biotic zone contained these food items in abundance; however, this zone is a narrow, Volume III, Part Two northeast-southwest oriented strip, and in the vicinity of the Project area this zone is less than 40 km wide. Depending upon the size of the Late Archaic territories, it is quite possible, even probable, that individual group ranges were much larger than could be contained within this area, even compensating for the increased size of the savannah during this mesic environmental period. The distribution of Pisgah Ridge chert demonstrates this fact, with a maximum distance of 70 km between known specimens. Given the increase in population and the concomitant decrease in group territory, environmental and social circumscription (Carniero 1970) would have existed and competition would have occurred over access to key resources. In addition, the reduced territories would have made high residential mobility a risky strategy for resource management, since groups would become more vulnerable to local fluctuations in plant and animal availability (cf., Ford 1979:236). For example, if acorn production significantly decreased in one group's territory, movement to better yielding trees may not have been a possible option if the better trees were in another group's range. A common means by which contemporary hunter-gatherers cope with this problem is through risk sharing (Wiessner 1982; Gould 1982). Generalized reciprocity (Service 1978) is maintained with neighboring groups, and social obligations are stored through feasting, exchange, and gift giving. Band coalescence at the sites with large depressions is proposed to have served this purpose. During periods when local resources were scarce, band aggregation would allow for redistribution of foods to those groups in need. Under conditions of better harvest, feasting and general socialization would serve to store obligations for future resource shortfalls. In addition the depressions were used for human burial, and as such served as cemeteries. This is the earliest known occurrence of cemeteries in the Project area, and marks the emergence of inheritance of critical and restricted food resources. As Charles and Buikstra (1983:121} have noted, “...the remains of one's ancestors on the land...provide a very strong argument for ownership.” Thus, the large depressions at Adams Ranch and Bird Point Island also served as territorial markers for local hunter- gatherer groups. As argued in Chapter 21 of Volume II, the location of these features may indicate prehistoric “tension zones,” where due to factors of geography, vegetation, or social interaction local groups came into contact more often. This pattern of territorial marking through defined cemeteri¢s is part of a larger trend noted throughout the western Gulf Coast Plain (Story 1985). ip summary, during the Late Archaic an increase in population is evident and was likely enabled by a mesic climatic interval. The Early and Middle Archaic strategy of high residential mobility was favored during the Late Archaic, but a reduction in group territorial size necessitated a change in management strategies. The reduction created a certain degree of instability because greater dependence was placed on the resources within a smaller area. Although overall environmental conditions were moister, periodic droughts nonetheless would have occurred and created stress upon certain groups. This resource stress was minimized through risk sharing with other hunter-gatherer groups, and by marking territorial boundaries with cemeteries to identify individual group claims to critical resource areas. Thus, we see a rise in cultural complexity compared with the previous Archaic groups, despite a persistence of the basic strategy of residential mobility. During the Richland Creek phase (A.D. 700 to 900) further changes in hunter-gatherer resource management strategies are observed, and may be related to a further increase in population. However, as noted earlier, this is a period of uncertain environmental impact upon the RCAP area. Corings from peat bogs located around the Project area have provided a pollen record indicating the beginning of a regional drying trend. However, the floodplain of Richland Creek was still actively alluviating and shows that significant moisture was falling within the Richland Creek watershed. Under such conditions, the Richland Creek area might not have experienced the drier conditions until the following phase. A further reduction in group territory is clearly evident by the distribution of the Pisgah Ridge chert type and the greater number of sites of this phase suggests a further increase in population. These two factors required fundamental changes in the organizational strategies for effectively dealing with the abundance of natural food resources. The increased population and decreased territories acted together to diminish the food base on a per capita basis as a result of the Late Archaic exploitation system. Four changes in resource management dealt with this imbalance between availability and need: a change in the natural resource mix, adoption of new technology, increased use of resource storage techniques, and a change in mobility patterns. Each change is discussed in detail below. During the Late Archaic, deer and turtle seem to have been the primary faunal species exploited (Table 18-5), and hickory nuts, Psoralea tubers, and seeds were the primary plant foods (Table 18-6), Although the data are somewhat biased by generally poor preservation and small sample size, a case can be made for broader based exploitation during the Richland Creek phase. The relative importance of deer decreased, and a broader range of alternative species assumed a significant part of the diet. For example, cottontail rabbit is more frequent at 41FT161B, turtle is more common at Polecat Hill (41NV203), and fish is more abundant at the Irvine site (41NV182). Moreover, floral remains similarly show the use of a wide variety of plants. Based on the percentage of features with a given species (41NV182), significant representations are observed for hickory nuts, pecans, acorns, | Psoralea tubers, seeds, and rhizomes (Table 18-9). Although it is difficult to assess the relative importance of plant foods versus animal foods based on the economic data, there is support for a shift from K-selected to r-selected species (Hayden 1981:525-527) during the Richland Creek phase. Ecologists use the terms of K-~- and r-selection to describe the relative reproduction rates and abundance of plant and animal species. K- selected species are noted by reproduction with heavy investment in one or a few offspring which take considerable time to mature. These species tend to be mammals such as deer and are usually large in body weight. These species are also susceptible to over- exploitation. In contrast, r-selected species are small, live less than a year, and reproduce in considerable quantities. Plants such as nuts, seeds, and Psoralea would fall into this category. These species are difficult to eradicate by over-exploitation and re- establish themselves quickly. For a given unit of resource, however, they may require more labor input during exploitation. The pattern then, observed during the Richland Creek phase is a shift from reliance upon K-selected species, such as deer and perhaps turtle, to r-selected species. The most important r-selected species are a wider variety of plant foods including hickory nuts, pecans, Psoralea tubers, and seeds. Two important technological changes are observed during this phase: the bow and arrow and the marked increase in the storage of food. Ceramics were also incorporated into the material culture, but these were first observed during the Transitional phase of the Late Archaic and are not unique to the the Richland Creek phase. The importance of the bow and arrow was that it improved hunting effectiveness (Hayden 1981:519), which in tum altered the basic cost-curves for animal explotation. For example, certain species, such as birds, could be exploited more easily. Of even greater importance in terms of overall resource management was the storage of foods. Although we lack direct evidence for this activity (i.e., large numbers of storage pits), large roasting pits are found and contrast with the small, single episode roasting pits found at the Middle Archaic Hardy (41FT200) site. Table 18-11 displays the mean maximum feature length of pits by period or phase; only those features from known temporal contexts have been included. The Transitional/Late Archaic shows the largest pit size, but this is based solely on the two large depressions at the Adams Ranch and Bird Point Island sites since no other roasting 253 pits could be positively associated with this period. Thus the absence of other pits attributed to this phase cannot be taken to indicate that roasting activity did not take place in smaller pits, but only that we do not have adequate evidence for this activity. Comparing the size of pits from the Middle Archiac deposit at Hardy to the Richland Creek phase, a significant increase is observed in the latter. The average pit size is nearly four times greater, which we interpret as an indication of intensive processing of plant resources for storage. As noted previously, many of the key resources of the Post Oak Savannah are noted by marked seasonality and must be collected and processed within a short period of time. Storage technology is a means by which bountiful seasonal resources can be transformed through appropriate methods into year-round staples (Testart 1982:523). Roasting, to dehydrate the foods and prevent insect and bacterial infestation, was a primary means of making these foods delayed consumables. The final change in resource management strategy was a shift from high residential mobility to lower residential mobility and moderate logistical mobility (Figure 18-12). This is seen through two types of data, both concerning the nature of intrasite feature patterns, As noted earlier in this chapter, middens occur for the first time during this phase, and these organically enriched residues are thought to relate to more intensive use of the sites. Activities were repeatedly conducted in certain locations, resulting in the increase in soil organics. The other data relating to a change in mobility patterns is the internal layout of activities at the Irvine site. Here, three separate types of features are found: large pits, small pits, and post holes. The post holes are found either isolated or as parts of clusters, and the clusters are interpreted to represent the locations of houses. The lack of complete circular or rectangular post hole patterns suggests that a less permanent construction was used than observed during the subsequent Round Prairie phase at Bird Point Island. Richland Creek phase sites such as Irvine probably represent semisedentary occupations, and can be viewed as part of a pattern permitting more intensive exploitation of reduced territories (Binford 1980) and are an expectable outcome of an increased population. Foods are being intensively collected by small work groups and brought back to a base camp. In summary, during the Richland Creek phase a further increase in population may have occurred in response to a continued mesic climate for the immediate Project area. In comparison to the Late Archaic, characterized by high residential mobility and control of resource instability through risk sharing and defined ownership to key resources by territorial marking, the increased population of the Richland Creek phase made this strategy unfeasible. The reduced territories became too small to allow high residential mobility to be an effective strategy. Instead, a pattern of semisedentary occupation based on increased logistical mobility was established, with a greater exploitation of r-selected species such as nuts, acorns, and Psoralea. During the following Round Prairie phase (A.D. 900 to 1300), marked changes in the organization of strategies for resource management are evident and the trend is for continued increases in complexity. The changes are a further response to the continued high population coupled with an apparent environmental change in the Project area. As noted earlier, this phase existed during Environmental Period II, a period of a progressive drying that began in the southern part of the state and spread northward. The floodplain deposits along Richland Creek suggest that this dry period was being experienced in the RCAP during this time, and the net effect was a reduction in rainfall for the area in comparison with previous periods (see Chapter 5, Volume I for details). It is impossible to determine if group territories changed in size since the numbers of points made of Pisgah Ridge chert are small, and these were generally not diagnostic of particular Late Prehistoric phases. Nonetheless, the data suggest that a constant group range was maintained throughout the Late Prehistoric (Richland Creek, Round Prairie, and St. Eimo phases). In terms of population, a similar level to the Richland Creek phase is evident, and this combined with the degradation in the environment would

## Page 274

254 have created a further imbalance between the food needs and resource abundance given the Richland Creek phase strategies for resource management. As a result, a variety of adjustments are evident. The first adjustment is a further change in the mix of wild food resources. The shift from K-selected to r-selected resources suggested for the Richland Creek phase seems to have continued during the Round Prairie phase, where the lowest frequencies of deer are noted in the faunal assemblages. In addition, the highest frequencies of turtle use are seen, as well as the continued exploitation of a variety of other faunal resources. In terms of floral remains, a similar pattern of usage is evident with the exception that a slightly greater reliance was placed upon seed resources (Table 18-6). This intensification of seed usage is seen more clearly in Table 18-9, where the percentage of all features containing carbonized seeds is given. Seed use reached its highest point during the Round Prairie phase, when between 66.7 and 81.5 percent of the features contained seeds. Table 18-7 displays seeds types by period or phase. Two seed groups are the most important: sumpweed (Iva annua ) and vetch (Vicia sp.) or peavine (Lathyrus sp.). Sumpweed is a suggested cultigen in eastern North America (Asch and Asch 1978), although the sizes of the specimens from the Project area are within the range of wild specimens (Fritz 1985). The plant grows in edge areas between permanently wet and drier areas, and is harvestable in late summer or early fall (Asch and Asch 1978). Although this plant would have provided an important dietary supplement, it does not grow in sufficient stands to have provided a staple food source (Asch and Asch 1978:315). Less is known about the vetch or peavine specimens, Both are perennial herbs that produce seeds in late spring or early summer (Mahler 1984), and were probably collected to supplement the food base. Bioarchaeological studies of skeletal remains from the RCAP detect a change in dietary emphasis during this phase, supporting the observations made on the bases of the economic remains. Although the skeletal sample from the Project area is small, the trace element data from Bird Point Island indicate significant temporal trends related to dietary change (see Chapter 5, Volume Il). Specifically, the level of manganese and strontium suggests that nutritional changes were occurring around A.D. 1000. An increased reliance upon nuts during the Round Prairie phase in comparison with the Transitional/Late Achaic burials at the site is suggested as the cause. No burials attributable to the Richland Creek phase were available for analysis, and thus it cannot be determined if this trend began earlier. . The technological adoptions of the Richland Creek phase continued into the Round Prairie phase. The occurrence of arrow points was higher than in the previous phase, suggesting more hunting with this tool (Table 18-12). Importantly, the size of roasting pits increased during this phase (Table 18-11), and suggests that larger amounts of plant foods were being prepared for storage. The importance of roasting activity in the economic system can be seen at Bird Point Island where stockpiling of unburned Wilcox sandstone occurred. As noted in Chapter 14 of Volume II, this material is naturally found in a slough along the southern margin of the site. Since this part of the site is periodically inundated by spring floods, the stockpiling was evidently conducted during the dry season to ensure that ample supplies of this rock were on hand for processing. This activity was particularly necessary for Psoralea, since this plant reaches its maturity in the spring when creek flooding could inundate the outcrop of Wilcox sandstone. The most significant change during the Round Prairie phase was the near complete sedentism seen at Bird Point Island. This was a change to high logistical mobility (Figure 18-12), whereby all resources were brought into the central base camp. Although the site was almost certainly abandoned for short periods for collection of certain resources, the overall use of the site was year- round, The evidence for this comes from several sources. First, the substantially constructed houses, noted by complete circular patterns of post holes, argue for more labor involved in the construction of the structure which implies longer anticipated use. Volume III, Part Two Next, the floral and faunal data suggest use of the site during all seasons. For instance, the vetch, Psoralea, and certain fruits indicate a spring harvest. The knotweed and other weedy seeds are from summer flowering plants, and nuts are exploited in the fall. The deer remains from Zone I of Feature 1, which are related to this occupation and to the terminal, or St. Elmo, occupation, include antlers fused to the frontal bones and deer mandibles from individuals aged approximately 1.7 years. Since antlers are shed in the winter and deer are born in the spring, the antler and mandible remains indicate a fall/winter occupation. And finally, the well developed hearth from inside House 1 suggests that it was used for household heating as well as cooking, further supporting a winter use of the site. In summary, the Round Prairie phase occupations are noted by a further increase in cultural complexity in response to a constant high population level and a degraded environmental condition. A broad based economic exploitation was practiced, with increased reliance upon seeds (an r-selected resource) and decreased use of deer (a K-selected species). A settlement pattern of high logistical mobility is evident, whereby complete sedentism was reached at the Bird Point Island site. The final period of prehistory recognized within the RCAP is the St. Elmo phase (A.D. 1300 to 1650), and it records a change to a resource management strategy that is similar in many respects to the Richland Creek phase. The St. Elmo phase occurred within Environmental Period UI, a period of significantly decreased moisture and a time during which climatic conditions similar to today’s were reached. Alluviation of the Richland Creek floodplain virtually ceased, and a forest replaced the previous bottomland vegetation of mixed woodland and grassland. Tall grass prairies were established in the uplands around the western portions of the reservoir. Although the data are inconclusive as to whether a change in group territorial size occurred, the lower numbers of sites do indicate a decreased population, We suggest that the decreased population levels are a cultural response to the continued environmental degradation that began during the previous phase. As the model in Figure 18-11 shows, a possible strategy to bring resource abundance and resource needs into balance is to decrease population size. A number of means to achieve this have been observed ethnographically, including infanticide and limitations on coitus (Hayden 1972). Exactly what methods were used by the inhabitants of the RCAP is not known, but the net effect, based on the density of sites, was to decrease the numbers of people. The economic strategy also changed in terms of resource mix. Although deer, a K-selected species, was the most commonly exploited mammal during all periods, it was more commonly exploited during the St. Elmo phase relative to the Round Prairie phase, and accounts for percentages of all faunal remains similar to that observed during the Transitional/Late Archaic. As far as plant use is concerned, seeds decreased in occurrence and Psoralea was more common. Significantly, maize was introduced for the first time into the economic system. However, as argued earlier, it was found in very low quantities and likely was a minor supplement to the basically wild diet. In fact, the low occurrence of this plant food may indicate that it was traded from other groups rather than grown locally. Table 18-9, showing the percentage of features that contain a given species, records a similar plant mix to that observed for the Round Prairie phase. The major exception, of course, js the inclusion of maize in the diet. The bioarchaeological studies on human skeletal remains from Bird Point Island support the interpretation of dietary change based on the floral and faunal data, The two St. Elmo phase burials from the site had high levels of zinc observed by trace element analysis which was interpreted to indicate an increased level of meat consumption (see Chapter 5, Volume II). In addition, higher frequencies of dental calculus were observed, and this, combined with the high level of manganese for Burial 16, was suggested to indicate the addition of maize to the diet. The same technological innovations that were employed during the Round Prairie phase are observed during the St. Elmo phase.

For example, arrow points indicative of the bow and arrow technology are more common (Table 18-12). Perhaps this is tied to the increased incidence of deer remains, again suggesting a greater emphasis on hunting. Ceramics, first introduced in the Transitional phase of the Late Archaic, reach their most frequent usage. The meaning of this is uncertain, but it implies increased storage in portable containers. Roasting, and the implied processing of food for storage, continues but with some significant changes. As Table 18-11 indicates, the mean size of pits decreases and is similar to that observed during the Richland Creek phase. Interestingly, the standard deviation associated with the pit sizes also decreases and indicates that the pits were more consistent in size. That is, there are fewer of the large roasting pits, and the trend seems to be towards smaller roasting pits, perhaps indicating less processing of plant materials for long term storage. , These data indicate a settlement pattern change during the St Elmo phase to increased mobility. Specifically, a combination of moderate logistical and residential mobility (Figure 18-12), or semisedentism, is suggested. The internal site pattern of features is once again marked by large pits, small pits, and scattered post holes. Middens are also noted, and the overall pattern argues fora temporary site occupation where structures were constructed that resulted in only a few post holes penetrating into the B horizon and remaining to be detected today. These less permanent structures contrast with the more labor intensive houses constructed at Bird Point Island during the preceding Round Prairie phase. In summary, the St. Elmo phase occupation in the RCAP records a return to a more mobile existence. Although sites appear to be semisedentary, perhaps occupied during certain seasons of the year, some indicators suggest a degree of mobility more comparable to the Transitional/Late Archaic. For instance, the greater reliance upon deer, a K-selected species, is more in line with residential mobility whereby. consumers can move to a new area when this species has been over-hunted (Hayden 1981:525- 527). And finally, the lower incidence of large roasting pits indicates that fewer plant resource were being processed. Modern studies of mobile hunter-gatherers have shown that storage hinders group movement and is avoided (Testart 1982:527). Overall, a decrease in complexity is evident during the St. Elmo phase, and we argue is due indirectly to a continued degradation of the environment. SUMMARY During the course of testing and four seasons of mitigation for the RCAP, both paleoenvironmental data and archaeological data were collected in an effort to study the relationships between environmental change and human adaptation in the Richland Creek vicinity. The results of palynological and geomorphological studies were used to reconstruct three major periods of prehistoric environmental change, and the results of archaeological analysis were used to define the periods of prehistoric occupation, with 255 most data available for five major periods. The basic environmental data are presented in Volume I, and the basic archaeological data are presented in Volumes I and III along with interpretations which rely on ethnographically observed hunter- gatherer behavior to reconstruct the adaptive strategies employed during the various periods of prehistoric occupation. These interpretations move beyond the limited conclusions that can be formed by examining the sets of physical items preserved at each site. Instead, they encompass all data within a framework based on modern hunter-gatherer behavior, relating the physical remains of human adaptation (e.g., plant remains, structures) to the social behavior responsible for the creation of. features and the deposition of artifacts (e.g., risk sharing through reciprocity). The net result is a model of hunter-gatherer adaptation along the Prairie Margin based on responses to population change and environmental change, which is amenable to testing by future research projects. The evidence for environmental change within the RCAP is recorded in floodplain sediments from Richland and Chambers Creeks and pollen records from nearby bogs. Environmental Period I (3000 B.C. to A.D. 500) was moister than the present environment, as shown by rapid sedimentation along Richland Creek and high arboreal pollen counts. From A.D. 500 to A.D. 1200, during Environmental Period II, a gradual drying trend began, marked by the deposition of finer sediments (clays) as a result of slower moving floodwaters. Finally during Environ- mental Period III (A. D. 1200 to A. D. 1820) the culmination of the drying trend occurred and floodplain alluviation ceased, causing a decrease in the size of the Post Oak Savannah and an increase in the Tall Grass Prairie environment. Although isolated artifacts related to Paleo-Indian and Early Archaic period occupations have been found in the Project area, the first period for which in situ deposits are found is the Middle Archaic period (3000 B.C. to 1000 B.C.). The fact that only four sites appear to have Middle Archaic components suggests that the population was relatively low during the period. The high frequencies of chert (a non-local resource) in the Middle Archaic assemblages suggest that these groups were highly mobile, ranging over a broad territory. The dart points and floral and faunal remains are all indicative of a hunting and gathering mode of subsistence. Thus, Middle Archaic populations are characterized by high residential mobility, whereby small groups of hunter- gatherers moved frequently to areas of abundant food resources. The Late Archaic/Transitional Archaic period occupations (200 B.C. to A. D. 700) are noted at several sites in the reservoir, which suggests that the population density increased. ## Page 276

256 the lithic assemblages suggest that group territorial size decreased as population increased. The moist climate associated with Environmental Period I provided favorable conditions for the spread of the Post Oak Savannah, the biotic zone with the greatest concentration of staple foods. This abundant food supply supported the increase in population noted for the Late Archaic/Transitional Archaic period. The settlement/subsistence patterns changed little from those of the Middle Archaic period. Groups of hunter-gatherers still followed a hunting-gathering lifestyle marked by high residential mobility. However, the larger populations confined to smaller territories placed more stress on the environment and made survival more precarious. A new adaptive strategy appeared during this period, which was marked by the use of large depressions at Bird Point Island and Adams Ranch for ritual activity involving roasting and mortuary use. The adaptive strategy linked groups of hunter-gatherers by social bonds involving ritual feasting and a communal site for placement of the ancestors. The food sharing behavior and social obligations inherent in this ritual activity provided a form of “subsistence insurance” whereby groups whose territories did not produce well during a given year could call upon related groups to provide assistance. The Richland Creek phase (A.D. 700 - 900) is marked by another increase in population with a concomitant decrease in territorial size, as indicated by lower chert frequencies and higher local quartizite frequencies in the lithic assemblage. The first evidence of structures within the reservoir occurs during this phase as clusters of post holes. Since no definable house patterns are present, these structures are believed to have been temporary dwellings. However, their presence marks a shift in settlement pattern to lower residential mobility (semisedentary). The adaptive response to smaller territorial range observed during the Richland Creek phase is a shift from K-selected to r-selected species which are harder to eradicate by over-exploitation. The Round Prairie phase (A.D. 900-1300) is marked by the lowest level of residential mobility and highest level of logistical mobility observed for any period recognized within the reservoir. A sedentary existence is indicated by the presence of three circular houses at Bird Point Island, and a decrease in chert frequencies, (especially Pisgah Ridge chert) indicates a decreased territiorial Volume III, Part Two size. The drying trend noted for Environmental Period II reduced the extent of the Post Oak Savannah, which led to an adaptive response in the selection of species exploited. An increase in r- selected species, such as nuts, is observed in the macrobotanical assemblage. In addition, an increase in the number of roasting pits used to prepare nuts and other plant foods occurred. Finally, the deterioration of the environment resulting from the continued drying trend of Environmental Period III] caused another major shift in settlement and subsistence patterns during the St. Elmo phase (A.D. 1300 - A.D. 1650). The advance of the Tall Grass Prairie and retreat of the Post Oak Savannah no longer permitted a sedentary existence. Residential mobility increased to the level observed for the Richland Creek phase, as evidenced by clusters of post holes from temporary shelters similar to those associated with Richland Creek phase components. Ceramic frequencies increased, which may indicate storage of food in ceramic containers. Significantly, com was introduced in small amounts to supplement the diet, reflecting the deteriorating condition of the local resource base. The results of archaeological research along Richland Creek document a gradual change in settlement and subsistence patterns through time. These changes were subtle; for the most part, the same species were used during all periods of occupation as a hunting and gathering economy persisted. However, shifts in the relative importance of K-selected and r-selected species were observed when the overall percentage of these species was compared on a period by period basis. As the territorial size of groups decreased, the shift from K-selected to r-selected species was required, and increased social complexity developed to promote group reciprocity as a risk-sharing mechanism. Environmental change and population change are viewed as the major determinants of human ecology in this interpretation. Although we recognize that social factors may have had a significant impact on the direction of settlement/subsistence changes, these factors cannot be measured with archaeological data. We have examined all archaeological data in light of modern hunter-gatherer data in an attempt to describe the social interaction that may be responsible for the archaeological record. However, our interpretations are admittedly simplistic and should be viewed more as hypotheses useful for future testing than as firm conclusions.

LITHIC ARTIFACT CATEGORY DEFINITIONS BIFACES PROJECTILE POINT A projectile point is defined as a symmetrical pointed biface with the proximal end modified (by notching, stemming, or thinning) to facilitate hafting. This category includes basal fragments of the same, but only when the hafting element is present. Possible projectile point tip, medial, and base fragments that do not possess a definable hafting element are included within the Biface Fragment category. In the site assemblage descriptions, projectile points are divided into Dart Point and Arrow Point subcategories, and are assigned to a recognized type whenever possible. CLEAR FORK GOUGE This artifact form was originally defined by Ray (1941). They have prominent, steeply chipped bits and are roughly triangular or subtriangular in outline. The bits themselves were formed with unifacial flaking, but the other edges were worked bifacially. DRILL A drill is defined as a bifacially worked artifact with a long, narrow blade. The blade edges are approximately parallel. The distinctive smaller specimens fitting this definition are included in a separate Drill/Awl category. DRILL/AWL Specimens in this category are characterized by their long, very narrow and thin bifacially worked blades. The bases of most by Daniel E. McGregor specimens are the unworked proximal portions of the flakes from which the tools were made. A few specimens have bifacially worked bases with stems for hafting. They are identical to specimens in Shafer's (1973:220) Awl category. BRISTOL BIFACE A Bristol biface is a bifacially worked artifact with circular or subcircular outline and relatively straight edges. Almost all specimens are without cortex.This artifact category was originally defined by Duffield (1963a:43-44). BIFACIAL KNIFE These are sufficiently whole bifacially worked artifacts not included in the above categories. These are differentiated from the Aborted Biface category below by the presence of at least one Straight blade edge formed by fine secondary retouch, and a complete absence of cortex. Although most specimens are complete, they lack evidence of preparation for hafting. Outline morphology is highly variable, including triangular, subtriangular, leaf-shaped, and oval specimens. ABORTED BIFACES Aborted bifaces are bifacially worked artifacts that appear to have been rejected at some stage in the biface production process. These have been divided into Early and Late Stage subcategories, depending upon the amount of bifacial reduction accomplished prior to discard. Arrow Point Preforms are aborted bifaces which are differentiated primarily on the basis of their small size. Fragments which may represent aborted bifaces, but are not sufficiently complete for confident classification, are included within the Biface Fragment category. 257

258 EARLY STAGE These specimens tend to be thick and somewhat irregular, with sinuous edges formed by the removal of large, thick flakes. They usually retain at least one area of surface cortex, have obvious material flaws, or have an area of hinge and step fracturing on one face. , LATE STAGE These are thinner, with straighter edges formed by the removal of smaller flakes than the specimens in the previous subcategory. Generally, all cortex has been removed, but the fine edge retouch that is characteristic of specimens in the Bifacial Knife category. ARROW POINT PREFORM These are made on small flakes with straight pressure-flaked edges. Although whole, they lack evidence of any modificaiton of the proximal end that would facilitate hafting. Some specimens retain portions of their original striking platforms. It should be noted that the Aborted Biface subcategories and the Bifacial Knife category are cut from what is actually a continuum in the biface production process, and that class assignment of certain specimens is somewhat arbitrary. The Arrow Point Preforms, Late Stage, and most Early Stage specimens could have been utilized as cutting or scraping tools. However, their generally “unfinished” appearance has led to their classification as pro- duction rejects. . BIFACE FRAGMENTS These are artifact fragments with at least one edge showing evidence of bifacial chipping. This is an other category for artifacts that are too fragmentary for confident classification into one of the above biface catgories. For purposes of description, these artifacts are subdivided into possible projectile point tip, medial, and base fragments, as well as an Indeterminate subcategory. UNIFACES STEEPLY CHIPPED UNIFACES Artifacts included in this category possess the following characteristics: 1) A zone of regular retouching rather than a more random pattern of flake scars. 2) Two or more rows of overlapping (stepped) flake scars along the working edge. 3) A working edge angle of greater than two degrees. GOSSETT GOUGE The artifacts in this category were made from rather flat quartzite nodules and have straight, steeply chipped bits at one end. The flat ventral surfaces of all specimens retain their nodular cortex, and many retain some cortex on their upper surface as well. This artifact category was originally defined by Story (1965:208-210). END SCRAPER A thick flake or similar piece of lithic material with one or both ends unifacially retouched to form a straight to convex working edge. Some specimens also exhibit retouch along one or both lateral edges. Volume III, Appendix A SIDE SCRAPER A flake with one or both of its lateral edges unifacially retouched to form a straight to convex working edge. SCRAPER ON TABULAR PIECE OF SILICIFIED woopD A tabular piece of silicified wood with one end unifacially retouched to form a steep, straight to convex working edge. These tools have been termed “Mineola end scrapers" by Johnson (1962:189). SCRAPER WITH GRAVER SPUR An artifact belonging to one of the above subcategories except for the presence of one or more small, pointed tips (graver spurs). GRAVER Members of this subcategory possess a pointed tip or spur formed by the intersection of two steep notches. SPOKESHAVE A steeply chipped uniface with one or more markedly concave working edges. MARGINALLY MODIFIED PIECES Artifacts included in this category are characterized by: 1) a single (non-stepped) row of flake scars forming a relatively acute angled working edge. 2) relatively small flake scars (all are less than 2 mm in width, most are less than 1 mm). GRAVER A piece possessing one or more pointed tips or spurs which have been formed by definite, regular retouch. DENTICULATE A piece on which retouching of an edge has produced a series of three or more pointed “teeth.” BURIN The specimens in this category each have a chisel-like tip formed by the removal of a flake edge parallel to the long axis of the flake. CONCAVE WORKING EDGE OR NOTCH A piece with a regular zone of retouching along a concave edge. STRAIGHT TO CONVEX WORKING EDGE A piece having retouch flake scars along one or more straight to convex edges. This subcategory is further divided on the basis of the nature of retouch: 1) those with one or more zones of regularly pattetned flake scars, and 2) those with retouch flake scars that are more "randomly" patterned.

Lithie Artifact Definitions CORES A core is defined as a nodular or tabular piece of lithic material from which flakes have been intentionally removed. Within this category, the artifacts can be subdivided according to the amount and pattern of reduction that had occurred prior to discard. The following subcategories were recognized. SPLIT OR TESTED NODULE A pebble or cobble with one or very few flakes removed. Although these are included in the core category by definition, their usefulness for technological studies is relatively limited. They probably represent discards from an early material selection stage of the core reduction process. FREEHAND PERCUSSION CORE A relatively large piece of lithic material from which a series of flakes has been detached. The recovered specimens indicate that a variety of reduction strategies was used. This group has been subdivided on the basis of the nature and positioning of its striking platforms. BIFACIAL PLATFORM Flakes were removed bifacially from one or more edges, but with no apparent attempt to thin the parent nodule. In some cases it is difficult to separate objectively these cores from certain specimens in the early stage Aborted Biface category. CORTEX PLATFORM Single Platform A single cortex platform at one end of the core. Double Platform (opposed) Two cortex platforms are present at opposite ends of the core. Double Platform (90-degree) Two cortex platforms are located at an approximate right angle to one another. Multifaceted nodule Flakes have been removed from a number of directions without consistent (patterned) platform development. PREPARED PLATFORM Platform preparation was essentially limited to splitting the nodule. The newly created, flat surface was then used as the striking platform for further flake removal. In some cases, a few additional flakes were removed from the platform surface itself, apparently for purposes of rejuvenation. 259 SMALL BIDIRECTIONAL CORE These are small chert pebbles with a series of flakes removed from opposite ends. They are similar to specimens which have been termed “bipolar cores,” and characterized as resulting from reduction by a hammer-and-anvil technique (Mallouf 1976:157; Shafer 1973:107-114). The small size of these cores would have made hand-held percussion difficult. CORE FRAGMENT A broken portion of a core that is too fragmentary for further classification. GROUND, PECKED, AND BATTERED STONE HAMMERSTONE A nodule of lithic material (generally quartzite) exhibiting evidence of battering on one or more ends or edges. MANO An ovate shaped nodule of quartzite or sandstone with one or more noticeably smoothed surfaces. GRINDING SLAB These are large, thick slabs (generally of sandstone) which have been ground smooth on one or more surfaces. These smoothed surfaces are usually flat, but in some cases are basin-shaped. The edges of some specimens have been shaped by battering and pecking. PITTED STONE These specimens are similar to Grinding Slabs except that they are smaller and exhibit one or more small depressions or "pits" which have been pecked into a ground surface. WACO SINKER These are small, oval quartzite pebbles whose ends exhibit well defined notches. These notches were formed by pecking and grinding. This artifact category was originally defined by Watt (1938). ABRADER These are pieces of sandstone that display one or more linear grooves on a relatively flat surface. GROUND STONE FRAGMENTS These specimens have at least one ground surface, but are too fragmentary for further classification.

## Page 281

ATTRIBUTES USED FOR CERAMIC ANALYSIS by James E. Bruseth The attributes used in the Richland Creek Archaeological Project ceramic analysis fall into three groups: vessel form, ceramic manufacturing, and exterior decoration. Each is discussed below. VARIABLES RELATED TO VESSEL FORM The first group of attributes for ceramic analysis includes four variables that describe various characteristics of vessel form. These variables are (1) location of the sherd on the complete vessel, (2) lip form, (3) rim orientation, and (4) sherd thickness. Each is described in detail below, and should provide a means of describing the sherd assemblage and of examining possible chronological relationships that these variables might have. All of them have been found to have chronological variability at other ceramic sites (Brown 1971; Bruseth and Perttula 1981; Hargrave 1982). Sherd location was divided into three attributes: whether a sherd was part of the rim, part of the body, or part of the base. Mention should be made that the base category cannot be consistently’observed and therefore is not a reliable indicator of the presence of this vessel part. That is, bases from flat-bottomed vessels are often easy to recognize whereas bases from round- bottomed vessels are more difficult. This difficulty is increased when the curvature of the base of round-bottomed vessels is similar to that of the walls. Moreover, the small size of the sherds from many sites further increases the difficulty of recognizing bases. A major goal of this variable was to obtain information on the types of vessel forms represented in the sherd assemblage. Since vessel form could be directly observed on only a very small number of sherds because of the small size of individual ceramics, it was hoped that this procedure might provide insight on the range of vessel forms used over time. Specifically, the relative frequencies of body to rim sherds provide an indicator of the overall range of vessel forms, albeit at a much grosser level than direct form observation (cf., Schambach 1970:294-298), For 261 instance, a large number of body sherds relative to rim sherds would indicate a predominance of restricted orifice vessels, deep- bodied vessels, or a combination of the two. Conversely, a high incidence of rim sherds relative to body sherds would imply unrestricted orifice vessels, shallow body vessels, or some combination. The former might indicate more storage forms, such as jars and bottles, while the latter might indicate food preparation and eating utensils. Rim orientation was selected to further examine the forms of vessels, and specifically, to help determine if more or less restricted orifice vessels exist in a given sample. The attributes observed under this variable were straight (i.c., vertical), everted (i.¢., inclining outward), and inverted (i.e., inclining inward). An additional variable used to describe vessel form was lip form, or examination of the cross section of the terminal margin _of the vessel orifice (Brown 1971:120). Five categories were defined (see Figure B-1). The reason for inclusion of this variable is based on the tendency of established ceramic types to show a greater incidence of flattened or rounded lips during the Early Caddo period and a greater incidence of rolled lips in the Late Caddo period of East Texas (Suhm et al. 1954), Since most of the decorated ceramics from the reservoir show similarity to Caddoan types, it was anticipated that temporal change in this attribute might also be found at Richland Creek. The final variable used was sherd thickness. This refers to the average thickness in millimeters of each sherd. This variable was included primarily as a means of increasing the level of -description of the ceramic assemblage. VARIABLES RELATED TO CERAMIC MANUFACTURING Included within this group are several observations which pertain to the manufacturing environment of the ceramics. These variables are sherd temper, color, and petrographic constituents. Sherd tempers were selected to cover the observed range of nonplastic additives to the clay. However, in some instances it is

Lip profiles identified during ceramic analysis: (a) flat, (b) rounded, (c) beveled, (d) exterior rolled, and (e) compound. not clear if certain tempers were originally part of the clay or clearly an additive, such as was occasionally the case with sand. Some of the clays in the vicinity are actually sandy clays and this material could have unintentionally been selected. At the same time, however, some sherds contained considerable quantities of sand and are quite clearly intentionally tempered wares; we refer to this temper as sandy paste. Tempers were megascopically identified unless there was a question, in which case microscopic examination was made. The predominant tempering agents were grog, sand (grit), bone, and shell. In some sherds no temper was visible, and these were identified as such. Sherd colors were identified according to a Munsell color chart to provide a consistent means of identification. All readings were taken under fluorescent light. The exterior, interior, and core colors were identified on all ceramics from the site. Several interpretations can be drawn from this variable. Shepard (1971:105) notes that there are two determinants of sherd color: clay source variability and firing environment. Generally lighter colors such as creams, yellows, oranges, and reds can be inferred to represent oxidized firing environments, whereas darker colors such as browns, grays, and black can be due to either reduced firing environments or clay sources (Shepard 1971:105). Thus, some indication of change or stability in clay sources and in firing environments over time can be obtained from this variable. Volume III, Appendix B A secondary objective of using sherd color was to help determine if the ceramics from the site were manufactured locally or were trade wares. It was reasoned that if all ceramics had been manufactured locally, similar firing techniques would likely have been employed and have resulted in a similar range of colors. On the other hand, if ceramics were being traded, then color variations representing different clay sources should be apparent when compared over time. This analysis assumes that vessels did not consistently originate from the same clay source over time, a situation that seems unlikely. The final variable of this grouping involved the identification of the minerological constituents through thin-sectioning and petrographic analysis of a sample of sherds from some sites to observe clay composition and to quantitatively approach the problem of ceramic exchange. A trial study of ceramic thin- sectioning and petrographic analysis was conducted during the survey and testing phase of the Project with encouraging results (Irvine 1982b), and further examination was considered necessary to resolve the question of ceramic exchange. VARIABLES OF DECORATION The final grouping of ceramic variables that have been used to analyze the ceramic collection consists of those which pertain to vessel decoration. The first is decoration method, and refers to the manner in which ceramic designs were executed on the exterior of the vessel. The specific attributes observed were punctating, engraving, incising, brushing, slipping, and various combinations of these attributes. In addition, decoration element configurations (Braun 1977:178) were noted for the assemblage; these refer to the combination and orientation of specific decorative elements. This is not to be confused with decorative elements alone, which refer to basic, irreducible parts of a design, such as a tool punctation or an incised line (Shepard 1971:266). This variable was only recorded when a sherd was large enough for secure identification of a given element configuration, and a sample size of at least two sherds was required to define an element configuration. This resulted in several decorated sherds not being classified.

## Page 283

PETROGRAPHIC ANALYSIS OF A SAMPLE OF CERAMICS FROM THE RICHLAND CREEK ARCHAEOLOGICAL PROJECT The analysis of the ceramics from the testing phase of the project (Irvine 1982) identified several types that are considered Caddoan (i.e., Canton Incised, Carmel Engraved) among the Richland sample. The identification of these pottery types was not unexpected since they have been reported from sites in the surrounding region, but one of the problems they pose is a determination of the way they were introduced into the area. Undoubtedly the original type styles were brought into the area either through trade or by migrating groups. The question to be answered from this analysis is whether or not these styles were then adopted locally and produced within the area or if they were continually being traded from outside. One approach to the problem was undertaken prior to the first mitigation season. A petrographic analysis of thin sections of sherds recovered during testing was accomplished. The purpose of this analysis was to identify mineral inclusions in the paste in order to provide information to help in determining if the pottery was produced using local clay sources. This feasibility study was performed on eight sherds which had been selected as representative plainwares within the sample. The results were encouraging, so it was decided to continue the analysis using sherds from the first season of mitigation. Twenty-one sherds were thin-sectioned for analysis from this season. This represents approximately 10% of the sample collected. The analysis was performed using a Nikon microscope, type #115 with a UXF camera system. The sherds used in the analysis were impregnated with blue epoxy before they were cut for thin sections. This enabled the petrographer to discriminate actual void spaces (which would appear blue) from spaces where minerals had been plucked out during polishing (these spaces are clear}. Only one thin section could not be analyzed due to its destruction during the polishing. All of the thin sections were cut on the cross sections of the sherds to allow examination of the paste mixture. RESULTS OF THE ANALYSIS The significance of the combination of minerals within the clay matrix and the make-up of the sand can only be understood if some by Marilee Irvine background information is provided about the local geology and the minerals identified. The minerals that were identified in thin section are commonly associated with an igneous parent material. The presence of this material may be a result of its chemical and physical weathering. A source for this material is the sandstone bedrock (the Wilcox formation) that underlies a portion of the Project area, and outcrops at the southeast end of the reservoir. This material is highly eroded and has changed the soil to a very sandy loam. A second source is the Pleistocene gravels, known as the Uvalde gravels, which occur in the Project area and are found from eastern Texas (Bruseth and Perttula 1981) and southwest into northern Mexico (Byrd 1971). These gravels were deposited in the Project area due to erosion and stream flow from the Llano Estacado area of the Texas Panhandle and northern New Mexico. The gravels are typically composed of waterworn pea gravel to boulder size quartz, quartzite, chert, limestone, silicified wood, a few Cretaceous fossils, and granite.The granite is probably derived from the Llano Uplift region to the northwest (Menzer and Slaughter 1971; Byrd 1971). There are 10 minerals identified from the sample, but not every sherd contains all ten. Only one is common to all the samples, quartz, while the others vary in their amounts. The other minerals include: quartzite clasts (which are basically recrystallized quartz), plagioclase and microcline (these are feldspars), biotite and other types of mica, opaques (such as Fe-Ti oxides), calcite, zircon, and tourmaline (zircon and tourmaline are the ony two heavy minerals present). All of these minerals are generally associated with a granitic parent material, The shape of the grains and their degree of sorting are important to determine distance from source localities. The more angular and poorly sorted the grains the closer to their source, while the more rounded and well sorted the grains the further from their source. Related to this sorting effect is the breakdown and loss of certain minerals over distances. For example, the feldspars (plagioclase and microcline) break down much faster than quartz, which is probably a reason for their low percentages. The fact that the feldspars that are present appear to be fresh (angular, poorly sorted) may indicate that they have not traveled far from their source locality, or that they have been mechanically 263

## Page 284

264 added to the clay matrix (Ren Thompson, personal communi- cation, 1982). Grain size and sorting may also help to determine differences in source localities. Differences in average grain size may indicate that different localities were being exploited. The average grain size of one sherd within the sample was significantly greater than the other sherds, which suggests that it may represent a different source. The other sherds are quite similar in average grain size (100 - 150 microns), which suggests that the sands in the area are comparable since the sherds analyzed come from five sites in the Project area. It is not likely that larger grain sizes would be found within this area but rather in a different locality. With the exception of one sherd, the selected sample that was analyzed appears to be fairly homogeneous in its mineralogical make-up (Table C-1). The proportions of certain minerals is fairly consistent for all sherds as well as the determined grain size and angularity of grains. The clay matrix constitutes an average of 70 to 75% of each sherd ranging from 55 to 90% within the sample. The clays are fairly homogeneous and more than 50% (15) contain traces of hematite-rich inclusions or blebs. These inclusions are secondary inclusions within the matrix. Grog inclusions were identified as components within the matrix and were usually distinguished by a different color and their angular shape. In some instances, it appears that two clays were mixed due to the differences in color, grain size, and volume. Quartz is the major component within the matrix averaging 20 to 25% for the sample with a range of 15 to 35%. Quartzite clasts were also detected in most of the sherds, but in a much lower percentage than the quartz grains. Twenty-five of the sherds contained quartzite clasts that averaged between 4 and 5% of the total matrix.The remaining elements identified are only minor inclusions within the matrix of the sherd. Microcline is present in 16 of the sherds and makes up 1% of the matrix. The Fe-Ti oxides (opaque) make up between 1 and 2% of the matrix in 22 of the sherds. The percentage of oxides would probably be greater, but in cases where the clay was dark the oxides are hard to disinguish within the matrix. The remaining elements (biotite, zircon, tourmaline, mica, and calcite) occur only in trace amounts. Bone was identified in 12 of the thin sections, ranging from only trace amounts to as much as 10% of the matrix. The bone used in the pastes of these sherds was characterized as small reptile, bird, and fish bone. This distinction was based on the bone structure when observed under the petrographic microscope (David Gillette, personal communication 1982). The sand within the matrix (sand refers to a specific grain size classification) was observed to be basically subangular to subrounded in shape and poor to moderately sorted. Grain size for all but one sample averaged between 100 and 150 microns with a range between 40 and 450 microns. A single sherd had an average grain size of 300 microns, which is much larger than the rest of the sample. In some instances where two clays were mixed they could be distinguished by differences in average grain sizes. The single sherd (41FT161B.50.99.F6) that appears to be different from the rest of the sample has several distinguishing characteristics. It has the lowest clay matrix percentage (55%) for the sample as well as the highest quartz percentage (30 to 35%). It also has some 5% quartzite clasts which are basically recrystallized quartz. The feldspars make up 5% of the matrix. These minerals are relatively fresh due to their observed angularity. Traces of biotite and zircon were also recorded.The identification of biotite was the only occurrence within the sample. INTERPRETATIONS Although no definitive conclusions about the location of pottery manufacturing are possible, some more detailed statements about the pottery itself and theories as to its origins can be provided based on the results of the petrographic analysis.The interpretations presented are based solely on the data from the analyzed sherds. Volume III, Appendix C One of the most interesting observations about the sample is the homogeneity of the analyzed sherds. All but one of the sherds have very similar mineral constituents with virtually the same percentages within the matrix. They are also very similar in the grain size observed, amount of sorting represented, and the shape of the grains.The sherds represented within the sample are of all different types and are both plain wares and decorated styles.The amount of homogeneity suggests that the pottery was all made from a common or at least a similar source. The single sherd that appears somewhat different was identified as sand tempered plain ware.The differences in the amount of quartz and quartzite clasts, as well as the larger average grain size and lower percentage of clay matrix, may indicate that this particular sherd comes from a different source area.The larger grain size is particularly significant here in that it is not common to find differences in grain size within the same area, particularly since the rest of the sherds are all averaging 100 - 150 microns for the average grain size.It may be, then, that within the sample submitted for analysis, that only one sherd seems to have a provenience that is different from the others. The minerals identified in thin section, as has been stated earlier, all appear to have an igneous parent material. It has been suggested that the parent material may be granitic. Granite and other igneous materials have been reported for the Project area either within the Uvalde Gravels or as a component of the Wilcox Formation sandstone bedrock underlying the area.Therefore, the minerals identified exist within the Project area and are most likely to be available either as a natural component of the clay or as a temper material available from the creek banks or from deposits on the terraces or in the uplands. , The angularity of the grains and the relatively small amount of sorting that has occurred indicate that the grains have not traveled far from their original source locality. Particularly the fresh nature of the feldspars suggests that they may have been secondary inclusions within the matrix, added as additional tempering for the pottery. The distance from the source may be as much as 200 miles (320 km), which is plausible since both Uvalde Gravels and the Wilcox Formation, as well as other sand formations (such as the Carrizo Sands), occur within that zone. So the problem becomes one of determining if indeed the pottery was made somewhere else and brought into the area, or if it was manufactured locally from the nearby clays. A thin section of a sherd from a Southwest Black- on-White stirrup spout vessel (recovered from Dallas County, Texas) has been analyzed under a petrographic microscope (see McIntyre and McGregor 1982). In contrast to the matrix of the Richland samples which are mainly quartz, this matrix and others from New Mexico (Shepard 1971) contain mostly basalt. Basalt is very common to the west of Richland and would be expected as a component of the clays from this area. Thin sections analyzed from eastern Oklahoma sites (Spiro, Brackett, and Paris Mounds) were also very different from the Richland samples (Ren Thompson, personal communication 1982). The samples analyzed had such small grain sizes that few of the matrix constituents could be identified. All of the sherds were similar in that the matrix was made up of very fine grained material. In contrast, the Richland samples had grain sizes identified as sand grain size. The question of provenience may never be answered, but this analysis has provided some answers to questions about the nature of the sherds. In every instance the temper identified by the archaeologist was confirmed by the petrographer. In several instances the petrographer identified bone in the matrix that was not originally observed, but in each case the bone occurred in the matrix of small grog pieces within the paste and was not observable except with a microscope. The question of the addition of sand (grit) to the matrix appears to be supported by the fresh, angular nature of the feldspars in comparison to the other grains observed in the paste. This seems to suggest that the sand was being mechanically added in addition to what was present naturally in the clay. This is also true for the sandy paste sherd which is somewhat different from the rest of the sample.

FLOTATION METHODOLOGY FLOTATION DEVICE The Motation device substituted for the froth flotation device was a 50 gallon barrel which had been modified by adding a flotation chamber, an overflow valve and an overflow chute. The flotation chamber was a 5 gallon bucket which was attached to the top of the barrel. A 6.4 mm screen rested on the bottom of the chamber. The overflow chute was designed to carry the float material from the flotation chamber into a series of screens (Nos. 6, 10, and 12). The overflow valve is connected to the barrel and was used to control the water level within the flotation chamber. FLOTATION PROCESS The flotation samples were pre-soaked to aid the breakdown of the soil matrix. No chemicals were used for deflocculation. While in operation, the barrel was filled with water until overflowing. The flotation sample was slowly added to the running water above the heavy fraction screen within the flotation chamber. A garden hose provided the pressure needed to churn the sample within the flotation chamber. Once the soil had been broken down by the churning water and manual stirring, the overflow valve was closed. This resulted in the gradual rise of the water level in the flotation chamber until it reached the overflow chute which directed the water and floated remains through a set of three 269 by Duane E. Peter screens (light fraction). This process continued for 20 minutes. At the end of that time, the overflow valve was opened, the water drained off, and the heavy and light fraction screens were dumped onto newspaper for drying. FLOTATION SORTING Once the fractions dried, they were sorted by means of screening and hand picking of the materials retained by each screen size. Initially, the heavy fraction was sifted through a 6.4 mm screen and all materials remaining on the screen were sorted and bagged. The material that passed through the screen was sifted through a smaller mesh screen (2 mm), and all macrobotanical, charcoal, stone, shell, and bone remains were bagged separately. All material, except stone, less than 2 mm in diameter was bagged and sent to the macrobotanical specialist. The light fraction material was contained within three samples: 1) 3.35 mm, 2) 1.7 mm, and 3) .85 mm. The largest of the light fraction samples was initially sifted through a 6.4 mm screen to remove grass stems and roots. The material that passed through this screen was then sifted through a 2 mm screen and sorted. Everything less than 2 mm in diameter from this sample and the smaller screen samples (1.7 and .85 mm) was sent to the macrobotanical analyst for examination without any preliminary sorting.

## Page 295

ATTRIBUTE ANALYSIS OF COMPLETE FLAKES A detailed attribute analysis of complete flakes was conducted on assemblages from five sites exhibiting good contextual integrity. These sites were 41FT200, 41NV182, 41FT201, -41FT193, and 41NV173. Four continuous variables and six nominal observations were recorded for each specimen. The following discussion presents the criteria employed in this analysis. I. Length - This attribute was measured at the maximum dimension of the flake parallel to the striking force. This dimension was measured to the nearest millimeter for all complete pieces. Il. Width - This attribute was measured to the nearest millimeter at the maximum dimension of the flake perpendicular to the striking force. ; Ill. Thickness - This is the maximum dimension of the flake _which is orthogonal to the length/width plane. This dimension was ‘ measured to the nearest millimeter. IV. Platform Thickness - This attribute is the distance between the inverse and obverse surfaces of the flake at the platform. This dimension was measured to the nearest 0.1 millimeter. All flakes exhibiting crushed platforms were assigned a value of 0.1 mm for this attribute. ‘ V. Platform Type - This attribute records the preparation modes for the removal of spalls from a core. Five attribute states were recognized: 1) Cortex - striking platform is unmodified; original cortex surface is present. 2) Single Faceted - single flake scar forms the platform surface. 3) Multifaceted - two or more flake scars form the platform surface. 4) Crushed - most of the platform surface was destroyed on impact; only a remnant, usually step fractured, remains. by Duane E. Peter VI. Percentage of Dorsal Cortex - The relative amount of cortex remaining on the dorsal surface of a flake. Five categories are recognized: 1) O percent 2) 1-25 percent 3) 26-50 percent 4) 51-75 percent 5) 76-100 percent VIL Dorsal Scar Pattern - This attribute records the complexity of scar patterns on the dorsal surface of a flake. Nine attribute states are recognized: 1) Unidirectional - all flake scars originate from one edge of the flake only. 2) Perpendicular - flake scars originate from two edges of the flake, which are orthogonal to one another. 3) Opposed - flake scars originate from the distal and proximal ends of the flake. 4) Tri-directional - the dorsal flake scars originate from three edges of the flakes. 5) Multi-directional - the dorsal flake scars originate from more than three directions along the flake's edges. 6) Cortex - the dorsal surface is unmodified. 7) Ventral surface - the dorsal surface exhibits the ventral surface of a previously struck flake; usually referred to as “bulb thinning” flakes. 8) Bilateral opposed - flake scars originate from both lateral edges of the flake. VIII. Error Recovery - This attribute records the proportion of flakes struck to remove previous errors such as hinge or step terminations and the method of their removal. Four attribute states are recognized: 1) Absent - no step or hinge terminations on the dorsal surface of the flake. 275


![Image 1 - Page 295](assets/McGregor and Bruseth 1987 - Hunter-Gatherer Adaptations Along the Prairie Margin/McGregor and Bruseth 1987 - Hunter-Gatherer Adaptations Along the Prairie Margin_p295_img1.png)

## Page 296

276 2) Present (0°) - flake removed from the same direction as the origin of the step or hinge termination. 3) Present (90°) - direction of removal of the error recovery flake is perpendicular to that of the error scar. 4) Present (180°) - direction of removal of the error recovery flake is opposed to that of the error scar. IX. Flake Termination Shape - This attribute records the presence or absence of errors in force when detaching a flake. Five attribute states are recognized: 1) Feathered - results from adequate force applied to the striking platform. 2) Hinge - the result of insufficient force to clear the projected flake but of enough force to be redirected by the mass of the core or blank. 3) Overpass - the result of a blow with too much force for the intended flake removal; the edge of objective piece opposite the platform is carried away with the flake. 4) Blacky - results from combined effect of striking point being too far from the face of the core and too much force being applied. Volume III, Appendix G 5) Snap - results from too much end shock or vibration, impurities, or fracture planes in material. X. Raw Material - This observation notes the lithic raw materials of the flakes. Most of the raw materials are of local origin which can be found in the upland lag gravels (commonly referred to as Uvalde Gravels) which are present along the drainage divides. Only the Edwards chert is an exotic from Central Texas. The following varieties of raw material are recognized: 1) Chert 2) Edwards Chert 3) Quartzite - commonly referred to as “Ogallala" 4) Pisgah Ridge Chert 5) Silicified Wood 6) Siltstone 7) Sandstone 8) Ironstone, hematite.
